HEADLINE: Rethinking Rail Travel 

 BODY:
The nation's highway system does not make a profit. Nor does the commercial aviation system. Nor does passenger rail. However, only one of these three vital links in America's transportation network, the railroad, is being asked to break even. Congress must abandon its fantasy that Amtrak can be self-sufficient. Only then can it engage in an honest debate about the kind of passenger rail system the country needs, and how to pay for it. 
 In 1997, in exchange for meager subsidies, Congress required that Amtrak be "operationally self-sufficient" by December of this year, or else. It is "or else" time, and the Amtrak Reform Council, created by the same law, is calling for radical restructuring. The council suggests that Amtrak be broken up into a regulatory agency, a regional body to assume ownership of the Northeast corridor track and an operating company. It would also like to open up certain routes to private competitors. 
 The council raises valid questions about Amtrak's accountability under the current arrangement, but new bureaucracies and privatization are not necessarily the solution. The fundamental problem undermining the nation's rail system, after all, is chronic underinvestment.
Ever since Congress created it in 1970 to allow private carriers to focus on hauling freight, Amtrak has been asked to do too much with too little. Amtrak's biggest financial burdens -- the council calls them unfunded mandates -- are long-haul trains and maintenance of the Northeast corridor. Amtrak's operating loss in 2001 was $1.1 billion, its largest ever. Long-distance overnight trains carrying 18 percent of all riders account for 75 percent of its loss. Meanwhile, not enough is being invested to upgrade antiquated infrastructure along the shorter, densely traveled corridors where trains make both economic and environmental sense. 
Congress and the public need to start thinking of fast, reliable trains that can link major cities in three hours or less as a key part of the overall transportation system's future. Once that happens, the roughly $3 billion a year needed over the next two decades to develop these high-speed corridors across the country will seem like a bargain, particularly when compared with what taxpayers spend on aviation and highways.
After Sept. 11, ridership levels soared by 40 percent along the Northeast corridor, where Amtrak trains do make an operating profit. Still, antiquated infrastructure means that the new high-speed Acela trains are unable to run at their optimal, 150-mile-an-hour speed for most of their journey from Boston to Washington. 
Crucial capital spending on the route, the Northeast's economic lifeline, should not be held hostage by the tiresome debates over Amtrak's annual appropriations. Instead, Washington should be focused on fundamental policy choices. Two come immediately to mind. One is to establish a source of dedicated revenue for the development of high-speed rail, much as highways and commercial aviation have their own trust funds. The other is to consider abandoning the long-haul routes, or at least finance them separately, in such a manner that they do not take dollars away from the sensible development of high-speed corridors. 
Long-distance trains with such evocative names as the Empire Builder and the Sunset Limited may have nostalgia value for train buffs and political value for members of Congress whose districts they service. But when one assesses the nation's transportation needs and available resources, it is hard not to conclude that they are an unaffordable extravagance. An honest debate about the future of passenger rail is long overdue. If it takes place, America can still salvage and strengthen the train system it really needs.

HEADLINE: Once Near Collapse, Kia Posts Its Best Annual Results Ever 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 18 

 BODY:
Kia Motors, which was on the brink of collapse during the depth of the Korean economic crisis in 1998, posted the best annual results in its 35-year history today.
 The automaker reported a net profit of $418 million for 2001, up 67 percent from 2000. 
 Kia, which was struggling under $10 billion in debt four years ago, owes its revival both to South Korea's improved economy and to its relationship with Hyundai Motor. 
Hyundai acquired 36 percent of Kia's stock in a controversial bidding process in 1998 and has revamped the company's management and consolidated production operations since then.
In fact, Kia's success in 2001 last year paralleled that of Hyundai, Korea's dominant motor vehicle maker. Earlier this month, Hyundai announced its own record net profit of $896 million, with the company's controlling stake in Kia accounting for part of the increase.
The jump in Kia's profits reflected record sales of 990,804 vehicles last year, including 223,721 shipped to the United States -- up 39 percent from the year before.
Gross earnings from sales last year climbed to $9.5 billion, an increase of 14.3 percent from 2000.
Kia -- like Hyundai Motor, which sold 1,598,965 vehicles last year -- said it expected United States sales to keep rising on the strength of minivans and midsize sedans that are now produced as veritable clones of Hyundai models.
Kia remained on an upward trajectory through the fourth quarter of 2001 with operating profits of $120 million. That was up 52 percent from the final three months of 2000, despite a 23 percent decline in net profits that analysts attributed to one-time gains reported near the end of 2000.
Kia's shares rose 25 percent last year on the Korea Stock Exchange. And the stock, which has risen 22 percent this year, closed 6.9 percent higher today than Friday's close. 
The revival of Korea, under court receivership when Hyundai submitted the winning bid in the court's third attempt at auctioning it off in October 1998, reflects the determination of the Hyundai automotive group to compete on a global scale with the giants of the United States, Japan and Europe. Now in control of 75 percent of the South Korean market, the Hyundai automotive group has roared ahead of its closest competitor, Daewoo Motor, which filed for bankruptcy in 1999 and has been floundering during prolonged takeover negotiations with General Motors.
G.M. is reported to be in the final phase of negotiations with Daewoo creditors, led by the government-owned Korea Development Bank, to take over Daewoo Motor on the basis of a memorandum of understanding signed in September.
One factor in the rise of the Hyundai automotive group has been its complete withdrawal from the rest of the Hyundai group, once Korea's largest chaebol, or conglomerate. Avoiding demands to invest in other Hyundai companies, Hyundai automotive has streamlined operations under Chung Mong Koo, eldest son of the Hyundai group's founder, Chung Ju Yung, who died last year.
Hyundai's only other Korean competitor is Renault-Samsung, introduced as Samsung Motor in the middle of the economic crisis in 1998 and later taken over by Renault. Renault-Samsung had 1.7 percent of the Korean market last year.

HEADLINE: Asia Markets Are Higher; Europe Is Off 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stock markets around the world were mixed yesterday, with shares moving higher in Asia but lower in Europe. United States markets were closed for Washington's Birthday.
 The dollar recouped early losses against the yen yesterday, after President Bush said he and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan had discussed devaluation. White House officials quickly said that Mr. Bush had misspoken and that he had meant to say the two leaders had talked about deflation. 
 The dollar bought 132.66 yen, down 0.08 yen from late on Friday in Tokyo but above its late New York level of 132.60 yen on Friday. In other currencies, the euro was traded at 115.92 yen, up from 115.85 yen late on Friday in Tokyo.
The blue-chip 225-issue Nikkei stock average rose 45.15 points, or 0.45 percent, to close at 10,093.25. On Friday, the average fell 32.99 points, or 0.33 percent. 
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index rose 40.93, to 11,02.81.
In London, stocks finished slightly lower, with the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closing down 28.20 at 5154.30. In Paris, the CAC 40 index was down 29.95 at 4347.05, while the Ibex 35 index in Madrid fell 88, to 7832.40.
In commodities trading, Brent crude from the North Sea for April delivery fell 31 cents, to $20.56 a barrel, on the International Petroleum Exchange in London.
Gold closed in London at $297.50 bid per troy ounce, down from $300.40 on Friday. Silver closed in London at $4.52 bid per troy ounce, down from $4.60.
In recent months, Japanese officials have sat by while the yen has fallen in value against the dollar. Tokyo's lack of concern for a weakening yen has prompted calls from Asian leaders and United States corporate executives, who say the currency shift unfairly gives Japanese exporters a competitive advantage. A weaker yen usually helps Japanese exporters because it lowers the price of their products in overseas markets and bolsters profits when converted from foreign currencies.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FIGHTING; 
In a Shift, U.S. Uses Airstrikes To Help Kabul

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 18 

 BODY:
American forces appear to have opened a new phase in the war in Afghanistan with two bombing raids over the weekend that Afghan commanders in the area said were aimed at clashing militia forces rather than the Taliban or Al Qaeda. 
 A statement on Sunday by the United States Central Command said American aircraft dropped precision-guided bombs when "enemy troops" attacked forces loyal to the eight-week-old Kabul government near the southeastern city of Khost on Saturday afternoon. The command said a second strike was carried out on Sunday, again with precision-guided bombs. 
 The strikes appeared to differ from previous American bombing raids in Afghanistan because, according to warlords in the region, they were aimed at controlling clashes among militia forces, and not at destroying the Taliban or Al Qaeda, the focus of American attacks since the first bombing raids on Oct. 7. If there have been earlier bombing raids on targets other than the Taliban and Al Qaeda, United States forces have not announced them. 
Although the details of the local militia clashes remained murky, the bombing raids seemed to have placed the United States for the first time in a position of using American air power in defense of the government of Hamid Karzai, the pro-American leader of the new administration in Kabul. After fighting broke out between rival warlords in northern and eastern Afghanistan in recent weeks, Mr. Karzai said he would request American airstrikes if they were needed to end clashes between armed factions that control much of Afghanistan outside Kabul.
American policy since the Taliban's collapse has been to offer strong political and economic support to the Karzai government, which took office in late December with a mandate to guide Afghanistan through the first six months of a 30-month transition to elections.
The United States also played a supporting role in establishing the British-led, 17-nation multinational force that helps provide security for the Karzai government in Kabul. 
But 4,000 American ground troops in Afghanistan have remained apart from that effort, focused on the pursuit of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.
American policy has aimed at achieving political stability under the Karzai government without the kind of major international military commitment that it supported in recent years in Bosnia and Kosovo. In both of those cases, Western-led international military contingents that included large components of American soldiers were deployed, involving tens of thousands of troops. 
The international force in Kabul is building to a manpower ceiling of 4,700 troops, with only a handful of American liaison officers, and has a mandate that limits it to the area immediately around Kabul.
Up to now, American commanders have insisted on keeping their focus on the drive against the Taliban and Al Qaeda. That effort is far from over, Gen. Richard B. Myers, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today in New Delhi.
"It's just the beginning," he told reporters, adding that American forces still had to "capture some of the leadership" of the two groups and "try to make the situation more secure." 
Officials of other Western nations who favor an expansion of the multinational force, along with top United Nations officials who have argued for extending the force across the country, say American officials have expressed concerns about the international troops getting caught in a civil war if the Karzai government fails to rein in the warlords.
But events in recent days, including the assassination of a Karzai government minister at the Kabul airport and renewed tribal clashes in the east and the north, have raised new doubts about the stability of the interim government, and about its ability to extend its authority beyond Kabul without increased international military support. 
Mr. Karzai said on Sunday that he would ask for more international support if unrest continued. 
"If the security situation in Afghanistan does not improve further, we will make sure the international security forces are asked, together with the Afghan forces, to take a stronger role," Mr. Karzai said at a news conference where he discussed the murder of Abdul Rahman, the aviation and tourism minister, as well as the tribal clashes. 
He added, "I will ask for every measure to bring security to the Afghan people. I will use international forces, Afghan forces, to make life good for these people. There is no way we will let Afghanistan go the way of the past. The gunrunners, those guys who think they can get away with murder, those days are over."
Obtaining facts about the weekend fighting and airstrikes was complicated by the lack of reliable sources in the area.
According to the Central Command statement, "pro-government forces" requested the raids after "enemy troops" fired on them as they attempted to pass a roadblock. The statement gave no details on the identity of the pro-government forces or the enemy troops.
But Afghan commanders in the area said the incident evolved from a clash between two local forces that did not involve the Taliban or Al Qaeda. Abdul Wali Zadran, a brother of Padsha Khan Zadran, a warlord in the region, said today that the clashes involved two tribal militias, one from the Kochi clan and the other from the Gorboz clan, about 20 miles east of Khost. He said the American bombing that followed had killed one fighter from the pro-government forces and wounded four others. 
The Khost region is one of many in the country that rival warlords have divided into armed fiefs.
Padsha Khan Zadran and another warlord, Zakim Khan Zadran, who have similar names and are from the same tribe but share no family relationship, have carved out separate strongholds in the region.
Both men have professed support for the Karzai government, and have competed for support from a small contingent of American troops based at Khost airport in support of the hunt for the Taliban and Al Qaeda. Both men have recruited tribal fighters who previously served with the Taliban. 
A report on Saturday by the Afghan Islamic Press, a private news agency with a credible record of reporting on Afghan fighting, said the bombing came when pro-Karzai forces sought to stop the tribal fighting.
But it was not clear whether the tribal militias were allied to the feuding warlords in Khost or whether they were fighting for other reasons. 
In another sign of the Pentagon's growing involvement in direct support for Mr. Karzai's government, Maj. Gen. Charles Campbell, the chief of staff of the United States Central Command, arrived in Kabul today to begin a mission to train a new Afghan Army, The Associated Press reported. 
Mr. Karzai's concerns were compounded today by a warning from the fugitive Taliban interior minister, Mullah Abdul Razzak, who was interviewed by Reuters at a hideout near Spinbaldak, on the Pakistan border about 80 miles from Kandahar. He said the Taliban would "soon resume our activities" in response to popular discontent over the lawlessness.

HEADLINE: Workers Held Hostage 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Does life imitate art, or what? Last weekend's box office was dominated by a movie in which Denzel Washington takes an emergency room hostage to secure treatment for his dying son. Last week's major political event, though it went largely unnoticed by the general public, was also a hostage drama: House Republicans blocked vital aid to the nation's most vulnerable workers, and have refused to release it unless they secure passage of a dying stimulus plan. The plan, you won't be surprised to learn, consists almost entirely of tax cuts for corporations and the wealthy.
 Here's how the blackmail scheme works. U.S. unemployment insurance, unlike benefits in many other advanced countries, has a sharp cutoff: 26 weeks and you're out. This cutoff can be rationalized as tough love; arguably the American system, by giving workers no choice other than to find new jobs, has helped prevent the emergence of a European-style class of permanent unemployed. But it's a very harsh rule to impose during recessions, when new jobs are simply not available. 
 And that's the current situation. Last week 80,000 workers reached the end of their benefits; the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities estimates that two million workers will have exhausted their insurance by June.
Fortunately, in practice the rule is relaxed in hard times. When recession strikes, Congress invariably acts to extend unemployment benefits. During last fall's stimulus debate, everyone favored a 13-week extension. True, both sides tried to tie that extension to other measures. But everyone expected that in the end Congress would extend benefits whatever the status of other stimulus proposals. Indeed, the Senate passed an extension by unanimous voice vote.
But the hard men of the House leadership refuse to allow a clean vote on unemployment benefits. Instead they continue to insist that it's their way or no way: they won't allow a vote on benefits extension except as part of a bill that mainly consists of tax cuts for corporations and families in upper tax brackets, pretty much identical to the failed stimulus bills of the fall. And they rammed that bill through last Thursday.
Let's leave aside, for a moment, the economic merits of those tax cuts. What's really striking about this tactic is its sheer bloody-mindedness: the House leadership is willing to impose pain on some of the most vulnerable people in the country, desperate families whose breadwinners have been unable to find jobs, in order to push a divisive, partisan agenda.
And for what it's worth, that agenda is also bad economics. Last month the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office reviewed a range of potential stimulus measures, including all the elements in the latest House bill. Sure enough, the bill consists largely of the very measures -- accelerated tax cuts for upper brackets, reductions in the alternative minimum tax on corporations -- that the C.B.O. concluded would be least effective. 
What these proposed tax cuts have in common, of course, is that they deliver not a penny of relief to the great majority of American families.
But isn't the House leadership's behavior just politics as usual? No, it isn't. Politics as usual is trying to attach goodies for yourself to bills that provide goodies to other people. Everyone does that. But extending unemployment insurance in a recession is so standard -- and refusing to do so is so cruel -- that the House action takes the tax-cut crusade to a whole new level of fanaticism.
Put it this way: At first, ordinary workers were told that they would benefit directly from lower taxes -- remember those "tax families"? Great effort was devoted to obscuring the simple truth that last year's tax cut offered crumbs for ordinary families, but huge breaks for the wealthy.
Then ordinary workers were told that they should support bills like the two House stimulus plans from the fall -- bills that offered retroactive tax cuts to corporations, big tax breaks to families with high incomes, and nothing at all to two-thirds of the population -- because those bills would create jobs. After all, tax cuts are part of the war on terrorism, or something. 
But now tax-cut advocates have moved from promises to threats. Support tax cuts for the elite, the House leadership says, or we'll cut off your unemployment benefits.
So what's next? Support tax cuts or we'll break your legs?

HEADLINE: Tougher Policies on Refugees 

 BODY:
Today 35 million people worldwide are fleeing war or persecution. The last time the number was this high, World War II was raging. Yet many countries are hardening their refugee policies. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees must cut its services -- which already fall far short of the need -- by 10 percent because contributions from the European Union have dropped. Even as wealthy countries cut back their financing for food, health and education in refugee camps, they are also taking in fewer people. Nations like the United States, Denmark and Australia, historically open to the persecuted, are now closing the doors. 
 Refugees are less popular than ever because of post-Sept. 11 security worries. But the concern is misguided; only the most incompetent terrorist would try to enter a Western nation as a refugee. A tiny percentage of refugees are accepted and the process takes years, much of that time spent living in a squalid camp. In addition, refugees coming to America have always undergone far more thorough background checks than people entering on student, tourist or business visas. 
 Australia's shift has aroused the most controversy, because it was so blatantly -- and successfully -- a campaign device for Prime Minister John Howard's center-right Liberal Party. Mr. Howard sent asylum seekers, mainly those fleeing Afghanistan and Iraq, to neighboring countries for temporary detention and then tightened asylum laws. Mr. Howard is now under attack for campaign statements asserting that heartless refugees had been throwing their children overboard. He acknowledges that this was untrue but said he believed it at the time. 
Sadly, Australia is not alone. Well before Sept. 11 European countries were tightening border controls, aiming to keep people out so they cannot even ask for asylum. One reason for the shift is that conservative parties are winning power and anti-immigrant parties have gained support.
Denmark is one example. The new center-right leadership, pushed by an anti-foreigner party that has doubled its parliamentary representation, has promised to limit the number of foreigners in the country. This is especially important because Denmark is to assume the rotating six-month presidency of the European Union later this year, and will have a strong influence over Europe's refugee policies.
In the United States, each year the president sets a maximum number of refugees America will accept. The figure has been declining for the last 20 years -- it is now 70,000, down from 200,000 in the mid-1980's. Priorities for entry are still tilted toward the cold war -- one of the largest groups admitted, for example, is Jews from the former Soviet Union, not among those in the most dire need today. In addition, the number of refugees accepted is always less than the ceiling, a policy some compare to launching lifeboats from the Titanic with some seats empty. After Sept. 11, refugee resettlement essentially stopped as increased security measures were put in place. It has restarted, but at a much slower pace. While the transition to more security should be temporary, the continuing degradation of protections for refugees is not. 
Taking in refugees may not be popular in hard economic times, but it is the right thing to do. Moreover, prosperous countries like the United States and Australia have found that refugees and their children can become among their most devoted and productive citizens. Western nations more and more are adopting the view that refugees are not victims in need of sanctuary but a political problem to be solved by keeping them anywhere but here. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VICE PRESIDENT; 
Cheney, at Marine Base, Reinforces Bush's Stand On War Against Terror

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: MARINE CORPS AIR STATION, MIRAMAR, Calif., Feb. 18 

 BODY:
Vice President Dick Cheney opened a four-day campaign-style swing through California today by underscoring America's resolve to stop Iraq, Iran and North Korea from continuing to develop or pursue nuclear, chemical or biological weapons.
 In a speech to 2,500 marines at this sprawling base north of San Diego, Mr. Cheney defended President Bush's decision to single out those three countries as an "axis of evil," defining a new phase in Washington's war against terror. Some allies have criticized Mr. Bush's language. 
 "The president's remarks caused a certain amount of hand-wringing in some quarters, but most Americans find it reassuring to have a commander in chief who tells the truth and who means exactly what he says," Mr. Cheney said.
"The United States will not permit terror states and their terrorist allies to threaten us with weapons of mass destruction," he said, speaking on the flight line in front of a CH-53E Super Stallion helicopter and F/A-18 Hornet fighter, two Marine Corps workhorses in the war in Afghanistan.
The vice president's remarks echoed those he made last week to the Council on Foreign Relations in Washington. But his words today took on added pungency as he addressed and then mingled over lunch with members of the Third Marine Aircraft Wing in their camouflage-green fatigues.
Nine marines stationed here were killed in two aircraft crashes in Afghanistan last month, and family members of some of them sat in the front row today for Mr. Cheney's Presidents Day speech.
Next month, Mr. Cheney is scheduled to visit 12 allied and Middle East countries in what is widely viewed as an effort to build support for toppling President Saddam Hussein of Iraq through the use of tougher economic penalties, covert operations, and, possibly, military force.
To wage the war on terror, Mr. Cheney, a former secretary of defense, said today that the administration's proposed $48 billion increase in Pentagon spending for 2003, the military's largest annual budget increase in 20 years, would help ensure that America's armed forces had "the best weapons, the best equipment and the best training."
The visit to California marks Mr. Cheney's first major trip since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, and his longest official foray outside of Washington as vice president.
For several months, Mr. Cheney has rarely been seen in public, working at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., or at an undisclosed location outside Washington.
But aides say he has not been to one of his secluded hideaways in more than two weeks, another sign that the administration is taking the wraps off a man who many in government and the political world believe is the most powerful vice president in the nation's history.
While in California, the vice president will focus on defense and economic issues. He plans to give a speech on national security at the Richard Nixon Presidential Library in Yorba Linda, visit farmers in Fresno and tour a high-technology site in San Jose. On Tuesday night, he will appear on the NBC program "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno."
"California is a one-stop shop for our big messages," said Mary Matalin, Mr. Cheney's senior political adviser.
But Mr. Cheney's visit also has a distinctly partisan political purpose: to pump up state Republican coffers and to rally party faithful before a three-way gubernatorial primary on March 5 to pick a candidate to challenge Gov. Gray Davis, the Democratic incumbent.
On Tuesday night, Mr. Cheney will dine with some of the state's wealthiest Republican donors at a private, $25,000-a-couple fund-raiser in Los Angeles that is expected to rake in more than $1 million for the state party. Later in the week, he will raise money for two House Republicans, Richard W. Pombo and John T. Doolittle.
Aides say Mr. Cheney will make at least 60 campaign appearances, mostly in House contests, between now and the Nov. 5 elections.
Earlier this month, Mr. Cheney raised money for three other House Republicans in tight races, John Hostettler of Indiana, and Anne M. Northup and Edward Whitfield, both of Kentucky.
"Cheney is returning to one of the traditional roles of the vice president, which is to carry a large share of the political load during the mid-term elections," said Rich Bond, a former chairman of the Republican National Committee.

HEADLINE: Bush Affirms U.S. Role in Asia in New 'Pacific Century' 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Declaring that the next 100 years would be the "Pacific Century," President Bush strongly reaffirmed the role of the American military in Asia during a speech today to the Japanese Parliament.
 The United States, Mr. Bush said, would stop aggression against South Korea, show "American power and purpose" in support of the Philippines, maintain its commitments to Taiwan and press forward with a missile defense system. 
 "America, like Japan, is a Pacific nation, drawn by trade and values and history to be a part of Asia's future," Mr. Bush said. "We stand more committed than ever to a forward presence in this region." 
Mr. Bush, who spoke toward the end of a two-day visit to Japan during a three-nation Asian tour, also powerfully endorsed what he called the economic reforms of Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi. Mr. Bush even likened Mr. Koizumi to a star of American baseball, Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners. "The prime minister can hit anything you throw at him," Mr. Bush said.
But in a subtle reprimand suggesting that Mr. Koizumi had not done all he could to restructure an economy that is veering toward crisis, Mr. Bush said that forceful action was needed immediately. He held up the American response to its savings and loan crisis and its earlier economic troubles as a model.
"As we made reforms, foreign investors regained faith in us, especially investors from Japan," Mr. Bush said. "We learned that in times of crisis and stagnation, it is better to move forward boldly with reform and restructuring than to wait, hoping that old practices will somehow work again. Through bold action, we emerged a better and stronger economy, and so will you."
At the same time, Mr. Bush extravagantly praised Japan for its support of the campaign against terrorism and said the world's two largest economies had successfully joined together to oppose aggression. Mr. Bush cited the logistical support provided by Japan's Self Defense Forces and its aid to Afghanistan, and said the United States and Japan were working together to find and disrupt terrorist cells. He also praised Japan for its advances in energy and medicine.
"Japan is making these great contributions even in a time of economic uncertainty and transition that has caused some to question whether your nation can maintain these commitments and your leadership in the world," he said. "I have no such questions, and I am confident that Japan's greatest era lies ahead."
Mr. Bush's reference to the Pacific Century was a revival of a phrase used more often in the early 1990's, when Japan was economically ascendant, and in contrast to the Century of the Americas theme that Mr. Bush had promoted during his 2000 presidential campaign.
After his speech, Mr. Bush and Laura Bush had lunch with Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko at the Imperial Palace, the former seat of the Tokugawa shoguns who ruled Japan for more than 250 years. 
Mr. Bush has spent much of his two days in Tokyo, a city he last visited in 1975, partaking of his surroundings like the world's most exclusive tourist. He and Mrs. Bush stayed at the luxurious, Moorish-style residence of the American ambassador, Howard Baker, and his wife, Nancy Kassebaum Baker. On Monday night, the Bakers, the Bushes and Mr. Koizumi broke away from the usual formal banquet held on such visits and had dinner at Gonpachi, a trendy new restaurant that is so enormous that the Japanese food cognoscenti refer to it as a theme park.
Mr. Bush ate the best of the nation's cuisine: yakitori, or grilled chicken; tempura; Kobe beef with tamari soy sauce; and a traditional egg custard, chawan mushi, with king crab and scallops. 
Mr. Bush has seemed to revel in Tokyo, particularly on this unusually brilliant day when the snow-covered slopes of Mount Fuji were visible behind the city's skyscrapers. He is clearly enjoying his role as a powerful American president shoring up an ailing Japanese economy.
In a joint news conference on Monday, Mr. Bush repeated that he wanted to keep "all options on the table" with Iraq, one of the nations he has called part of his "axis of evil." But he also said that he wanted "to resolve all issues peacefully, whether it be Iraq, Iran or North Korea."
But while Mr. Koizumi endorsed Mr. Bush's tough words, he was more conciliatory toward North Korea, saying his nation, "through cooperation and coordination with the U.S. and South Korea, would like to work on normalizing our relationship with North Korea."
After the lunch at the Imperial Palace, Mr. Bush left Tokyo for South Korea, where anti-American protesters have demonstrated and occupied the American Chamber of Commerce. He is to travel to the demilitarized zone on Wednesday, and visit China on Thursday and Friday.

HEADLINE: Tentatively, North Korea Solicits Foreign Investment and Tourism 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: ONJUNG-RI, North Korea 

 BODY:
The display cases are in place, the tourists are here, their wallets filled with American dollars. Only the perfumes, whiskey and cigarettes are lacking to open the first duty-free shops in North Korea.
 One hurdle remains to foreign investment. "If we sell $1 million a month, how do we get the money out?" Thakor P. Sharma said from Singapore when asked about the delay in opening his nine duty-free shops across North Korea. He expects to resolve the money-transfer issue this spring says he urges his North Korean negotiators to keep politics to one side, lecturing them that "money talks." 
 A new language of foreign investment, trade and tourism is filtering into North Korea, long written off as a granite-hard bastion of communism. Over the last 18 months, this "hermit nation" has gone on line with an e-mail service and signed its first onshore oil concession with a foreign company. In the months before North Korea became a charter member of President Bush's "axis of evil," this long-reclusive nation established diplomatic ties with 14 Western nations. 
Although President Bill Clinton eased most restrictions on trade and investment with North Korea in June 2000, large American companies shied away from conducting business after efforts to establish diplomatic ties foundered at the end of the Clinton administration. Although Americans are free to travel to North Korea, President Bush has taken a hard line, arguing that the nation's missile exports and biological warfare capabilities are a threat to the United States.
 On Tuesday, Mr. Bush arrives in Seoul for a two-day visit to South Korea. On Monday, in Tokyo, he starkly contrasted the divided halves of Korea, saying at a news conference: "On the one side of a parallel, we've got people starving to death, because a nation chooses to build weapons of mass destruction. And the other side, there's freedom." 
 Last Friday, Mr. Bush said that if North Korea stopped exporting missiles, "we would welcome trade." In an interview with a Seoul paper, Joongang Ilbo, he added: "We would help welcome North Korea into the family of nations, and all the benefits, which would be trade and commerce and exchanges." 
This year, North Korea will get limited cellphone and Internet service and hold an arts festival and three trade fairs. It will also have a modern hotel, partly foreign-owned, open in Pyongyang, the capital -- all to attract foreigners.
"They are after tourism," said Nick Bonner, whose company, Koryo Tours, is offering package tours from Beijing for $1,590. After Mr. Bush lumped North Korea with Iran and Iraq as forces of evil, Mr. Bonner predicted that Americans would not be issued visas to attend the arts festival.
"North Korea has no choice," said Bradley O. Babson, a Washington economist who has studied North Korea for the World Bank. Referring to the end of communist ideology in China and Russia, he explained: "The neighborhood has become market-oriented."
With China's booming economy exerting a growing influence on North Korea, direct flights are to start next month linking Pyongyang with Dalian and Shenyang, two commercial centers an hour away by jet.
At the prodding of Russia, North Korea's largest creditor, plans are advancing for two big projects: a $250 million upgrade of the main rail line to allow goods to be shipped from Seoul to Europe, and a natural gas pipeline to link Siberian gas fields with South Korea.
North Korea may hold the key, but South Korea is the prize. South Korea has about 48 million people -- more than twice as many as North Korea -- and its economy, the 13th largest in the world, is 25 times as big. South Korean auto workers produce as many vehicles in two eight-hour shifts as North Korea turns out in a year.
After losing Soviet subsidies in the late 1980's, North Korea's economy contracted by about half, and its debt soared to around $12.5 billion. It is now heavily dependent on food and oil donations from the United States, South Korea and Japan.
But investment is trickling in. This spring, work is to start on a 2,317-square-mile oil exploration and production concession in North Korea, won last fall by Sovereign Ventures of Singapore. In July, cellphone service is to start under a joint venture of Loxley Pacific of Thailand and North Korea's telecommunications ministry. Human rights groups are proposing that foreign companies follow a code of conduct similar to the Sullivan principles that prepared South Africa for a post-apartheid society.
"I saw some Americans of Korean origin looking at oil and gas prospects," said Glyn Ford, a British member of the European Parliament who was in Pyongyang last summer for the opening of the British embassy. Given North Korea's power shortages and rundown ports, he said: "At the moment, very cheap labor is the only thing the North Koreans have going for them."
With more and more delegations traveling to Pyongyang, the number of foreign companies at this May's trade fair is expected to be triple last year's level. Two new fairs will be held this year, one sponsored by the European Union, one focused on information technology.
"Business people are feeling more comfortable now that the diplomatic platform is in place," said Roger Barrett, managing director of Foreign Business Development Associates, a Beijing company that took seven groups to North Korea last year. Mr. Barrett, a Briton who plans to open an office in the North Korean capital in April, said: "When you go around the office buildings in Pyongyang, you would be surprised by the number of European and Asian companies. There are about 20 or 30."
In 2000, most restrictions on American trade, travel and investment were lifted. John J. Schwartz, a vice president at Wente Vineyards of California, said the business mood he encountered recently in Pyongyang reminded him of market openings in Russia, Vietnam and Cambodia.
"In each newly developed market, they see capitalism as a fast buck," said Mr. Schwartz, who plans to sell wines in Mr. Sharma's duty-free shops. "It's always great to be the pioneer, the maverick -- but they are the ones that often get burned."
While visiting executives may be heartened to find a DHL counter in their Pyongyang hotel, the pitfalls of being a pioneer can be seen in this tourist enclave 130 miles to the southeast.
From the docks of a nearby seaport, four miles of freshly laid railroad tracks lead to a modern mineral water bottling plant. Its clean lines, robin's-egg-blue walls and red trim stand out amid the drab decay of the countryside. In 2000, the Taechang Company of South Korea, spent $12 million to build the plant and the railway.
But after a successful year, North Korea changed the rules, demanding a 30-fold jump in its cut of the cash flow.
"We couldn't make both ends meet," said Kong Soon Hyoung, the assistant manager, so the plant has suspended operations.
Nearby, the Hyundai Asan Corporation's Mount Kumgang tourism project limps into its fourth year. After losing roughly $300 million, Hyundai won South Korean government subsidies in January to keep tours running through this year. Fewer than 4,000 tourists, or 10 percent of the goal, come here each month by cruise ship from South Korea. Hyundai says it will never make money if tourists cannot come by bus.
"Road access would change a lot," said Kim Han-Soo, Hyundai's manager, as tourists shopped for handicrafts. By road, this mountain resort, seven miles north of the demilitarized zone, would be five hours from the greater Seoul-Inchon region, home to 20 million people. A duty-free shop, a golf course and skiing would also help.
In its first two years, Mount Kumgang provided North Korea with foreign exchange equal to 20 percent of its exports. But North Korea still failed to live up to its promise to allow road access, and now Hyundai is $1.2 million behind in payments to the north.
Hyundai's losses have scared away many investors. In a poll last summer, 88 percent of 600 South Korean companies said they had no plans to do business in the north.
To ease tensions, South Korean President Kim Dae Jung seeks to weave business links. Last year South Korea published a 250-page English-language "North Korea Business Factbook." Easing inter-Korean tensions has more than sentimental appeal. South Korean officials admit that it is an inexpensive insurance policy to calm investors, contributing to the $50 billion that has flowed into South Korea since 1997.
"There are over 125 South Korean firms doing business in North Korea," said Donald P. Gregg, president of the Korea Society in New York. "They find it difficult to get through the bureaucracy. Once they do, they find the North Korean workers literate, hard workers and excellent value."
While the Bush administration takes a confrontational approach, other nations are building a web of trade and investment ties. Last July, Asea Brown Boveri, the Swiss engineering group, opened an office in Pyongyang to support its contracts to modernize electric distribution.
Working from a Chinese border town, Thomas Payne, another Californian, has sold chili peppers and T-shirts printed in English to North Koreans. His advice? "North Koreans are good people, but always get paid in advance," he said.
With the trade, aid, investment, schools and roughly 200 Westerners now living in Pyongyang comes a more liberalized way of thinking.
Controls are bad for business, Mr. Sharma frets into the phone from Singapore. Worried about future traffic through his duty-free stores, he suggests that the police should just loosen up. With three shops under construction near North Korea's land borders, he said: "We need a couple of hundred people a day, not just a couple of dozen."

HEADLINE: Cuomo, the Sequel; 
A Son Seeks to Remake Himself, but in His Own Image

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Andrew M. Cuomo has served as a member of the cabinet of President Bill Clinton. He managed his father's first campaign to become governor of New York. He spent a year as a senior adviser to Mario M. Cuomo, working out of a vast office in the State Capitol. At the age of 44, Mr. Cuomo has worked as a lawyer and as an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and has created a program to provide housing for the homeless.
 But throughout his career, there are two things that Mr. Cuomo has not done: He has never before run for office himself. And, other than the brief stints as his father's $1-a-year adviser and as an assistant prosecutor, he had never held a position inside the governments of New York City or the state. 
 As the younger Mr. Cuomo gathers himself up now to attempt to defeat the man who forced his father out of public life eight years ago, that lack of experience -- along with the sense among some Democrats that Mr. Cuomo has descended upon New York after six years in Washington and immediately grabbed for the top rung of the ladder -- has emerged as an obstacle that many Democrats and Republicans argue Mr. Cuomo needs to overcome. 
Mr. Cuomo is in a Democratic primary against H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller who has a sweep of experience in state government and the admiration of much of his party's establishment. And Mr. Cuomo is running at a time of anxiety and fiscal turmoil, in a state reeling from a terrorist attack, a political environment that is likely to put a premium on maturity and experience. It is hardly a coincidence that Gov. George E. Pataki has taken to referring diminutively to the younger Cuomo, who has always called himself "Andrew," as simply "Andy."
If Mr. Cuomo is worried about any of this, he is not showing it. Brash, ambitious, and hungry for victory, Mr. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary, is methodically remaking himself as he approaches this race, with an agility that recalls Mario M. Cuomo's skills. It is not that he is not experienced, Mr. Cuomo explains patiently in laying out his campaign. It is that he is the outsider offering reform to a political culture -- the government in Albany -- that Mr. Cuomo argues has become "institutionally corrupt."
"This race will come to be about change versus the status quo," Mr. Cuomo declared, sitting in his downtown law firm office with a view of New York Harbor at his back. "If you feel comfortable with the way things are going, and you're happy with the current trajectory, then vote for the status quo: 'I want four years like the last four years.' George Pataki. Or McCall."
"I just see the situation fundamentally differently than they do," Mr. Cuomo said, adding, "The system has to be fundamentally changed. This is not about incremental shifts. The culture of Albany, the performance of Albany, is fundamentally flawed."
At a factory in Rochester last week, Mr. Cuomo declared: "They are consumed with their own personal politics, and they've forgotten the public interest."'
It is a campaign appeal that, right down to the specifics of its change versus status quo language, is almost identical to the one that Mr. Clinton used in his campaign against George Bush in 1992. Mr. Cuomo describes Mr. Clinton as a "good friend," and leaves little doubt that he intends to ride on Mr. Clinton's residual coattails in the state that the former president now calls home.
Still, Mr. Cuomo may find himself constrained in the extent to which he can run against the Albany establishment, given the 16 years his own father served as lieutenant governor and governor. While not disputing Mr. Cuomo's argument about the depth of dysfunctionality in New York State's government, Democrats and Republicans suggest it really has not changed much, if at all, since Mr. Cuomo moved out.
And no matter how he presents himself, Mr. Cuomo faces an opponent, in Mr. McCall, who is perceived as paying as many dues -- from comptroller to state senator to head of the New York City school board -- as Mr. Cuomo has not. Representative Charles E. Rangel, the Harlem Democrat who is one of Mr. McCall's prominent supporters, said Mr. Cuomo's resume was rather scant, and suggested that Mr. Cuomo might step aside this time to run under Mr. McCall for lieutenant governor.
"I really don't see anything beyond the secretary of HUD and the Dad," Mr. Rangel said. "I think in fairness to my party, I should give him a chance to run the string out and see where he thinks it's going to go.
"But quite frankly, it's my hope that he might take his youth and build on his need for experience and seek to run for lieutenant governor," he continued. "It would seem to me that even people who are not supporting him would believe that that, in some sense, would be paying dues and showing that he does not want to weaken our chances winning the gubernatorial race, which would be very difficult for any of our candidates anyway. And having a primary doesn't help us."
Mr. Cuomo said, with a flick of his hand, that he saw no circumstances in which he would drop out, and he rejected those criticisms. "I believe I have more experience and qualifications than most people who run for the office, period," Mr. Cuomo said. "I have experiences that you just don't have on a statewide level."
Mr. Cuomo's aides later released information comparing Mr. Cuomo's former Washington office with Mr. McCall's, noting, for example, that the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development had a payroll of 10,000 people compared to 2,300 in the comptroller's office, and that Mr. Cuomo administered a budget of $34 billion compared with $221 million for the comptroller's office.
He added: "And we don't take turns, because this is not about my turn or your turn. We don't make decisions in the back room in the Democratic Party."
Indeed, Mr. Cuomo's aides asserted, he has been aggressively campaigning across New York, raising money at a faster pace than Mr. McCall, and in recent months winning such key endorsements as that of Steven Pigeon, the Erie County Democratic chairman. He also has been laying out the foundations of the campaign in much clearer terms than Mr. McCall has to date.
In his visit to Rochester last week, Mr. Cuomo said that upstate New York was "a Death Valley economically," arguing that its economy under Mr. Pataki had stagnated as the national economy under Mr. Clinton -- with Mr. Cuomo's assistance, according to Mr. Cuomo -- was roaring. Mr. Cuomo even came prepared with specific figures to show how much HUD assistance went to Rochester under Secretary Cuomo. ("I was looking at the numbers today: $150 million in federal aid came through HUD to Rochester and Monroe County while I was there," Mr. Cuomo said at a news conference.)
Secondly, in an interview, Mr. Cuomo attacked the slow pace of the development corporation appointed by Mr. Pataki to lay out plans for what to do with the World Trade Center site, and warned that the delay could endanger efforts to recover New York's downtown. "The window closes," Mr. Cuomo said. "And people are watching, and people are nervous."
But most of all, Mr. Cuomo said, the public education system would be his defining theme. "In terms of an issue that's going to illustrate what we're talking about -- changing the culture, changing the mentality, accountability, performance -- it's all going to be around education," Mr. Cuomo said.
Mr. Cuomo said that a large part of his plan would be changing the governance of the state's school systems, by giving the governor direct authority over education in New York; and he suggested, without saying outright, that he would support the bid by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to persuade the Legislature to give the mayor direct control of the city's school system.
"Let's say hypothetically, I say the mayor has to be in control, the governor has to be in control," Mr. Cuomo said, using a hypothetical construction that was intended, he explained, to make sure that he does not divulge this early what he promised will be "a very big news story" in his campaign. That, he continued, would set him apart from the Democratic establishment, including Mr. McCall.
At this point, Mr. Cuomo's campaign manager, Josh D. Isay, interjected to inquire if this part of the interview was on the record. Informed that indeed it was, Mr. Cuomo settled back in his seat for a moment.
"If I were to say that,"' Mr. Cuomo said with a grin. "So this is a very big deal. There are some issues there that are so clear as to speak to the cultural shift. If I were to say I'm with Bloomberg, it would say you're against Democrats in Albany, literally all the Democrats in Albany, and you're pointing out Pataki's impotence on the issue because Pataki will say, 'I tried to do that, I failed for eight years.' "
But that was about as far as Mr. Cuomo would go, at least until later in this campaign, in detailing his ideas. "The state is responsible for the public education system," Mr. Cuomo said, fairly shouting in his office. "Fix it! The governor is like, 'It's not me, I'm not responsible, it's the Board of Regents. The regents say, 'It's not me, it's the chancellor.' Fix it!"
"Someone has to be in charge," Mr. Cuomo said. "I'm going to say, I run the public education system. If it's not reformed at the end of four years, fire me."
Similarly, when asked how he would change the system in Albany, Mr. Cuomo plunged again into murky waters. "I would start by doing things," he said. "Doing things. You want to change the culture? You want to start to get people to notice you and believe in you? Do something. Do something. You're not going to do it with words."
But clearly, most of Mr. Cuomo's attention these days is focused on leaders in Albany. He argued that Mr. Pataki had run a caretaker government, and that given the tenor of much of Mr. Pataki's time in office -- which was mostly a period of prosperity -- New Yorkers had little concern about what the state government was doing.
"Well, now things are not O.K.," Mr. Cuomo said. "That great Clinton economy is over. Now the tide has dropped and the rocks are showing, and it's ugly."
Then he continued, like a train rolling down the tracks: "And now you have these real security issues. And now people are starting to move out. And now people want some help. And when you now need something, and you look to Albany, what was a joke last year -- their level of dysfunction -- now is frightening."

HEADLINE: U.S.-China Tensions Ease Before Bush Trip 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Feb. 18 

 BODY:
Given the tortuous recent history of Chinese-American relations, the atmosphere surrounding President Bush's visit to Beijing this Thursday and Friday is amazingly relaxed.
 American officials hope there will be progress in controlling the spread of weapons. They are pleased that China has agreed to a live broadcast of the leaders' news conference, to allow Mr. Bush to display his Texas charm to the masses. 
 The Chinese are likely to release a prominent dissident or two by way of a welcome gift. They seem willing to suppress their deepest fears about American intentions in Asia, instead celebrating their partnership against terrorism.
Small-bore agreements on the environment, energy, health care and trade may be signed with fanfare. But no one expects this visit -- by coincidence, exactly 30 years after President Nixon's stunning first meeting with Mao -- to yield major advances or ugly encounters.
Leaders on both sides are aware of the pitfalls that lie ahead, but they seem determined to cultivate cooperation where they can, in part as a bulwark against future clashes.
Chinese leaders worried as Mr. Bush took office that their country was becoming the new whipping boy of American foreign policy. That fear eased after Sept. 11, when it became clear that the United States had an overriding new global enemy.
"Sept. 11 changed the agenda of American foreign policy," said Wang Yong, executive director of the Center for International Political Economy at Beijing University. "China became a less important issue for the United States."
He said the underlying problems in Chinese-American relations had not disappeared. "But recent events have given the two countries some time," he said, "a chance to work toward stronger long-term relations."
Apart from the nasty surprises in recent years that have caused strains -- like the American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and the episode with an American spy plane -- each side retains serious concerns.
The Chinese worry that the Bush administration will tilt toward Taiwan and sell it ever more advanced arms. 
This week China, which continues to view Taiwan as a renegade province, is certain, at a minimum, to insist that Mr. Bush restate his fidelity to "one China." But the potentially explosive issue of arms sales will receive only passing reference, diplomats predict.
The Chinese wonder how temporary the surging American military presence in Asia will be, and they were frightened by Mr. Bush's declaration of an "axis of evil" consisting of Iraq, Iran and North Korea. They know that some Bush officials would not mind if the American plans for a national missile defense also served to neutralize China's nuclear forces.
The Americans are alarmed by what they say is China's failure to halt its exports of nuclear and missile technologies, and they are monitoring China's own military buildup. 
The yawning American trade deficit with China is a perennial issue, and President Bush has made it known that he will press China about religious oppression and legal rights.
Yet an image of friendship is being scripted for what is officially described as a "working visit," rather than a "summit meeting" with its required pageantry. For now, Washington and Beijing appear eager to nurture the good will and shared interests growing out of the war on terror and China's scheduled opening of markets as it enters the World Trade Organization.
By all accounts, China has supported American goals in Afghanistan and the effort to cool tensions between India and Pakistan because it wants to further its own interest against Muslim extremism as well as improve ties with the United States.
Chinese leaders have even swallowed their misgivings about the spread of American bases in the region, which some military experts here fear is part of a long-term plan to encircle and contain China.
China has agreed to permit the opening of an F.B.I. office here, diplomats say..
One factor driving China's cooperative stance these days is its desire to avoid foreign crises at a time of economic turmoil at home and imminent turnover in the national leadership, said Kenneth Lieberthal, who was a top adviser on Asia policy in the Clinton administration.
"Right now the Chinese are really looking to avoid external complications," Mr. Lieberthal said. "They are not out there looking for issues to express great outrage about."

HEADLINE: In a Merger Of Networkers, Ciena Will BuyONI Systems 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH with SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
The Ciena Corporation, a maker of fiber optic network equipment, said yesterday that it would acquire ONI Systems, in a stock transaction worth $900 million. 
 The deal comes as telecommunications equipment suppliers struggle amid spending cutbacks by big carriers like Qwest Communications and WorldCom. Ciena and ONI executives, as well as analysts, said the merger might help Ciena and ONI market their products as the industry's deep recession persists. 
 While Ciena, based in Linthicum, Md., has focused on equipment for long-haul network operators, ONI's speciality is network equipment for use within metropolitan areas. 
"This will, hopefully, allow Ciena to sell a wider variety of equipment to its customers," said Mark Storm, an analyst at Frost & Sullivan in Norfolk, Va. "Of course, doing so depends on the overall recuperation of the industry."
Until now, Ciena has concentrated on supplying switching equipment and equipment for networks that send voice and data traffic across continents and oceans. But that market is weak because of an excess of network capacity built in the late 1990's by now-struggling companies like Global Crossing, Level 3 Communications and 360networks. 
ONI Systems, by contrast, makes specialized optical communications equipment for use in cities and densely populated suburban regions. Its products, which use tiny lasers and filters, increase the capacity of fiber optic strands by sending information with pulses of light, rather than electric current.
This metropolitan market is considered technically more complicated to reach than the long-haul telecommunications market. For that reason, it lagged behind the long-haul market in the late 90's but is considered healthier by some executives today. 
"When spending returns to the overall sector, it will return, first and foremost, to the metropolitan area," said Gary Smith, the president and chief executive of Ciena. He called the current downturn "an ideal time" for Ciena to reposition itself for an eventual rebound.
Mr. Smith predicted that prospective customers would do business more readily with a single, merged equipment manufacturer than with two smaller, separate companies that sold either long-haul or metropolitan area equipment. 
Although Ciena is a larger company than ONI, the stock of ONI has performed better than Ciena's this year. ONI's shares have declined 11.6 percent since the start of this year, closing up 19 cents on Friday at $5.54. Ciena's stock price has fallen 39 percent, closing at $8.73 on Friday, down 39 cents.
If the acquisition is approved by regulators and shareholders, each ONI share will be exchanged for 0.7104 share of Ciena, giving ONI stockholders ownership of about 24 percent of the combined company.
Ciena competes against a number of much larger companies, including Lucent Technologies, Nortel Networks and Alcatel.
After layoffs of some 380 factory workers in November, Ciena has about 3,500 employees. It was profitable in 2000 but lost money last year.
By contrast, ONI of San Jose, Calif., has never posted a profit since its incorporation in 1997. It introduced its first product in 2000 and has enjoyed rapid growth. But its expenses have significantly exceeded its revenue.
ONI's president and chief executive, Hugh Martin, said that the merger would help his company reduce marketing costs, while gaining credibility with the giant United States and European telephone companies that constitute its natural market. 
Without naming the companies, Mr. Martin said that four large, international carriers were currently testing ONI's equipment, and one of the big regional phone companies had notified ONI that it intended to make a purchase.
"They're very excited about the product, but they're also concerned about our ability to support that very high demand," Mr. Martin said. "They said ONI will have to train 1,000 people in two quarters if selected. You can imagine if a company our size had to train all those people in two quarters that would be a very ambitious task."

HEADLINE: New York Outside, and Rio in the Kitchen 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE LOUIE 

 BODY:
WHERE do New York City's nearly 12,000 Brazilians usually eat? Not, it seems, in the handful of Brazilian restaurants in the city.
 At Emporium Brasil on West 46th Street, 80 percent of the diners are Americans, said Regina Silva, one of the owners. The same is true for Churrascaria Plataforma on West 49th Street, where a largely American clientele comes for Brazilian barbecue, said Joao de Matos, an owner. 
 While many cultures, like the Chinese or the French, show off their most extraordinary food in restaurants, Brazilians save the most authentic, intensely seasoned dishes for home.
"Brazilians are not geared to eating Brazilian food out," said Cherie Y. Hamilton, an American who has lived in Brazil and is author of "Cuisines of Portuguese Encounters," (Hippocrene, 2001). 
Jorge Pontual, a reporter in New York for Rede Globo, the Brazilian television network, said, "Upper-class Brazilians go out to eat Italian, French, Japanese or Chinese foods, but not Brazilian."
In New York, Brazil's home-cooking tradition is perpetuated by people like Lia Gomes, 48, a housekeeper in Manhattan who came here 28 years ago from Recife, on Brazil's northeastern coast. Ms. Gomes has cooked since she was 14, when her mother insisted that she cook before she went to the beach. Once, she purposefully oversalted a dish, hoping her mother would say that she was such a bad cook she would never have to cook again.
"My mother said, 'Cook it again.' " Ms. Gomes said. Since that day, she said, "When I cook, I put my heart into it." 
One of her specialties is a flavorful fish stew. She sprinkles fresh lime juice and seasoned salt on sea bass steaks, fries them until they are golden, then simmers them for 10 minutes in a thick rich sauce of chopped tomatoes, onions, garlic, sweet red and green peppers, cilantro, tomato sauce and coconut milk.
Her fingers are nimble. She pats the steaks lovingly, as if she were caressing a child's cheek. As she chops the tomatoes, she seeds them simultaneously with a swift move of the thumb.
Brazilian cuisine is a mix of Portuguese influences -- like tomatoes, rice, dried salted codfish -- and African ones, with black beans, palm oil and okra. Indian, Italian and French ingredients and techniques also play into it. The food is not fiery, but every Brazilian cook has a glass jar of a smoldering pepper sauce, molho de pimenta, made of tiny red or green malagueta peppers steeped in olive oil. Vinegar and cachaca, a liquor distilled from sugar cane, are also added sometimes. Some cooks sprinkle the oil on every dish, making eating even scrambled eggs a tongue-smarting event. Brazilians keep pepper sauce for years, and replenish it with fresh oil, just as bakers hoard original starters for their breads.
At the Upper East Side home of Mr. Pontual, the television reporter, and his wife, Angela, cooking has become a team affair. Mrs. Pontual, who remembers helping her grandparents make sausage at their farm in Goias, a state in central Brazil, did all the family cooking until three years ago, when she became a writer and editor of Brazilian news at Bloomberg Television. Long days at work made her too tired to cook, so she became a speed cook.
She took a dish that normally takes a full day -- soaking black beans overnight, then cooking them with bay leaves and sausages for two hours -- and turned it into a fully flavored facsimile that takes 30 minutes.
The secret is a can of Goya black bean soup. Ms. Pontual cuts up bacon, linguica -- the Portuguese sausage -- and garlic, and sautes the meats and garlic. "Cook until it smells good," she said, pouring in the soup and a little water. She serves it with a pan-fried filet mignon and rice, Brazilian-style: garlic is sauteed in oil, the rice is added and stirred, like risotto, for five minutes before water and a sprinkle of salt are added. 
She also taught her husband how to cook. "I began when Angela stopped," Mr. Pontual said. "Traditionally, men don't cook. It's now glamorous for men to cook. It's considered to be something chic, and to know complicated dishes and to show off. " 
Each week, Mr. Pontual, who cooks not for glamour but to do his share of the work, makes one of his six favorite dishes, among them chicken and okra, pork tenderloin, or a muqueca, a stew of soft-shell crabs.
Cooking, of course, is an act of community. Michele Scheinkman, a family therapist in Manhattan originally from Rio de Janeiro, found herself lonely one recent night. Her husband, Jose, a professor of economics at Princeton, was teaching in Paris. Their only child, Andrei, was away at college. So she invited some friends over and cooked a classic Brazilian dish, a bacalhoada, or codfish stew. 
Ms. Scheinkman poured a little olive oil in a pot, and layered in slices of onions, potatoes, salted codfish that had soaked overnight, tomatoes, minced garlic, scallions, parsley and pitted calamata olives. After cooking for 25 minutes, what had looked like a dry though colorful dish became a bubbling casserole. The tomatoes and onions had given off their juices, which blended to a pale gold, speckled with bits of parsley. In the alchemy of cooking, the potatoes and the fish were perfectly, equally tender. It had the requisites of Brazilian home cooking -- soulful, hearty and flavorful. 
"When my husband calls me tomorrow, I will tell him that I miss him," Ms. Scheinkman said, "but if I can eat nice food with good friends, I'm not lonely."

FISH STEW WITH COCONUT SAUCE
Adapted from Lia Gomes
Time: 55 minutes

Juice of 1 lime
3 cloves garlic, peeled and minced
1 teaspoon Lawry's seasoned salt
4 fillets sea bass or red snapper, rinsed and dried
2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
1 onion, peeled and diced
1 red bell pepper, cored and diced
1 green bell pepper, cored and diced
1 1/2 tablespoons chopped cilantro leaves
2 plum tomatoes, seeded and diced
1 8-ounce can tomato sauce
1 cup coconut milk
1/4 cup flour
1/3 cup corn oil
4 servings cooked white rice.
1. In a flat pan large enough to hold the fish, mix together the lime juice, garlic and seasoned salt. Add fish and turn fillets until well coated. Let rest 20 minutes.
2. Place a wide, deep pan over low heat, and add olive oil. Add onion, red pepper, green pepper, cilantro and tomatoes. Saute until softened, about 10 minutes. Stir in tomato sauce and coconut milk, and simmer uncovered for 10 minutes.
3. While sauce simmers, prepare fish. Pat fish dry. Place flour on a plate, and turn fish in it until covered. Place a large heavy skillet over medium heat, and add corn oil. Increase heat to high, and add fish to pan. When one side is golden brown, turn to brown other side. Drain on paper towels.
4. Transfer fish to sauce, spooning sauce over it. Leave fish in sauce on a low flame for 10 minutes. To serve, place equal potions of rice on four serving plates, and top each with a fillet and sauce.
Yield: 4 servings.

INSTANT BLACK BEANS
Adapted from Angela Pontual
Time: 30 minutes

2 strips bacon, chopped
6 ounces chorizo, linguica or kielbasa sausage, diced
2 garlic cloves, peeled and finely chopped
2 15 1/2-ounce cans Goya's black-bean soup
1/2 bay leaf, finely chopped.
In a large saucepan over medium heat, fry bacon until crisp. Add chorizo, and saute until browned, about 3 minutes. Add garlic, and saute another minute or two. Add bean soup, bay leaf and one cup hot water. Bring to a boil, and reduce heat to medium low. Simmer uncovered until mixture is thickened, 15 to 20 minutes.
Yield: 4 servings.

HEADLINE: Across the Great Divide 

BYLINE:  By Dan Savage; Dan Savage is editor of The Stranger, a Seattle-based newsweekly.

DATELINE: SEATTLE 

 BODY:
When I went to Chicago for a wedding a few years ago, I decided to spare myself the agonies of air travel and take the train. I booked a first-class sleeping compartment on the Empire Builder, one of Amtrak's most historic trains, which travels more than 2,000 miles over the Cascades and across the Great Plains. Since then, I've taken the Empire Builder half a dozen times, and the stops along the way -- places like Havre, Mont., Minot, N.D., and Red Wing, Minn. -- have become for me more than abstractions on a map. 
 Traveling by train, I've spent time with people I would never have met otherwise. Once in Havre, I played poker at 8 o'clock in the morning with an elderly rancher I'd had dinner with on the train the night before. The Empire Builder makes an hourlong morning stop in Havre, and when I got out to stretch my legs, the rancher hurried over, grabbed my hand and asked if I would be so kind as to escort her to a small casino a few blocks from the station. She didn't want to go by herself, she explained, because it isn't ladylike to gamble alone so early in the morning. We talked politics at dinner the night before and in the casino that morning; she was a straight, pro-life Bush supporter, and I am a gay, pro-choice Gore voter -- and we got along famously. 
 Not everyone can afford the Empire Builder -- the time or the money. With stops, the trip takes about 46 hours, and for coach, the price is about $300 round trip. But a cost-benefit analysis is the wrong way to measure the value of train travel. The best justification for traveling by rail, and the best rationale for continuing its federal subsidy, is cultural.
After the last election there was a lot of talk about "red America" and "blue America," about the divide between the heartland and the coasts. The heartland, colored in red on the maps behind the network news anchor desk, was home to socially conservative Bush voters. Socially liberal Gore voters lived in big cities and on the blue-colored coasts.
Amtrak alone can't bring the reds and blues together. But trains like the Empire Builder provide a real, tangible link between small towns like Havre and big cities like Chicago. Flying tends to magnify the distance between places like Minot and Seattle, with planes swallowing up people in one urban area and burping them out in another. Traveling on the ground, you can see that the divide between red and blue, between urban and rural, isn't all that sharp. Rural fades into suburban, suburban into urban and back again.
Some have suggested that Amtrak's long-distance routes be transformed into the rail equivalent of luxury cruise ships. That's a poisonous idea. In the rural areas once served by Amtrak, there would be few travel options left, and while luxury trains might still pass through huge swaths of red America, they would be filled with wealthy tourists from blue America. Still, Amtrak lost $1.1 billion in 2001, its largest deficit ever, and it isn't going to be self-sufficient by the December 2002 deadline set by Congress five years ago. Amtrak has said it may eliminate as many as 18 long-distance trains if it doesn't receive at least $1.2 billion from Congress this year.
That's a substantial amount of money, I realize, even if it does occasionally bring together unlikely companions for a game of seven-card stud. But the federal government subsidizes airports to the tune of $13 billion a year and spends more than $30 billion on highways annually. In this context, $1.2 billion hardly seems excessive.
I know train travel doesn't make economic sense for everyone -- the bus is still the cheapest way to get from place to place, especially in red America -- and I harbor no illusions about its potential to bridge anything other than the Continental Divide. All I know is that I enjoy it, even learn from it, and that if more Americans would make time for the train, they might feel the same way.

HEADLINE: Construction of New Homes Rose By a Surprising 6.3% in January 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Home builders, aided by low mortgage rates and mild weather, broke ground in January on the largest number of projects in nearly two years, the Commerce Department reported today, raising hopes that the housing market would help revive the economy.
 Construction of new homes and apartments rose last month to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of 1.68 million units, a 6.3 percent increase over December's level. 
 The increase, which was larger than expected, pushed housing construction to its highest level since February 2000 and came after a 2.3 percent decline in December.
Analysts noted that low mortgage rates had helped the housing market thrive despite recession.
Another factor attracting new-home buyers is the appreciation in housing values, particularly as stock prices decline, economists said. Mild weather also played a role. "It looks as if housing will help the economy escape the recession," said Joel L. Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisers.
Construction of single-family homes rose 3.5 percent in January, to an annual pace of 1.35 million, on top of a 4.4 percent increase in December. The building of apartments, condominiums and other multiple-unit housing rose to a pace of 287,000 units in January, an 8.3 percent increase from the previous month. In December, multifamily-housing construction plunged 20.4 percent.
By region, housing construction rose 8.7 percent in the Northeast in January, to a pace of 162,000. In the South, it increased more steeply, up 14.4 percent to an annual 800,000. But in the West, housing construction fell 3.6 percent, to a pace of 377,000, and in the Midwest, it dipped 0.3 percent, to a 339,000 unit pace.
