HEADLINE: Pataki's Santo Domingo Tour Passes Into Tropic of Politics 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Children, adults and scruffy dogs crowded pastel cinder block storefronts, hanging on wrought iron security gates, waving and cheering at the pack of dignitaries who strolled today through Cristo Rey, one of the poorest barrios in this city.
 Alma Santos, a 22-year-old hairdresser, did not recognize the lanky American who was the center of attention, towering over the rest of the group. When told it was George E. Pataki, governor of New York, she said, "Who is that?" When Mr. Pataki's role in his homeland was explained, she smiled broadly and said, "I'm glad he's here." 
 Mr. Pataki this week became the first sitting governor of New York to visit this nation that is the source of a growing voting bloc back home, making a 22-hour tour of the capital city, before proceeding this afternoon to Puerto Rico. He repeatedly showed off his much-improved Spanish, visited the president, offered comfort to the families of people killed on American Airlines Flight 587 and delivered medical supplies. At each stop, the reactions of Dominicans, who were often nonplussed or a bit cynical about Mr. Pataki's motives, were enthusiasm and gratitude that he would focus his attention on them. 
Most of the Dominicans who saw him today may have had little idea who he was or why he was here, but not so their former compatriots in New York, where his visit was heavily covered by the Spanish-language media, and the English-language, as well, a fact that was noted approvingly by his aides.
By afternoon, it seemed that this year's race for governor of New York was being conducted more here than there, as Andrew M. Cuomo, one of the Democrats seeking to unseat Mr. Pataki, arrived in the Dominican Republic, holding his own meeting with President Hipolito Mejia, before visiting a housing project. Peter Ragone, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, the former United States housing secretary, said the trip had been planned for "well over a month," though the reporters Mr. Cuomo so ardently courts did not learn of it until today.
Mr. Cuomo emphasized that this was not his first time in the country, noting that he had visited as part of the federal government's relief efforts after Hurricane Georges wiped out whole towns here in 1998. "I'm very happy to be back in Santo Domingo and to have the chance to meet with President Mejia," he said in a statement.
While Mr. Pataki, a Republican, insisted that "this trip isn't about politics," he is running for a third term, and he has aggressively pursued Hispanic support in New York for the last year and a half. Last year, Mr. Pataki became an outspoken critic of the bombing tests on the island of Vieques. He visited the island -- his arrival today marked his second trip to Puerto Rico in 10 months -- and he has worked hard to build personal ties to Hispanic political, labor and business leaders. His hand-picked state party chairman, Alexander F. Treadwell, has said that Republicans' future rests on recruiting Hispanic voters.
His aides said yesterday that the State of New York, and not Mr. Pataki's campaign, would pay for this trip, but they would not provide an estimate of its cost. In addition, his wife, Libby, planned to join him on Thursday for a few personal days of vacation, which the governor planned to pay for personally, his aides added. 
The third major gubernatorial candidate, Comptroller H. Carl McCall, spent much of the day at a national meeting of a government employees' union in Washington. Mr. McCall's campaign strategist, Hank Sheinkopf, said, "Pataki's interest in the Hispanic community has to do with the fact that Democrats outnumber Republicans in New York by a 3-to-2 margin, and he's trying to cover that, and with respect to Andy, Andy has no record and Andy likes photo ops, and Andy's trying to build a base."
(For his part, Mr. Cuomo planned to travel to Haiti next, and had issued a statement saying he would meet with President Jean Bertrand Aristide. And he had his family in tow.)
The politicians who accompanied the governor here -- mostly Hispanic Democrats -- found the jockeying vastly amusing, and said it could only benefit their communities. "After Sept. 11 and Flight 587, there is a need to pull people together, and Governor Pataki is doing that," said Assemblyman Jose Rivera of the Bronx, who supports Mr. McCall. "If, unfortunately, that makes him more popular in our communities, and we Democrats have some catching up to do, then so be it."
At each stop today, the governor, who arrived in Santo Domingo Monday evening, used a few words of good Spanish, drawing howls of approval when he declared, at a Roman Catholic Church in Cristo Rey, "Cristo Rey es mi barrio" -- "Cristo Rey is my neighborhood." He has clearly been practicing.
"He listens to Spanish language radio, he has some tapes he listens to, he speaks in Spanish with some members of his staff," said Michael McKeon, the governor's communications director.
Time and again, Dominicans said it came as a pleasant surprise that a governor of New York would focus his attention on them. In particular, they said, they would not have expected him to devote much of his day to touring Cristo Rey, an area not found in the guidebooks, where the governor stopped at a church, a soup kitchen and a medical clinic, the jacket of his navy wool suit only briefly removed in deference to the tropical sun, his tie tightly knotted throughout.
"The Dominican politicians don't come here," said the Rev. Rogelio Cruz, the priest who acted as the governor's guide through Cristo Rey. "When there are elections they might come, but after they win, we don't see them for four years. Governor Pataki is here."
There are elections in New York this year, a fact that was not lost on the more worldly people who greeted Mr. Pataki, Father Cruz included. "I'm surprised to see him here, but I think the Hispanics are getting more attention in New York and there is an election coming up," said Dr. Pedro Silverio, director of the economic research center at a university here where the governor had breakfast with local business and religious leaders. "But whatever the reason, the important thing is he is recognizing how important the relationship is with the Dominican Republic."
 The trip grew from tragedy, when Mr. Pataki showed the World Trade Center site to President Mejia, who extended an invitation then to visit his country. Two months later came the crash of Flight 587 on the Rockaway Peninsula, bound from John F. Kennedy Airport to Santo Domingo, killing 265 people, many of them Dominican-Americans with family in both countries.
The governor described the meeting with relatives of those died as the main reason for making the trip. But time and again, their questions dealt with matters over which Mr. Pataki has no control, like visas and settlements with American Airlines. He promised to have a pamphlet drafted, explaining to the families their legal rights, to work toward memorials to the victims here and in New York, and to promote better coordination among agencies responding to the tragedy.
After the meeting, Patricia Encarnacion and Alba Baez sat to one side, wiping tears from their cheeks as Mr. Pataki took questions from reporters. Jovanny Baez, husband of Ms. Encarnacion and son of Mrs. Baez, died in the crash, and they learned today that, as they had suspected, there was little Mr. Pataki could do about their resulting legal problems.
"He didn't seem to have the answers, but it's good he came," Mrs. Baez said. "It's good someone is listening."
It was a sentiment heard throughout the day.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: HEARTS AND MINDS; 
Bush Will Keep the Wartime Operation Promoting America

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER and JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
President Bush has decided to transform the administration's temporary wartime communications effort into a permanent office of global diplomacy to spread a positive image of the United States around the world and combat anti-Americanism, senior administration officials said today.
 "The president believes it is a critical part of national security to communicate U.S. foreign policy to a global audience in times of peace as well as war," said Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director. 
 While discussions are at a preliminary stage, officials said there was general agreement in the administration that the intense shaping of information and coordination of messages that occurred during the fighting in Afghanistan should become a permanent feature of national security policy.
The White House office to be created to carry out the policy will coordinate the public statements of State, Defense and the other departments like the Voice of America to ensure that foreign correspondents in Washington as well as foreign leaders and opinion-makers overseas understand Mr. Bush's policies. 
"What is important is we want to do a better job of using the government seamlessly to give direction to the president's global diplomacy," a senior administration official said.
Officials said the new office would be entirely separate from a proposed Office of Strategic Influence at the Pentagon, which would use the media, the Internet and a range of covert operations to try to influence public opinion and government policy abroad, including in friendly nations.
That office is contemplating plans, which are being reviewed by Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld, to disseminate information, and possibly even disinformation, in foreign media as part of an aggressive campaign by the military to promote American policies overseas.
Today, the president of the Radio-Television News Directors Association, Barbara Cochran, wrote a letter to Mr. Rumsfeld objecting to any plans involving the spread of false or misleading information by the Pentagon.
Like the office of Homeland Security, the efforts to centralize public diplomacy following the Sept. 11 attacks have grown in importance and urgency in the last six months.
So far, the new White House office has no name, no director and no budget, though officials say Mr. Bush has said money will be no obstacle in pursuing the effort. The earlier White House push to create a more positive image of the United States after Sept. 11 was led by Karen P. Hughes, senior adviser to the president and is known as the Coalition Information Center.
The major goal, officials said, is to stem what the White House sees as a rising tide of anti-Americanism.
"A lot of the world does not like America, and it's going to take years to change their hearts and minds," said a senior official involved in the discussions. 
The president broached the possibility of a permanent mission in a meeting with the top people who speak for the administration in September. "He told us that we were going to be at this for a long, long time," one participant said, "that we were setting a template for future presidents, that we had to think big, strategic, historic thoughts." 
Global diplomacy as envisioned in the new office will inject patriotism into the punishing 24-hour, seven-day news cycle, officials said. It will include information campaigns about Mr. Bush's domestic policy -- like education bills -- as well as traditional information about the military, diplomatic and economic sides of national security policy, officials said.
Rather than create agencies, the new office would take advantage of the huge communications network of American embassies, their media offices and the broadcast network already in place under the State Department. 
Charlotte Beers, a former advertising executive now in charge of public diplomacy at the State Department, has used her marketing skills in an attempt to make American policies as familiar as American culture. 
Officials involved in the global communications effort said it required clear direction from the White House to break down the bureaucratic walls built up around the government after the cold war ended and the focus on defeating a clear-cut enemy disappeared.
Foreign journalists say they have given up getting meaningful interviews from American officials here. Only the most senior ambassadors from allied countries meet regularly with government policy makers. 
"There was often the feeling that we were either taken for granted or considered irrelevant," said Patrice de Beer, the former Washington correspondent for Le Monde, the French daily. "We don't expect anyone to deliver state secrets to us but to be accessible to explain what the policy was. That's all." 
In the earlier White House effort, Ms. Hughes joined forces with her British counterpart to put together the Coalition Information Center, known as the war room. 
When Washington decided to highlight the Taliban's policy against women's rights, officials enlisted not only First Lady Laura Bush but Cherie Blair, the wife of the British prime minister.
"The Afghanistan women's campaign was the best thing we've done -- giving insight into their vision of the future," said Jim Wilkinson, the head of the Coalition Information Center.

HEADLINE: Honeywell Hires TRW Chairman as Chief 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Honeywell International, after a search of several months, said yesterday that it had hired David M. Cote, 49, chairman of the TRW Corporation, as its chief executive, effective immediately. Lawrence A. Bossidy, 66, Honeywell's current chief, will remain chairman until June 30. Then Mr. Cote, who signed a five-year contract, will get that title, too. 
 Analysts say that Mr. Cote was not Honeywell's first choice. As recently as December, analysts were pegging Karl J. Krapek, who retired as president of United Technologies in January, as a front-runner. 
 Still, most analysts seemed pleased with Mr. Cote's appointment. "Dave Cote is demanding, he's disciplined, and he's a great decision maker," said Howard A. Rubel of Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
In a conference call, Mr. Cote and Mr. Bossidy reaffirmed plans to keep Honeywell -- whose attempt to merge with General Electric last year failed -- independent.
"I'm not interested in merging or selling off parts," Mr. Cote said. "I want to grow the bottom line by growing the top line."
He faces an uphill battle. The Sept. 11 attacks, combined with the plummeting economy, wreaked havoc with the market for cockpit controls, plane parts and other aerospace-related items, which provide about 40 percent of Honeywell's sales. And the sluggish economy has hurt Honeywell's chemicals businesses.
Moreover, although Honeywell recently sold its brakes business, it still faces possible litigation from its use of asbestos in break pads.
"Asbestos problems can always come back to haunt them," warned Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst with Prudential Securities.
Mr. Cote told TRW that he was leaving late last week. TRW named Philip A. Odeen, who was retiring as executive vice president for Washington operations, as its nonexecutive chairman, and pulled Timothy Hannemann and John Plant, the respective heads of TRW's aerospace and automotive businesses, into a makeshift office of the chief executive. Mr. Odeen expects it to take at least four months to find a new chief.
"We were surprised that Dave left, but we have a good team in place," Mr. Odeen said. 
Now, finally, Mr. Bossidy makes the same claim for Honeywell. Mr. Bossidy retired as Honeywell's chief executive when his former company, Allied Signal, merged with Honeywell Inc. in 1999 to form Honeywell International. Then last year, Michael R. Bonsignore, Mr. Bossidy's successor, resigned in the wake of the failed merger with G.E., and Mr. Bossidy came back from retirement. 
He has since slashed jobs and sold ancillary businesses, and analysts increasingly recommend the shares. Yesterday, though, investors were not listening: Honeywell's shares dropped 99 cents, to $32.65.
In many ways, Mr. Cote's background is well suited to Honeywell. Like Mr. Bossidy, he spent more than 20 years working for G.E., rising through several management posts in G.E.'s aircraft engines, silicones and appliances divisions. He earned a degree in business administration from the University of New Hampshire while supporting himself as an hourly worker in a G.E. plant in Hooksett, N.H. William J. Conaty, senior vice president for corporate human resources at G.E., said Mr. Cote became a finance and management whiz on the job. 
By the time Mr. Cote left G.E. for TRW in 1999, he was president of the $6 billion GE Appliances division. More important, he was well steeped in Six Sigma, the quality-control program that both G.E. and Honeywell have used to cut costs and shore up productivity. 
Those who know both Mr. Bossidy and Mr. Cote are struck by their similar styles. "They're hard-driving, results-oriented people who have no hidden agendas," said Mr. Conaty, a close friend of Mr. Cote. 
Although his tenure at TRW was brief -- Mr. Cote was just named chairman in July -- his impact was considerable as he sold off numerous businesses, cut jobs and consolidated TRW's three automotive divisions into one unit. He also replaced 8 of the top 14 executives at TRW. 
Although few analysts recommend TRW stock, many gave Mr. Cote an A for effort. "They were impressed with how dramatically he reduced overhead and revitalized management," said Charles L. Hill, director of research at Thomson Financial/ First Call.
Mr. Cote's departure shook up TRW shareholders. Though the appointment was not announced until after the market had closed, word leaked out earlier. Shareholders sent TRW shares down $3.29, to $41.75.

HEADLINE: Bush Plays Ball With Japanese Premier 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH and JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
In one appearance after another during President Bush's 72-hour stay in Japan, his praise for Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi was so hearty that many Japanese were left with the impression of one long bearhug.
 During a joint news conference on Monday, Mr. Bush spoke over and over again of his confidence, faith and trust in Mr. Koizumi and his efforts at economic reform. Mr. Bush resumed that tone today before Parliament, comparing the prime minister to Ichiro Suzuki of the Seattle Mariners, the 2001 American League most valuable player. 
 The president called Mr. Koizumi "a close friend," who "reminds me of a new American star, Ichiro -- the prime minister can hit anything you throw at him."
Mr. Bush's unusually enthusiastic embrace comes, awkwardly, at a time when Japanese themselves have been fast losing confidence in a leader who had been extraordinarily popular. So from economic experts to stock traders to Japanese political analysts, the question many people were asking today was whether the American pep talk would do Mr. Koizumi any good.
The initial response from the markets was not encouraging. The Nikkei 225 index of the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell back below the psychological 10,000 barrier, and the dollar enjoyed its biggest gain in a week, jumping about one yen to hover around 133 yen.
While answering reporters' questions during the news conference, Mr. Koizumi spoke with remarkable candor at one point about Japan's string of economic reversals since the late 1980's. "Ten years ago Japan was perhaps a little overconfident," he said. "Today, Japan has lost confidence in itself."
Many Japanese political analysts say that lately it is Mr. Koizumi himself who has lost self-confidence as well as the confidence of the public. The prime minister has been battered in opinion polls recently over his firing of a popular foreign minister and is increasingly facing challenges from within his own Liberal Democratic Party.
Indeed, before his vaunted economic reforms ever got off the ground, Mr. Koizumi has been under pressure to change direction and declare a new war against deflation.
"The most important impact of the visit will be on Koizumi himself, because Koizumi lost his confidence," said Ikuo Kabashima, a political analyst at Tokyo University. "The gesture of friendship from President Bush will give him more legitimacy within his own party. The impact on the people, though, is less certain, and in the end it may be pretty slim."
But because Mr. Bush did not offer advice to Mr. Koizumi publicly, nor did the prime minister make his persistent but vague pledges to carry out economic reforms any clearer, few analysts were willing to predict a new departure for the Japanese economy or for Mr. Koizumi's standing with the public.
"Bush felt it was wise to show strong support for Koizumi rather than making critical, or even constructively critical comments," said Takashi Inoguchi, a specialist in international relations at Tokyo University. "It was amazingly amicable, but without much substance. The result is that we were left with a lot of ambiguities on both sides."
On North Korea, for example, Mr. Koizumi expressed understanding for Mr. Bush's comments, including his inclusion of that country in an "axis of evil," but said Japan wanted to normalize relations with North Korea. On global warming, the prime minister contradicted Mr. Bush ever so subtly, saying he saw no conflict between protecting the environment and fostering economic growth.
American ambiguities were just as evident. Andrew Smithers, a British economist here, said after Mr. Bush's plane had taken off for Korea: "I don't think there is likely to be an economic impact at all. The American attitude to Japan is caught in a bind -- they want the Japanese economy to recover, but it can only recover with a weaker yen, which they don't want."
Mr. Smithers contends that Japan can start reducing its public and private debt loads only through controlled inflation. 
Similarly, although Mr. Bush may have avoided criticism of Japan himself, in a recent drumbeat of statements, Bush administration officials have been more direct.
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, for example, recently spelled out this recovery recipe: "Japan needs to counter deflation, it needs to rely on the market to revalue and revive unproductive assets, and it needs to foster more opportunity through deregulation."
Then Glenn Hubbard, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, said in an interview with Japanese reporters, "There's no way Japan can export itself out of its problem without fixing the nonperforming assets and changing the monetary policy."
Japanese and American political analysts agree that beneath the smiles and complimentary talk, Washington is deeply worried about Japan, but also deeply conflicted about what it can do to help this country get its house in order.
The Bush administration has seemed eager to highlight a different approach to Japan from that of the Clinton White House: more friendly support and less lecturing. But in light of this country's steadily worsening economic circumstances, many Japanese say they would welcome more American pressure.

HEADLINE: A News Agency's Rose-Colored Glasses 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
Minutes after President Bush's plane touched down in Seoul today, North Korea's news agency sought to upstage him with an amazing report that two halos had just appeared in the sky above the legendary mountain birthplace of Kim Jong Il.
 "Inhabitants were delighted to see a rare cloud in the shape of Kimjongilia," the state news agency added, referring to an artificially bred flower named after Mr. Kim, North Korea's leader. "Even the sky above the Mount Paektu area seemed to be decorated with beautiful flowers" said the dispatch, written 200 miles away in Pyongyang, the capital. 
 In what the news agency reported as divine coincidence, on Mr. Kim's 60th birthday last Saturday, Mount Paektu marked its 60th day of snow cover, which had accumulated to exactly 60 centimeters.
Churning out of old-fashioned news tickers in Japan or read on the Internet (www.kcna.co.jp), the Korean Central News Agency provides a window on the strange, secretive world of North Korea, a totalitarian government that Mr. Bush lumps together with Iran and Iraq in "the axis of evil."
Through the dispatches of the agency, which is controlled by the ruling Korean Workers Party, an image emerges of an Asian Sparta, a highly militarized, ultra-nationalistic government that seeks to inculcate worship of Mr. Kim. Readers learn that Mr. Bush is "a moral leper," who leads the "empire of the devil." "After flying into South Korea with many war servants and warmongers," the agency said, he is "to examine a plan for a war against the North."
Reflecting the agency's praise of Mr. Kim's "army-centered leadership," North Korea devotes an estimated one quarter of its economic activity to the military, fielding the fourth largest standing army in the world, 1.2 million soldiers.
"The North Korean propaganda machine does not need to be taken too seriously -- it is on auto pilot," Selig S. Harrison, author of a new book, "Korean Endgame" (Princeton University Press, 2002) said from Washington. Noting that the news agency issued a dispatch condemning terrorism after the Sept. 11 attacks in the United States, he added, "When it winds down, that is significant because it means that someone from above has reached out."
Li Yang Su, KCNA's distributor in Japan, said in an interview: "They are, in a word, bashing Bush very hard. They feel Mr. Bush is stifling them, or aiming at the extinction of North Korea." 
But with the latest James Bond movie being filmed with "North Korea" scenes, the agency's approach to news contributes to the reclusive nation's "international villain" stereotype.
North Koreans, whose only access to information is from state sources, will not learn that the United States is the largest food and fuel donor to North Korea.
In the late 1990's, under Mr. Kim's leadership, a famine created by bad weather, a state farming system and a cutoff of Soviet subsidies killed as many as two million people, or almost 10 percent of the population. Today, the United Nations World Food Program, which helps feed 30 percent of North Korea's people, appealed for more money, saying that with pledges for only a quarter of the campaign's $216 million goal, aid would be cut off in early March.
The news agency did not mention that today, reporting that Mr. Kim has pledged to "build a powerful socialist country where national power is strong, everything prospers and people have nothing to desire more in the world."
Mr. Kim's birthday festivities included a garden show. In Pyongyang, the news agency reports, 500,000 people have visited the show. Displaying an enthusiasm that does not seem to extend to growing food, the agency reported that "80 organizations across the country presented more than 14,300 potted Kimjongilias," many coming from the more than 120 Kimilsungia-Kimjongilia greenhouses built across the country in recent years.

HEADLINE: BUSH SAYS THE U.S. PLANS NO ATTACK ON NORTH KOREA 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: PANMUNJOM, South Korea, Wednesday, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
President Bush said today in Seoul that the United States had no intentions of invading or attacking North Korea and that his goal in the Korean peninsula was peace.
 In remarks meant to soothe the fears and anger of South Koreans about what the president has called an "axis of evil" made up of Iraq, Iran and North Korea, Mr. Bush said he fully supported the so-called sunshine policy of negotiations with the North embraced by the South Korean president, Kim Dae Jung. 
 Mr. Bush said dialogue with North Korea was not inconsistent with the tough "axis of evil" talk he first used in the State of the Union address three weeks ago. 
Although the United States has never given any indication that it would attack North Korea, an action that American defense officials have said they considered inconceivable, Mr. Bush's remarks showed the extent to which he has had to reassure American allies at a time when his harsh words are still rebounding around the world.
"Let me explain why I made the comments I did," Mr. Bush said in a joint news conference with Mr. Kim. The president said he spoke out because he believed in freedom and was "troubled by a regime that tolerated starvation.
"I worry about a regime that is closed and not transparent," he added. "I'm deeply concerned about the people of North Korea."
Mr. Bush said several times during the news conference that an offer the United States made for talks with North Korea last June had not been answered and that contact between the two nations was now up to Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader.
"We're more than willing to speak out publicly and speak out in private with the North Korean leadership," he said. "And again I wonder why they haven't taken up our offer."
Mr. Bush explained his intentions toward North Korea, saying: "We're a peaceful people. We have no intention of invading North Korea. South Korea has no intention of attacking North Korea. Nor does America. We're purely defensive, and the reason we have to be defensive is because there is a threatening position of the DMZ, so we long for peace. It's in our nation's interest that we achieve peace on the peninsula."
Mr. Bush said it was not counterproductive to lash out at a country and its leader and then expect the leader to sit down agreeably for talks. As evidence, he cited President Ronald Reagan's success in dealing with the Soviet Union and said the South Korean president had reminded him of that this morning in Seoul.
"During our discussion, President Kim reminded me a little bit about American history when he said President Reagan referred to Russia as the Evil Empire and then was able to have constructive dialogue with Mr. Gorbachev," he said, referring to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the former Soviet leader.
Similarly, said Mr. Bush, "I will not change my opinion on Kim Jong Il until he frees his people and accepts genuine proposals from countries like South Korea and the United States for dialogue, until he proves to the world that he has a good heart."
In his remarks, Kim Dea Jung reiterated that there was disagreement between the United States and South Korea over North Korea, although he did not express any opinion about the "axis of evil," which has undermined his position with South Koreans terrified of war with the North. "There was some indication there might be some difference of opinion,' Mr. Kim said. "We were able to reconfirm that there was no difference of opinion between Korea and the United States."
Mr. Kim said he and Mr. Bush had agreed to work together to stop the North from developing weapons of mass destruction and to push for removal of missiles on its border that were within easy striking distance of Seoul, the South's capital.
After meeting with Mr. Kim, Mr. Bush traveled to the edge of the demilitarized zone to deliver a speech there. 
The word "evil" resurfaced again before the speech on a tour of the DMZ, where Mr. Bush reacted in disgust when he learned that axes used to kill two American servicemen were in a museum across the border to the north. "No wonder I think they're evil," he said.
In his formal remarks, he said people on both sides of the border wanted to live without the threat of violence, famine and war. "I see a peninsula that is one day united in commerce and cooperation instead of divided by barbed wire and fear," said Mr. Bush, with Mr. Kim at his side. "Korean grandparents should be free to spend their final years with those they love. Korean children should never starve while a massive army is fed. No nation should be a prison for its own people."
The White House arranged for the speech to be delivered for maximum photographic effect from the Dorasan Station, a sleek new facility near a new rail line and a new road that are to connect the North and South for the first time since the Korean War. South Korea finished its stretch of the road and rail line up to the demilitarized zone this month, just in time for Mr. Bush's visit, but North Korea has yet to start construction. Mr. Bush called on the North to finish the road and the rail line. 
At a meeting in the northern capital, Pyongyang, in June 2000, Mr. Kim and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, agreed to relink the two nations by road and by rail. Kim Dae Jung triumphantly returned from the trip declaring that "a new day is beginning," but he has been frustrated by the North's failure to follow through on this part of the deal.
Today, Mr. Bush's remarks were far more regretful rather than antagonistic, although he did repeat a sentence from his State of the Union address that "We must not permit the world's most dangerous regimes to threaten us with the world's most dangerous weapons." 
He literally cast the division between North and South as one between darkness and light. "When satellites take pictures of the Korean peninsula at night the South is awash in light," he said. "The north is almost completely dark."
Mr. Bush said the road connecting the two Koreas was a solution. "Traveling south on that road, the people of the North would see not a threat but a miracle of peaceful development -- Asia's third-largest economy, risen from the ruins of war," he said. 
Mr. Bush is on the second leg of a six-day visit to Japan, South Korea and China, a trip that was to have taken place last fall but was rescheduled after Sept. 11.
He is to travel to Beijing on Thursday. He said in his news conference that he did not know if he would meet with any political dissidents or Christian activists, but that in his last visit with the Chinese leader, Jiang Zemin, he had put his concerns about religious freedoms in China in the context of his own faith.

HEADLINE: Foundation Announces 2 New Grant Programs 

 BODY:
The Howard Gilman Foundation has announced the creation of two grant programs that will award about $9 million over three years to nonprofit performing arts organizations in New York City. The grants, announced Tuesday, will be for artistic and organizational development and technical assistance for dance and for the training of young dance and theater performers. 
 "Howard Gilman loved the arts and especially dance and dancers," Isabella Rossellini, the chairman of the foundation board, said, adding "With our new programs, the foundation will build on Howard's legacy by helping performing arts organizations and talented young artists pursue their dreams." Mr. Gilman, who died in 1998, was the chairman of the Gilman Paper Company and a philanthropist who supported the arts, animal conservation and medical research. 
 The Partners for Performing Arts Program will give three-year grants ranging from $100,000 to $450,000 to dance companies, performing arts presenters and small theaters in New York City that have demonstrated exceptional promise or sustained excellence. The grants are to be used for artistic and organizational development and technical assistance. The foundation will also make available its White Oak Plantation in northeast Florida, where the White Oak Dance Project was formed by Mark Morris and Mikhail Baryshnikov, for artistic residencies. 
The Training and Mentoring Young Talent Program will award one- or two-year grants, ranging from $10,000 to $75,000, to nonprofit organizations offering formal professional and preprofessional training in the arts. 
Arlene Shuler, the foundation's executive director, said that the programs had been in the planning stages for a year and were not a response to economic problems in the arts after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11. "Performing arts groups are essential to New York City's vitality, but sustained support for core artistic and organizational needs is hard to find," Ms. Shuler said. "We're trying to make a difference by addressing this need. We hope that this encourages others to give to dance and the other performing arts."

HEADLINE: Five Rooms, Gucci View 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM L. HAMILTON 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif. 

 BODY:
CHRISTINE FRANZ, 35, a software consultant who looks like Meg Ryan, was exactly what developers had in mind when they started Santana Row, a Silicon Valley crest in the latest, most ambitious wave of shopping malls.
 Ms. Franz, demographic perfection, stared out through fashionable sunglasses at the muddy Main Street of the 21-acre site, now concrete and steel. By August, when the $475 million "lifestyle village" is scheduled to open, Santana Row's 17 city blocks will boast 100 specialty shops, including Gucci, Tourneau and Burberry. 
 But shopping is only the start. Santana Row will also be home to the people who live above the stores in 1,200 studios, lofts, town houses and villas. 
Welcome to mall-town America. You can now drop where you shop, a few steps upstairs.
Santana Row is the largest example nearing completion of a new hybrid of retail development and housing that has seized the imagination of the shopping center industry in the last year, just as regional megamall developments have begun to lumber and older suburban strip malls shutter and die.
More than a dozen such malls are breaking ground nationally, in Cincinnati; Littleton, Colo.; Richmond Heights, Mo.; and elsewhere. Developers and municipalities say they have the potential for profit, reinventing dead retail property in older suburbs. Open-air and upscale, with Main Street-style architecture, they are intended to appeal to young professionals with expensive brand-name tastes and retirement-ready empty nesters looking for downtown's retail sophistication.
Commercial developers like to call these shopping villages "communities." The affluent, amenity-laden life as a salable daydream has a familiar history, whether as housing at the edge of the golf course green or condominiums at the tennis club.
Ms. Franz was, to a corduroy-collared, denim-jacketed T, a prime prospect on Santana Row's open-house tour. "Forgive me for sounding snobbish," she said. "But the retail sounds like it's going to be top-notch." A 40,000-square-foot Crate & Barrel will sell the welcome mats.
Fred Smith, 52, an engineer on the tour with Ms. Franz, said: "It's fantastic. I could go downstairs to Starbucks for coffee, then come back upstairs and work on my computer, then go back down to Chili's for dinner."
Mr. Smith is the other side of Santana Row's demographic silver dollar: baby boomers on the brink of retirement, looking for a last place to live -- 20 million of them turning 55 within the next two years.
"And shopping-wise, it's very nice not to have to drive," said Annette Hamon, 55, a graphic artist who owns a house in Cupertino, Calif. "I'd like to live someplace where you don't have so much upkeep yourself."
The builder of Santana Row, Federal Realty Investment Trust, a retail-property developer based in Rockville, Md., with $2.5 billion in assets, compares the mall's mix of shopping and living to a typical neighborhood in New York.
But urbanists debate whether the demography of a private development pinned specifically to upscale shopping and dining will actually invite the true diversities of metropolitan life, while retailers weigh the risk that upstairs residents with eyesore tastes in window curtains could ruin their sales image below.
Santana Row's developers are giving stores the option to dress the residents' windows above, in certain buildings. The 6,000-square-foot Gucci may, if it chooses, install blinds in the apartments that will display retail logos when pulled down, said Marc McQuain, the retail development manager -- an ultimate brand extension that may or may not bother residents, depending upon the strength of their shopping allegiances.
"At the end of the day, it's a shopping center," said Barbara Lamour, 29, touring with her father, Will Heiduk, a retired engineer. "It's not a community. It's a business."
Santana Row, though it will have street mimes and strolling mandolin players, will not have public parks, day care or senior-citizen centers, schools or community boards. And its retail tenants will be well tailored to the tastes of residents whose incomes will support the proposed rents -- $1,500 to $10,000 a month. Dean & DeLuca, not Safeway, will be the corner grocery. Santana Row will have no church, but there will be an imported 18th-century French chapel, selling flowers.
Lifestyle villages are rapidly eclipsing in scale and civic posture earlier, smaller residential-shopping developments like Mizner Place, in Boca Raton, Fla., built in 1988. The Streets of West Chester in suburban Cincinnati and Birkdale Village, a 52-acre shopping and residential community outside Charlotte, N.C., have also broken ground in the last year. Housing is also being integrated, as a second phase, into many of the 25 existing open-air, upscale shopping malls that developers call "lifestyle centers," to convert them to villages.
A PricewaterhouseCoopers report on shopping malls issued last year estimated that 18 percent of the nation's 2,800 malls are dead or dying as commercial ventures. It cited aging malls' inability to compete with newer malls that provide a stronger draw with movies and other recreation, and increasing dissatisfaction among suburban shoppers bone-tired of highway trips and traffic. Lifestyle centers, many planned to include residences, are replacing them. Santana Row, which sits at an intersection with two other malls, is being built on the site of the former Town and Country Mall, now the mud of its new Main Street.
With one third the retail space of existing regional megamalls, which have a million square feet or more, these hybrids exclude "big box" department stores like Macy's as anchors, considered mass-market merchants, preferring higher-end chains like Williams-Sonoma, which owns Pottery Barn.
Small examples of centers with retail and residence integration, like Phillips Place in Charlotte, developed in 1997, have succeeded at maintaining a high level of the right, exclusive retail tenants and a high level of resident occupancy -- 90 percent at Phillips Place.
"There is 'city' life, and there is 'some' life, and there is 'no' life -- the suburbs," said Dr. Keoni Udarbe, 34, who lives in a one-bedroom apartment above Cradle and All, a baby-goods shop at Phillips Place. "If I need to have a dinner party, I can walk to Dean & DeLuca." Dr. Udarbe, a psychiatric pediatrician who moved from New York City, had no problems with the urban character of his new home, including the December toy drive in the courtyard and the week of ho-ho-hoing below his balcony. "But it's not like living in the city. I lived in the city -- and this is not close."
Christopher Cole, a director of development on the East Coast for Terranomics Development, a retail development company based in New Jersey, said that interest in projects like Santana Row "is driven by municipalities wanting urban centers, where you live and shop in the same neighborhood."
Susan F. Shick, the executive director of the San Jose Redevelopment Agency, which rezoned Santana Row's land to allow both housing and shops, said, "When a developer comes in with more retail -- and high end -- why would you say no?" Centers like Santana Row, she said, can create a profitable synergy of uses for developers and a high tax base for the neighborhood, but also, potentially, a hellishly high density of people and cars at a single site.
In Rochester Hills, Mich., the Village at Rochester Hills, a lifestyle center now being built, was not allowed residences in its plan largely because of the congestion they stood to create.
"The whole area's bursting at the seams," said James Fielder, vice president for acquisitions for Robert B. Aikens & Associates, the developer. "It was shot down in discussions with the municipality. I didn't think it had a snowball's chance it would go through."
What gives developers any confidence that there is a market for shopping mall villages?
"This is the American cultural response to boredom with the suburbs," said Alex Krieger, chairman of the department of urban planning at the Harvard Graduate School of Design. "Clothing suburbia in urban mannerisms, for a market of people who think it's funky to have restaurants and shops downstairs -- it's a great marketing gimmick, but it's pretend urbanism."
"What the developers don't bank on," he added, "is that if it succeeds, those folks above Banana Republic and Pomodoro's will start complaining about longer shop hours, liquor licenses, pedestrian traffic. It's succeeding now because it's a novelty."
Retailers also question the idea's basic equations.
"For developers it works, because it adds a good-sounding thing to the economic package," Howard Lester, chairman of Williams-Sonoma, said. "But I don't think residential means a heck of a lot to retailers. I need 80,000 households to drive a Pottery Barn or Pottery Barn Kids." Mr. Lester, who is not joining Santana Row because he already has shops in a mall across the street, added, "I don't know that the fact people are living above makes it more attractive to me as a customer."
On a recent Sunday at Santana Row, a dozen shoponauts stomping up the concrete steps to view model apartments presented a diversity of opinion.
"It's going to attract single people, with fewer attachments," said Karen Dalal, 33, who lives in a ranch-style house a mile away. "I mean, I have a couple of dogs. I'm not going to bring them into a community like this."
Laura Ward, 32, on tour with her partner, Brent Gregersen, 31, said, "For me, personally, because I have two children, it just doesn't seem like it will be right."
Neither dog runs nor playgrounds are in the plans at Santana Row.
But there will be a Starbucks and a Chili's and 19 other restaurants, said Steven J. Guttman, chairman and chief executive of Federal Realty Investment Trust.
"It's a good example of how the market for something as mundane as housing has changed from a good that somebody buys to a package of services, only one of which is a residential living space," said Peter Francese, founder of American Demographics magazine.
"The people doing this have realized that 'it's the amenities, stupid,' " he said. "What do people want in a lifestyle -- not what do people want in a four-walled box."
Robert Gibbs, a retail consultant who helps developers incorporate urban thinking into suburban projects, says that aging baby boomers might well prefer the mall as a mailing address.
"They're coming onto the market looking for smaller multifamily luxury housing in town," he said. "They spent their lives in suburbs, driving their kids to soccer. They want to be able to walk to shops and restaurants. Their tax advisers are telling them they don't have to own a home -- because they don't need the tax deduction -- but to sell the four-bedroom $400,000 empty nest, put the money in the bank, rent a $2,000 apartment and live on interest."
Mr. Gibbs added dryly, "The smarter new shopping centers know this."
Ms. Franz, the software consultant, wasn't packing up house just yet.
"This is huge -- it's like a mall," she said, looking up Santana Row's dirt avenues. "How do you find comfort living at the mall?"

HEADLINE: British Industrial Icon Is Joining Exodus Trend 

BYLINE:  By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: MALMESBURY, England 

 BODY:
When he created the no-wheel wheelbarrow and went on to invent the no-bag vacuum cleaner, Britons tended to look upon James Dyson as just one more in a tradition of inventors -- eccentric but harmless.
 Then, when Mr. Dyson, who is now 54, turned his iconoclastic ideas into a privately held business with sales of $316 million in 2000 and an estimated value of $700 million, the perception shifted. The inventor became an icon of innovative Britain. His surname has become a brand and has been imprinted on the eight million Dyson bagless vacuum cleaners his company has sold since 1993. 
 Now, though, Mr. Dyson has assumed another persona. Having said he would never abandon the land that nurtured him, Mr. Dyson announced this month that he planned to close an assembly line here and shift production of all his vacuum cleaners to a much cheaper Asia. The move will eliminate 800 of the 1,800 jobs at his six-year-old plant near this ancient market town 100 miles west of London, saving payroll and other costs as Mr. Dyson prepares to introduce his products into the United States market this summer. Labor unions have accused him of betrayal -- a charge that rankles with him.
"Survival is what's going on here," Mr. Dyson said in an interview. "I put $:40 million of my money into this business to try to make manufacturing work here. But I have to regard the law of economics. If we are to survive as a business, we have to go where manufacturing is economical. I am not betraying anybody."
Mr. Dyson's decision has illustrated a malaise in the British economy that has left economists pondering whether the land that created the Industrial Revolution is finally saying farewell to manufacturing quicker than its European neighbors. In the last three decades, manufacturers have seen their share of Britain's annual output cut in half, while services like banking or restaurants have prospered in a new kind of economy that has given Britons jobs, low interest rates and huge spending power without, so far, fueling inflation.
"The country as a whole is in a two-speed economy where the consumer economy is roaring away and manufacturing is in a deep recession," said Eric Britton, an economist with Oxford Economic Forecasting, a consulting concern. "It is a feature of developed economies that the manufacturing sector tends to go down. But that has been far more accelerated here than in France or Germany."
That shift is cited as one reason, by some tallies, Britain is ahead of the global game. Over all, the British economy is expected to grow about 2 percent this year -- sluggish but still more nimble than either the United States, Japan or the European Union, which buys around 60 percent of Britain's exports. Just recently, the bullish housing market pushed the average price of a house in Britain beyond the psychological barrier of $:100,000 ($142,000) after prices soared by at least 17 percent last year -- eight times the rate of inflation -- giving Britons the same confidence the stock boom of the 1990's gave Americans.
The British "are able to sustain a high level of consumer credit because they have a large comfort factor in the value of their properties," said David Brown, the chief economist at Bear, Stearns here.
While much of Continental Europe struggles with unemployment, British joblessness is down to about 3.2 percent. Interest rates are at a 34-year low. Taxation, which is higher than in the United States, still takes far less from paychecks than in the Continental European economies.
But that is only one side of the story. Britons may have jobs, but they work the longest hours in Western Europe and their productivity ranks way behind the levels achieved in the United States, France or Germany. Their public services -- railways, hospitals and schools -- are creaking after decades of underinvestment. And, from a land once labeled by Napoleon as a nation of shopkeepers, Britain has become a nation of shoppers: consumer spending accounts for a full 60 percent of the economy.
Contrast that with the old-fashioned business of making things to sell. Last year, manufacturing shed 150,000 jobs -- while service industries like call centers added almost 230,000 jobs -- as factory output shrank by 5.4 percent and the sector's share of the nation's economic activity fell below 20 percent. 
But does it matter?
So long as consumers continue to spend the way they are doing -- stores recorded an average increase of 7 percent for the year-end holidays -- growth, too, will continue. But so will the amount of debt incurred by the average household.
On average, British householders owe 109 percent of their annual income, including mortgages, up from 92 percent in 1998. Those figures might not seem especially troubling -- nowhere near as ominous as their equivalent during the country's late 1980's boom, which led to recession. But, according to recent figures from the Office of National Statistics, both unemployment and inflation have begun to increase. That puts pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates. Higher interest rates, increasing costs and fewer jobs, in turn, would reduce borrowing and make repayments more expensive.
"The rate at which consumers are running up debt is not sustainable," Mr. Britton at Oxford Economics Forecasting said. But many economists argue that no one is losing too much sleep. Except, of course, manufacturers, who argue that the decline of their businesses is so advanced that it may be irreparable, leaving the country perilously dependent on a fragile service economy. Indeed, some manufacturers argue that their industry has already reached what one called a "subcritical mass" from which it cannot recover.
That argument has been reinforced by the high costs of doing business in Britain at a time when the pound's strength against the euro makes British exports to the European Union expensive. "Europe is our main export market and the country's main export market," Mr. Dyson said. While the pound has weakened against the dollar, it has maintained its strength against the euro. "That's really damaging," he added.
Also, expenses in Britain are at least 30 percent higher than in parts of Asia, where Mr. Dyson already manufactures some of his vacuum cleaners and where he will soon manufacture the rest, leaving his research and development team, a washing machine assembly shop and main office staff at his plant here.
By moving production to Asia, he said, his aim is to be closer to suppliers and to pare down costs in advance of his marketing in the United States, which he estimates will cost $20 million to $30 million. The move to the United States is crucial, he said, because America accounts for around 85 percent of the world's sales of upright vacuum cleaners.
But shifting production out of Britain will be one more blow to a broader decline in a culture of manufacturing. "No one really wants to make anything," Mr. Dyson said. "Engineering and manufacturing are very unsexy."

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH: GAMING; 
Economist Finds Value And Fixed Books in Online World

BYLINE:  By Lynn Harris 

 BODY:
Tracking phantom subsidiaries is one thing. For a real accounting challenge, try balancing the books for an entire virtual world. 
 Edward Castronova, an economist at California State University at Fullerton, recently published an economic analysis of the virtual world Norrath, the locus of EverQuest, Sony's popular online fantasy role-playing game. 
 His analysis, titled "Virtual Worlds: A Firsthand Account of Market and Society on the Cyberian Frontier," not only examined Norrath's internal marketplace but also determined that its gross national product per capita was the 77th-highest in the world, right between Russia's and Bulgaria's. One unit of Norrath's currency, the platinum piece or pp, , is worth more than the yen. Mr. Castronova's own character avatar made a living by selling "misty acorns" to "rich people" for 8 pp each. "Now I can buy a nice hat," he said. 
Then there's the Enronian side of the game: an offline black market for Norrathian goods in very real dollars, which some players are prepared to spend. Since EverQuest items are Sony's intellectual property, selling them for American currency is considered theft. Nonetheless, in a survey by Mr. Castronova, 45 percent of the respondents said they knew someone who had traded Norrathian goods for dollars. 
Virtual worlds should not be dismissed as geek fringe, he says. If nothing else, they make money. That's better than many other Internet ventures. Lynn Harris

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Regain Some Recent Losses, With Dow Up 2%

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Investors took advantage of lower prices from a two-day sell-off and sent the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 200 points yesterday.
 They traded a little more cautiously in technology issues, which were troubled by reports of improper accounting at Computer Associates. 
 The blue-chip Dow gained 196.03 points, or 2.01 percent, to close at 9,941.17, rebounding from declines totaling 256.85 points in the previous two sessions.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 24.96 points, or 1.43 percent, to 1,775.57. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 14.64 points, or 1.35 percent, at 1,097.98. 
Advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange surpassed those declining by more than 3 to 2. Volume rose to 1.45 billion shares.
Depressed stock prices have served as a catalyst for buyers in the last few weeks, though trading has been dominated by selling on fears about weak business and a lack of credibility in corporate bookkeeping in the wake of Enron's collapse.
Analysts said many of the gains yesterday also grew out of short-sale covering as investors who had bet prices were headed lower were forced to buy stocks to cover their positions. The prevalence of short sellers in the market is another sign of investors' lingering pessimism.
"We're beaten up pretty good," said Larry Wachtel, market analyst for Prudential Securities. "So, every now and then we lift up."
Shares of Computer Associates International, the software maker, plunged $4.40, to $20.91, on reports that federal prosecutors were investigating whether the company overstated sales and profits to inflate its stock price. The company said it was unaware of an inquiry and had not been contacted by the authorities.
I.B.M., which had dropped on reports questioning its accounting, slipped 23 cents further yesterday, to $99.31.
But the lower prices helped buyers at least temporarily set aside some accounting concerns. The biggest gain among Dow stocks came from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which increased $3.73, to $117.10. Merck, another Dow component, rose $2.01, to $61.26. A White House aide was quoted as saying that the administration would propose that officials of a planned Medicare drug-card program negotiate for discounts directly with drug makers, rather than with pharmacies.
DuPont gained 82 cents, to $46.33, after Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown raised its recommendation to strong buy from market perform. Such upgrades helped other stocks, like Circuit City, which climbed $2.21, to $24.32, after Merrill Lynch raised its near- and long-term recommendations to strong buy from buy.
Among technology producers, Oracle rose 72 cents, to $15.51, after a Banc of America analyst upgraded it to buy from market perform.
The market was little influenced by a report that consumer prices rose 0.2 percent in January after dipping 0.1 percent in December. --------------------

Treasury Prices Decline
(By Bloomberg News) -- A bond rally stalled for a second day yesterday as expectations of economic recovery prompted investors to buy stocks, drawing cash away from fixed-income securities.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Treasury note fell 6/32, to 99 28/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.89 percent from 4.87 percent on Tuesday. The price of the 30-year bond declined 4/32, to 99 24/32. Its yield rose to 5.39 percent from 5.38 percent.
"Investors seem to be embracing the recovery story a bit more," said Kevin Flanagan, a fixed-income strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.

HEADLINE: Trying to Catch Up To a Hungry Beetle; 
Invading Tree Pest Fights Tough

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
It has been here for at least a decade, quietly chewing its way through the city's beloved maples and elms, leaving barren neighborhoods and parks in its wake. First discovered in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, it appeared in Queens, Long Island and Manhattan, before finally, disappointingly, wreaking its telltale damage within the stone walls of Central Park, uncovered at the end of last month. 
 Even as teams of inspectors try to scour every vulnerable tree in the city and scientists race to develop ever more sophisticated methods of search-and-destroy -- from sexual lures to computerized eavesdroppers -- officials are discovering just how formidable the Asian longhorned beetle can be. 
 Asked what the best hope was for eliminating the beetle from native soil, David Lance, an entomologist at the United States Department of Agriculture's plant protection lab on Cape Cod, said, giddily, "Well, just beat it to death with as many sticks as you can, basically." 
But those sticks have thus far proven elusive. "At this point, there is no question that the U.S.D.A. and the state are doing everything in their power," said E. Richard Hoebeke, the Cornell University entomologist who first identified the distinctive black-and-white beetle here. But he added: "Not a whole lot has changed in the six years we've been fighting this animal. We're a little better at finding it, but we haven't discovered that silver bullet to eliminate it." 
Eradication efforts have at times progressed more slowly in New York than in Chicago, the only other North American city to have uncovered infested trees. Experts predict that Chicago will be first to get its population under control, discovered about two years after New York's, although, Mr. Hoebeke said, "Chicago is not out of the woods yet, no pun intended."
Chicago, which was able to learn from the New York experience, was the first to use tree climbers to comb the upper branches, as opposed to relying heavily on ground surveys with binoculars. In New York, tree climbers began working comprehensively just last year, and have since discovered infestations in trees, like the two maples in Central Park, that had already been examined from the ground, heightening the worry among researchers and officials that there are many more pockets of infestation to be found.
"Being No. 1 isn't always so great," said Christine Markham, the national Asian longhorned beetle program director for the U.S.D.A., adding that it took time to amass the information and resources to carry out an effective battle plan. By the time the Chicago infestation was discovered, officials were already aware of the potential damage. Because of that, and because of Richard M. Daley, the mayor of Chicago, known as an ardent protector of trees, that city was better able to coordinate its attack from the onset, Ms. Markham said.
"When we first started, we weren't operating on a shoestring, we were operating on dental floss," said Joseph P. Gittleman, a U.S.D.A. official who has overseen New York City's eradication efforts practically from the start. "We had six or eight people, we were working out of our cars, we didn't have our own binoculars, you didn't have your own anything," he said, explaining that the Asian longhorned beetle "doesn't have the same kind of political clout as something that affects citrus or wheat," crops whose damage has immediate and obvious economic consequences.
In addition, not only is New York's infestation older and more deeply entrenched than Chicago's, officials say, but New York's streetscape, with its many courtyards, attached row houses and rooftop gardens, is less accessible to inspection equipment, making for more tedious hand-to-foreleg combat. And then there is the congenital squinty-eyed stance of the typical New Yorker, who is less likely to open the door for a nonuniformed visitor asking to look at that big willow out back.
But experts say that the beetle could be devastating. Since the first findings in Greenpoint, more than 3,500 New York City trees, among about 7,000 nationwide, have been sacrificed to the insects, officials say, and the threat extends to more than 1 billion trees belonging to host species like maple, birch, horse chestnut, poplar, willow, elm and ash. 
Experts said that in China, the beetle's native home, its population exploded in fields of poplar that had been planted to reforest vast tracts of land. The wood from the trees, riddled with Asian longhorns, was then used in packaging goods for transport, thus unwittingly creating an export system for the pest. 
It is not clear whether the beetle first arrived here by air or sea, but in its wake, the United States imposed requirements that solid wood packing material coming from China and Hong Kong be treated to ensure that it is free of insects. Still, no such prohibition yet exists for wood packing material from Europe, where infestations have recently been discovered. And, as Mr. Hoebeke explained, there are more threats hovering at the borders. 
In August, an infestation of citrus longhorned beetle, a close cousin of the Asian longhorned, cropped up near Seattle in an open-air quarantine center holding imported bonsai maples, and there is evidence that the beetles spread miles away. "Again, what we've been learning is that in addition to solid wood, much of these bonsai are also insect-infested," Mr. Hoebeke said.
Experts say that these infiltrations are inevitable in the face of increasing international trade, which Mr. Hoebeke estimated brings in several new exotic species a year.
But the battle of the beetle rages on. Following Chicago's lead, officials injected healthy trees in parts of Brooklyn, Queens and Manhattan last year with a pesticide compound, Imidacloprid, as a preventive measure. Officials hope that the compound, spread throughout the bark, will kill the adult females nibbling the trunks to lay their eggs. 
Scientists are also trying to develop chemical lures, some that mimic whatever attracts males and females to one another, others that mimic what attracts them to certain types of hardwoods, that could be used in traps. But that avenue is limited. Mr. Lance said that it appeared unlikely that the insect responds to attractants over a long range as do some insects, but he held out hope for developing one that works short-range.
More promising, perhaps, is an acoustical device with far-reaching applications that could detect the insect chewing inside the tree, even pinpointing its stage of development. Researchers have already experimented with such a device in New York last year, in which sensors are attached to the tree and then the recorded sounds are fed through a computerized neural network. They hope to have a prototype of sorts ready to test this spring. 
Michael T. Smith, a research entomologist on the project, said that they were working toward creating a sensor that could detect chewing sounds in the top branches from the base of the tree, obviating the need to climb. It costs a lot to have screeners in New York, he said, "and if they have to climb, it really costs."
But for the time being, climbing is the only tried and true method. Dozens of surveyors, sometimes climbing out of a two-foot-square bucket in rough weather to reach branches soaring 75 feet, perform these jobs each weekday throughout the city, looking for often-camouflaged egg sites or dime-sized exit holes.
As a squad of inspectors balanced themselves high overhead in Central Park one recent weekday morning, Mr. Gittleman explained that when trees are cut down, they are replaced with other varieties as a matter of practicality. "There's no prohibition on planting host material," he said, adding that it costs $600 to $800 to put a tree in the sidewalk and that the city had been vigilant about diversifying its stock.
Still, he said, he and many of the officials in the project are pained to condemn even a single tree.
"To be out in some neighborhood where you find an infestation in an American elm that's survived everything else, and then that thing gets it," he said, "it's heartbreaking."

HEADLINE: Panel's Ruling on Royalties Is Setback for Web Radio Services 

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
The fledgling Internet radio industry was handed a setback yesterday as a government arbitration panel said online radio stations should pay recording companies nearly 10 times what the Webcasters had proposed for the songs they play.
 The panel's long-awaited recommendation was considerably less than the rate the recording industry had suggested. But several Webcasters said that if the proposal passed the next hurdle -- approval by the United States Copyright Office, which set up the panel -- it might mean an end to free radio on the Internet. 
 "Over a million people play our free service every month," said Dennis Mudd, chief executive of Musicmatch, "and it's going to be impossible to even come close to breaking even with these new rates. Radio on the Web should be able to serve the same function that radio over terrestrial airwaves performs, and it's not going to be able to do that because of these rules."
Under the panel's proposal, commercial Webcasters would pay royalties of 0.14 cent per listener per song. Internet transmissions of regular AM or FM radio broadcasts would cost 0.07 cent per song. Rates would be lower for noncommercial broadcasters, at 0.02 cent for radio rebroadcasts and 0.05 cent for Internet-only programming.
The rates would be effective retroactively, to 1998. The rules also require Internet radio stations to count their users and report their geographic locations. Some Webcasters say fulfilling that requirement would violate their privacy policies.
Analysts said the ruling would help dispel the uncertainty that has hovered over the Internet radio business since a 1998 federal law mandated that Webcasters -- unlike conventional radio stations -- pay royalty fees for the songs they broadcast.
"At least this will allow them to create business models," said Aram Sinnreich, a senior analyst at Jupiter Media Metrix, an Internet market research firm. "The question that remains, though, is: How many online broadcasters are going to be able to develop business models that can handle this kind of structure?"
Internet radio, which seemed to provide the proverbial level playing field because no one had to own a broadcasting tower or be part of a media conglomerate to compete effectively, has proved more difficult than it initially seemed. Advertisers have been hard to come by, and bandwidth costs have remained fairly high. Industry executives said yesterday that the new rules would hasten the fallout and consolidation already under way among Webcasters.
Still, music industry representatives have argued that Internet entrepreneurs need to find a way to make a profit while fairly compensating artists and record labels for the use of their work. Several Webcasters, including Musicmatch and RealNetworks, offer successful subscription-based radio services, for instance.
"Artists and labels, who have supported these new businesses from the start with their music, are one step closer to getting paid," said Hilary B. Rosen, the president of the Recording Industry Association of America, which represents the major labels.
Jonathan Potter, executive director of the Digital Media Association, said the recommendations would probably lead to more interactive offerings, which allow a user to select a list of songs to be played, because the panel rejected the recording industry's request to impose a premium on such services.
Representatives from both sides can continue to press the Copyright Office for proposal changes for 60 days. Eric E. Van Loon, a member of the three-person arbitration panel, said that the panel had received more than 14,000 pages of testimony from more than 50 witnesses.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
A bull market and a boom in 401(k)'s must mean fat pensions? Think again.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and of a new journal of social health, Indicators. Both publications are based in Armonk, N.Y. He is an adjunct professor of humanities at Cooper Union. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
IT was the great bull market of the century. It began in 1982 and sent the Dow Jones industrial average up some tenfold. So how many households were able to build their nest eggs to a level of wealth they could once only dream about?
 To listen to some advocates of "defined contribution" retirement plans, like 401(k)'s, just about anyone could have done it. These plans allowed workers to escape from stodgy old-fashioned fixed-benefit plans, save what they could and manage their own money by buying mutual funds or even individual stocks. Meanwhile, their employers typically matched or even exceeded their contributions. And Washington conferred the same tax deductions on these plans as on the old defined-benefit plans. 
 But here are the stunning facts. Two-thirds of American households have not increased their retirement wealth from pensions at all since 1983 (compared with households led by people of comparable ages in that year) or have experienced a drop in the value of their pensions. Prof. Edward N. Wolff, the New York University economist, calculated the value of both defined-contribution and defined-benefit plans, based on data from the Federal Reserve and the Internal Revenue Service.
It turns out that in 1998, 65 percent of all American households headed by a person between 47 and 64 had either the same pension wealth, adjusted for inflation, than households headed by people in that age group did 15 years earlier, or even less. For the household right in the middle of the pack -- the median -- retirement wealth fell 13 percent from 1983 to 1998. The figures include neither the market boom of 1999 and 2000 nor the bust of 2001.
What disguised the facts before was that overall gains in these retirement accounts were large. The problem is that these gains went disproportionately to the wealthy. For example, according to Professor Wolff's calculations, the households that had more pension wealth than 80 percent of all others -- those in the 80th percentile -- increased their retirement wealth by 19 percent. That was a respectable amount, but hardly outstanding, given the booming stock market. The big gains went to the really rich. Those in the 95th percentile experienced a rise in pension wealth of 176 percent in 15 years -- a nearly threefold increase. 
So what is going on here? Defined-contribution plans, like 401(k)'s, are supposed to give employees of all incomes an opportunity to earn better returns. Meantime, as William Wolman and Anne Colamosca point out in their book "The Great 401(k) Hoax," available this spring from Perseus Publishing, corporations no longer have those pesky long-term liabilities to employees to worry about. But the investment risk is all on the worker. Defined-contribution plans have replaced defined-benefit plans in company after company across the nation, Mr. Wolman and Ms. Colamosca note. Professor Wolff's figures reinforce the point.
The great promise does not seem to have worked. Even when adding up the current value of Social Security benefits, pension wealth and a household's net worth -- the value of a house and other major assets, minus all debt -- Professor Wolff finds that wealth at retirement is down a remarkable 17 percent for the typical household headed by someone 47 to 64. The figures for those over 65 are more positive, but not by much.
Why haven't defined-contribution plans provided more retirement security in this era of soaring stock prices? One problem is that people often manage their investments poorly. Enron employees were urged to place most of their eggs in one basket: Enron stock. But when Enron collapsed late last year, the retirement savings of many were wiped out.
Some workers also take too little risk. This experience should serve as a warning to those who advocate the privatization of Social Security, a move that would let individuals manage a portion of the program for themselves. 
But there are more important factors. The first is that wages grew slowly or fell for many people over these years, and pension programs are usually based on wages. Even the value of Social Security fell in these years as a result of poor earnings growth for so many workers. Also, some companies abandoned pensions altogether, and many workers lost pension assets when they lost their jobs.
A second factor is that some defined-contribution plans are more generous for those nearer the top of the income spectrum. For example, employers may contribute a greater proportion of a high-level worker's income to the pension plan.
A third factor may be obvious, but it is not widely understood. Because these contributions are usually based on a percentage of income, they are regressive by design. The more you make, the bigger the company contribution, even when the proportion matched is the same. The large early investments can compound rapidly over time.
Finally, defined-contribution plans require more voluntary savings on the part of workers. The point is to induce workers to save more. But the philosophy founders on the simple facts. It is far easier to save when you are making a lot of money than when you are making a little. The great advantage of Social Security as a retirement system is that its benefits tend to equalize retirement incomes. But the defined-contribution plans are adding to inequalities.
The upshot is that many Americans will have less income as a proportion of their current earnings when they retire. In an expansion of his research, published by the Economic Policy Institute in Washington, Professor Wolff calculates that only 57 percent of households will be able to replace half or more of their current earnings level during retirement. In 1989, the percentage was 70 percent. Only one in four households will be able to produce $1,000 in retirement income each month, even when including Social Security benefits.
When average wages failed to grow in the 1980's and the first half of the 1990's, one response was always that workers were compensating for the poor performance because they now owned a piece of a rising stock market being propelled by higher corporate profits. It is still widely claimed that the movement toward defined-contribution plans helps that happen for typical workers. But the benefits of these plans are related to earnings, and now the hard empirical facts support early fears.
Washington gives corporations big tax breaks for defined-contribution plans. But despite a soaring stock market, which will almost surely not be repeated any time soon, not even those in the 80th percentile increased their retirement wealth substantially, and most American households fell behind. The Americans who have benefited most are the rich.

Percentages are based on figures adjusted for inflation (Sources: Edward N. Wolff, New York University; Federal Reserve; Internal Revenue Service)
