HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: PUBLIC OPINION; 
Worries About Pensions Show a Rise

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 

 BODY:
Sharply growing public interest in the collapse of the Enron Corporation has spurred widespread fear about retirement accounts but has not increased hostility to business generally or generated support for greater regulation, according to a national poll released today by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.
 Thirty-three percent said the biggest lesson to be drawn from the collapse of Enron was "that retirement accounts are not as safe as many think they are," and 25 percent said that was the second-biggest lesson. Among other responses on the lessons of Enron, 20 percent said corporate executives were too focused on profits, 19 percent said corporations had too much influence in Washington and 17 percent said business was not regulated enough. 
The people who were most worried about retirement accounts were those on the verge of using them, respondents between ages 50 and 64. Forty-two percent of that group said the Enron case worried them, compared with 26 percent of those 65 and older.
But some general views of business held steady with past measures. Fifty percent said government regulation of business was necessary, while 41 percent said regulation did more harm than good -- a percentage statistically indistinguishable from the 48 percent who said regulation was necessary and the 41 percent who said it was harmful in an August 1999 survey. Both polls had margins of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
And while 77 percent said a few large corporations "hold too much power," the same share said so in 1999. But there was a small decline, to 40 percent from 45 percent in 1999, among those who said business struck a proper balance between profits and the public interest.
The Feb. 12-18 survey of 1,199 adults found 28 percent saying they were following the Enron story very closely, while another 28 percent said they were following it fairly closely. In a mid-January survey by the Pew Research Center, 19 percent said "very closely" and 23 percent said "fairly closely." 
Those percentages are unusually high for a business story. In the last decade it was topped only by the 35 percent who said they followed a story of General Motors layoffs in January 1992. The 28 percent figure was matched by those who said they followed very closely the June 2000 federal court decision ordering the breakup of the Microsoft Corporation.

HEADLINE: IMPASSE IN ISREAL: REACTIONS; 
United Nations Leader Urges International Action on Mideast

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 21 

 BODY:
Warning that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict was "sliding toward a full-fledged war," Secretary General Kofi Annan said today that it had become essential for an active international effort and "new thinking" to get the sides talking again.
 The notion of any outside involvement in the conflict, other than American mediation, has been strongly resisted by Israel and the United States, as it was by their representatives today after Mr. Annan spoke. 
 But in an address to a special session of the Security Council, Mr. Annan sounded an unusually urgent alarm about the disintegration of the situation in the Middle East, declaring, "Truly, we are nearing the edge of the abyss." 
He said that existing American proposals -- known as the Mitchell and Tenet plans -- to bring the Israelis and Palestinians back to negotiating table "can certainly not be said to have succeeded."
"I truly believe that it is imperative for the Security Council and the wider international community to work in a concerted manner with the parties," Mr. Annan said. 
More pointedly, he said that the Israeli insistence on an end to Palestinian violence as a precondition for negotiations -- a position supported by Washington and one that Mr. Sharon repeated in an address today -- was no longer viable. 
"A reduction in the violence is the most immediate priority," Mr. Annan said. "But I have become more and more convinced that trying to resolve the security problem on its own cannot work." 
Mr. Annan spoke shortly after Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon delivered his address in Jerusalem, in which he also announced plans for a buffer zone between Israeli and Palestinian territories and demanded a full disarmament of the Palestinians. 
The secretary general argued that security had to have a context. "It has to be addressed alongside key political issues," he said, "particularly the question of land, and the economic and social issues, including the increasingly critical desperate conditions of the Palestinians."
The "key problems," Mr. Annan said, again diverging widely from the Israelis, were the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territory, security, "the need to end violence, including terrorism," and economic deprivation and suffering. "These are inter-linked problems, encompassing the political, security and economic domains," he said.
Mr. Annan's speech represented a relatively aggressive foray into Middle Eastern diplomacy for the secretary general, and it combined a number of themes he has been pressing in recent weeks. 
The Security Council meeting is scheduled to continue next week, when the Arab states are expected to propose a resolution, using Mr. Annan's speech as support, for a call for the council to send a mission to the region and also for some monitoring mechanism for any agreement on continuing negotiations.
There was little doubt that the United States would resist any such resolution, as it usually has in the past. John Negroponte, the American representative, said he would withhold comment until he saw the proposals. But he made clear a resistance to international involvement, noting that the United States was of the view that it was preferable for the two parties to settle their differences. 
But European representatives indicated they thought the council should take a position, even over American resistance. "Violence is being used as part of a deliberate policy on both sides, and it is pointless," said the British representative, Sir Jeremy Greenstock. "I hope the council will collectively be saying that." 
In the corridor outside the Security Council chamber, the Israeli representative to the Security Council, Aaron Jacob, spoke dismissively of the idea of outside intervention. "One side has resorted to violence and terror, others come and say, 'Let's invite a third party,' " he said.
The Palestinian representative, Marwan Jilani, said that was a position "shared only by Israel and one other member of the international community," meaning the United States.

HEADLINE: Not Wanted: '02 Graduates Seeking Jobs 

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
When the millions of students who are set to graduate from college this spring started out in the late 1990's, the stock market was on a bull run and the dot-com frenzy was in full swing. At colleges across the country, career-services offices fashioned makeshift interview booths to accommodate the companies on a hiring binge.
 Fresh-faced 22-year-olds commanded signing bonuses of $10,000 or more. People with bachelor's degrees in engineering or computer science often had a dozen job offers, some with six-figure salaries. Liberal arts majors found plenty of opportunities, too, working for Internet companies and consulting and financial firms. 
 Those heady times are gone. With the economy still struggling, layoffs increasing and corporate America wary about the near future, students who complete their undergraduate degrees this year face the worst job market for college graduates in nearly a decade. 
"It's not like people even want a job in their major -- they just want a job," said Sakara A. Bey, a senior at Tufts University who is majoring in engineering psychology. "It's become a prize possession."
Amid a severe retrenchment in hiring that began last summer, said Marilyn F. Mackes, executive director of the National Association of Colleges and Employers, "the job candidate is no longer calling the shots." The association calls this year's job market the tightest for graduating seniors since 1994, when companies began hiring again -- slowly -- after the 1990-91 recession.
Ms. Mackes estimated that there would be 20 to 25 percent fewer jobs for students who graduate with bachelor's degrees this year, typically in May or June. That does not surprise Nathan I. Perlis, 21, a biology and Judaic studies major at Tufts, who has long planned to go to medical school. "Out of 20 friends, I have one who actually has a job," he said in December, about two months after the peak recruiting season at most colleges. "A lot aren't even looking because they know it's so hard."
At Boston University, barely 50 companies came to a two-day recruiting fair in October, compared with about 100 the previous year, said Richard A. Leger, director of career services at the university. Many companies had just instituted hiring freezes, he said, and even those that showed up were, in many cases, there simply to maintain a presence on the campus. Among the no-shows at a B.U. off-campus job fair last month in New York, he said, were Ogilvy & Mather, the advertising agency, and Zenith Media, a communications company that is part of the Zenith Optimedia Group.
Recruiters may not return soon. In January, the unemployment rate was 5.6 percent, the highest level since April 1995. The unemployment rate for college graduates who are 25 or older nudged down to 2.9 percent last month from 3.1 percent in December -- the highest level since April 1993, according to the Bureau for Labor Statistics. Economists expect jobless figures to continue to rise, although at a slower pace. Layoffs have been pronounced in the financial services, consulting, manufacturing and technology industries. Particularly hard hit has been the travel industry.
"You send companies e-mail messages and they say 'We're on hold,' or you never hear back," Mr. Leger said. "It's like we're the ones having to do the recruiting."
Michael J. Walsh Jr., B.U.'s director of career services for engineering students, said 34 companies pledged to come to a job fair for engineering majors earlier this month, compared with 59 companies last year. Seven of the companies agreed to come after Mr. Walsh waived the $250 participation fee for them.
Worse, only 12 companies, mostly military contractors, have signed up to recruit B.U. engineering students this spring, compared with 20 last year. While Mr. Walsh would not name companies that had dropped out, he said they included major computer and software concerns and struggling or defunct dot-coms.
The drought has spurred him to cold-call prospective employers and scan local help-wanted ads for leads.
But such efforts may not bear fruit for another six months. Philip D. Gardner, director of the Collegiate Employment Research Institute at Michigan State University, said that most of the 290 companies surveyed by the institute in October were likely to resume hiring in the summer when students are not on campus and are hard to track down.
FleetBoston Financial, the large bank based in Boston, said it planned to hire only about half as many new graduates this year, mostly as financial analysts and loan officers, according to James E. Mahoney, a spokesman. He noted, though, that last year was a record hiring year for the company. EMC, a data storage company based in Hopkinton, Mass., about 35 miles west of Boston, plans to reduce its hiring of fresh graduates this year by half, to several hundred people, said Greg Eden, a spokesman.
Not all companies are closing their doors. Gillette, which has headquarters in Boston and makes a range of personal goods besides razors, will hire 13 new graduates to start in late spring, one fewer than last year, said Stephen K. Brayton, a spokesman.
The sudden shift in the job market has led students to plan for futures they never envisioned. That may not necessarily be bad, though.
"I'm looking at Teach for America and FEMA," said Adam D. Babin, 21, an advertising major at B.U., referring to a high-school teaching program and the government's emergency-management agency. "Everyone's either going to do something unrelated to their major or move back home."
Around a dozen undergraduates interviewed at Tufts and Boston University late in December said the dwindling number of jobs was also prompting many of them to apply to graduate school in their disciplines or to law school. The Law School Admission Council, an industry organization in Newtown, Pa., said that as of Jan. 26, applications to law school from people of all ages were up 25.2 percent over last year.
But more schooling is not an attractive option to Pavan Pant, 21, an engineering and computer systems major at B.U. "A lot of kids simply don't want to go to grad school after four years in college," Mr. Pant said. He is hoping that his internship last summer at I.B.M. will lead to a job at the company but he does not yet have an offer.
Compounding their troubles, many seniors will have sizable student loans to pay off after graduation. David S. Stein, a clinical psychology major at Tufts with $20,000 in student loans, said he hoped to land an $18,000-a-year job at a home for troubled children and families in Needham, Mass. But if he gets that job, he said, he will have to live with his parents, ask them for money and take out more loans.
Other students said they were scrambling for part-time internships that might become full-time paying jobs. Jean M. Papalia, director of career services at Tufts, said approximately 100 students participated over winter break in one- to two-week internships arranged by the university at local companies and organizations, up from 70 the previous year. The number of companies recruiting at Tufts last fall was much lower, she said, though she could not provide details.
Mr. Gardner of the Collegiate Employment Research Institute said that many engineering and computer science majors would probably receive at least one offer. But starting salaries will not be as stratospheric as in years past. The average high-end salary for computer science majors has fallen from around $65,000 to the low $50,000's, Mr. Gardner said. 
Liberal arts majors are finding the job market particularly tough. 
Amanda K. Bronesky, 21, a senior majoring in international relations and Spanish at Tufts, said she was crushed when EF Education, a language school company based in Cambridge, Mass., dropped out of a Tufts career fair in October. But Ms. Bronesky said she hoped to land an internship, paid or unpaid, at Explorica, an educational exchange company in Boston. Her backup plan is to live with her parents in Denver, and work as a waitress.
"Before the economy got bad, jobs were just given to students," said Ms. Bey, the Tufts senior, whose plan is to apply to graduate programs in engineering psychology. "Now the companies are saying, 'Come and find me.' "

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ON PATROL; 
International Troops Help Bring Order to Kabul's Streets

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS

DATELINE: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 19 

 BODY:
For the past six weeks, Maj. David Buckingham of Manns Choice in southwestern Pennsylvania has been wearing the dark red beret of a British paratrooper, living by kerosene lamp in a wrecked Kabul high school and trying, as best he and the British troops can, to bring security to a quarter of a million people in a war-shattered district in the western part of this capital.
 Not many months ago, Major Buckingham was serving in the United States with the 101st Airborne Division. But now he spends his days in Kabul on an exchange with the Parachute Regiment, one of the British Army's most decorated combat units, as part of the force supporting the new post-Taliban government. 
 For Major Buckingham, the assignment must seem a paradox. While he oversees patrols in the shattered streets of Kabul and works alongside the local police to curb the lawlessness that surged in the wake of the Taliban's collapse, his old unit, the 101st Airborne, is doing what soldiers like to do most -- soldiering against the enemy.
After all, the 101st Airborne boasts a rich history in World War II, when it was a battlefield partner with the Parachute Regiment in the drive to Berlin. Known as the Screaming Eagles, the American division has been operating out of Kandahar airport, the main American base in Afghanistan, conducting helicopter missions against Taliban and Al Qaeda targets alongside American Special Forces teams.
While his American colleagues may have the more glorified combat role, Major Buckingham, a 36-year-old engineering graduate of Penn State University, considers himself lucky because the exchange with the Parachute Regiment is a choice midcareer assignment. 
Instead of working a desk job in Washington, which would have followed his stint with the 101st Airborne, he is part of the 4,500-troop International Stabilization Assistance Force, or ISAF, representing 15 nations and operating under a United Nations mandate.
"I'd have been somewhere in the basement of the Pentagon -- doing important stuff for sure, but not as much fun as being in the field like this, as any infantryman will tell you," he said as another 20-degree night settled over the paratroopers' bare-brick, unlighted and mostly unheated bivouac at a high school in the Karte Seh district of Kabul.
What the force has been doing has consisted partly of showing the flag, sending troops on patrol on foot and in jeeps. The idea is to be seen by Kabul's one million residents and -- the soldiers hope -- to enlist help against the armed gangs who have exploited a power vacuum that followed the flight of the Taliban.
In this, just about everybody here agrees, the soldiers have made an important impact, sharply reducing crimes like murder, house-breaking and car hijacking in just weeks.
The force has also begun to help rebuilding roads, schools and clinics, restoring power lines and getting the garbage trucks back in service. Perhaps most important, the soldiers have reopened Kabul airport, assigning teams to remove unexploded bombs, shells and mines; blow up the wrecks of fighter planes left by Soviet occupation forces; and fill craters on the runways and taxiways. 
Only three months after it was silenced by American bombing, the airport has heavy transport aircraft landing around the clock, including, for the first time this week, a Boeing 747 jumbo jet, chartered by the American charity CARE.
The difference is mirrored everywhere in the city. "The improving security situation has underpinned an improving commercial confidence," the commander of the international force, Maj. Gen. John McColl of Britain, said at a recent news conference.
"The first day I came to Kabul in mid-December, the streets were quiet, there were few cars and the level of economic activity seemed low," General McColl said. "Six weeks later, Kabul is teeming. The markets are full of goods, the streets are full of people and there seem to be more cars on the road every day." 
The change is not confined to Kabul; in itself, the end of the Taliban's repressive rule allowed much in the normal life of the country to resume. But Kabul is the only city to have the steadying influence of the international force, and thus has improved to an extent unmatched elsewhere, a situation that is increasingly cited in the debate about the next step.
The United States has resisted any expansion of the force beyond Kabul, saying Afghanistan's future security lies in building a new national army, which Washington has pledged to help finance and train. The American view reflects a determination not to be drawn too deeply into Afghanistan's internal affairs, and thus risk making a much larger force -- which many Afghans favor -- hostage to a new political breakdown or, worse, to another civil war.
The operations of the stabilization force are completely separate from those of the 4,000 American troops currently based in Afghanistan as part of the hunt for remnants of the Taliban and Al Qaeda.
But senior officials from other nations who deal closely with Afghanistan say expanding the multinational force may be the only way to check the power of the feuding warlords, who control most of the country, and to give the fledgling government a chance to extend its authority.
The case has been made most insistently by Hamid Karzai, chairman of the interim administration, who has continued to press for a wider mandate for the security force despite the rebuff he received two weeks ago when he made the argument in Washington and London.
Patroling the streets with Major Buckingham's troops, the force's popularity seemed clear. As dusk settled, a dozen British soldiers fanned out to either side of the street as they made an hourlong tour through a blasted landscape of crumbling buildings, where whole neighborhoods have been virtually obliterated by artillery battles between the rival Afghan forces who fought for Kabul in the years before the Taliban took the city in 1996. Pedestrians and bicyclists hurrying home before the pitch-darkness of a night without electricity paused to greet the soldiers.
Muhammad Anif, a 30-year-old pharmacist, waved breezily in response to a greeting of "Salaam!" from Sgt. Martin Seville, section leader in charge of the patrol.
"We feel so happy when we see the ISAF soldiers," Mr. Anif said, "because we feel that we are free."
Nearby, a group of young men who grew up in Pakistan after their families fled the Soviet invasion of 1979 agreed.
"We hope they stay for a long, long time and expand to every part of the country," said Naib Khan, a 19-year-old who returned to Kabul last month to apply for entry to Kabul University. "Please tell America, Afghanistan loves the ISAF!"

(Photographs by Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Harvard to Require Top Score To Earn Advanced Placement 

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
In the latest blow to the increasingly popular program of advanced placement courses, Harvard University will no longer award college credit to freshmen who score lower than five -- the top score -- on examinations in the subjects.
 Most colleges give credit for a score of three, four, or five on the advanced placement tests, administered by the College Board, but many of the most selective schools are discussing limits on credits for the scores. 
 In recent years, many high school students have used the examinations to impress admissions officers, avoid introductory courses and even enter college as sophomores.
Last year 820,880 high school students took 1.38 million advanced placement exams -- more than twice as many students as took them a decade ago. Last year, 13 percent of the students earned fives, 20 percentfours, and 27 percent threes. 
Harvard's decision, first reported yesterday in The Boston Globe, was based in part on a finding that in second-year chemistry and economics, students with scores of four, and no previous Harvard courses, did far worse than those who scored five, and worse than the class as a whole.
Harvard is apparently the first school to require scores of five for advanced standing, or sophomore status. Starting with the class of 2007, only those with at least four fives will be eligible.
But some other elite schools, including the California Institute of Technology, give no advanced placement credit, and at others some departments give no credit or credit only for a score of five.
Last week, a study by the National Research Council criticized advanced placement math and science classes as cramming in too much material at the expense of understanding and as failing to keep up with developments in the subjects.
While the trend nationwide is for public high schools to offer more advanced placement classes, some selective private schools are moving the other way. In New York, the Fieldston School, which recently dropped the courses, found that this year's seniors, the first with no advanced placement classes on their transcripts, did just as well in college admissions as previous classes.
The proliferation of the credits presents colleges with a practical problem and an intellectual one. 
As a practical matter, at most selective schools, a significant part of the class may be eligible to place out of the freshman year. "Now that the Ivy League schools get so many students with six, seven or eight AP's," said Lee Jones, the College Board vice president responsible for the program, "there's a real issue about how many credits they're going to give to how many students." 
As an academic issue, some schools are concerned that many students with good advanced placement scores may nonetheless be unprepared for high-level college work.
Ronald M. Latanision, a material science professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said: "About two years ago, we decided we would no longer give AP credit in chemistry, because the previous year, a third of the freshman class placed out of chemistry, but when they went into upper-level courses, they were clearly not prepared. We don't discourage kids from taking AP courses, but we're not going to give credit."
Other departments are concerned, but there is no across-the-board view yet, Dr. Latanision said. "There's definitely concern about biology and writing, and it wouldn't surprise me if down the line we made an institutionwide decision not to give credit."
Boston University is reviewing its policies after finding that in 2000 the number of entering students with advanced placement credits had doubled from the number in 1995.
Mr. Jones, of the College Board, said he was convinced that those who scored well on the tests were ready for advanced courses.
"Our data shows that students with a three or above do just fine in the next-level courses, and that, at most institutions, those with four virtually always outperform students who took the introductory course at the college," he said.
But the professors who teach them are not so sure. 
"Students who do well on the AP exams have learned to answer the kind of questions that appear on the AP exams," said Daniel L. Goroff, a Harvard math professor, "but they may or may not be prepared to think on their own and grapple with conceptual questions at a college level.
"There was work done here some years ago on the cognitive development of students in the college years, finding that they come to college thinking there is a right answer that the authorities have to tell them, and that they have to memorize. We want them to learn to think on their own." 

CORRECTION-DATE: February 28, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Friday about Harvard University's decision to give college credit for advanced placement courses only when students score a five -- the top score -- on examinations, rather than a three, four or five, misstated the newspaper that first reported on the decision. It was The Harvard Crimson, not The Boston Globe.

HEADLINE: Proposals For Memorials Move Close To Approval 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Two proposals for temporary memorials to the victims of the World Trade Center attack, one using huge beams of light and the other a damaged bronze sculpture, are moving closer to approval, city and state officials said yesterday. 
 The remains of the spherical bronze sculpture by Fritz Koenig that stood in the World Trade Center plaza would serve as the centerpiece of a temporary memorial being considered by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the group overseeing the rebuilding of downtown. The memorial would remain in place for as long as two years, while a permanent memorial was conceived and installed at the site of the fallen towers. 
 City Hall officials also said yesterday that a proposal to erect a temporary memorial project known as the Towers of Light was still under consideration and could be approved as soon as today. The memorial, which would project two huge beams of light into the night sky from a location near the former site of the trade center, is likely to last several weeks to a few months, the officials said. 
The Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has identified four potential sites for its temporary memorial, Alexander Garvin, the group's vice president for planning, design and development, said yesterday at a meeting of the corporation's board.
The sites and the proposal to include the sculpture in a temporary memorial will be presented Thursday to the Families Advisory Council, a group of victims' family members who have been selected to advise the development corporation. 
Louis R. Tomson, the president and executive director of the corporation, said that the plans might change based on the feedback from the advisory panel. 
The sculpture, which was damaged in the collapse of the towers, is stored at Kennedy Airport.
Each of the four sites is near ground zero. One is along Church Street, near the public viewing platform; one is near the intersection of Liberty and West Streets, near the family viewing platform; another is in a lot at West and Murray Streets, in Battery Park City, the site of a temporary shelter for rescue workers and equipment; and the fourth is in a small triangular plot of land at Murray Street and North End Avenue, also in Battery Park City.
The large lot being used by rescue workers, which is cater-corner to the northwestern edge of the disaster site, has also been discussed as a location for the Towers of Light project.
Talk about the temporary memorial has focused on March 11 as a target date to open the project, six months after the terrorist attacks. But Daniel Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, who has been working with the development corporation, said yesterday, "I don't think it's appropriate to put too much emphasis on March 11."
Also yesterday, the development corporation proposed a $10 million grant program to train or retrain workers at small businesses south of 14th Street, and released the details of its proposed $200 million grant program to retain and attract residents to Lower Manhattan.
Companies affected by the attack will receive priority for the grants, according to an outline of the program.
The corporation gave preliminary approval to the program of grants for housing assistance to residents below Canal Street. Under the proposal, which will go through two public comment periods and which must be approved by the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, residents closest to the site would receive 30 percent of their monthly rent or mortgage and maintenance payments, up to $12,000 over two years. 
That benefit would be available for people living anywhere below Chambers Street and west of Broadway, including all of Battery Park City. For others living below Canal or Rutgers Streets the benefit would be the same but limited to $6,000 over two years. 
All of the resident grants require a commitment to stay in Lower Manhattan for at least two years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The damaged sculpture by Fritz Koenig, from the World Trade Center. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Officials Say Recession Has Most Likely Ended
Economists and government officials said that the recession had almost certainly come to an end but that it remained unclear how strong and sustained the recovery would be.
 White House officials said the economy was growing at a modest but accelerating rate and credited the tax cut President Bush signed into law last year for minimizing the depth and duration of the downturn. Page A23. 

Computer Associates Shares Slide
Shares of Computer Associates International skidded for a second day on reports that federal regulators and prosecutors are investigating its accounting practices. The company also tapped a line of credit that comes due in 2003 to repay shorter-term bank lines of credit and prevent a shortage of cash. Shares of Computer Associates dropped $2.01, or 9.6 percent, to $18.90. In the last month, the shares have lost half their value. C2.

Aetna Reports a Loss for Last Year
Aetna lost money last year, the company said, but added that it was "on track" to return to an operating profit in 2002. The company declined to respond to analysts' questions about how soon its turnaround effort would deliver a profit or how much it might be. C8.

Nasdaq Tumbles to Four-Month Low
Stocks fell yesterday, driving the Nasdaq composite index to its lowest level in almost four months. The Nasdaq tumbled 59.33 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,716.24, its lowest close since Oct. 31. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 106.49 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,834.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 17.03 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,080.95. C8.

Congress Seeks Data on ImClone
A Congressional committee asked seven pharmaceutical companies to turn over records pertaining to negotiations they had with ImClone Systems about its cancer drug, Erbitux. Separately, ImClone's chief executive, Samuel D. Waksal, returned $486,000 to the company that he gained from stock sales that might have violated a rule on trading by insiders, the company said. C2.

Talks in Terror Insurance Venture
Three of Europe's biggest insurance companies -- Allianz of Germany, Swiss Re and Zurich Financial Services -- are in talks to set up a Luxembourg-based joint venture that would provide partial insurance coverage for terror-attack risks in Europe, perhaps with government backing. C12.

AT&T Moves President Closer to Top
By all appearances, David W. Dorman, left, would have to do something shocking to avoid becoming AT&T's next chief executive. That became clear as AT&T named Mr. Dorman, the company's president, to the board. It has been clear for at least a year that Mr. Dorman was the favorite to become the chief executive once the company sold or spun off its cable television operation. C2.

Big 5 Under Scrutiny Overseas
The credibility of the Big Five accounting firms is coming under attack overseas in the wake of Enron. Europe, meanwhile, is stepping up calls for the United States to recognize international accounting standards. In Australia, Enron's fall is painfully familiar, given the collapse of the HIH Group, the country's No. 2 insurer. World Business, Section W.

Official Says Greenspan Is Staying
Alan Greenspan has no intention of stepping down soon as the Federal Reserve chairman, Lawrence B. Lindsey, the White House's chief economic policy adviser, said. C8.

Inquiry Into Smirnoff Promotion
Advertising, labels and packaging for the popular new Smirnoff Ice malt alcohol beverage are being referred for scrutiny to two federal agencies after a competitor complained that those marketing materials mislead consumers into thinking it contains Smirnoff vodka. C4.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
JUDGE CERTIFIES CLASS-ACTION STATUS IN SUIT AGAINST RAND

BYLINE:  By Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

 BODY:
 A federal judge has certified a 1996 suit brought by women employees at the RAND Corporation, the research group, as a class action. The decision, made earlier this week by Judge Richard W. Roberts of United States District Court in Washington, clears the way for a federal lawsuit. 
The class consists of about 250 women who worked at RAND as long ago as 1994 and as recently as 1998, said Michael D. Lieder, a partner at Sprenger & Lang in Washington, which is representing plaintiffs. The plaintiffs contend that the company discriminated against them, paying them thousands of dollars less than it paid men, he said. A lawyer for RAND played down the significance of the ruling. "We view this simply as a step in the process," said Karen J. Kubin, whose law firm, Cooley Godward, is representing RAND. "If the case does get to trial, we're confident that RAND will prevail." Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

HEADLINE: As Endowments Slip at Colleges, Big Tuition Increases Fill the Void 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

DATELINE: FORT WORTH 

 BODY:
With their endowments and contributions continuing to shrink in a sagging economy, the nation's private colleges and universities are raising tuition for the next academic year more sharply than in recent years, sometimes significantly so.
 The sometimes striking tuition increases, just now being reported, come after seven years of moderate tuition increases at generally twice the rate of inflation. Colleges are also scaling back on construction and hiring, after a span of flush years when the institutions added buildings, increased faculty sizes and created academic programs. 
 "Tuition is definitely going to go up at a disproportionately higher rate than we have seen in recent years," said Larry Goldstein, a senior fellow at the National Association of College and University Business Officers. "Tuition rates have been remarkably stable because of the good economy. Now the economic pressure has increased, and they cannot keep tuition growth at this level anymore." 
Texas Christian University, a private campus in the middle of this onetime cattle town, has decided to raise tuition by 8.7 percent, to $16,300, for the next academic year, the biggest increase in the university's 129-year history.
Barnard College, in New York City, reported a tuition increase of 5 percent, to $24,090. Last year's increase was 4 percent. At Cornell University, tuition will be $27,270, a 5 percent increase that is the largest in seven years. 
The tuition at George Washington University will rise by 4.9 percent, the largest increase in four years and one that ends a 13-year trend of declining tuition increases. The tuition increase at Dartmouth College will be 4.5 percent, breaking the institution's longtime policy of keeping increases under 3.5 percent. At Emory University, tuition will increase by 5.4 percent; last year it grew 4 percent. At each of these three institutions, tuition will be around $27,000 a year; room and board can add $8,000.
This fall, Baylor University in Waco, Tex., will charge freshmen $15,700, 33 percent more than it charged current first-year students. The chief financial officer, David Brooks, said the increase was largely a result of the university's ambition to move into a rarefied group of colleges by adding buildings and faculty members. The endowment has also declined.
College endowments lost 3.6 percent on investments in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2001, the biggest drop since 1984, according to a survey of 610 public and private colleges conducted by the National Association of College and University Business Officers. The trend continued from July to December 2001.
"An economic downturn negatively affects every other university revenue source," said David L. Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities. "It affects corporate and foundation giving, earnings from endowments and fund-raising from alumni and friends. Tuition is the one revenue stream over which independent universities have control."
Most colleges spend part -- often about 5 percent -- of their endowments annually. 
The hefty tuition increases at private campuses come as many state legislatures have cut budgets for public universities, causing double-digit tuition increases.
In the private realm, Texas Christian increased tuition because its endowment dropped by 13 percent from its $1 billion peak in March 2000 and alumni contributions decreased by 15 percent in the last quarter of 2001, compared with the same period in 2000, the chancellor, Michael R. Ferrari, said. In the 1990's, the university raised tuition 4 percent to 5 percent annually. 
"It stinks," Sarah Horton, a sophomore, said of the tuition increase. "My parents and I had set aside a chunk of money for my college education, expecting tuition to increase only a little bit every year. Now I would have to scrape around a little more than I would like to."
Ms. Horton, who had planned to travel in Thailand this summer, said she had now decided to get a "lucrative job" here at home to save for the next academic year.
Larger tuition increases are not the universities' only response to the economic downturn. Cornell has imposed a hiring freeze on nonacademic staff until at least June. Emory has asked its academic deans to eliminate centers and institutes that are not performing well. Duke University has frozen the budget of every administrative unit. Harvard plans to close the Washington office of its Kennedy School of Government. 
While these are natural responses to difficult economic times, they seem particularly jarring to college administrators after years of giddy expansion, when many endowments doubled and even tripled. 
With the increased income pouring in from the stock market, Bowdoin College built a theater, a student union building, a coastal studies center and three dorms. Emory cut its student-faculty ratio to nine to one this year from 20 to one in 1991, the provost, Howard Hunter, said. Princeton University replaced some student loans with scholarships.
The endowment losses have been sizable. Boston University's endowment, once $930 million, declined by $256 million from 2000 to 2001. Emory, which once had an almost $5 billion endowment, now has $4.4 billion. Harvard, the wealthiest of American colleges, saw its endowment drop $900 million to $18.3 billion within a year. 
The decreases reflect the downturn of the domestic stock market, where more than a third of college and university money is invested.
According to a survey of 450 institutions of higher education by Commonfund Institute, a Connecticut organization that manages more than $27 billion for more than 1,500 nonprofit organizations, last year many universities reduced the percentage of endowments that contributed to the operating budget in an effort to protect their nest eggs. The average percentage, or payout rate, shrank to 4.8 percent last year from 5 percent.
At least one college president decided to buck the trend. "We saved the nest eggs for the rainy days, and now it's raining," said Morton Schapiro, the president of Williams College, who has persuaded his board to increase the payout rate of the college's $1.3 billion endowment. "We need to dig into the endowment now precisely because that's what we've saved the money for."
Alumni and corporate contributions to colleges have also declined. Stanford University, often the front-runner in attracting donations, received $120 million less, or 26 percent, in the 2001 fiscal year compared with 2000.
The sudden change is palpable at Texas Christian, where construction is under way for a student recreation center with a rock-climbing wall, indoor and outdoor pools, and a fully wired technology center. The next project, a new student dining hall, has been postponed indefinitely. 
Some students here argue that their university's fiscal caution is unwarranted. Although Texas Christian's endowment has slipped to $870 million from its $1 billion peak, it was $700 million just four years ago. Why not spend some of the nest egg accumulated during prosperity, the students ask. But university administrators disagree.
"If you spend too much of your endowment, you are eating your seed corn," said Carol Campbell, the vice chancellor of finance at Texas Christian. "Next year, you won't have anything to plant."

HEADLINE: Looking Askance at U.S. Auditors 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER

DATELINE: LONDON, Feb. 21 

 BODY:
For years they have offered the auditing world's answer to the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval: With the stroke of a pen, a Big Five accounting firm can lend instant credibility to the books of a company.
 And credibility means money. Without a Big Five audit, it is more difficult for companies in Western Europe -- and all but impossible for those in the East -- to raise capital from foreign investors. 
 But the credibility of the Big Five is coming under attack. Alarmed by the failure of the Enron Corporation, regulators from Milan to Moscow are giving the work of American auditors new scrutiny, and finding some of it wanting. Fuming investors are accusing auditors, who are supposed to be promoting good corporate governance and transparency, of instead turning a blind eye to mismanagement and corruption. 
Two of the most prominent cases center on accusations that auditors helped paint a veneer of legitimacy on dubious transactions that stripped away billions of dollars in assets from companies -- a practice grown so common in some countries that it has acquired a slang name, tunneling.
In Moscow, a Russian financial oversight panel said this week that it would examine the audits by PricewaterhouseCoopers of Gazprom, the giant natural gas monopoly that minority shareholders contend has been tunneled. Regulators are still investigating the June 2000 collapse of Investicni a Postovni Banka, a large Czech bank, where the role of Ernst & Young as auditor is the subject of an inquiry by Czech regulators.
Ernst & Young said it had cooperated fully with investigators and that "no wrongdoing could be found on our part." The firm noted that a Czech parliamentary committee investigating the matter found that the bank had misled its auditors.
Citing a policy of not discussing pending investigations, PricewaterhouseCoopers declined to comment on the Gazprom matter.
Speaking generally, accounting executives defended the track records of the Big Five (the other three are Deloitte & Touche, KPMG and Arthur Andersen). In many countries where they operate, the executives said, the legal and regulatory framework underpinning responsible financial reporting is either nonexistent or has been put in place only recently.
Local laws often oblige foreign accounting firms to work through a locally owned affiliate rather than allowing them directly to control the office that bears their name, the executives said. And accounting rules in many countries embody standards of transparency and disclosure that are still crude in American terms.
"We can't always paint the picture as we see it," said Richard H. Murray, global head of legal and regulatory affairs for Deloitte & Touche. Often, he said, auditors face a "kind of Hobson's choice" between tolerating clients who do business the opaque local way and having no clients at all. 
Some of the people who rely on audits to make lending decisions do not see it that way. At a recent meeting in London, executives from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development fretted that auditors are not doing enough to ensure that company reports paint a true picture. "Ultimately, auditors should be held accountable," said Noreen Doyle, the group's head of banking.
Lured by the prospect of new markets for their services after the fall of the Soviet Union, most of the Big Five firms opened offices in Moscow, Prague and Warsaw in the mid-1990's, and rushed to train a cadre of accountants in the ways of the West.
But the stampede of client companies seeking Big Five audits overwhelmed the limited supply of trained auditors, and the quality of the work suffered, analysts said. Making matters worse in some countries was the absence of any homegrown competition. In Prague, "without an audit from the Big Five, you have no audit," said Michal Rizek, an analyst with CAIB International Markets.
One result has been relationships between clients and auditors that are "too cozy," said John Rieger, head of corporate affairs for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.
Minority shareholders in Gazprom are trying to shake up the coziness with a vote to dismiss PricewaterhouseCoopers as the company's auditor at the annual meeting in June. They say audits have failed to depict the true state of the company's finances. For example, only after a public outcry last year did PricewaterhouseCoopers disclose information about related-party deals at Gazprom, including the granting of billions of dollars in construction contracts to a company called Stroitransgas, which is owned in part by relatives of Gazprom management.
Gazprom, which controls the world's largest reserves of natural gas, was itself shaken up last year by President Vladimir V. Putin, who installed new management and said that "enormous sums" had been siphoned out of the company.
"Pricewaterhouse did a horrible disservice to shareholders and the government by whitewashing the whole thing," said William F. Browder, whose Russian investment fund, Hermitage Capital Management, has been an investor in Gazprom since 1996. "We want to make an example of them so that no auditor ever feels comfortable doing this again."
When an auditor does sound the alarm, a company's management can often find a rival willing to keep mum. When a 1996 audit by Coopers & Lybrand, now part of PricewaterhouseCoopers, disclosed serious shortcomings in the provisions for bad loans made by Investicni a Postovni Banka, the bank dismissed Coopers and brought in Ernst & Young to perform a new audit, which found the bad-loan provisions to be more than adequate.
Even so, rumors of insufficient reserves persisted, prompting a run on the bank in the spring of 2000 that ultimately forced it into administration. Regulators, forensic accountants and investigators are still trying to find $9.5 billion of assets that were listed on the books of the bank that Ernst & Young certified. 
Ernst & Young's German office has since taken over operations at the Czech office, which had been owned by three local partners.
In Western Europe, regulators are bolstering enforcement activities. Investigators in Britain are examining the role of Arthur Andersen in accounting irregularities discovered last year at SSL International, the maker of Scholl sandals and Durex condoms. Arthur Andersen has said there is no evidence that any of its audits were deficient.
Italian regulators recently ordered PricewaterhouseCoopers to suspend one partner over irregularities in the accounts of a regional banking group, Banca Popolare di Novara. The firm said it would lodge an appeal against the order.
Spanish authorities have fined Deloitte & Touche in connection with the collapse last summer of Gescartera, a Madrid brokerage firm whose inability to account for some 100 million euros in customer funds has led to charges of embezzlement against its owners. A Deloitte spokeswoman said it was contesting the fine.
Most analysts and industry executives say that problem cases are the rare exception and that most Big Five auditors in Europe and elsewhere do their work with an admirable, if unsung, thoroughness and professionalism befitting their reputation. 
So it is all the more alarming, Mr. Browder of Hermitage Capital said, when an auditor does turn out to have dropped the ball -- or worse, to have been a participant with crooked managers -- because "these guys are supposed to be part of the solution, not part of the problem."

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: CONSULTING; 
Keen Rivalry By Consultants Expected After Auditors' Shift

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER

 BODY:
The shift away from consulting by big accounting firms is likely to lead to new and intense competition over clients as independent firms aggressively pursue companies that have bought consulting services from their auditors in the past.
 Those firms could be joined by consulting businesses that are being spun off from two of the Big Five. But the soon-to-be-independent firms face a very poor market, analysts say, in part because accountants' consulting units have been indirectly tainted by the collapse of Enron, whose auditor, Arthur Andersen, also sold the company consulting services. In addition, the consulting industry has been in a slump for more than a year because of the recession, making the businesses even more unattractive. 
 "The economy's terrible, and nobody's buying these services," said Tom Rodenhauser, president of Consulting Information Services in Keene, N.H. "No one may buy them, and their services may be drastically cut. It's quite possible that they could wither to the point of inconsequence. That's the most dire prediction one could make."
Even with the changes that the Big Five accounting firms have said they will make, concerns about conflicts of interest for accountants are likely to persist because there are some kinds of services that they will continue to sell, like tax advice. That means there is still the possibility that an auditor's judgment will be swayed by the prospect of nonaudit-related fees.
PricewaterhouseCoopers has said it intends to spin off its consulting unit through a public stock offering, and Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu recently announced plans to separate from Deloitte Consulting, though it has not specified how. Ernst & Young and KPMG have already separated from their consulting arms. Only Arthur Andersen, which was formally divorced from Andersen Consulting, now known as Accenture, last year but which has built its own consulting business over the last few years, has stated that it intends to hold on to consulting.
All of the Big Five firms, however, have said that they will curtail the consulting services they sell to companies they audit. The shift creates an opening for big technology consulting companies that are not affiliated with accounting firms, like Electronic Data Systems, I.B.M. Global Services and Accenture. 
"It's a great opportunity for both I.B.M. and E.D.S. to take market share," said John McCain, president of the E Solutions consulting unit of E.D.S. In the past, he said, it has been difficult for consulting firms to compete against accountants who audit a potential client. "They've got some great relationships that they've built up over decades that are very hard to unseat," he said
Because accountants are being forced to limit their consulting work, he said, E.D.S. is aggressively courting companies that until now have bought consulting from their accounting firms. "Their clients are worried," he said, referring to the accountants. "The problem is real, and it's reasonably substantial."
KPMG Consulting, formerly a unit of KPMG, is also aggressively pursuing clients that bought consulting services from auditors, said Rand Blazer, the firm's chief executive. "We have a proactive campaign that's under way," he said, adding that he was glad KPMG Consulting separated from its parent -- the firm went public last year -- when it did. "The whole process of becoming public is not as easy as one-two-three," he said. "We're glad to have this behind us."
Now is also not a great time for a consulting firm to go public because worried clients, coupled with the slow economy, do not make them particularly attractive to either investors or potential acquirers, Mr. Rodenhauser, the analyst, said.
PricewaterhouseCoopers tried to sell its consulting unit nearly two years ago, but the deal fell apart when the prospective buyer, Hewlett-Packard, balked at the price. PricewaterhouseCoopers had wanted close to $18 billion for the business, according to reports at the time. Now the firm says it is planning a public stock offering instead.
Executives at Deloitte Consulting, who had long emphasized that they wanted to remain a part of Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, say they are not sure what direction the firm will take.
"We're looking at our options," said Douglas M. McCracken, chief executive of Deloitte Consulting, adding that several possibilities were being considered, including a stock offering, a sale, taking the firm private or a merger. "By the end of May, we'll have a decision."
Andersen has consistently insisted that it has no plans to separate from its consulting business, although executives in the industry have said that the firm has raised the possibility with some technology companies. Large technology companies like Hitachi, Compaq Computer and Fujitsu have made no secret of their interest in building consulting operations that can compete against I.B.M. Global Services.
Over the last year, the path to a public offering has already been blazed by Accenture and KPMG. While both companies have done reasonably well, Accenture has pleased Wall Street more even in a down market, said Jack Sweeney, an editor at Kennedy Information, which tracks the consulting industry. 
"Accenture, I think two times for the first two quarters, came in above expectations, and KPMG hasn't done that," he said, referring to Accenture's earnings reports. "Those who follow, they want to borrow a page from Accenture."
Even after the sale of the consulting businesses, accounting firms will still do more than audit companies, accountants say. For example, some accounting firms have provided tax advice for at least as long as they have provided audit services, said Dennis Nally, managing partner of PricewaterhouseCoopers's business in the United States. 
"We think the provision of tax services in no way impairs our independence or objectivity," Mr. Nally said. "In many cases it's also crucial to have that kind of capability within our organization to do an effective audit," because understanding corporate transactions often requires an understanding of their tax implications, he said.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE OVERVIEW; 
Connecticut Feels Fallout From Enron

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER with MICHAEL BRICK

 BODY:
Trying to make up for $220 million lost in a murky deal with the Enron Corporation, the Connecticut state trash authority voted yesterday to raise its rates, effectively increasing household garbage fees in 70 towns -- representing more than a third of the state -- by nearly $50 a year.
 Though the State Legislature may challenge the fees, they represent perhaps the most concrete example of how Enron's collapse has jolted the finances of people who never worked for, held shares in, or knew the first thing about the company. The deal with Enron, meanwhile, has set off an election-year political fight in Connecticut. 
 At a meeting in Hartford, the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority, a quasi-independent public agency, voted to increase its trash-dumping fees by 31 percent and to impose a $20 fee for collecting recyclable waste. 
Last March, the authority paid Enron $220 million, ostensibly to take over a contract from a local utility to buy the authority's trash-generated steam electricity. In exchange, Enron -- though it never actually transported or sold the electricity -- agreed to pay the authority nearly $2.4 million a month, through the contract's expiration in 2012. 
With Enron's collapse, the authority became one more unsecured creditor, and officials acknowledged earlier this month that they would probably never recover the $220 million they advanced to Enron.
The deal has been criticized by the state attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, a Democrat, and by Democratic candidates for governor. The Democrats have been eager to blame the $220 million loss on Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican whose co-chief of staff, Peter Ellef, is the chairman of the trash authority.
In a preliminary report released Wednesday, Mr. Blumenthal denounced the deal as an unsecured loan "disguised and camouflaged" as an energy transaction. He said the authority, which state law prohibits from making loans, hoped to reap a 7 percent profit over the contract's 11-year span. The terms of the contract would have obligated Enron to pay the agency $21.3 million from April 2001, when it took effect, to December, when the company filed for bankruptcy protection.
As for Enron, Mr. Blumenthal said in an interview yesterday that its "motive was to have a quick $220 million, which it certainly did not book as a liability." He added that the deal "fits the pattern" of many other transactions that Enron made in the months before it collapsed, borrowing money in deals that made little long-term financial sense. 
Enron, he said, was required to make its monthly payment to the state agency regardless of whether it produced any electricity. Under the deal, Enron gained title to the authority's energy only for an instant before it was transferred back to the agency, Mr. Blumenthal said. 
In essence, his report concluded, Enron did nothing in return for the money it received from the Connecticut agency except promise to pay it back, with interest. "This $220 million was an infusion of cash when Enron needed it," he said. 
An Enron spokesman declined to comment on the matter, saying he was unfamiliar with the transaction.
Mr. Ellef, the trash authority chairman, defended the deal as a good arrangement for the state that simply got caught up in a financial debacle that humbled dozens of other institutions, as well. "We were the victim, like everyone else was," Mr. Ellef told reporters yesterday. 
Mr. Blumenthal's report criticized the trash authority for employing as its lawyers on the the deal the same law firm that worked as Enron's chief lobbyist in Connecticut. 
The Hartford-based firm, Murtha, Cullina, Richter & Pinney, said earlier this month that it had disclosed its dual role to both sides in writing. A spokesman for the firm declined to comment on the matter yesterday.
Robert E. Wright, the president of the trash authority, whose board members are appointed by the governor and legislature, said last week that the deal with Enron evolved from meetings in 2000 about a fuel cell venture.
As the talks proceeded, he said, Enron became increasingly interested in taking over the authority's contract with the Connecticut Light and Power Company, a local utility, to buy power that the authority generated from a Hartford-area trash-to-electricity operation. 
Exactly why Enron wanted to assume the contract under terms that obligated it to pay money back with interest is unclear. 
Mr. Blumenthal said yesterday that, according to documents and other evidence his office has examined, Enron appeared to have discovered during the fuel cell talks that Connecticut Light and Power planned to pay the authority $280 million to back out of its contract.
"Enron found that C.R.R.A. was on the verge of receiving this very large amount of money," he said. "The discussions went from there."
Separately, the judge presiding over Enron's bankruptcy case turned back a request from creditors to put a trustee in control of the company's finances. But the judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan, ordered the appointment of an examiner to monitor the finances of Enron's main operating unit, Enron North America. Judge Gonzalez ordered the examiner to prepare a report on transfers of money from the unit, which includes Enron's pipelines and formerly included its trading operation, to the parent company.
Creditors had asserted that Enron could be moving funds generated from energy trading contracts to other units, including some that are not in bankruptcy. They argued that Enron North America could have generated billions of dollars while extracting itself from contracts as it prepared to transfer Enron's trading unit to UBS Warburg last month.
Enron responded in court filings that it was not draining away money and pledged that its bankrupt units would work with the creditors to ensure that money borrowed by other parts of the company was repaid.
An Enron spokesman, Vance Meyer, said that the company had no objection to the judge's action. "At the end of the day, our goal is to emerge from bankruptcy," he said. "To do that, the creditors have to be comfortable with the operation. We hope today's decision gives them an added sense of confidence so we can continue moving forward together."
Judge Gonzalez had given a group of Enron's creditors -- participants in the company's 401(k) plan -- a small victory on Wednesday. He partly lifted a stay on lawsuits by the plan participants, allowing them to begin demanding information from Enron as they pursue litigation in a federal court in Houston.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Ellef, left, chairman of the Connecticut Resource Recovery Authority, and Robert E. Wright, its president, at a meeting yesterday. (Bob MacDonnell/The Hartford Courant via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Initial Jobless Claims Increase 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 

 BODY:
The number of Americans who filed initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose 10,000 last week, the Labor Department reported today.
 The number remained below 400,000 for the seventh consecutive week, the longest such stretch since the recession began almost a year ago, providing a sign of recovery. 
 A separate report from the Commerce Department showed that the United States trade deficit in goods and services unexpectedly narrowed to $25.3 billion in December from $28.6 billion in November as oil prices fell.
For all of 2001, the trade deficit narrowed to $346.3 billion from a record gap of $375.7 billion in 2000.
Two other reports released today offered signs that the economy might be rebounding. The index of leading economic indicators rose in January for a fourth consecutive month and manufacturing in the Philadelphia area improved.
"It's increasingly clear that we have turned the corner," said Bill Cheney, the chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. The leading indicator index, a gauge of the economy's performance over the next three to six months, rose 0.6 percent last month after a 1.3 percent increase in December, according to the Conference Board, a business research group. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia's factory index rose to 16 in February, the second month of growth after 13 months of decline.
The narrowing of the trade deficit may prompt the government to revise upward its 0.2 percent estimate of fourth-quarter growth. "A 1 percent rate now looks possible," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
UNITED AIRLINES IS RECALLING 1,200 FLIGHT ATTENDANTS

BYLINE:  AP

 BODY:
 United Airlines is recalling 1,200 of the 2,700 flight attendants who were laid off last fall, citing its plan to add flights in April in response to stronger customer demand. 
Almost two-thirds of those being recalled are based at United's Chicago and San Francisco airport hubs. The move brings to 2,000 the number of flight attendants recalled in the last three weeks. United, a unit of the UAL Corporation, announced earlier this month that it would add 127 flights to its daily schedule, currently about 1,700 flights, and recall some flight attendants and furlough fewer pilots.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Are Lower as Nasdaq Scrapes a 4-Month Bottom

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, driving the Nasdaq composite index to its lowest level in almost four months, on speculation that a profit rebound for telecommunications and computer-related companies might be weaker than forecast.
 Intel and Cisco Systems led the decline. 
 The Nasdaq composite index tumbled 59.33 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,716.24, its lowest close since Oct. 31. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 106.49 points, or 1.1 percent, to 9,834.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 17.03 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,080.95. 
The Nasdaq has lost 12 percent this year; the S.& P. 500 has fallen 5.9 percent; and the Dow, 1.7 percent.
Intel fell $1.96, or 6.2 percent, to $29.48 after a Banc of America Securities analyst, Douglas Lee, reduced his earnings estimates, citing weakening demand in the second quarter.
Cisco slid $1.58, to $15.11. The New York Post reported that Cisco executives held stakes in a partnership that benefited greatly in the 1990's from ties to Cisco. Cisco executives declined to comment.
Ciena dropped $1.10, to $7.60. The company, the No. 2 maker of fiber optic phone equipment in the United States, said sales this quarter would miss forecasts as two big customers may order less than expected.
Renewed concern over corporate accounting practices hovered over the market. I.B.M. dropped $2.93, to $96.38. The company has lost 20 percent this year amid questions about its accounting practices.
Computer Associates International dropped $2.01, to $18.90, after it tapped a reserve bank line as its short-term financing costs soared on reports that the F.B.I. was investigating its record-keeping.
"It's going to take signs earnings are going to get better to get this market going," said John Waterman of Rittenhouse Financial Services. "Accounting questions add to the lack of confidence."
The American International Group shed $2.68, to $71.04. It received subpoenas from the Securities and Exchange Commission as part of an investigation into the accounting practices of PNC Financial Services, an A.I.G. partner.
"There are still a lot of issues out there with accounting," said Tom Schrader, head of listed trading at Legg Mason Wood Walker. "Almost all companies pay accountants extremely well so they can make their numbers," which may have led to inaccuracies, he said.
Telecommunications services shares dropped after BellSouth reduced its 2002 profit forecast, citing currency devaluation and deteriorating economic conditions in Argentina and Venezuela.
BellSouth, the big local phone-service provider in the Southeast, dropped $2.50, to $37.95. Verizon Communications fell $2.16, to $44.45. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, gaining ground as the stock market rally on Wednesday fizzled. 
Longer-dated Treasuries also rose slightly after dealers reversed hedges associated with the sale by Walt Disney of $1.75 billion of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds. 
The 10-year note rose 10/32, to a price of 100 6/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.85 percent from 4.89 percent on Wednesday.
The price of a 30-year bond gained 12/32, to 100 4/32. Its yield fell to 5.36 percent from 5.39 percent.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says Higher Taxi Fares Are Needed to Lure Drivers 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
New Yorkers can expect a taxi fare increase because the industry cannot attract enough drivers under the current fee structure, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.
 "Somehow or other, if you don't make it economically attractive to people to drive taxis, the public's not going to have taxis, and the ways that you basically do it is by raising fees and passing that money on to the drivers," Mr. Bloomberg said. 
 The idea of a higher fare surfaced toward the end of last year, when a segment of the taxi industry petitioned the Taxi and Limousine Commission for a fare increase of 23 percent, which would bring the cost of the average trip to $8.45 from $6.85.
Matthew W. Daus, the commission's chairman, said yesterday that while nothing had been determined as yet, the commissioners had reached a consensus in December that some sort of increase was warranted, but their estimates ranged from 12 to 17 percent instead.
The former mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, had favored an increase tied to the size of the taxis used, so that the larger the cab the higher the fare, an option that is still under consideration as the city begins phasing out small cabs. But a fare increase, Mr. Daus said, would be designed primarily to address the shortage of drivers and to keep pace with the higher costs associated with service and fleet improvements. Mr. Daus estimated that before the Sept. 11 attacks, at least 500 cabs each day had been sitting idle because of the driver shortage, and that since then the problem had intensified. The commission plans to hold a job fair in the middle of March to help fill an estimated 2,000 to 3,000 open jobs.
Mr. Daus added that the commission was also considering a congestion pricing option that would shift the nighttime 50-cent surcharge on cab rides to the morning and evening rush hours to encourage drivers to bring cabs into the city at times when high demand is unmet.
Officials said yesterday that they were sill working on the details of when, how or precisely what sort of increase would go into effect. Mr. Daus explained that the group that had petitioned for a fare increase, the fleet owners, represented only 20 percent of the industry and that the commissioners were waiting for evidence that the increase was warranted from the rest of the industry, individual owner-operators and longterm lease-holders.
Yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg said that he did not know if he would support an increase as high as 20 percent, but said New Yorkers would probably see some sort of increase.
"The fact of the matter is unless you have taxis out in the street the public is not well served at any price," he said.
