HEADLINE: Belgrade Relishes Life At Peace 

BYLINE:  By NEIL STRAUSS; NEIL STRAUSS is a cultural correspondent for The Times in Los Angeles.

 BODY:
IN 1990, Belgrade was a bustling worldly city, an oasis of cafes, culture and night life that formed the cultural center of the Balkans. The next year, however, eight years of almost continuous war began, in which the old Yugoslavia broke up along the fault line of religious tensions and nationalism. The conflict culminated in 1999 when NATO bombed Serbia to force the Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic to withdraw his security forces from Kosovo.
 Today, on first impression, you'd never know that Belgrade, the capital of Yugoslavia, had just surfaced from a long, gruesome war that decimated its economy and destroyed tourism. On a monthlong visit to Yugoslavia in September, during which I traveled from the monasteries of the north to the beautiful Montenegrin coast in the south, I was surprised to find myself constantly drawn back to Belgrade. 
 My companion was an old high-school friend, Marko, who had just decided to return to his home country. In kindergarten in Chicago, we used to make fun of Marko for being Serbian. We didn't actually know what Serbian was: it was just different. Now, so many years later, I was surprised to find myself not only joining him in Serbia (Yugoslavia comprises Serbia and Montenegro) but also finding its social life so appealing. 
Belgrade itself has had a long and troubled history. Strategically situated at the confluence of the Sava and the Danube Rivers, it has been destroyed on numerous occasions since Roman times. The Sava bisects the more picturesque old city (which contains only a few streets with buildings that have survived since the late 18th century and the Beaux-Arts boom 100 years ago) from new Belgrade, a very unappealing sprawl of Socialist-style apartment-block housing. The city's official population is around two million, but that doesn't include a substantial community of war refugees. 
Despite its poverty, Belgrade is an astonishingly stylish place on first impression. Its countless cafes were packed day and night; the clubs on boats moored along the Danube and the Sava were filled with boisterous revelers; the city's main tourist attraction, the Kalemegdan Fortress, was overrun with embracing couples; and the pedestrian mall in the old city was teeming with leggy women and muscular crew-cut men.
On closer inspection, however, something seemed odd. At the cafes, the most animated topic of conversation, even among schoolchildren, was politics. At the clubs, most patrons had enough disposable income for just one drink or perhaps two; from the Kalemegdan Fortress, the blackened and bombed-out Socialist Party headquarters was visible; and in the pedestrian mall, tourist stands sold "Serbia by Night" postcards depicting a burning wartime skyline.
Add together these two profiles of Belgrade and you have what Americans sometimes call "the new normal." This is a city recovering its pride, spirit and resilience after a war and residents call a revolution, the overthrow of Slobodan Milosevic. Perhaps the most poignant example I saw of this post-trauma business-as-usual mentality was a computer screen saver in the window of a car dealership. Scrolling across the screen in large red letters was: "What has happened to the world we once knew??" 
Though a State Department consular information sheet issued in August notes that "no specific threats or incidents of harassment involving American citizens have been reported since the Kostunica government took office in October 2000," Serbia nonetheless attracts few American or other tourists these days. It is, however, a very easy place to visit. As one Serbian told me, "There are no cheesy tourist traps in Belgrade, because there are no tourists." 
A disadvantage is that few hotels and banks, and almost no restaurants, accept foreign credit cards, and cash machines don't recognize American bank and credit cards. Travelers are advised to take plenty of cash, preferably changed into euros (which are accepted almost everywhere).
Visiting Belgrade is an especially strange experience for an American. Before Sept. 11, Serbians liked to point out the five or so NATO-bombed buildings in the city center and ask Americans, with more curiosity than hostility, "Why did you bomb us?" During a brief visit in January, the comments I heard were more along the lines of, "Now you understand." But as anyone who has studied the complex politics of the region or read Rebecca West's complex and wonderful 1,100-page-plus Yugoslav travelogue "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon" knows, we don't really understand. 
For hundreds of years, Serbia has been the whipping boy of the Mediterranean. A barrier between Muslim Asia and Christian Europe, it was occupied and over the course of 500 years, it was often ravaged by the Turks. (On a day trip to the beautiful medieval monasteries around Belgrade, it was rare to find a church that hadn't suffered significant destruction by the Turks.) 
Then after 63 years of tenuous autonomy, which was constantly sabotaged by Austro-Hungarian manipulation, Serbia faced devastation in World War II. It is still possible to envision the paths the Nazi bombers took when they bombarded the city if you look for diagonal strips of newer buildings surrounded by older apartments.
Add the trauma and unrest of the Balkan wars of the 1990's, which have ended but resolved little, and most visitors today leave with the impression that Serbia is simply between wars. But Belgrade's resilient spirit can be seen every day in its cafes and streets. A visit should not be mired in the past (the National Museum of Art is so lacking in funds that its collections of Renaissance, medieval and foreign art are locked away in the basement). It is for enjoying the moment. 
Belgrade's inhabitants clearly do this well: they remain among Europe's handsomest people, proud and stylish. A strict macho code is enforced among the men, who rarely smile, while the women wear designer impostors of surprisingly high quality. There is a common joke that the average Serbian makes $100 a month, but spends $200 a month on clothes. 
The trendy denizens of the city can be seen most warmer days on Prince Michael Street (a store-lined pedestrian road in the center of old Belgrade), which is typically bursting with life, its cafes teeming with students, politicians, artists and intellectuals. Rewards for the tourist are in the details: the joke-cracking flutist panhandler, the peasant musician playing the a bagpipelike instrument made from a sheep bladder, and especially the postcard stands. 
Nearly half of the postcards show photos of bombed Belgrade buildings or pay tribute to Belgraders' defiant spirit during the NATO bombing. A card showing boys scampering around twisted wreckage comments sarcastically: "The children playground, designed by NATO." Another pictures the supposedly undetectable F-117A spy plane that was shot down. It reads: "Sorry, we didn't know it was invisible. Greetings from Serbia."
Several blocks away from all this morbid wit is the University of Philosophy, which houses a bookstore and cafe, both called Plato, that can serve as a good home base. A mostly outdoor affair with chic modern decor, Cafe Plato was a good place to meet and make new friends. More than half the people I tried to talk to spoke at least conversational English, and were happy to talk politics, compare cultures, lambaste Slobodan Milosevic or crack jokes over a $2 sandwich or a delicious $1 banana frappe while listening to a student jazz band on the balcony above. 
Adjoining the cafe, the bookstore offered Internet access, a decent selection of books in English, and a well-read cashier who recommended "Death and the Dervish" by Mesa Selimovich. The nearby ? Cafe, the oldest in town, offered more rustic charm, traditional food, and a taste of Belgrade's intellectual life of yesteryear. On arriving one afternoon, Marko and I found a table of old-timers belting out traditional songs in a baritone sing-along.
Perhaps my favorite site in the city is a work in progress, the immense St. Sava Temple, off the Bulevar JNA. Modeled after the Hagia Sofia in Istanbul (and built to scale), St. Sava has been under construction since before World War II and shows no signs of being completed any time soon. 
But the structure stands, and it's intriguing to wander in and see the largest cathedral in the Balkans filled with bulldozers and a crane. The security guard, for a small tip, took Marko and me up flights of stairs to a walkway around the exterior of the dome, which offered an even more beautiful view of the Belgrade skyline than the one from the Kalemegdan Fortress. Afterward, he showed us every detail of the cathedral, from the mosaics that had only just begun to cover the immense interior to the different types of marble being fitted to the exterior.
The greatest pleasure of Belgrade, however, was its cafes and clubs. The Serbian capacity for night life is nothing short of amazing: some diehards go out seven nights a week, and still manage to make it to work the next morning. When I refused cigarettes, alcohol or coffee, most Serbians, whether teenagers or grandparents, looked at me in shock and asked a variation of, "What is the point of living without these small pleasures?"
Around dusk, I liked to stroll along the ramparts of the Kalemegdan Fortress to Cafe Cinema, a sprawl of tables and balconies arranged at the very top of the stone stronghold. At that time of day, wolves could be seen baying in the zoo below. On weekend nights, live bands performed and hundreds of tables filled with glamorous Belgrade youth while revelers flocked to Klub Cvijeta elsewhere in the fortress.
Afterward, for a traditional Serb meal, we would wander Skadarska, a cobbled street two blocks from Prince Michael Street, once the Montmartre of Belgrade. Besides the statues, galleries and museums dedicated to the artists who once lived there, Skadarska is known for its dozen-plus restaurants, with large outdoor cafes and roving string bands. 
The restaurants -- That Hat of Mine, the Three Hats, the Two Deer, and There Are Days -- most dating to the first half of the 19th century, still serve quality traditional favorites: njegoseva persutto (a thin ham usually served with kajmak, a rich spread that's equal parts butter and cheese), karadjeordjeva snicla (snicla means schnitzel), and filet mignon in mushroom sauce. The food was especially good at Ima Dana.
For a young, modern take on Serbian cuisine and dining rituals, a more hedonistic time was to be had at Reka, about 15 minutes away on the bank of the Danube. There is only one seating, around 10 p.m, and people stay very late. The crowd, mostly from the theater community, and the bright lights, colorful paintings and an arty ambience gave it the feel of a hip East Village restaurant. 
Most patrons drank the smooth Montenegrin wine before feasting on seafood. The fresh trout and the risotto with calamari went down as smoothly as the wine. After dining, we danced with other patrons to live music, in this case a talented cover band that played equal parts rock and roll, torch songs and Serbian pop.
For a late-night dinner, Klub Knjizevnika (Writers Club) offered another scene, one of artists, writers and celebrities in constant heated debate. Its food -- particularly the rich, cool ajvar (chopped pepper salad) and tender lamb -- ranks among the city's best.
After dinner, we usually walked to the picturesque, tree-lined Strahinjica Bana in the old city. Though taxis are cheap in Belgrade, gas prices are so high that many drivers refuse short trips. Strahinjica Bana is lined with cafes that serve as popular resting places between dinner and clubbing. Among the best were the oddly named Mamma's Biscuit House (known locally as Stelina), which specializes in fruit jams and fresh fruit cups topped with homemade whipped cream, and the more upscale, trendy Studio.
After coffee and dessert, the night finally begins in earnest. In the last few years, the banks of the Sava and the Danube have become lined with about 150 boats, most of them ad hoc nightclubs that are packed every night in spring and summer. Any visitor can take a taxi to Dunavski Kej Usce, Bulevar Nikole Tesle or Savski Kej, walk along the river and choose a floating scene, from black-lighted ships blasting techno to immense floating restaurants to grungy rock schooners. 
The most interesting were the careening Gypsy music clubs and the ones with cover bands playing Serbian pop, to which women gyrated their hips like belly dancers while men locked arms and sang along drunkenly. The lyrics, in Serbian, were fantastic odes to intoxicated, passionate nights that the singers hoped would never end.
And in Belgrade, the night doesn't have to end. There's still Quorom 33 and the Underground for late-night dancing on weekends, and after-hours at Nana doesn't get going until 3 a.m. At dawn, revelers stop by Nislija, a fast-food stand across the street from Tas, a more upscale club frequented by local gangsters. There, one can savor pljeskavica, a spicy hamburger, and watch an event that is an anathema in most Serbian pop songs: sunrise.

A city for partying along two rivers
Usually, United States citizens need visas ($45) to enter Yugolsavia. But through March, 30-day tourist passes ($4.90), issued at border crossings, are sufficient. Information: Yugoslav Embassy, (202) 332-0333, fax (202) 332-3933; www.yuembusa.org.

HEADLINE: SPRING THEATER; 
Six Decades Later, Still The Great American Musical

BYLINE:  By ETHAN MORDDEN; Ethan Mordden's latest book is "Open a New Window: The Broadway Musical in the 1960's" (Palgrave).

 BODY:
HERE'S an "Oklahoma!" story: shortly before rehearsals began, one of the show's producers, Theresa Helburn, told the librettist Oscar Hammerstein II that he and the composer Richard Rodgers ought to write "a song about the earth."
 Bewildered, Hammerstein asked Helburn what she meant. 
 She wasn't sure herself. "Just a song about the earth," she repeated. "The land." 
That, of course, was to be the show's rousing, even ecstatic title song. However, while creating an anthem for the land, Rodgers and Hammerstein were also singing of the people who settle on and develop it -- all of it. The song is called "Oklahoma," but it really means "Americans": their morality and government and spirit, how they learn the arts of compromise and tolerance in order to deserve the liberty that democracy fosters.
The people will get a chance to sample the show's unique explanation of how Americans invent themselves on March 21, when "Oklahoma!" opens on Broadway almost exactly 59 years after its premiere. This revival at the Gershwin Theater, directed by Trevor Nunn, was first mounted for the Royal National Theater in London. Unusually, it is neither a Highly Important Deconstruction by a Wunderkind Director (as with the current "Cabaret," reconceived by Sam Mendes) nor an affable reimagining (as with the recently departed "Annie Get Your Gun").
Mr. Nunn restored some dialogue from the musical's source, Lynn Riggs's play "Green Grow the Lilacs," and topped off "It's a Scandal! It's a Outrage!" with a few uncredited new lines. The choreographer Susan Stroman designed completely new dances to replace the original Agnes de Mille choreography, a feature of "Oklahoma!" revivals till now. Even the dance music itself has been newly arranged.
Above all, writers have commented on an unexpectedly dark feel to the story, typical of the modern musical but unusual two generations ago. Still, this is essentially the piece that Broadway first saw in 1943, running for five years when hit musicals lasted a year, and immediately becoming -- and then remaining -- the Great American Musical.
Why this one? Doesn't the picture of courtship rites among cowboys and their girls and its territorial feud between farmers and ranchers seem quaint today? Is the entire first act really about whether or not Curly will take Laurey to the box social? It sounds awfully corny.
Well, here's another "Oklahoma!" story. In the 1940's, musicals rehearsed with the cast broken into separate groups. The composer, choreographer and dancing chorus might work in one place while the librettist, director and actors worked in another. There was a bit of sharing, and the singing chorus floated around as required. Still, a show's "parts" were made and then assembled, which is why most musicals never quite fit together.
Now, one Saturday, the director, Rouben Mamoulian, decided to run the first act. The show's parts were coming together for the first time, all the performers in one room, moving through the action from dialogue to song to dance. Hammerstein was in the country that weekend; Rodgers was taking it easy in his apartment. Perhaps Mamoulian thought this an ideal time to see what they had, in a relaxed workshop atmosphere.
But something else happened that day. Speech effortlessly slipped into music and song reached for dance to express what words cannot, and everyone present began to realize how inevitably "Oklahoma!" unfolded. It was one thing happening all the way along, like a pane of glass. De Mille followed the feminist number "Many a New Day" with an extrapolation of woman's restless dreams of escape from a system run by men; the slimy villain sang a song of longing, "Lonely Room," that glowered like a depraved rainbow. The actors stood transfixed. They were gaping at something new in the musical: consistency. The parts matched. And the stage manager ran to the phone, called Richard Rodgers and said, "You'd better get down here quick!"
Because "Oklahoma!" was inaugurating a new age that very day. It was not the first integrated musical, as some seem to think. But it was the first universally popular integrated musical in which every aspect of composition and production enhanced the narrative. The parts didn't just match. They made love to one another. As Rodgers himself put it, "The orchestrations sound the way the costumes look." 
So "Oklahoma!" became most people's idea of The One. But why has it remained so, after longer-running hits like "My Fair Lady" and "A Chorus Line" or such critics' conjuring tools as "Gypsy" and "Follies"? Even Riggs's totally forgotten play is, paradoxically, famous -- simply for being the totally forgotten blueprint for "Oklahoma!"
Oddly, that original "Green Grow the Lilacs," in 1931, was already a sort of musical. Folk songs were interpolated into the action, mainly for atmosphere but also for character. Riggs's hero, Curly, opened the show with the jaunty "Git Along, Little Dogies," just as Rodgers and Hammerstein's Curly opens "Oklahoma!" with -- well, one could call it expansively jaunty -- "Oh, What a Beautiful Mornin'."
Also oddly, the play's use of "Old Paint," "Home on the Range" and so on prefigures the folkish style in which Rodgers and Hammerstein sometimes worked. Like Irving Berlin's "God Bless America" and "White Christmas," their music can seem less invented than invoked, summoned up out of the hum of American life. In "Carousel," doesn't "You'll Never Walk Alone" sound like a hymn, "Blow High, Blow Low" like a sea chantey? I mean real ones. In "The Sound of Music," "Edelweiss" suggests a traditional ballad so authentically that many people assume it's folk music. So if "Green Grow the Lilacs" borrowed folk music, Rodgers and Hammerstein "wrote" folk music.
In "Oklahoma!," we hear a horse-and-buggy clip-clop in "The Surrey With the Fringe on Top" that simply doesn't belong in a Broadway pit. "The Farmer and the Cowman" is a vast barn dance, and "All er Nuthin' " struts bowlegged. It's a rodeo cantata. 
Still more oddly, while bearing the naive sound of folk music, the "Oklahoma!" songs utilize the sophistication of the best theater music in treating character. Curly's "Oh, What a Beautiful Mornin' " is sunny and teasing, like Curly himself, a waltz with the typical Rodgers "wrong note" (on "morn," in the first line). It's ravishing yet elemental, the signature of a young man with his history entirely in the future, happy to be where he is, doing what he does.
Comparably, Laurey's "Many a New Day" wears a twisty little turn in its melody. It suggests her capricious but also stubborn nature. Rodgers tweaks the tune -- that's the caprice -- but he goes on tweaking it, 10 times in a single chorus. That's stubborn.
In a way, these two songs are antagonists, just as the bickering lovers Curly and Laurey are. He is that despair of women, the eternal show-off who charms the world. He drives her crazy with his braggy self-confidence and skylarking improvisations. That surrey with the fringe on top? Sheer invention. "Made the whole thing up outa my head," he taunts, as she flies into a rage and tries to run him off her spread.
Yes, Laurey is a landowner, her own master. Is she, in fact, the show's protagonist? Hammerstein's work is filled with strong women, from Rose-Marie to Anna Leonowens (in "The King and I"), and while he and Rodgers don't exactly take Curly for granted, they honor Laurey with the most prestigious element of 30's-40's-50's musical comedy: a Dream Ballet.
This genre stops the action to explore it psychologically. It was de Mille's idea to confront Laurey with conflicting temptations, one romantic (with Curly) and one fleshly (with Jud). To this point, Laurey seems to be torn between them. But the ballet, titled "Laurey Makes Up Her Mind," finds Jud murdering Curly and carrying Laurey off. Is this what she wants? What she fears? Or is she simply too sensitive a soul for pioneer territory?
Far more amenable to life in the wild is Ado Annie, whose relationship with the cowboy Will Parker balances the idyll of Curly and Laurey. Laurey is intelligent and complex; Annie is a puffcake. She is also as available as Laurey is self-protected, the girl who famously "cain't say no."
But Will is as steady as Curly is wild. Curly will have to settle down; Will is already settled. And that's Will's problem: Annie is wild, too. It is as if the characters were taking on the nature of their region, as if pioneering made folks into authoritarians or rebels. The wilderness needs culture and law, but too much control creates doubters, brawlers, or even, like Annie, flirts. One has the feeling that a nationality is being revealed in microcosm, not merely as farmers and cowmen but as personalities. The land tells us who the people are. And we had better know: this is a place where problems are settled by shotgun. 
It has to be, for the aforementioned slimy villain, Jud, is the sort who likes to incinerate those who thwart his will. Part of this show's ebullient Americana is the unpleasant truth that evil will keep coming at you until you kill it. One piece of democracy is the harmonizing of discordant agendas. But another piece is the expunging of the wicked.
One more reason for the prominence of "Oklahoma!" lies in its timing. Depression economics had forced musicals of the 1930's to favor easy entertainment. They offered star turns and fun but lacked content. It was Ethel Merman Sings Her Cole Porter Torch Song; or Bert Lahr Spoofs the Fancy-Pantses; or even the two together in Louis XV wigs in "DuBarry Was a Lady."
This explains why the show was originally such a hard sell to investors. It's a cliche as celebrated as "Oklahoma!" itself. But so what? Breakthrough art always has trouble arranging its start-up financing. What matters is the show's unprecedented success, which pointed the way to musicals that were about something and which ultimately led Merman herself to play the mother of all mothers in "Gypsy," one of the most about-something shows of all time.
The influence of "Oklahoma!" was not only lasting but immediate, as writers investigated historical American subject matter and producers made pets of de Mille and the new young ballet guys who rose up in her wake, like Jerome Robbins and Michael Kidd. Only it wasn't ballet any more. Ballet was so 30's. Now it was: Dance, with its synthesis of hoofing and arabesque, as if Martha Graham had married the Nicholas Brothers. "One Touch of Venus," "Bloomer Girl," "On the Town," "Sing Out, Sweet Land!," "Brigadoon" and "Paint Your Wagon" count among the musicals made possible by "Oklahoma!" Countless others were made better. The show most directly produced by "Oklahoma!" was, of course, "Carousel," Rodgers and Hammerstein's second collaboration. Their third, "Allegro," invented the concept musical. But their first, "Oklahoma!," invented the musical. 
That is, "Oklahoma!" reconceived this indigenous American form from the makeshift to the organic, from entertainment to enlightenment. It is worth noting that even Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein's "Show Boat," the first of the great musicals and older than "Oklahoma!" by more than 15 years, came under the influence of "Oklahoma!": in a revival in 1946. Produced by Rodgers and Hammerstein, this revision sought to reintegrate disparate elements of "Show Boat" along "Oklahoma!" lines -- to make those orchestrations, so to speak, reflect the costumes. Everything that mattered was turning into "Oklahoma!"
The show's subsequent history typifies the classic: a major and quite faithful film version in 1955; remountings of the original staging at City Center and Rodgers's own production at Lincoln Center in 1969; then a successful Broadway revival in 1979.
The present National Theater version was unveiled in 1998, with the about-to-be movie star Hugh Jackman and Josefina Gabrielle as Curly and Laurey; an American guest, Shuler Hensley, as Jud; and the English comic actress Maureen Lipman as Laurey's testy Aunt Eller. She referees the hostilities between both Curly and Laurey and the ranchers and farmers, and finally seems almost like the show's M.C. (The first character we see, she introduces the title song and generally shows up decisively every time the action gets dangerous.) Andrea Martin takes the role, with Patrick Wilson (of "The Full Monty") joining Ms. Gabrielle and Mr. Hensley from London. 
The British have a special relationship with "Oklahoma!" On its first London visit, in 1947, it was the biggest success in Drury Lane's 285-year history. More pertinent, it was a greeting from one ally to another after their triumphant defeat of fascism in the Second World War. Obviously, "Oklahoma!" opened on Broadway during that war -- precisely two months after the Battle of Stalingrad, which seemed a turning point in favor of the Allies. At the time, the show's message felt poignantly joyous amid so much death and destruction. In London in 1947, it was a kind of handshake, even an embrace after a job well done: the survival of a civilization.
Classic musicals are revived not only for their artistic quality but also for the feelings that they convey. "Show Boat" celebrates the diversity of America and its love of theater. "West Side Story" warns against intolerance. "A Chorus Line," when it reappears, will hearten us with those two Great American Things: show biz and being young.
"Oklahoma!" returns because it defines Americans as a people, generous but plain-spoken and tough on spoilers. Yet it is poetry -- the sunny rhapsody of the opening; the devolution of Curly's "Surrey" boasting into a lullaby of self-revealing tenderness using the same melody; the way "Out of My Dreams" so wistfully soars into the fantasy of a community united. 
Half a century after the premiere of "Oklahoma!," we are again at war, against the same kind of enemy as in 1943: solipsistic, vastly intolerant and gunning to restore Stone Age values. "Oklahoma!" reminds us why we fight. It's about the people, the land.

HEADLINE: After 3 Murders, a Neighborhood Worries 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD WEIZEL 

 BODY:
AFTER being jolted awake at 3 a.m. on Feb. 6 by the sound of the police and fire truck sirens and the glare of flashing lights that penetrated the shades of his bedroom window, Robert Fern couldn't believe what he saw out the window of his Jefferson Street home in Milford.
 A line of police cars had formed up and down the cul-de-sac where he and his family have lived for nearly 20 years. Dozens of police officers crouched behind the cars and had their guns pointed at the house directly across from his. 
 Mr. Fern said several SWAT team officers were putting on what appeared to be heavy suits of protection, and the police were screaming to anyone who came outside to go back in. 
Then "just like in the movies and on television" a man came out the front door and raised his arms in the air and yelled 'don't shoot, don't shoot," Mr. Fern said. "They ordered him to get down on the ground and within seconds he was handcuffed and in a police car. Not long after that it looked like they had carried out some bodies. It was all so surreal, it looked like a war scene."
A few hours later the police revealed that the city's first double homicide in more than 40 years had occurred during a two-hour hostage drama in which two women had escaped by jumping out a window to safety. Another woman living in the home had been sexually assaulted by her ex-boyfriend with their four-year-old daughter present. 
Two men who lived in the house, Richard Drury, 49, and his nephew, Mikel Brady Sr., 35, had been stabbed to death. Russell Dortche, 42, of West Haven, the former boyfriend of Mr. Drury's daughter, was arrested at the crime scene and still is being held in lieu of $5 million bail on two counts of murder, felony murder and other charges.
In a community where murders happen about every decade or so this was particularly unnerving: it was the second time killings had occurred there within nine months. 
About a half-mile away on a cozy street right along the beach off Bittersweet Road, Charles Ende, 72, recalled how it was just last May that he chatted with his neighbor, 28-year-old Kelsey Monahon, on a rainy spring afternoon. An hour or so later, Ms. Monahon, who was pregnant, was bound, gagged and strangled to death in her Shorefront Road apartment across the street. 
No arrests have been made, though the police have been assuring residents that this was not a random-intruder crime and that the victim very likely knew her assailants and willingly let them in.
"I've been living down here since 1958 and you don't expect something like this around here, that's for sure," said Mr. Ende, a retired grocery store manager. "This is such a peaceful, quiet beach community and when Kelsey was killed it was like a lightning bolt had hit the whole neighborhood. We're still in shock." 
Nine months later, the police and the state's attorney's office are still conducting what they say is an "active" investigation and again recently told residents they do not believe the murder was a random crime.
But the three killings in two separate incidents have so upset residents that many people are now locking their doors, even when they're home, and some are installing house alarms.
"We never used to lock our doors when we went down to the beach, but it's a different world now and I make sure to lock my door whenever I go out, especially after these latest killings," said Letitia Malone, who lives within a mile of Jefferson Street and has lived in the area for 54 years. 
"It's very disquieting, to say the least, and I think a lot of people in the community are feeling much more vulnerable," Mrs. Malone said. "The three murders couldn't help but have that effect. Over all it still feels safe, but who would have ever thought that something like this could happen around here, not just once, but twice within a year?"
Alderwoman Mary Lou Kecko, a member of the Walnut Beach Association that has been trying to promote the area's revitalization, said some people were more fearful, but others seemed more concerned that publicity about the killings would hurt the group's economic development efforts and property values. 
Ms. Kecko, who has lived in the community for several decades, has been trying to persuade residents that the two violent episodes, "while certainly not in the category of random and rampant crimes" should not be forgotten about so quickly either. She said it is important that residents be more aware of what is happening on their streets and that if something looks "even the slightest bit suspicious" they must get involved and at least call the police.
Ms. Kecko has been one of the leaders in the effort to transform the community into an artist's colony that would include new shops and restaurants to help revitalize an area that has never recovered from the closing of an amusement park about 50 years ago. 
About 10 years ago, neighborhood-watch programs and the police worked together to drive out motorcycle and youth gangs that were becoming involved in drug dealing. 
"There is a feeling of disgust, outrage and an element of fear by some, but then there are those who feel they are doing what they can and that this could have happened anywhere," Ms. Kecko said. "While it could have happened anywhere, the point is it happened here in our community and that's something we have to accept and deal with. We all need to look at what we can do to try and prevent horrific violent crimes like this in the future."
With that in mind, Vaughan Dumas an officer in the Milford Police Department, made a presentation last week to members of the Walnut Beach Association that included advice to residents on how to make their homes safer and what to watch out for in their neighborhood. Mr. Dumas, who serves as the department's community services and public information officer, told residents they should be vigilant about reporting anything unusual and to always lock their doors.
"The killers in all three murders entered through unlocked doors," Mr. Dumas said. "Keeping your doors unlocked is a definite no-no."
Because of the most recent homicides Mary Galvin, the state's attorney in New Haven, tried to assuage growing public fear.
"People need to calm down, it's not like there's some wild man running around out there who is going to strike again," Ms. Galvin said. "That is still an open investigation and police are still actively pursuing leads." Ms. Galvin declined comment on whether there was a specific suspect or suspects or whether there were any arrests imminent.
Groups like the Walnut Beach Association are trying to educate and inform both adults and children without unduly scaring them. Richard Freda, president of the association said he hoped the killings at least helped raise public awareness about safety without hurting the morale of the community.
"We all know how horrific these killings were and it's something, thank goodness, that is alien to us," said Mr. Freda, who has lived in a home near the beach since 1972. "But people just need to live their lives. You can't stop things like this and you can't stop your life when they happen."
Mr. Freda's wife Cathy Coda, 53, has lived near the beach her entire life. "I just don't remember any other murders," she said, "and while I do believe these are isolated incidents it's still a shocking thing when it happens right down the street."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Bob Ende, above, on the front deck of his Bittersweet Avenue home in Milford, across the street from the garage apartment where a murder took place last August. Right, the house where two murders occurred earlier this month. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COUNTY LINES; 
Onward in Armonk

BYLINE:  By MAREK FUCHS 

 BODY:
THE doughnut machine snarled and hissed, a line stretched out the door and all the Schultz's Cider Mill regulars were there. For a moment, it looked like nothing had changed and nothing ever would. 
 Jim House, who ran a gas station and raised seven children in Armonk, was there. So was Nellie Palamarczuk, who was born in Armonk in 1930 and has lived here ever since. And my father, who for 30 years has come weekend mornings to read his newspapers over doughnuts and cider walked in too, though, probably for the first time, he had forgotten the newspapers. 
 In came LeRoy Mecklenburg. "You're still here?"
Buddy Schultz answered: "Another week."
"Good," said Mr. Mecklenburg, "but we've got to get you here another year. Actually, I'm 72. We've got to get you here until I die." 
The two friends shared a laugh, which was cut short by the dispiriting truth: Schultz's Cider Mill, a legend here for a half century, is closing at the end of the month. Staffed by three generations of the Schultz family, the roadside business has always sold freshly pressed apple cider, hot, fresh doughnuts and fresh vegetables. In 1964, what longtime residents call Armonk's second most famous business, I.B.M., opened their worldwide headquarters down the street. But, as if in rebellion against the computer age, Schultz's tabulates purchases on your shopping bag, in black crayon. 
Pilgrims came from all over to wait in line, but for those of us who grew up in Armonk, the cinnamon and sugar-powdered doughnuts were our collective madeleine. 
The regulars were always there, men and women who bought houses in Armonk when prices did not resemble the Gross Domestic Product of Finland. They sat on uncomfortable wood benches and enjoyed each other's company. 
To them, the closing of this place is emblematic of what has happened to their Armonk. 
Michael E. Fareri, a developer, is buying Schultz's and the land it sits on in a sale that is scheduled to close on March 28. Mr. Fareri plans to build about 30 single-family structures, the latest word in seven-figure housing. 
Rebecca A. Kittredge, the deputy supervisor of North Castle, which includes Armonk, said that she was sad Schultz's is closing. "But in fairness," she added, "the Schultz family wanted to retire and it's not the sort of business that someone else can come in and run."
Mrs. Palamarczuk, who came to Schultz's for the "camaraderie and the doughnuts," hardly recognizes the town that has been her home for 70 years. "Now," said Mrs. Palamarczuk, "you just pass these office buildings and big houses." 
The town always seemed one step removed from the commuter towns around it because it had no Metro-North train station. What was, even through most of the 1980's, a one-stoplight main street, has now been stretched much longer by strip malls. Of course, selection is much better now. You can get high-end catered food and even massages. But the town no longer has a supply of old-line places where people meet, the sort of places, like Schultz's, that defined Armonk. There was Doc's Pharmacy, which had a soda counter with stools, and Art's Stationery, which sold soda, newspapers, bags of popcorn -- everything, that is, except stationery. 
"There are no landmarks left," Mrs. Palamarczuk said. 
Armonk, to be sure, will go on. It's a quick drive from the planned development to I-684, on the side of town closest to the North White Plains train station, and the school system is excellent. In the homes that will rise, families will arrive, the kids will grow quicker than anyone had expected, and there will be happy times. 
But there used to be open space and woods, said Bruce Knox, who grew up in Armonk and still lives here. 
When he was a boy, he said, he and his brother, Jim, used to walk through the woods from their home in the Whippoorwill section of town and get on line at Schultz's where they would pass the time by trying to predict which lump of dough would wind through the Rube Goldberg-like machine and come out as their doughnut. Though the Knox brothers would like to make one last ceremonial walk to Schultz's, they cannot. "Those condos up behind where the bowling alley used to be took the place of the woods," Mr. Knox said. 
So where will my father and his friends go to sit in the future, I asked. My father shrugged. "I guess there's the Starbucks in Mount Kisco." He paused. "And also that Starbucks in Chappaqua."

HEADLINE: THE WAY WE LIVE NOW: 2-24-02: ON LANGUAGE; 
Acronymania

BYLINE:  By William Safire

 BODY:
Who affixes glorious names to acts of Congress -- with words whose initial capital letters spell out a hard-selling acronym?
 When you ask a spokesman for the House Judiciary Committee who in the vast federal establishment came up with the u.s.a. patriot Act, you get a bravely bureaucratic, "It was a collaborative bipartisan effort of the full committee." That'll be the day. When you press further, you discover that a partial coiner was a determinedly anonymous staff member of the Senate Judiciary Committee who called the initial antiterrorism statute the Uniting and Strengthening America Act. (u.s.a. -- get it?) 
 But U.S.A. is a set of initial letters pronounced individually, not forming an acronym that can be pronounced as a word or is already a word. The key to infusing the quickly drawn legislation with a rousing title in which the flag fairly flapped came from House Judiciary. A junior staff member there named Chris Cylke achieved acronymic immortality by coming up with this inspiring moniker: Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism Act of 2001. Put it all together, and it spells patriot. 
Now join the House contribution with the Senate's name, and you get Uniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism -- the u.s.a. patriot bill, promptly signed by President Bush into law and, with a label like that, hard to criticize in any way. 
This posed a challenge to the professional acronym-creators at the Pentagon, home of fate (Fuse Arming Test Equipment, though often embarrassingly confused with a different program, Female Acceleration Tolerance Enhancement). Within that Puzzle Palace, an accidental acronym was formed when the phrase Global War on Terrorism became popular among military briefers and point-sheet writers. This group of words was initialized, as is the custom with all Department of Defense phrases; unfortunately, it produced gwot, universally pronounced with a rising inflection as "Gee-what?" The image it projects is of a brass hat scratching his head, however, which is why the phrase may be dropped from internal d.o.d. communications. 
More recently, the Students for Global Justice and other opponents of globalization who demonstrated peacefully at the World Economic Forum in New York were organized under the banner of the Anti-Capitalist Convergence. However, the initials a.c.c. hold no meaning for anyone, and capitalism is not the dirty word it used to be. To deal with questions raised by the bigwigs huddling in the Waldorf-Astoria, anarchists, Marxists and other image-makers converged to create International answer. The title is an acronym of Act Now to Stop War and End Racism. Executives inside the Waldorf suspected that the demonstrators created the title to fit the word.
Some acronyms are standing the test of time. In 1960, as optical scientists were studying maser -- from Microwave Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation -- along came the bright idea of amplifying a highly coherent beam of light, promptly dubbed a laser. (Tangent: Will somebody explain to me why every focus is now laser-focused? Lasers can guide, ignite, heat, drive and print, but focus? This is the hottest compound adjective around today, leaving all other focuses fuzzy. In Enron's 2000 annual report, the company claimed to be "laser-focused on earnings per share," at which point I should have become suspicious. End of tangent; this column is determinedly laser-unfocused.)
In Jennet Conant's coming book, "Tuxedo Park," about a social setting in which key scientists worked during World War II, the origin of radar is recounted: United States Army scientists used r.p.f., for "radio position finding," while the British preferred r.d.f., for "radio direction finding." The Navy liked "radio detection and ranging," or radar, which the British accepted by 1943. That's a partial stump word, using a first syllable and then initials; a purer stump word is hazmats, familiar to drivers of trucks containing nitroglycerine and similarly hazardous materials. 
A pure acronym -- nimby, "not in my backyard" -- long ago took hold among zoning lawyers and environmentalists. madd -- Mothers Against Drunk Driving -- has become well known, spoofed by dam, Mothers Against Dyslexia. 
The recent spate of acronymania (and do not write that as acronymphomania) can be combated only by resolute ridicule. A cartoon in Punch showed marchers under a banner titled cocoa, the Council to Outlaw Contrived and Outrageous Acronyms. This was topped by Jack Rosenthal's satire in The New York Times calling for the Action Committee to Reform Our Nation's Youth Morals.

COLD CASE SQUAD
What has become of Chandra Levy? The question about this missing person is triggered by the F.B.I.'s grim refusal to accept the phrase Cold Case squad.
Last summer, before the nation's attention turned away from the vanished Congressional aide, Jim Stewart, a CBS reporter, said that "the F.B.I. officially transferred the Chandra Levy investigation to its Cold Case unit, which has historically handled only the toughest of cases that have few clues. . . . Cold case means cold leads, few tips and little to go on."
The F.B.I. responded with an angry news release referring proudly to its Major Case squad and coldly noting, "It is not correct to call this squad the 'Cold Case' squad."
Following this up, I was informed by an F.B.I. spokesman: "It has always been the Major Case squad. Cold Case squad is used by the media, not by us. The squad that we have in our office is called the Major Case Homicide squad. We do not call it a Cold Case squad."
And as for you journalists who don't accept our official law enforcement terminology -- freeze!

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX; 
Unemployed Once, Twice . . .

BYLINE:  By NEAL GOMBERG; Neal Gomberg is a creative director who lives in Chappaqua.

 BODY:
LAST September, I joined the swelling ranks of the unemployed. I didn't actually keep a diary of my experiences, but would have had I thought of it. Nevertheless, all of the following is true.
 Tuesday, Sept. 4, 2001. Returned to work after a long, relaxing Labor Day weekend. Had just started writing ads for a new business pitch (the United States military account), when Greg entered my office, closed the door and delivered the bad news: he had to let me go. (Only in America can you salute the country's work force on Monday and be asked to leave it on Tuesday.) Greg insisted that it had nothing to do with my job performance, that I, along with more than 80 other people, was a victim of the "numbers." He wore a genuinely pained expression. So did I. 
 Wednesday, Sept. 5, 2001. Spent most of the day appreciating whoever it was who invented severance.
Friday, Sept. 7, 2001. In my new position of ex-employee, I showed Greg my final piece of ad copy. It was a bit awkward, so I resorted to gallows humor by quipping, "Hey, if the client doesn't like it, you can always say you fired the writer."
Friday, Sept. 14, 2001. I've been granted permission to use my office indefinitely. Since Sept. 11, I've been sitting at my desk, fighting off shock, fear and the urge to look for a job because to do so would be insensitive and disrespectful. Even for someone in advertising. The United States military has more important things to do (and no longer has an image problem), so the new business pitch was postponed.
Wednesday, Sept. 19, 2001. Greg entered my office and delivered good news: I was rehired. Not permanently, but who's hired permanently anymore? Here's how Greg explained it: he needed my help on the United States military pitch and I needed a job, so what the heck. 
Thursday, Sept. 20, 2001. Returned to work in my unusual position of "unemployed new employee." Everyone seemed happy to have me back. I was happy too, even though it would be bad form to complain about my job.
Thursday, Oct. 4, 2001. Called a headhunter who said it was so dead out there that she was closing her doors. Question: Who do headhunters call when they're out of work?
Friday, Oct. 12, 2001. Not very motivated to look for a job. Could it have something to do with the fact that there aren't any? I've called all my contacts and every last one of them said: "Not only are there no openings, we're laying people off."
Friday, Oct. 19, 2001. Had just completed my work on the United States military pitch when Greg entered my office and told me for the second time in six weeks, that he had to let me go.
Saturday, Nov. 3, 2001. Had a dream in which I did such a good job after being laid off that they named me "Ex-Employee of the Month."
Friday, Dec. 14, 2001. When I'm working I wish I had more spare time. Now that I have nothing but spare time, I wish I had something else: an income. I continue to make calls, but there's still nothing out there. Oh well. Not landing a job when there aren't any has to be better than not landing a job when there are dozens of them.
Tuesday, Feb. 19, 2002. The totally unexpected happened: I got a job. A good job. I start next week. I'm lucky to have gotten a job when there aren't any. I'm lucky I've been able to eat while I've been unemployed. I'm also lucky to have had the continuing support of my wife and two daughters, who are pleased, not just because I landed a job, but because I'll be spending less time at home. Finally, after giving it some serious thought, I'm prepared to make one positive statement about my unemployment experience: it ended. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester; 
Number of Million-Dollar Home Sales Rose in 2001

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH Westchester's luxury housing market staggered at times in 2001 under the weight of a national economic recession and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, it still finished the year somewhat ahead of the previous year after a spike in sales activity during the fourth quarter.
 According to numbers from the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service -- which represents more than 500 real estate offices having listings in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties -- 578 million-dollar homes in Westchester changed hands in 2001, up by 7 percent from 539 in 2000. The service said it had not compiled the total dollar value of the sales. 
 The 7 percent increase, however, falls short of the performance in the past several years, when percentage increases for volume were in the double digits, figures from the listing service show. For example, the 539 luxury homes sold in 2000 represented a 31 percent increase over 1999. And in 1999, the 410 homes that sold for $1 million or more represented a 33 percent increase over the previous year's total of 308. 
Anthony P. Cutugno, executive vice president in charge of luxury sales for Houlihan/Lawrence, said that during the first eight months of last year, sales activity in the luxury home market was sluggish. Then, after the terrorist attacks in late summer, he said, there was an eight-week period during which the real estate market almost came to a halt.
"But then the activity suddenly picked up, and the fourth quarter of 2001 ended up being very strong, especially in the very high end of the luxury category," said Mr. Cutugno, whose agency operates 25 offices in Westchester, Putnam and southern Dutchess Counties.
Some real estate agents were pleased that despite the difficulties in 2001, there was still a 7 percent climb in luxury sales. But others cautioned that the number may give a deceptively rosy impression -- especially if one factors in the effects of what P. Gilbert Mercurio, the executive director of the Westchester County Board of Realtors, called "bracket creep.
In its year-end summary of real estate activity, the Board of Realtors reported that the median price of a single-family house in 2001 rose to $449,900 -- $42,900, or 10.5 percent, more than the median a year earlier.
"Therefore, if a house was selling for $900,000 in 2000, it would probably be selling for a million in 2001," Mr. Mercurio said, explaining bracket creep. "One has to consider that when looking at any increase in sales of luxury homes." 
Figures from the Westchester-Putnam Multiple Listing Service, a subsidiary of the Westchester County Board of Realtors and the Putnam County Association of Realtors, showed that only 14 homes priced $4 million and over sold in 2001 in Westchester, compared with 21 homes in that category in 2000 -- demonstrating a weakness the very high end of the luxury market.. 
Joseph Valvano, managing broker for Coldwell Banker Ye Village Realty in Dobbs Ferry, attributed the decline in the sales of high-end luxury homes to caution of the part of buyers who were directly affected by the downturn in the stock market. But he said that the persistent lack of inventory -- which was plaguing all sectors of the Westchester residential real estate market -- was still resulting in a seller's market.
Susan Greenberg, a sales associate specializing in luxury homes for Julia B. Fee in Scarsdale, observed that bidding wars on the more desirable homes -- older homes that had been tastefully renovated and were in excellent condition, for example -- still took place last year, indicating that even though the market was slower, it was still healthy.
In general, the most sought-after luxury homes have large bathrooms, family rooms, luxury master baths with many closets and large kitchens, Mrs. Greenberg said. If a house languishes on the market, she added, it is usually because the property is priced too high.
The Multiple Listing Service showed that 24 homes sold for $3 million to $4 million in 2001; 79 properties sold in the $2 million to $3 million range; and 461 homes sold in the $1 million to $2 million category.
LAST year's sales of more than $1 million continued a trend observed in 2000: a spread into communities other than Scarsdale, Rye, Bedford and Bronxville, the localities traditionally associated with luxury sales. 
Until two years ago, for example, no homes had sold for more than $1 million in the Croton area. "Now, the $1 million mark is frequently being surpassed there," Houlihan/Lawrence reported. It sold Rolling Stone Farm, a 100-plus acre estate in the Croton area, for more than $4 million, and Long Vue, the former home of Gloria Swanson, for more than $1.5 million.
Houlihan/Lawrence, which has two high-end marketing divisions, also reported that during 2001, the luxury market continued expanding into Putnam County, especially Garrison and Cold Spring along the Hudson River. As recently as five years ago, there were no sales in excess of $1 million in all of Putnam, according to the agency, which operates one of its high-end divisions in conjunction with Sotheby's International Realty, and the other through its own Luxury Country Properties program.
Still, the most frequently listed postal addresses for $1 million-plus home sales in 2001, according to the Multiple Listing Service, continued to be Scarsdale, where 86 homes sold for $1 million and more, followed by Rye, where 80 were sold. Next on the list was Bedford with 52, followed by Harrison with 41, and then Armonk, with 36. In Chappaqua, 34 were sold; in Bronxville, 34; in Larchmont, 28; in Purchase 27; and in Pound Ridge, 23.
The highest priced home to sell last year was in Bedford for $8.5 million.
The highest-priced property still on the market in Westchester is Stonwin Farm, the family estate in Scarsdale of the noted jeweler Harry Winston, listed at $18 million.
Others on the market include: Rose Briar Hill, overlooking the Hudson River in Briarcliff, which is listed for $5.7 million; Manursing Island Manor in Rye -- which was built in 1916 for George Jay Gould, the son of railroad tycoon Jay Gould -- at $5.9 million; and Greenfields, a classic Georgian manor in Bedford, listed at $5.925 million.
Real estate agents said buyers of luxury homes represented all age groups and tended to be professionals and celebrities. Some buyers were moving from less expensive neighborhoods in Westchester to more exclusive communities, others were moving up to more expensive homes in the same communities and yet others were coming from New York City.
But Steven Meyers, president of Houlihan/Lawrence, said the surge in activity late in the year did not appear to validate a much-talked-about theory that residents of Manhattan would flee to relatively "safe havens" in the country.
F RANKLY, we saw virtually no sales emanate from people reacting to fears of terrorist attacks," he said. "The surge in sales in the fourth quarter was largely generated by a number of buyers who had been looking in the market for long periods of time who concluded that the prices and interest rates in the fourth quarter were conducive to buying."
Interest rates on mortgages as of mid-February were as low as 5.875 percent for a three-year adjustable-rate mortgage and as high as 7.125 percent for a 30-year mortgage of more than $300,700, according to the Manhattan Mortgage Company in Purchase.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The house at 130 Washington Avenue, Dobbs Ferry, which sold for $1.75 million, was one of 578 million-dollar sales in Westchester in 2001. (Photographs by John W. Wheeler for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/The Bronx; 
Prime Office Space Is Planned in Unlikely Sites

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE Bronx is not the first place most people would think of when looking for Class A office space. But two developers think the time may be ripe to entice tenants to the borough's lower rents, central location and good transportation links.
 Both plan to convert existing structures into modern office space with the power and telecommunications infrastructure that most tenants demand today. Both are doing preliminary work at their sites, but neither intends to proceed further without signing an anchor tenant. Both claim to have deals close to signing. 
 The Simone Development Company of New Rochelle has already attracted attention -- not all of it welcome -- with its plans to convert part of the former Bronx Developmental Center, a onetime state mental health facility, into offices and, if demand develops from biotechnology companies, laboratory space. The company has begun demolishing the interior of the 330,000-square-foot building and plans to modify the saw-toothed outer walls to produce a squared-off shape containing 450,000 square feet of space.
This has brought outcries from preservationists, who have bemoaned any change to the building, which was designed by Richard Meier and which features elongated porthole windows and an aluminum-colored skin.
Although the AIA Guide to New York calls the building "a consummate work of architecture," the fact that it has sat empty for several years demonstrates that its layout is inefficient for most uses, said Joseph Simone, the president of Simone Development. "The floor plates do not work for anything except maybe a dormitory and psychiatric center," he said. "We are squaring off the building to eliminate the saw-tooth."
He also plans to eliminate the porthole windows and replace them with rectangular office windows and to replace the aluminum-colored outer skin with white aluminum panels.
Mr. Simone said the 350,000-square-foot building is to be the first phase at the 18.5-acre site, which he bought from the state of New York last May for $3.7 million. The state still owns part of the original tract, which has other buildings on it. Depending on demand, up to 1 million square feet of space could be built at the Simone site, which is near the Hutchinson River Parkway in the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx. The complex will be known as the Hutchinson Metro Center.
"Joe Simone is spending massive amounts of money" on the conversion, said Steve Kane, a broker with the Tamerlane Realty Corporation, who specializes in Bronx properties. He said prospective tenants for new developments in the area, in addition to private business, could come from such public institutions as colleges and hospitals. He said what little modern office space exists in the Bronx is already occupied. "There's no space to lease," he said.
Other brokers noted that the Bronx had recently been attractive to retail developers recently, with Home Depot, Pathmark and Target Stores planning or building large projects in the borough.
Not far away, in the East Tremont section of the borough, a building that formerly housed the warehouse and distribution center for the Loehmann's clothing stores is also being offered for redevelopment into modern office space. The developer is a joint venture of the Dedona Contracting Corporation, an area builder, and the Westchester Creek Corporation, which has a long-term lease on about 18 acres of land in the area as a result of an urban development program dating back to the Lindsay administration.
LOEHMANN'S has relocated its warehousing and distribution operations to northern New Jersey, but is planning to keep its headquarters and buying offices in the building, which is at 2500 Halsey Street, said Joseph Dedona of Dedona Construction. He said Loehmann's would occupy 40,000 square feet of space at one end of the 152,000-square-foot building, unlike its current situation, where the offices are spread out around the structure. Loehmann's will continue to own the building, said Arnold Spellun, a lawyer who is the principal owner of Westchester Creek.
If another substantial tenant signs a lease, the joint venture is prepared to convert the rest of the warehouse into one-story, high-ceiling office space. "We have Loehmann's," Mr. Dedona said. "One more tenant and we're ready to go."
In addition to converting the existing building, the developer is prepared to build a new structure of five or six stories next to it if demand warrants. The addition could swell the project into a total of 389,000 square feet of space.
One attraction of office space in the Bronx for tenants is lower rents than Manhattan and some parts of the suburbs. Annual rents for prime space in the borough range from "the high $20's to low $30's" a square foot, according to Mark A. Jaccom, an executive vice president of Julien J. Studley, a brokerage that generally represents tenants but is working in this case for the developer.
Mr. Jaccom said the East Tremont location could prove attractive to companies seeking to improve their security by spreading their operations over several locations because of the good subway, bus and highway links to other parts of the city.
Economic incentives from the city -- mostly property tax abatements -- make the area attractive to developers. "I have office buildings in Westchester County, and I know you cannot cover the costs of new construction there," Mr. Dedona said. "In the city, with the incentives, you can cover the cost of construction. Besides, there is almost no Class A space available here."
The city has been trying for decades to foster economic development in the area, according to Mr. Spellun. "During the Lindsay administration, the city set up the Zerega Avenue industrial urban renewal project, which still exists." About 100 acres of land, then covered with scrap yards and auto body shops, were acquired by condemnation, he said. The Westchester Creek company, named after an inlet of water off the East River that comes within 25 yards of the Loehmann's property, took a 90-year lease on its share of the assembled property.
"One of the problems with redevelopment in the city is getting big chunks of land," Mr. Spellun said. "This was similar to what the city did in College Point," an area in northern Queens.
He said a building in the eastern Bronx would be attractive for its low costs compared with Manhattan and some suburbs, the access to a nearby work force and the good transportation links. "The Cross Bronx, New England Expressway, Hutchinson and Bruckner all intersect within 300 yards of here," he said.
And the image of the Bronx as a place with a high level of crime is outdated, Mr. Kane said. "Loehmann's ran a two shift operation here," and employees walked several blocks at night to the nearest subway stop, he said.
