HEADLINE: Deciding Whether To Make a Home Near Ground Zero 

BYLINE:  By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
THE Reynolds family has a choice to make, and Mary Reynolds is of two minds. Part of her wants to move permanently out of the Gateway Plaza development at Battery Park City, taking advantage of the owner's offer to let any tenant leave by March 31 with no financial penalty for breaking the lease. 
 But another part of her wants to stay. She has lived in Gateway for 12 years and is raising four daughters there. She considers it a community. 
 "I never felt fully safe here after the '93 bombing at the trade center," Mrs. Reynolds said, "and after Sept. 11 people said I was crazy to come back. But this is a very special place. We were a neighborhood. We had a park, a promenade, a river and sailing on the river. It was safe. The children could be independent at an early age. I still don't know what we'll do." 
Ambivalence about staying or leaving is a persistent refrain among many of the families in Battery Park City's two residential neighborhoods, the North and South, after the catastrophe at the World Trade Center close by on Sept. 11. Brokers and building owners report that in several buildings over 25 percent of the tenants have moved away permanently since then. Others have come back, sometimes to different apartments. Many seem to be uncertain about how long they will stay.
But for those dedicated to the future of Battery Park City, the emphasis now is on restoring, rebuilding and reoccupying, on getting the nation's largest master-planned in-city community back on track. Whatever the decision of long-term tenants, it is the new arrivals who are providing the most optimistic outlook and perhaps the more patient attitude about the area's future.
Last week, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, a governmental agency formed in November by the governor and the mayor, proposed grants totaling $200 million to people committed to staying in lower Manhattan or moving there for at least two years. Earlier, the Battery Park City Authority announced its own incentive program for residents, totaling $15.6 million.
It was not clear last week whether the benefit under the authority's program would be deducted from the larger benefit anticipated under the development corporation's proposed program. Leasing agents expect the new incentives to stimulate rental activity. 
There are 6,400 apartments at Battery Park City, 4,200 of them in pure-rental buildings, many recently completed in the North neighborhood, which builders call TriBeCa West. The rest of the apartments, 2,200 of them, are in condominium buildings in the South neighborhood. 
Many of these are occupied by their owners, who by and large have stayed put since Sept. 11. But others are held by outside investors, who rent them out to corporations and individuals. As in other rentals, vacancies are above normal, with some condominium owners resorting to short-term leases as well as lower rents to bolster income.
The apartments that sustained the most blast and smoke damage in the attack were in Gateway, in the center of Battery Park City between the two major residential neighborhoods. It is the largest and oldest of the developments, with 1,700 rental apartments in a six-building complex built and owned by the Lefrak Organization.
Market rents for vacancies had reached $2,800 for some mid-level one-bedrooms and $3,700 for two-bedrooms by last September. Average rents are down roughly 20 percent, according to Lefrak executives. 
The occupancy includes many long-term tenants with school-aged children. The Lefrak Organization says that 30 percent of the tenants have either left for good already or have notified management that they intend to.
Explanations for departures are not hard to find. Some leave because of dissatisfaction with air quality and other environmental factors, and doubt over when or whether normalcy can be restored. Others leave because of job losses or relocations. Many are unwilling to put up with inconveniences of uncertain duration, or they are disheartened by the disruption of community life and the departure of friends. The very trauma of the events of Sept. 11 was enough to keep some away.
In the weeks after Sept. 11 prospective new renters came mainly in search of bargains. They found them. In many cases apartments went to people relatively unfamiliar not only with Battery Park City but also with downtown itself. Rents for vacant apartments were down by 20 to 25 percent, rental agents say, and in some cases as much as 30 percent after negotiations. More recently they report reductions from pre-September market rates are closer to 15 to 25 percent, depending on the building.
At a building called Tribeca Pointe in the North neighborhood, Douglas Babbin and his fiancee, Elizabeth Cook, rented a 12th-floor two-bedroom two-bath apartment overlooking the Hudson River in December. The rent was $3,450 a month, down from $3,800 for the previous tenant.
"We had been trying to find something reasonable since last May," said Mr. Babbin, a 44-year-old financial adviser who had been living in Murray Hill. "We checked Battery Park City but didn't think we could get a good deal. Then after Sept. 11 rents went down drastically and we saw a good opportunity."
With so many apartments available, the couple was able to shop the market without feeling under pressure to make a decision quickly or risk losing the apartment, Mr. Babbin said. "There was breathing room to evaluate all the apartments that were available."
AT another North neighborhood building, Tribeca Bridge Tower, leasing agents said that last summer one-bedrooms were renting for $2,500 to $2,800, two-bedrooms for $3,700 to $4,900, and three-bedrooms for $5,300 to $6,200. After Sept. 11, new tenants were negotiating deals at 25 to 30 percent below former rents, said Stephen V. Maschi, the leasing director. Current rents for vacant apartments are 15 to 20 percent below the market rents before Sept. 11, he said.
Tribeca Bridge Tower is a three-year-old project with 150 apartments rising above an elementary and intermediate school. Between 40 and 50 tenants left for good after September, Mr. Maschi said. To induce others to stay on, a rent abatement was offered, averaging 20 percent for 20 months, ending May 31 of next year. 
At a building in the South neighborhood called Liberty View, Dorota Orczyk and her husband, Shane Ojar, decided that even a direct view of the trade-center site was no disincentive to renting. Three weeks ago the couple took a two-bedroom apartment on the 19th floor, with a bird's-eye view of the site looking north from one bedroom. They left a $2,400-a-month one-bedroom near Gramercy Park and rented a two-bedroom one-bath apartment for $2,250.
"We have always liked the area," said Ms. Orczyk, who expects her first child next month. "The view doesn't bother us. It's amazing to see the progress being made every day."
But recovery requires more than lower rents. The public will ultimately have to be reassured on environmental safety and air quality, owners and leasing agents say. Economic revival downtown is also necessary.
Tenant satisfaction will be affected as well by the speed and efficiency with which the Battery Park City Authority succeeds in restoring public amenities and ease of access to the entire 92-acre site. At present north-to-south traffic on West Street, both pedestrian and vehicular, is closed off from Chambers Street to the entrance to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, making it awkward for residents to drive or walk to destinations outside Battery Park City itself.
Much of the major restoration and improvement work on public spaces will get under way in March and April, said Timothy S. Carey, president of the authority. Construction of a temporary bridge over West Street at Rector Street is scheduled to start April 1, with completion four to six weeks later. In early April an emergency high-tension electric wire that now runs across the property is to be removed, clearing the way for repairs to streets, curbs, sidewalks and the esplanade along the river, as well as the restoration of normal north and south pedestrian traffic within Battery Park City.
The delayed construction of a 1.9-acre park, tentatively named Teardrop Park, in the North neighborhood is to begin in April. Even earlier, in March, reconstruction is to start on the ball fields that were commandeered for heavy rescue equipment after the attack. A United Artists theater with 16 screens will reopen in April or May, Mr. Carey said, and a closed Embassy Suites hotel is also scheduled to reopen in May.
Another incentive to tenants to stay, and for new tenants to move in, is a $15.6 million disaster relief package that the authority said earlier this month had been authorized by the governor, the mayor and the city comptroller. The amount that will paid roughly equals three months of payments due to the authority for land rent, payments that the authority passes on to the city in lieu of property taxes, and other fees.
Residents in the pure-rental buildings could start receiving checks as early as June of this year, Mr. Carey said. New tenants arriving before July 1 will also be eligible for these payments. In the pure-rental buildings this averages $1,846 an apartment, but the actual amount per apartment will differ depending upon how the charges are apportioned by owners to apartments of differing characteristics. When individuals are named on the lease, payments will go directly from the authority to the tenant. The method of dealing with corporate entities has not been decided.
In the condominiums the benefit would average $2,850 an apartment. As of last week no final determination had been made on how the money would be dispersed. The direct beneficiary presumably could be the owner, whether a resident or an outside investor, or it could be resident-owners only and lessees of the apartments, whether a corporation or an individual, in the case of nonresident owners.
One of the knottiest real-estate problems arising out of the drop in apartment rents in Battery Park City involves these condominiums. There are 11 of them, out of a total 27 residential buildings, counting the six-building Gateway complex as one building. Not only ownership but also leasing management is dispersed.
Because of the economic downturn, renting was weak even before Sept. 11. A survey in late January by Empire State Properties, a brokerage that handles the leasing for many investor-owners, found the overall vacancy rate in the condominiums to be 28 percent. 
TEN of the condominium buildings began a "rent strike" in September, withholding from the authority payments due for land rent, payments in lieu of property taxes and other fees. The 11th condominium, Hudson View West, was barred from taking this step by a court settlement in a lawsuit over nonpayment of these charges in the 90's. At least 60 apartments are operated on a rental basis in Hudson View West, Empire State Properties said. The building has 108 apartments.
"The decline in rental income has been a disaster for our condominiums," said Eugene Glazer, chairman of the Battery Park City Homeowners Coalition and a retired financial consultant who has been the owner-occupant of a condominium in the Regatta, on South End Avenue, since 1989. Investor-owners are not collecting the revenue they need to keep up with their expenses, said Mr. Glazer, who owns only the apartment in which he lives.
In discussions with the coalition the Battery Park City Authority has insisted that it has no authority to modify its charges, and it has notified the condominiums that it intends to pursue the full amount that it is owed -- about $13 million. However, the discussions are continuing, the authority said.
Another problem for a few condominiums arises from the leasing policy of some investor-owners. Weak demand for apartments compels them to offer ever-shorter lease terms, which itself becomes a management problem for the building and raises its operating expenses. "Short-term occupancy undermines the viability of residential condominiums," Mr. Glazer said. But forcing owners to make leases longer in a weak market could seriously damage the finances of some condominiums, owners say.
The Regatta, with 80 percent resident ownership, adopted strong measures against excessive short-term occupancy, including a cap of 7 percent on the number of apartments that can be owned by a single entity, Mr. Glazer said.
Even among investor owners there are distinctions. The largest among them is the Milstein Organization, the builder of four condominiums with 1,400 apartments in the South neighborhood. Milstein has sold many, but it still owns 575 condominiums. In one building, the 293-unit Liberty View, 150 apartments are furnished and rented out on leases running a minimum of one month. Milstein also manages these apartments. 
Other condominiums have more dispersed ownership, but no building-by-building breakdown of the percentage of resident as opposed to investor ownership is available. 
At the Cove Club condominium, Simone Wegge, an assistant professor of economics at the CUNY campus on Staten Island, and her husband, Victor Valdivia, who runs an investment research firm, bought a two-bedroom apartment at the Cove Club condominium for about $460,000 in the summer of 2000. They lived there for several months, then moved to a rental on Staten Island in March 2001 after Ms. Wegge took her present job.
"We rented out our apartment on a six-month lease for a rent that was high enough to cover our costs," Ms. Wegge said. "But in November rents were down about 40 percent. We got a tenant for three months at a rent 35 percent below our previous rent. We were running a deficit of $1,500 a month. Then the tenant moved and now the apartment is vacant."
In pure-rental buildings, many of the rent reductions for existing tenants were agreed upon in negotiations with tenant associations. One lawyer, Jack L. Lester, said he represented associations in eight downtown buildings, including four at Battery Park City. The settlements reached ranged from reductions of 20 percent to 30 percent, depending upon the amount of damage a building sustained. Reductions run from four months to as long as two years. Once the reduction expires, the rent goes back to the previous rent, which becomes the base for calculating future increases.
Mr. Lester said that he still has three open cases in Battery Park City -- 50 and 70 Battery Park Place and 333 Rector Place. About a third of the tenants are withholding rent those buildings, he said.
At Gateway, the Lefrak Organization had to undertake a major reconstruction job, especially in Building 600, which had significant damage. Apartments there could not be occupied for three months. The eastern face of Building 600 is not scheduled to reopen until April or May.
Gateway tenants were charged no rent while they could not occupy, and they were given 30 days of free rent from the time the owner declared their building ready for occupancy. Tenants who had been paying less than Sept. 11 market rents were also given a rent credit of 15 percent, lasting for one year from the end of the free-rent period and calculated on their September rent. 
The rent credit was an inducement for long-term tenants to come back. For newer tenants, who were paying closer to the market rent last September, rents were adjusted to put them in line with the schedule adopted for new leases after Sept. 11, which is approximately 20 percent lower than the one used previously. In the new schedule rents on the middle floors of the buildings average $1,500 a month for studios, $1,900 for one-bedrooms and $3,000 for two-bedrooms, but specific rents may vary greatly from the average based on the floor, the exposure and the building itself.
UNDER an agreement reached in 1995 and running until 2005, tenants in occupancy when the agreement started get lease-renewal increases that follow the guidelines of the rent-stabilization system. Currently, these increases are 4 percent on a one-year lease and 6 percent on a two-year lease. Tenants at Gateway pay free-market rents on their initial lease and guideline increases on renewal. The system applies regardless of the level of the initial rent.
The leasing agent for new tenants at Gateway is Empire State Properties, whose principals, Suzanne Miller and Deborah Hildreth, are longtime Gateway tenants themselves. Their company has handled condominium rentals in Battery Park City for seven years. It was hired by the Lefrak Organization in December, and it has leased out 160 apartments to new arrivals since then.
The typical new Gateway renter is a single person or a couple with no children, Ms. Miller said. "The overwhelming number of vacancies were in our studios and one-bedrooms," she said. "I myself know 10 families who had to move their children to two different schools in the weeks after Sept. 11, and now they don't want to move them a third time to come back to P.S. 89." P.S. 89, in a new building in the North neighborhood, is scheduled to reopen on Thursday; the intermediate school in the same building reopened in January.
Many of the new arrivals are graduate students who plan to stay one to four years, Ms. Miller said. Only six of the new arrivals have school-age children. The average age of new tenants is 30.
A total of 180 Gateway tenants have moved to different apartments within Gateway itself, taking advantage of vacancies to improve their housing situation. Others have moved elsewhere in Battery Park City. Among the latter is Enzo Bono and his family -- his wife, Tina, and their daughters Nicole, 11, and Elisa, 5. Their two-bedroom $3,200-a-month apartment in Building 600 overlooked the trade center site.
In January the Bonos rented a two-bedroom apartment on the eighth floor of 22 River Terrace, a Rockrose Development Corporation building along the river, and converted it to a three-bedroom. The view is to the northwest. The rent is no higher than they paid before -- $3,200 a month.
The couple has been living in Battery Park City since 1987. "I like the location," said Mr. Bono, who works in the freight-forwarding business at Kennedy International Airport. "I didn't feel like running away. Once the reconstruction starts, everything should get back to normal. Eventually I will look to buy."

HEADLINE: 'It Takes a Lot of Courage To Do Something New' 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
 SHIRA P. WHITE contends that American companies need to be more creative, yet one company she wrote about, Enron, took creativity to a level that proved its downfall. In an interview, she spoke about striking the right creative balance. WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

Q. Did Enron's executives cross the line from creativity to something else?

A. The jury is still out about what they actually did. They may have done illegal things and they may have done immoral things, but they may also have had some good ideas. I think we should separate out the good ideas from the bad things and see if they have some application. There is a really big difference between creativity and illegality.

Q. Is true innovation still occurring despite all the bad things that have happened in the economy?

A. Yes, I believe so and really hope so. Now it's even more important for people and companies to be creative and to get creative about the tight spots they're in. The worse the economy, the more creative you have to be.

Q. Why aren't American companies more creative in what you consider the right kind of way?

A. For most companies, it hasn't been a priority. They don't screen employees on the basis of creativity. Their systems are not designed for creativity, but rather efficiency.

Q. Do you think executives manage too much by the numbers?

A. Yes, it is largely numbers-oriented. Even on a psychological level, people are resistant to creativity. People don't want to rock the boat or make waves. It's easier to do it the way it's always been done. It takes a lot of courage to do something new.

Q. You wrote that the average corporate brainstorming session doesn't really work. Why doesn't it?

A. Most of the time, it doesn't work because in most organizations, it's an isolated activity. They'll call a brainstorming session, bring in a facilitator, sit around for an afternoon and come up with all sorts of ideas. But the ideas aren't based on any preparation. Then, afterward, people go back to their offices and nothing ever happens. The ideas collect dust.

Q. What's wrong with the innovation process at most companies, then?

A. Most companies don't even have one. If you walk into 90 percent of organizations and ask, "Do you have an innovation process?" the answer would be no. You'd get puzzled looks.

Q. Now that the technology bubble has popped, some people think that America's most innovative days are gone. Do you?

A. I don't think our creative juices are shot. Do we have more creative days ahead of us? I think so. There is certainly higher awareness for the need for higher creativity and innovation than ever before.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
What Goes Around Comes Around -- Including Blame

BYLINE:  By David Kocieniewski; David Kocieniewski is Trenton bureau chief for The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
It's only been a month since James E. McGreevey assumed the throne of New Jersey politics, but already the state Republicans are shocked -- shocked! -- at the shrill sound of partisanship emanating from the Governor's lips.
 After spending the campaign assailing Republicans who controlled Trenton for 10 years for their borrowing and spending, Mr. McGreevey has devoted much of his first few months in the limelight, well, assailing Republicans for borrowing and spending. 
 His inaugural address was peppered with pointed references to the "irresponsible borrowing and runaway spending" of his predecessors. His budget address expanded on that theme to describe the Republican reign as "a failure of will, a failure of courage, a failure of leadership." 
Mr. McGreevey's aides have conducted so many news conferences to remind New Jerseyeans his predecessors created the state's budget mess that it wouldn't be surprising to find that he had changed the state symbol to a pointed index finger, with the motto "They Did It!"
Not surprisingly, the "they" Mr. McGreevey refers to, are not amused. Assemblywoman Rose Heck has accused the Governor of "trying to beat up" on her and fellow Republicans. Joseph Kyrillos, State Republican chairman, has repeatedly exhorted the Governor to stop the "campaign rhetoric." The Senate co-president, John O. Bennett, has compared the governor to Chicken Little and urged him to mute the partisan insults before they hinder attempts to solve the state's budget problems. 
This newfound Republican pacifism might be slightly more persuasive if the party hadn't spent the past decade blasting Democrats for the sins of Jim Florio. Governor Florio, you may recall, was elected in 1989 and quickly pushed a through a tax increase that led angry voters to cast Democrats into exile for nearly a decade. 
Mr. McGreevey's victory in November took some of the sting out of that charge. But don't be fooled; the specter of the Florio tax hike and its ensuing electoral disaster still hang heavy over Mr. McGreevey's head. During the campaign, Bret Schundler, the Republican candidate, badgered Mr. McGreevey for weeks about taxes, until Mr. McGreevey finally made a promise not to increase taxes. 
Since taking office, he's been desperately trying to make himself some wiggle room on the issue by explaining that he only promised not to raise the sales or income tax. That way, if the economic downturn forces him to enact a tax increase, Mr. McGreevey can at least defend himself against charges that he broke his promise. But either way, he knows that any increase will give Republicans ammunition to attack him as the second coming of Florio.
That's the trouble with mudslinging. Voters tell pollsters they hate it. Politicians insist they abhor it. Often, though, an attack ad or a biting retort can be highly effective. 
The trick is knowing how far to push your criticism and how long your charges will resonate. But it is, at best, an inexact science, because there is no statute of limitations for political blame. 
Some tribal societies still wage wars to avenge grudges from past centuries past. Middle Eastern political leaders stoke anti-American sentiment by invoking the Crusaders, even though the Crusades ended hundreds of years before the American Declaration of Independence. 
Here at home, attention spans tend to be shorter, forcing political combatants to focus on the more immediate past. During the presidential primary of 2000, for instance, Senator John McCain was able to present himself as the candidate who would end the influence of big money in politics. Never mind that in 1991 Mr. McCain was rebuked by the Senate ethics committee as one of the Keating Five -- a group of senators who intervened with federal regulators on behalf of Charles Keating, a political donor who owned a troubled savings and loan and was eventually jailed for fraud. In modern presidential politics, that was apparently ancient history.
As Mr. McGreevey begins his term, he'll have to gauge very carefully how long the public will allow him to blame Republicans for the pain his budget cuts are certain to inflict. Conventional wisdom among New Jersey Democrats is that Mr. Florio compounded the anger about his tax increase by failing to prepare the public for it adequately . So Mr. McGreevey's carping about the budget woes, and his constant reminders that the debt was run up while Republicans were in power, can be seen as a very vocal attempt to avoid repeating that mistake. 
But the governor must also be careful not to pound Republican leaders so hard that he completely alienates them. Although Democrats control the Assembly and have a 20-20 split in the Senate, the bad medicine in Mr. McGreevey's coming budget will be much easier for the public to swallow if it is approved by a bipartisan vote in the Legislature. If the state resorts to tax increases during Mr. McGreevey's tenure, which some Democrats fear is likely, that, too, would be made more politically palatable by a few Republican votes. 
For now, the Governor can revel in the fact that there is only one real megaphone in New Jersey politics, and it belongs to whoever is governor.
He'd do well to remember, however, that during all the years the Republicans were ridiculing Jim Florio, they never needed to ask him for his vote.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Insurers Find Profit in a New Risk Consciousness

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
THE insurance industry has long depended on fear of the unforeseen. Lately, the unforeseen has created a boom for a type of insurance coverage that has been around for years -- protection from political turmoil.
 Events of the last six months -- from the World Trade Center attacks and the United States war on terrorism to the economic crisis in Argentina -- have jolted multinational companies into remembering that the world is a dangerous place to do business. 
 Many American corporations with overseas operations have been rushing to buy special insurance to protect themselves not only against terrorism, riots, civil war, strikes and coups d'etat, but also against nationalization and government interference with the flow of profits back home.
"There's a new risk consciousness," said John M. Minor, a senior executive at Aon, one of the largest commercial insurance brokers. "It's a different attitude, maybe a sense of vulnerability, that we didn't have before Sept. 11." 
At some insurance companies, sales have doubled for what is known as political risk coverage. Patricia L. Skold, in charge of such insurance at the Chubb Group, said it had received 1,500 applications for coverage in the last six months, up from an estimated 750 in the comparable period a year earlier.
Companies that had never bought the specialized coverage are now signing up; others are expanding coverage. In many cases, terrorism coverage previously was included in general property policies at little or no extra charge. But now many property insurers are refusing to provide terrorism coverage in that way, meaning that corporations must buy it separately or as part of a political risk package.
One big pharmaceutical company had been operating around the world for years without political risk coverage. But in November, Mr. Minor said, it paid $1 million for $70 million in coverage on its plants and sales offices in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Peru. He said it was considering extending the coverage to its operations in Asia.
Just last Tuesday, Ms. Skold said, a company that makes and installs telecommunications equipment in Africa completed a deal with Chubb to nearly triple its policy, to $30 million from $11 million.
Political risk coverage is one of the most expensive and, for insurers, one of the most profitable of products. For example, $50 million of comprehensive political risk coverage can easily cost $625,000 to $1.75 million a year, compared with $75,000 to $175,000 for the same amount of standard property and casualty coverage for international operations. The prices are high because the businesses that need the coverage are in intrinsically risky situations. Claims are rarely filed, but without such coverage, a corporation would be vulnerable to events that could wallop its bottom line. 
INSURERS calculate premiums based partly on what they call "country risk" -- an evaluation that considers factors like corruption and political unrest. Angola, where a civil war has simmered for decades, is considered a riskier country than South Africa, for example.
Insurers also look at the nature of the business to be insured, said Mr. Minor, who is in charge of political risk coverage at Aon. A chemical plant, he said, is a riskier proposition than a cannery; joint ventures with local partners are more likely to go wrong than businesses in which the foreign owner has more control; and high-technology companies are less likely to become targets for government takeover than some other businesses because their success depends upon highly skilled managers. These days, as the United States pursues Al Qaeda and Osama bin Laden, countries like Pakistan, India, Bangladesh, Yemen, Sudan and other Islamic nations top the insurers' list of risky places to do business.
Risks can rise unexpectedly because of events elsewhere. When President Bush labeled Iraq, Iran and North Korea an "axis of evil" in his State of the Union address, for example, many executives at American businesses abroad cringed.
"It just increased the uncertainty and nervousness," Mr. Minor said.
Insurers who specialize in political risk coverage say they also see a surge in a related coverage -- export credit insurance, which enables American corporations shipping goods abroad to collect the money they are owed even if their customers fail to pay.
In one such deal that reflected nervousness over Brazil's financial stability, the American International Group and a European insurer sold coverage to Embraer, the Brazilian aircraft manufacturer, on its purchase of $150 million worth of aircraft engines and avionics parts. Embraer paid for the insurance to protect its lender, a syndicate of banks led by J. P. Morgan Chase, in the event that an economic crisis in Brazil prevented Embraer from repaying the loan.
While Lloyds of London has been offering coverage on almost any peril for hundreds of years, political risk insurance began to be sold widely in the 1970's as American and European businesses rapidly expanded manufacturing and sales around the world, in search of low-cost labor and new markets. To encourage the international business, the United States set up the Overseas Private Investment Corporation to provide financing and insurance for American companies. But there was more work than it could handle, so in 1978, A.I.G. began offering political risk coverage. Now several units at Lloyds and half a dozen private insurers offer it. The World Bank, as well as some European governments, also provide the coverage.
UNLIKE most other types of insurance, political risk coverage grants ownership of the insured property to the insurance company if it must pay a claim. The insurer is then free to sell the property.
When that happens, said Ms. Skold at Chubb, insurers often cannot get back all they paid out. But, she said, the money they do recover adds significantly to an already very profitable line of business.
A.I.G., for example, became majority owner of a gold mine in Guadalcanal that an Australian company abandoned after civil war broke out in the Solomon Islands nearly two years ago. A.I.G. paid the mining company's claim under its $35 million policy and expects to sell its share of the mine. "We expect to achieve a substantial recovery," said John J. Salinger, president of A.I.G.'s political risk unit. 
Sometimes, insurers may need years to get their money back. In 1984, A.I.G. insured $25 million in logging equipment sold to a government agency in West Africa. A.I.G. said the government refused to pay, so the insurer paid its client and sought to recover the money. "We had to wait for a new government to come to power," Mr. Salinger said. "But when they did, we negotiated a repayment schedule." This year, he said, A.I.G. expects to receive the final payment.
Recovery of property and money can require negotiations with national governments. In many cases, that means talking to the chief of state. To increase its political influence, A.I.G. created a separate company for political risk coverage and recruited a board of high-profile former diplomats and government officials including Henry A. Kissinger; Richard C. Holbrooke, the former United States Ambassador to the United Nations; and Moeen Quereshi, who served briefly as the prime minister of Pakistan in the early 1990's.
The political risk insurance business has grown in spurts. "Every time there is a new crisis, demand goes up," Mr. Salinger said. 
But that is exactly the wrong time to buy insurance. "When the risk and demand go up simultaneously," Mr. Salinger said, "the rates go up, too."

HEADLINE: BOOK VALUE; 
Finding the Wellspring Of Corporate Creativity

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN 

 BODY:
DAVID DITZEL had a prestigious research job at Sun Microsystems in 1995 but was spending too much time in meetings that didn't matter much to him. "I didn't like where things were heading, and I didn't believe in the vision, so I became demotivated," he is quoted as saying in a new book. "I had to force myself to go off and think of something new." He quit his job and founded Transmeta, which has a radical new approach to making semiconductors.
 Mr. Ditzel is an example of a "hip, hot and happening" innovator, or "H3 ," portrayed in the book, "New Ideas About New Ideas: Insights on Creativity from the World's Leading Innovators," by Shira P. White, a New York-based consultant (Perseus Publishing, $26). The term H3 may make readers roll their eyes, as Ms. White acknowledges, but don't let the instant cliche deter you. Her book -- which she wrote with G. Patton Wright, whom she describes as a writing coach and mentor -- is filled with insight about the creative process and is presented most engagingly. It is precisely in these tough economic times, she contends, when innovation has a black eye because of the bursting of the dot-com bubble and the collapse of incubators like IdeaLab, that true innovators keep pushing ahead with a search for "leap innovation." 
 Much ink has been spilled on the topic of innovation, but Ms. White approaches the subject in a fresh way, partly because of her background and training. She had been a painter but decided to get a master's degree in business administration at New York University. Ms. White tells how she butted heads with one professor of management of information systems: The professor gave the class an assignment. Ms. White came up with a novel solution, but got a D. The reason, she remembers the professor saying, was that it wasn't the answer the professor was seeking. The business mind, it seemed to Ms. White, was closed to creative solutions. 
Since getting her degree, Ms. White has led something of a dual life. She has served as an instructor at the Pratt Institute and a lecturer at New York University's School of Visual Arts. She also started a consulting business, SPWI -- the letters are her initials, plus "I" for innovation -- which helps companies innovate. 
For "New Ideas," Ms. White interviewed a mix of 100 artists and sculptors and architects as well as business leaders at America Online, Corning, EMC, Enron, Genzyme, I.B.M. Research, ImClone Systems, Microsoft, Palm, Progressive Insurance and others.
Obviously, at least one of these companies has been too creative. Ms. White met and quotes Enron's former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, and former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, discussing their pursuit of creative people for their staff and their expansion into new lines of business. She was able to adjust many of her references to Enron because much of the news about the company's collapse happened just before the book went to press this month. The fact remains, however, that the company was in many ways an innovator, coming up with a new market for trading commodities and for hedging, among other things. 
ImClone, another company that figures prominently in the book, has encountered problems in trying to have its new anti-cancer drug approved by the Food and Drug Administration. 
And her praise of Corning, a leader in fiber optics, and IdeaLab, the technology venture capital firm, overlook some harsh realities: Corning lost $5.5 billion last year and idled many factories because of the global glut in fiber optic cable, and investors in IdeaLab have sued its founder, Bill Gross, accusing him of squandering their money.
But none of that detracts from the overall message that Ms. White offers. As was the case with Mr. Ditzel, the best innovators find it hard to work in an organization that is too wedded to the status quo. In traditional organizations, "people who have investments in the 'old model' are not always happy to see new talent coming along with a bright and shiny new design," Ms. White writes.
"Typically, the need to change is in conflict with the need to stay the same," she adds.
SHE says the best way for top executives to encourage innovation is to spot the talent in the company, then give these people enormous room to run and expose them to other influences, whether art or different scientific disciplines. 
The point is to create what she called a "spark soup" of data and thought-sharing from which new ideas emerge. "New things don't tend to come out of heavy organization," she writes.
Some executives, like Corning's former chairman, Roger G. Ackerman, even allow ideas they don't like to percolate. They also encourage innovators to play around with their mistakes. The company, she argues, has a "new-idea culture."
Elsewhere, she writes that true innovators do their best work when they have emotional connections to others in their research unit. Ms. White quotes Mr. Gross, of IdeaLab, as arguing that researchers should be organized as "tribes" doing battle against other tribes. That allows for "greater intimacy, better communications and more camaraderie," the author says.
Reflecting her artistic background, Ms. White writes that too many executives attempt to make decisions strictly by the numbers. The numbers, like returns on investment, often don't capture "mushy stuff" like the quality of a company's employees and the value of brands and customer bases, she says.
One surprise in the book is that Ms. White finds creativity in companies that aren't widely known for innovation: Progressive Insurance, Welch Foods and Capital One Financial, for example. Progressive, now the No. 4 insurer in the country, has turned auto insurance upside down by figuring out ways to offer lower rates in many cases and changing the way accident victims repair their cars. Rather than giving a customer an estimate to take to a repair shop, which encourages both the customer and repair shop to pad the bill, Progressive takes charge of the repairs and has them done at a lower cost.
THE company's chairman, Peter Lewis, told Ms. White that he got some of his best ideas when he swam -- with a tape recorder poised at each end of the pool. "I've solved most of my problems at the end of the workday, in a somewhat altered state of consciousness," Mr. Lewis said.
Aside from the broad lessons on creativity, the book offers compelling personal accounts of how brilliant people create new things. The sensational design that Frank Gehry developed for the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, started when Mr. Lewis of Progressive Insurance hired the architect in 1989 to design and build his dream house. "I started playing with movements, making shapes that are dynamic and have a quality of movement to them," Mr. Gehry said in the book. One thing led to another, and the design morphed into a museum. 
Many creative people play with ideas and concepts that suddenly blossom, Ms. White concludes. Her innovators often pursue projects in unrelated spheres of life, all at the same time. Sometimes they need immersion in the spark soup; at other times, they need isolation to work all night on new inspirations. 
"New Ideas" has an inspirational quality to it, but not in a crass "lose 10 pounds in five days" way. Even if the technology bubble has popped and Enron has crashed, American creativity isn't over. No one can put innovation in a bottle, but we can keep learning about how to do it better. Ms. White's book will encourage readers to do that.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
An Art of Realism Amid Recession And Budget Cuts

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE; E-mail: fee@nytimes.com

 BODY:
MAURINE D. KNIGHTON, executive director of 651 Arts, wants to make one thing clear: her arts organization is no victim. 
 No. Not even as she talks about cuts of $250,000 in a $1.25 million annual budget for a group that bills itself as Brooklyn's premier presenter of African diaspora arts. The cuts do mean that the group's 2002 main-stage season has been postponed until May, and that a $200-a-ticket gala scheduled for yesterday was canceled. 
 Ms. Knighton, 42, is an animated native of Mississippi who has led the organization for more than 4 of its 13 years. She insists that any setbacks stemming from Sept. 11, city budget cuts and the recession actually represent an opportunity. An opportunity for minority arts groups like 651, with its staff of seven and a loyal group of volunteers in Fort Greene, to find new ways to raise money. What is crucial, Ms. Knighton says, is to persuade more black people to buy a ticket for, say, a dance troupe as readily as they would for a church raffle. 
Historically, there are many reasons that has not happened. But the times call for black New Yorkers who have a sense of self-worth and a few extra dollars to help institutions that support black artists. "At a basic level, it is a validation of self," Ms. Knighton said.
She has a few strategies in mind. They include forming partnerships with profit-making arts groups and luring more people to serve on 651 Arts' nine-person board. She hopes to expand the board to 20. Ms. Knighton also wants to aggressively increase individual donations, now a small part of a budget dependent on foundation grants.
At 651 Fulton Street in the Majestic Theater, 651 Arts dwells in the same valley of cutbacks and uncertainties as most of the city's 2,000 arts institutions. They all face the gravest economic period since the fiscal crisis in the 1970's. But when big institutions catch cold, those run by minority groups get pneumonia.
"Groups of color have fewer resources and less access to money available through philanthropy," said Norma P. Munn, chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, an arts advocacy group. "They get a smaller amount than that given to comparable white organizations. It's more patronizing than racism."
As artists and patrons, blacks have historically not only been excluded from mainstream institutions, but also, until recently, lacked their own. Many of the most established black cultural institutions are not that old. The Alvin Ailey dance group started in 1958, the Studio Museum of Harlem in the mid-1970's. That is one reason blacks have been more accustomed to giving to churches or schools, rather than to arts organizations, said Claude Johnson, 651 Art's director of institutional planning. 
But 651 represents a second wave in black cultural institutions. For one, its mission is to reach beyond what black Americans are doing in theater, dance, music and the humanities and to represent black talent worldwide. At the same time, it wants to remain linked to its base in Fort Greene, a neighborhood known for attracting a diverse black population and nurturing black artists. 
As a showcase for dance artists like Donald Byrd ("Harlem Nutcracker" and "Jazz Train") and its acclaimed annual "Black Dance: Tradition and Transformation" festival, which brought together black dancers from places like South Africa, Paris and London, 651 had started to hit its stride.
As the predominantly black Fort Greene continues to change, though, with more whites attracted to the neighborhood's elegant brownstones and funky vibe, some wonder whether 651 will be helped or hurt. 
Ms. Knighton says enough newcomers have embraced 651. Some artists and business people also think 651 can capitalize on the new elan and money. Others fear it could go the way of the black artists who put Fort Greene on the map, but were pushed out by rising rents.
"We as artists have to reaffirm how important these institutions are to us," Tracie Morris, a poet who lives in nearby Cobble Hill, said of 651. "Where is the place for the innovative black artist? There has to be a way to address this issue without wringing our hands about it."

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/John D. Enlund; 
Country Growth Fund

 BODY:
THE economic slowdown, now an official recession, may last longer than most people think, contends John D. Enlund, lead manager of the $175 million Country Growth fund.
 "Our concern is that we have a recessionary environment driven by an overcapacity in production," Mr. Enlund said from his office in Bloomington, Ill. "We're not so sure that the interest rate cuts and fiscal stimulus will be enough to soak up all that extra capacity." 
 His cautious stance has prompted him to raise the fund's cash stake, to 12 percent from a more typical 3 to 5 percent. "We found some opportunities in the post-Sept. 11 market drop," he said, "but not much since then."
The fund returned 4 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with losses of 3 percent for its group of large blend funds and 3.3 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, according to Morningstar Inc. It lost 9.6 percent in the last 12 months, versus losses of 14.4 percent for its group and 12.7 percent for the index.
On March 1, the fund will beginassessing a sales charge of 5.5 percent on new Class A shares, as an incentive for its sales force.
Mr. Enlund, 45, works with four other money managers at Country Trust Bank, the fund's adviser. Together, they manage about $8 billion in five funds plus individual and insurance accounts.
To pick the 70 or so stocks in the fund, Mr. Enlund looks for growing sales and earnings over the next three to five years. He shops mostly among United States companies with capitalizations of at least $5 billion.
For 60 to 70 percent of the portfolio, he aims to buy companies in the S.& P. 500 and to roughly replicate the 10 industry sectors of the index. The remainder of the fund can include stocks outside the index, and is used to emphasize or de-emphasize the 10 sectors, depending on Mr. Enlund's economic outlook.
Generally, he keeps sector weightings within 50 percent, in either direction, of their levels in the index.
For now, the weightings essentially mirror those of the index, he said, because he added more technology stocks after Sept. 11, bringing the tech percentage up to the mid-teens.
There is one exception: energy stocks. They account for about 10 percent of the fund's assets, compared with 6 percent of the index. "Recognizing that oil prices are very low right now," he said, "we think that new reserves will have to be developed over the next five years."
Mr. Enlund seeks attractively priced growth stocks. The earnings growth rate for the portfolio companies has averaged 11 percent a year over the last 10 years, in line with the index. But the fund's companies trade for about 20 times projected 2002 earnings, well below Wall Street estimates of 28 times to 40 times this year's earnings for the S.& P.
In selecting companies, he also looks for strong revenue growth from new products or new stores, for example. "I prefer growth from internal sources as opposed to acquisitions," he said, "because I think it's more sustainable."
Last summer, Mr. Enlund began buying shares of the Apache Corporation, an oil and gas company based in Houston. He paid $49.04, on average, adjusted for a stock dividend; they closed on Friday at $51.57. His 12-month target price is $60.
"As oil prices turn around in the next 24 months," he said, "the company will be a major beneficiary of increased prices and its ability to find and exploit reserves."
HE also likes the Target Corporation, the Minneapolis-based retailer that operates Marshall Field's department stores and Mervyn's and Target discount stores. He began buying the stock in late September at $28.63, on average; it now trades at $44.39, compared with his target price of $49. He said the Target discount stores had a slightly more upscale clientele than rivals, Wal-Mart and Kmart. The stores have been introducing supercenters combining general merchandise with groceries. Earnings should continue growing at a percentage pace in the mid-teens, he said.
Last fall, Mr. Enlund started buying shares of Siebel Systems of San Mateo, Calif., which provides sales, marketing and customer service information software to businesses. He expects continuing strong demand for the software, with average annual earnings growth of more than 25 percent over three to five years. 
He paid $13.20 a share, on average; the stock closed on Friday at $28.94. He said the stock would be a candidate for sale as its price approached $40.

HEADLINE: Web Site Helped Change Farm Policy 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
Throughout the angry Senate debate about whether to limit subsidies to wealthy farmers, lawmakers kept referring to "the Web site" to make their points.
 "You can see on the Web site -- 10 percent of the farmers get most of the money," said Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma. 
 "I looked up Indiana on the Web site," said Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, "and very few Indiana farmers would be affected by a modest limit."
No one had to ask, "What Web site?" 
It is www.ewg.org, operated by the Environmental Working Group, a small nonprofit organization with the simple idea that the taxpayers who underwrite $20 billion a year in farm subsidies have the right to know who gets the money.
Conceived by Ken Cook, 50, director of the group, the Web site has become unusual in the crowded world of special-interest politics, where it is hard to get noticed in Washington, much less heard.
It not only caught the attention of lawmakers, it also helped transform the farm bill into a question about equity and whether the country's wealthiest farmers should be paid to grow commodity crops while many smaller family farms receive nothing and are going out of business.
In farm circles, where neighbors now know who is receiving the biggest checks from the government, the Web site has name recognition roughly equal to that of Heinz ketchup.
"Now I understand how my 'farmer' brother-in-law can afford a $400,000 condo at the beach, despite all his poor-mouthing," a Texas woman wrote after searching the Web site.
To the uninitiated, the small, specialized niche on the World Wide Web looks like an overnight success. Since going public in November, it has recorded 20 million searches.
But Mr. Cook said the site was the culmination of his life of thinking about farms and the environment.
His grandfather Samuel Cook founded the family ranch outside Roselle, Mo., in the foothills of the Ozark Mountains. His uncle inherited the farm. Ken Cook grew up in a St. Louis suburb after his father died when he was 5 years old. But the large Cook family, headed by his uncle Paul, took him in every summer and most holidays, teaching him to cut and bale hay and tend to the calves on the family's 1,000-acre spread. He is anything but romantic about life at the Cook ranch.
"From a car window all those family farms look picturesque, but when you're living it, it can be endless chores," he said. "The barnyard. The pastures. I loved it."
Mr. Cook studied agriculture and history at the University of Missouri, and later received a master's degree in soil science.
His early goal, he said, was to put his education to work protecting the environment and places like the Cook farm.
But most of the decisions about farming and the environment were being made in Washington, so he moved here in 1977 and spent the next 15 years trying to find a suitable job.
"It wasn't an easy time," Mr. Cook said. "There was almost no room for conservation programs on the farm while farmers were planting fence post to fence post."
As an agriculture analyst at the Congressional Research Service, Mr. Cook learned the value of analyzing government data for lawmakers.
"I got lucky and worked with a great agricultural economist, Barry Carr, who taught me how to think about agriculture policy," he said.
Later, as a freelance writer, he got to know the ways of the Washington press corps.
When he and Richard Wiles founded the Environmental Working Group in 1993, they dedicated themselves to research with political punch. All research projects had to include plans showing how the project could open the political debate and be used by journalists.
They spent their $2 million annual budget on computer database experts, large computer servers and salaries for the 20 people who work at the group's offices in Dupont Circle. The money is raised from nonprofit benefactors like the Joyce Foundation.
The farm subsidy database was the first big project.
It took roughly six years to cultivate: four years of filing requests under the Freedom of Information Act to find out what was available and get the information from the government and two years of the tedious work of compiling the data and putting the information on the Web site.
"We figured that the power of information alone would do more than we could accomplish lobbying or writing elaborate reports," Mr. Cook said. "The data shows what farmers already knew -- the big farms are getting bigger and driving out the smaller farms, thanks to big government subsidies." 
The group's success has brought opponents.
Representative Larry Combest, Republican of Texas and chairman of the Agriculture Committee, accused the group last week of trying to eliminate all support for farmers.
"This is a conservation group that would like to take every dollar in a farm bill and spend it on environmental programs, have no farm programs at all," Mr. Combest said on a radio interview with KPAN in Hereford, Tex.
For Mr. Cook, statements like that, and others that accuse him of being a city slicker without a soul, are vindication that he was right to follow his first impulse and stick to what he knew.
"In my mind, when I talk about water pollution from farm runoff I see the charts and the data, but I also see the pollution in the family creek on our farm," he said. "That was from mining. We work on mining, too."

HEADLINE: Florida Hopes Spring Brings a Rebound 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: KISSIMMEE, Fla., Feb. 22 

 BODY:
Free tattoos in Panama City Beach, discount Disney tickets in Orlando and breakfast in bed in Kissimmee. Those are some of the perks up for grabs simply for partying in parts of Florida this spring.
 Hit hard by the steep drop in visitors after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, hotel operators in Florida vacation cities are aggressively competing for the spring break crowd -- those noisy throngs of young people with shorts, tank tops and open beer containers that some places once tried just as hard to drive away. 
 "Our rates are low and we've had to cut some deals," said Gary Lobo, general manager of the Clarion Hotel Maingate here. Along with the $49.95 a night rate, he is offering his guests free breakfast during spring break and promoting a free shuttle service to the theme parks. 
"We've had to be very aggressive," Mr. Lobo said. "A full hotel at a lower rate is better than an empty hotel with a full rate." 
Sulma Crosby, who cleans rooms at the Clarion knows that a full hotel during spring break, from mid-March until early May, means catering to rambunctious teenagers, more wet towels from the pool and more beds to make. But after having had her work week cut from five days to two, Ms. Crosby is looking forward to making as many beds as she can manage. "I'm sure we're going to do better with spring break," she said. "Everybody was hurting bad. At this point we really need them." 
In Daytona Beach, events organizers are counting on brisk spring break business, too, hoping to help it along by spending a bit more this year on spot advertisements on MTV, ESPN and other frat-friendly channels in 35 markets. Organizers have also mailed about 50,000 promotional posters to fraternities and sororities on college campuses. 
Daytona Beach's spring break planners also say that the lingering fear of flying among travelers since Sept. 11 may give the town a competitive advantage. 
"We're typically a drive destination," said Scott Edwards, chairman of the Daytona Beach Spring Break Marketing Committee. "I think we're getting some people who would have traveled to Mexico or elsewhere just because they can just drive here instead of fly."
The Flamingo Inn in Daytona Beach is counting on the college crowd driving from across the country. "Nothing is going to stop them from getting to spring break," said Merle Kappelman, owner of the hotel, which closes its doors to the public and rents rooms exclusively to college students from March 9 to April 15. 
One city, though, has decided not to court spring break business. Officials in Fort Lauderdale, which took years to shed its image as the nation's spring break capital, say the city cannot afford to woo too many students, even if times are hard.
"South Florida in general is in much better shape than when college kids were in town," said Nicki Grossman, president of the Greater Fort Lauderdale Convention and Visitors Bureau, who recalls the 1980's when the city's one mile stretch of beach was overrun by 370,000 loud, rowdy, drunken college students. 
"They want inflatable 30-foot beer cans on the beach, they want MTV, drinking contests, and they're not going to find that here," Ms. Grossman said. "It is an image we're recovering from." 
Instead, Fort Lauderdale, which boasts of drawing only 15,000 spring breakers last year, is betting on family-oriented tourists and business conventioneers returning over the next year if the economy continues to pick up and there are no new terrorist attacks. Students are simply not good business, Ms. Grossman said. "The price a college student is willing to pay for a hotel room doesn't make it worth it for us." 
Other cities are looking to snag visitors for spring break any way they can. 
"When the events unfolded in September, we felt we needed to concentrate on this more," said Jayna Leach, a spokeswoman for the Panama City Beach Convention and Visitors bureau. So the city signed up more corporate sponsors this year to offer such enticements as free tattoos and passes for open bars at nightclubs. Events planners are spending more money on advertising, including a 12-page insert in college newspapers promoting the area.
Not to be outdone, the Orlando visitors bureau lined up more than 50 area hotels to reduce rates, offer free nights with extended stays and provide free breakfast and other perks. It also teamed up with Disney and other area theme parks to promote discount and second-day-free tickets to some attractions.
"Obviously we're competing with other sun destinations," said Jos Estorino, senior vice president of marketing for the Orlando/Orange County Convention and Visitors Bureau. "It's a recovery plan."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Pennsylvania college student, John Sterner, frolicked with other young people in Daytona Beach, Fla., last year for spring break. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL: INSIDE THE N.B.A.; 
The New Rules of the Game in Building, and Rebuilding, a Winner

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

 BODY:
In less complicated times, this is how you made your team better at the N.B.A. trading deadline: a free-agent-to-be All-Star was acquired for a couple of nice role players and a draft pick or two, or you got rid of an overpaid albatross for someone else's overpaid albatross, hoping he would fit in better.
 Every now and then, a young, emerging player would land in a general manager's lap, if for no other reason than his current team was afraid it could not sign him to a long-term deal after his contract was up. 
 But no one trades those kinds of players anymore; the teams they signed with as rookies now re-sign them. Fewer and fewer franchises exchange high-priced lemons because of luxury-tax and other economic fears. 
"Building and bettering your team is much different than it once was," Chris Wallace, the Boston general manager, said in an interview last month. "For a while, the draft became less important than stockpiling your salary-cap money and grabbing the big talent. Now, most of the top guys don't make it to free agency." 
Four of the best players to emerge from the 1997 draft -- Vince Carter, Paul Pierce, Dirk Nowitzki and Antawn Jamison -- all signed maximum extensions with their respective teams in the last year. The collective bargaining agreement signed by players and owners in 1999 gave teams much more leverage in re-signing their stars.
"A guy really has to hate his situation for you to get a star," Wallace said. "It's not like 1996 when you had Alonzo Mourning, Juwan Howard and Shaquille O'Neal. Guys like that just don't hit free agency anymore. You're looking at an era where it's imperative to draft well and improve your team incrementally sometimes, rather than going crazy all at once."
The Celtics were one of only eight National Basketball Association teams to make a deal before last Thursday's trading deadline, acquiring the veterans Rodney Rogers and Tony Delk in a five-player deal with Phoenix on Wednesday. Boston sent the rookie Joe Johnson and the veterans Randy Brown and Milt Palacio -- along with its coming first-round draft pick -- to the Suns. 
In interviews recently with nine of the league's general managers, a consensus of the job began to emerge. Not only are executives dealing with high school juniors contemplating leaving without their diploma, but economic realties have forced many teams to rethink their strategy. 
"First of all, there are no geniuses in this business," said Jerry Krause, who before Chicago's recent three-year slide was twice named executive of the year. "Anybody who has a set formula, I'd love to see it. A G.M.'s job is complicated.
"Fifteen or 20 years ago, I went and watched the best college seniors in the country," Krause added. "You'd see a sophomore or junior who could play and you'd write his name down, figuring you'd see him in two years. Last year, I saw more high school games than I ever dreamed of. You throw in the European scouting, more complications in the salary cap, and the job just gets bigger and bigger."
Krause and the Bulls last week traded for Jalen Rose, Indiana's leading scorer and most versatile player, and point guard Travis Best. Chicago parted with Ron Mercer, Ron Artest and Brad Miller and the backup point guard Kevin Ollie. Chicago also received Norm Richardson and a conditional second-round pick. 
Rose represented Krause's first major acquisition after several failed attempts to make room under the salary cap and to acquire big-name free agents like Tracy McGrady and Eddie Jones, who ended up with teams in their home state of Florida. "We really wanted Tracy and Eddie," Krause said. "We thought they would have changed us dramatically. But I couldn't control where they were born."
Krause and other executives say there are four elements in building a team: the draft, free agency, trades and working with current players to better the team from within. "But with cap situations, trade kickers and sometimes the goals of management differing from the goals of ownership," Krause said, "it's tough for some teams."
Donnie Walsh, the Pacers' team president, recently said one of the major frustrations was finding a top-flight center to contend with the Lakers' Shaquille O'Neal. 
"Everyone is looking for a matchup for Shaq," Walsh said. "In the finals two years ago, I looked down low and couldn't see Dale Davis behind Shaq. When you can't see your center, it's time to rebuild."
"In two years, there'll be a lot of big guys out there," Walsh said, referring to 2003 free agents like Tim Duncan, Jermaine O'Neal, Michael Olowokandi and Antonio McDyess. "But there are no savior, young big men out there right now. That guy is probably in Tibet. We'll hear about him in two years."
The Celtics' Wallace said there is no sure-fire plan, but he added that patience helps. "Fans and media are always calling for change," he said. "I mean, the Nets' trading for Jason Kidd may be extraordinary for the Nets. But how many teams come out overwhelming winners in deals? Some of the best deals you do are the ones you don't do.
"It's really easy to get blinded on the short term and end up in that maze. I equate N.B.A. basketball with being in a maze. You don't want to get further in the maze."

Hockey Instead of Hoops
Andrei Kirilenko got to watch one of the heroes from his homeland Friday night. Kirilenko, a 20-year-old Utah Jazz rookie, took in the United States-Russia Olympic semifinal, cheering wildly for the Russian goalie, Nikolai Khabibulin, in the Americans' 3-2 victory. 
Kirilenko was in Salt Lake City because he had some down time with his Jazz teammates before they went back on the road again. Not that that is a bad thing.
Forced out of the Delta Center, the figure skating site at the Winter Games, the Jazz (31-24) has used its unheard-of nine-game road trip to re-establish its credibility as a bona fide playoff team.
Utah has won six straight on the road, playing that archaic pick-and-roll style that has characterized its success for parts of three decades. Coach Jerry Sloan is cursing less and praising more, Karl Malone and John Stockton are putting up numbers again, and the emergence of Kirilenko, along with Scott Padgett, has given the Jazz a bit of youthful pizazz. 
Kirilenko had 21 points and 6 blocked shots in a rout of Denver last Wednesday, the final game of an extended 10-day trip. Padgett made 9 of 12 shots in only 27 minutes. It was Utah's ninth victory in 11 games. The Jazz also beat Indiana, Philadelphia, Toronto, the Knicks and Cleveland on the road. 
"We caught some teams at the right time," Sloan told The Salt Lake Tribune. "And we caught some teams that were struggling. But we were struggling, too. So it's been nice to see our guys play with a little more energy and to start playing more as a group. When those things happen, you've got a chance to win."

Knicks Draw Little Interest
They shopped Charlie Ward again, to no avail. The names of Shandon Anderson and Othella Harrington almost came up, too. Marcus Camby was even on the block, receiving little interest from teams seeking big men.
What the Knicks found out at the trading deadline: either Latrell Sprewell or Allan Houston will most likely have to go this summer in order to land the prized big man they truly covet.
More than ever, no one is very interested in New York's players. The Knicks wanted Raef LaFrentz, but they could not acquire him with what they were offering. There was talk of Juwan Howard, too, but that died quickly. 
In the end, they may have been used as pawns in the Dallas-Denver deal. Free agents have always used the Knicks for leverage, knowing that New York will force other teams to pay top dollar.
But when the Knicks cannot even pull off a minor deal to better themselves in February, well, it might be wise for season-ticket holders to make vacation plans for late April.

HEADLINE: Governors Want Congress to Ease Welfare Work Rule 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
The nation's governors, who helped write the landmark 1996 welfare law and its stringent work requirements, are now urging Congress to let states relax those requirements for some people on welfare.
 Leaders of the National Governors Association said the group would adopt a new policy on welfare at its winter meeting, which began here today. 
 The governors, an influential voice on national welfare policy, plan to reaffirm the importance of work as a condition of receiving cash assistance. But in view of the sluggish economy and rising unemployment, they say, the work requirements for some families appear unrealistic, and some welfare recipients need more education and training to secure jobs.
Governors also intend to oppose President Bush's effort to cut federal highway spending by 27 percent, or $8.5 billion. Such a cut, they say, would eliminate tens of thousands of jobs and disrupt work on hundreds of road projects. 
Gov. Bill Owens of Colorado, vice chairman of the Republican Governors Association, said the president's highway proposal should not and probably would not become law.
"The president has a role as commander in chief that none of us have to share," Mr. Owens said in an interview. "He needs to make defense and homeland security a priority. Most governors try to make transportation a priority."
In addition, the governors, seeking ways to rein in the explosive growth of Medicaid, said they would pressure drug companies to contain pharmaceutical costs.
Federal law "may be contributing to the rising cost of prescription drugs" by impeding access to lower-cost generic drugs, the governors said in a resolution likely to be adopted at their meeting here.
In the draft policy statement on welfare, the governors said, "The focus on work should remain paramount." But, they said, states should be able to expand the definition of "work activity" to include more job training, education and drug abuse treatment.
Under the 1996 law, at least 50 percent of all families on welfare and 90 percent of two-parent families are supposed to be engaged in work. The governors say Congress should eliminate the higher requirement for two-parent families, which, they say, may unintentionally discourage the formation of such families.
Bush administration officials say they will emphasize work when they make recommendations on welfare policy in the next few days. Many state officials want more flexibility. Governor Owens of Colorado said these goals could be reconciled by allowing welfare recipients to pursue "work-oriented" education and training.
"If you allow education to mean pondering the majesty of the Pyramids, that would not fit the definition," Mr. Owens said. "But if education is closely related to work, I'm in favor of that."
In addition, the governors say Congress should let them relax the time limits on receipt of cash assistance. Under the 1996 law, families generally are not permitted to receive federal welfare benefits for more than five years. Many families are now approaching that limit.
The governors' policy statement says that "at state option and under certain limited circumstances, individuals who are working in unsubsidized employment consistent with the purposes of the law should have the ability to earn additional months of eligibility," beyond the five-year limit.
At a news conference opening today's session, Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican who is chairman of the National Governors Association, cautioned federal officials against trying to impose more mandates and requirements.
"The objective here is not to substitute conservative micromanagement for liberal micromanagement," Mr. Engler said. "The problem is micromanagement."
Governors take credit for making the 1996 law a success. The number of welfare recipients has plummeted, to 5.3 million last September from 12.2 million in 1996. The proportion of children in poverty declined to 16.2 percent in 2000, the lowest level in more than two decades, from 20.5 percent in 1996, according to the Census Bureau.
But governors say they now fear that Republicans and moderate Democrats will try to outdo each other in imposing stricter work requirements, which could prove impossible for states to meet.
Two centrist Democrats -- Senators Evan Bayh of Indiana and Thomas R. Carper of Delaware, both former governors -- said they would soon introduce a bill increasing the work requirement, so that 60 percent of families on welfare would have to be working by 2007.
"The traditional approach of our party has been not to emphasize work requirements," Mr. Bayh said in an interview. "But those requirements have been important in moving people from dependence to self-sufficiency."
Mr. Carper said he knew there would "be some apprehension among some governors about raising the work requirements." 
Mr. Bayh said: "We want to be reasonable. If unemployment rises significantly in a particular state, the new requirements would not be phased in as rapidly there."
Some conservatives in and out of Congress want to set aside federal money for programs that promote marriage and encourage fathers to be more involved in the lives of children on welfare. The new policy statement says "governors oppose any effort to establish set-asides or further restrictions" on the use of federal welfare money.
Under the 1996 law, each state receives a lump sum of federal money, with broad discretion to use it for the benefit of needy families. Any requirement that states spend a certain amount for a specific purpose "would violate the basic tenets" of the law, the governors contend.
Federal grants to the states for public assistance total $16.5 billion a year. Some Republicans have said Congress can reduce this amount because the welfare rolls have shrunk. But governors say Congress should increase federal welfare spending to keep pace with inflation in coming years.
The governors' statement is silent on whether states should be required to increase state spending on welfare to keep up with inflation. In the absence of such a requirement, members of Congress say, they are unlikely to increase federal grants.
"You can't ask the federal government to increase its share without asking more from the states," a Congressional aide said.
The governors also called on Congress to give states the option of restoring welfare benefits to legal immigrants who have not become citizens.
With President Bush focused mainly on war and national security, and with Congress at a partisan impasse on many issues, governors have taken the lead in shaping domestic policy.
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat, is leading efforts to put the governors on record in support of federal legislation that would increase access to generic drugs, as an alternative to brand-name medicines.
"Pharmaceutical companies are exploiting loopholes in a 1984 law to extend their patents unfairly, and this is costing states millions and millions of dollars," Governor Dean said.
The Federal Trade Commission and many states have accused drug companies of engaging in anticompetitive behavior to delay entry of generic drugs into the American market.
Brand-name drug companies deny there is any problem. They are lobbying the governors' association to reject Mr. Dean's proposal.
The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, a lobby for brand-name drug companies, says that 45 percent of prescriptions are already filled with generic drugs, up from 18 percent in 1984. Generic drug makers will have new marketing opportunities in the next few years, as patents for many popular drugs expire, the group said.
