HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
ConsumersHave Saved The Day. Well, Maybe.

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
SKEPTICISM about the economy is becoming harder to sustain. The latest statistics are too hopeful. They increasingly suggest that recession is giving way to recovery, although the three most important statistics -- business investment, corporate profits and production capacity -- have yet to go in the right direction. Until they do, the incipient recovery will have no legs.
 But that is tomorrow's hurdle. Responding to the unmistakable symptoms of a reviving economy, the nation's forecasters have put aside skepticism. Forecasters who still say the economy is contracting are hard to find. Consumer spending has held up far too well. Soon, the forecasters argue, the other engines of growth will kick in. 
 Richard Berner, chief domestic economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, shows the current mood. "The United States," he said, "is soon likely to lead the rest of the world out of recession just as we led them into it." To Mr. Berner, the economy is already expanding at a healthy clip, and in the second half of the year, growth will surge at a 4.5 percent annual rate, reminiscent of the late 1990's.
Consumer spending has indeed held up beyond most everyone's expectations. Despite crushing debt, endless layoffs and a scarcity of new jobs, families have kept spending. Millions behave as if the recession was someone else's experience, not theirs. Personal consumption expenditures, the government's calculation of total consumer outlays, rose in each of the last three quarters, particularly in the most recent, in disregard of the recession. 
"What surprised everyone was that the consumer did not flee," said James Glassman, an economist at J.P. Morgan Chase.
The current quarter is producing another strong showing from consumers. Retail sales data through last week was robust. Now the forecasters are optimistically expecting the next shoe to drop. Thanks to all the consumption, companies have run down their inventories of unsold goods to unusually low levels. Restocking is imminent, the forecasters say. Restocking, in turn, requires stepped-up production, and when that happens, the recovery is on its way -- unless consumption falters.
A little skepticism is in order here. Why has consumer spending held up so well? There are several reasons, none of them all that solid. 
Bargains have played an important role. In past recessions, rising prices inhibited consumers. This time, the inflation rate is hardly noticeable; price-cutting has been widespread -- zero-interest auto loans being only one example. "Consumers overcame their caution about the economy because they thought prices were so low they would never get a better bargain," said Richard T. Curtin, director of the University of Michigan's Surveys of Consumers. 
Low interest rates have also encouraged spending. So have falling fuel prices. As rates fell, mortgage refinancing put billions of dollars into the pockets of homeowners without raising their monthly payments.
The problem is that none of these factors are likely to repeat themselves. And hourly wages, while still rising smartly in the fourth quarter, have begun to show signs of faltering as unemployment moves higher.
"Wages are the last domino to fall," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute. "The progression is weak economic growth, rising unemployment and then wages lose ground."
BARGAIN prices are also a burden. To restore profits, companies must either raise prices or cut costs, particularly labor costs, even more than they already have. Either way, consumer spending is endangered. But without the prospect of rising profits, companies are unlikely to revive investment in new machinery, computers and the other tools of production. Without that revival, the incipient economic upturn is likely to vanish.
Recognizing this hole in their optimism, many forecasters express confidence that capital spending will pick up by late summer. By then, they say, overcapacity will have disappeared. American companies will no longer have more tools than they need to satisfy demand, and capital spending will resume.
Maybe. Or maybe, instead of recovery, there will be a second dip into recession. One or two forecasters mention this double dip and are hooted down by their colleagues. That only goads Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, to fresh expressions of doubt.
"As America's sole surviving double dipper," he said, "I would concede that the numbers have broken to the upside temporarily. But that has happened in past recessions, only to give way to fresh hard times. Skepticism should not be suspended."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE -- BUZZ; 
New Cigarette Tax? Young Smokers Just Shrug

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE 

 BODY:
THE SETTING -- The smoky back streets behind the Dalton School, on East 89th Street near Park Avenue. Students huddled in their overcoats last Wednesday, stealing puffs of cigarettes between classes and after school, dutifully respecting the school's no-smoking zone out front.
 The teenagers had many opinions about the $1.50 city cigarette tax proposed by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The jump in the tax -- it is now just 8 cents -- is intended both to ease the city's budget deficit and to reduce smoking by raising prices to nearly $7 a pack. 
 "The numbers are clear," Mr. Bloomberg said. "You raise cigarette taxes, the kids smoke less."

THE BUZZ -- "I doubt it," said Adam, 18, disputing the mayor's theory as he stood behind a bagel store on 88th Street. "If kids can afford $5 a pack, another couple of bucks won't make much of a difference. Instead of spending a dollar on soda, I'll spend it on cigarettes."
At the same corner, Tanya, 16, was polishing off a Marlboro Light. "I only go through a pack a week," she said. "So $2 is not going to make a huge hole. It's just annoying."
Others stood on principle. "If people are going to smoke, don't try to tell people what to do by jacking up the price," said John, 18, who calls himself a social smoker. Alexandra, 17, who is partial to Marlboro Ultra Lights, added: "This is not about stopping smoking. It's about getting money." 
None of the smokers interviewed would divulge their full names, in contrast to their nonsmoking peers. "I think smoking is disgusting, and you can print that," said Sean Glass, 17. "Anything to make people stop is good. If I smoked, I would be against it. But I think it's disgusting."
The Dalton students were quick to note their relative wealth, and suggested that a steeper cigarette tax would discourage their less fortunate peers. "I imagine it's a fairly regressive tax," said Reid Capalino, 17. "I'd be interested to know, aren't the majority of people who smoke low-income?"
Several seniors guessed that one-third of their classmates enjoyed the occasional puff, and were skeptical that a few dollars, here and there, would alter a habit so ingrained in certain social circles. "Drugs are expensive, and people do that," said Dana Weissman, 17.
But Erica, 16, who started smoking nine months ago, was already forming an economic game plan if the tax were approved. "I think we'll start sharing cabs," she said. DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Optimism Returns For Airline Stocks

BYLINE:  By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
MANY airline analysts are peering past the terrorist attacks and the weak economy to better times for the industry. The premise is that it is better to be six months early with these stocks than one month late.
 "We definitely expect a significant rally for most airline stocks," said Susan M. Donofrio, an analyst at Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. 
 JetBlue Airways, a budget start-up, disclosed plans this month for an initial stock sale, reflecting the renewed industry confidence. The announcement, originally planned for Sept. 11, also pointed up the relatively sunny operating climate for low-cost, low-fare airlines compared with industry giants like American Airlines, a part of AMR; United Airlines, owned by UAL; and Delta Air Lines. 
Buying airline stocks can require a strong stomach. Many carriers are still reeling from the economic slowdown and Sept. 11.
Industry load factors -- the percentage of seats occupied by paying customers -- fell by 11 percentage points in mid-September, forcing the large airlines to mark down fares and cut capacity 15 to 20 percent.
In the quarter ended Dec. 31, the major airlines, which have large networks and connect passengers through hub airports, reported losses totaling $2.8 billion.
So far, more nimble low-fare airlines that fly direct routes, like Southwest Airlines, JetBlue and AirTran, have remained profitable.
For most airlines, load factors have largely recovered to pre-attack levels. In January, load factors for the overall industry actually edged above year-earlier levels.
"Recession is not necessarily bad for all airlines," said Michael J. Linenberg, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Low-cost carriers can gain profitable market share as the major airlines cut capacity, he said.
There are two schools of thought about which airlines to buy. One favors the no-frills variety while the other finds more potential -- with more risk -- in the major, established lines.
"The Wal-Marts of the airline industry do well in a downturn," said Mr. Linenberg, who continues to recommend Southwest because of its cost advantages. Its shares have climbed 58 percent since Sept. 17, to $20.58. He said the shares could reach $25 within a year.
Jamie Baker, an analyst at UBS Warburg, also expects the low-fare airlines to retain their edge. "Given the uncertainty and time delays of the airport experience, I expect leisure demand to recover more quickly than business demand," he said. "So airlines that cater to the price-conscious traveler should see a quicker return to pre-attack levels."
Mr. Baker is bullish on AirTran, which he thinks will benefit from sharp capacity reductions by competitors in its Northeast markets. It now trades at $6.31; his 12-month price target is $8.50. 
Because of its enormous fixed costs, the industry is highly leveraged and prone to huge profit swings. Since commercial aviation was deregulated in 1978, some 137 airlines have filed for bankruptcy.
Investors who think an economic recovery is imminent may be attracted to the major airlines, whose fortunes are more cyclical. 
For example, Brian D. Harris, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said he expects demand for air travel to recover fully by year-end. He is bullish on the larger airlines. "There are some very appealing valuations among big, ugly cyclical majors, trading below their Sept. 10 levels," he said.
Continental Airlines, he said, has the best growth prospects. But he considers its shares, like those of the other cyclically sensitive carriers, to be very risky. His 12-month price target for the stock is $42; it now trades at $30.90.
Mr. Harris downgraded Southwest in January to neutral from buy, citing its valuation. Southwest's market value exceeds that of all other domestic carriers combined.
Resolution of security and insurance issues after the passage of the airport security act is crucial, said Ms. Donofrio of Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "Travelers should begin to notice tighter and more consistent security checks," she said.
Higher insurance and security costs hurt the low-cost carriers disproportionately. "Their lean cost structures makes make it harder for them to absorb the higher costs," she said. Her top pick is Delta, which she said could rise to $61 in 12 to 18 months, from $32.77 on Friday.
LINDA R. KILLIAN, manager of the IPO Plus fund of Renaissance Capital, likes the two-year-old JetBlue, based in New York. "It's very efficient but with some nice touches, like satellite television and leather seats," she said.
Steven R. Hendrickson, president and co-founder of the Kiehl Hendrickson Group, an aviation consulting firm in Minneapolis, said that the smaller airlines might be more vulnerable to price wars, but that JetBlue had special advantages. "They are remarkably well capitalized for a start-up," he said. "So it's less likely that another carrier would initiate a war of attrition."
Clifford M. Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution, expressed doubts about the big airlines. "If things come back, they'll do better," he said. "But if the economy just limps along, it will be survival of the fittest."
What if another shock devastates demand? "At least airlines can adjust prices and routes," he said. "Thank goodness the industry's deregulated."

HEADLINE: White House Memo; 
Cheney Takes to the Open Road And Basks in a Warmer Spotlight

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 

 BODY:
Vice President Dick Cheney has suffered a hail of criticism for refusing to release records of meetings his energy task force held with executives from the Enron Corporation and other companies. This week, Mr. Cheney found a way to change the subject: skip town.
 Hopscotching through California to a string of events and political fund-raisers, the vice president was in the public eye for the most extended time since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Freed from his "secure, undisclosed locations," Mr. Cheney hit the road in a carefully scripted four-day trip. The vice president says the trip had nothing to do with Enron. But it did enable him to shed his big-oil image for a while and play to his strengths before cheering audiences. 
 Mr. Cheney, a former secretary of defense, talked tough on Iraq to marines in San Diego. He promised help for farmers and ranchers in the San Joaquin Valley. He promoted Mr. Bush's vision of a new economy to business leaders in Silicon Valley. He raised money for two grateful House Republicans. He also joked with Jay Leno on "The Tonight Show." On Sunday, Mr. Cheney will close the Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City. 
"It's been a good trip," Mr. Cheney said in an interview aboard Air Force Two on Thursday, the last day of his California swing before heading to his home in Jackson, Wyo., for the weekend. "California is a very important state. They've got a major role to play in terms of the economy."
For a White House that hates for Mr. Cheney to overshadow Mr. Bush in any way, the vice president's Western tour was the ideal antidote to the Enron scandal -- at least until Friday, when the General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, filed suit to require the administration to release the records of the task force meetings.
But even as those court proceedings drag out over the next several months, look for Mr. Cheney to spend more time on the road, balancing his duties as the vice president of a nation at war with partisan politicking in an election year in which control of the House and Senate are at stake.
"After months of focusing on national security, you're now seeing Cheney carving out a broader role for himself," said Vin Weber, a former Republican congressman and a close friend of the vice president. "He's attendant to the same concerns about his public persona as any other political leader."
Next month, Mr. Cheney will embark on a grueling 10-day, 12-nation trip to the Middle East and Europe to shore up support for the administration's war aims. Last week, he gave a major foreign policy speech at the Council on Foreign Relations.
On the domestic front, the vice president still plays a pivotal role as the bridge between the administration and Republicans on Capitol Hill. Before Election Day in November, Mr. Cheney is expected to make at least 60 campaign appearances, mostly for House candidates.
"It's something I enjoy doing," Mr. Cheney, a former Wyoming congressman, said of the traditional vice presidential job of stumping for candidates. "It's good for business, shall we say, in terms of a lot of what I have to do on the Hill. The members care a lot about it. They know you're out there lending a hand to maintain or build a majority that's running the bank politically."
For Mr. Cheney, this trip was an opportune time to test his new routine, spending what will be a total of 10 straight days outside Washington. He bracketed the California trip with quail hunting in Texas last weekend and a planned appearance presiding over the Wyoming Legislature on Monday. 
Mr. Bush was traveling in Asia, and he and Mr. Cheney never spoke directly during their trips. The separation was their longest since taking office. Congress was in recess.
The vice president's mission this week was to "flesh out" themes in Mr. Bush's State of the Union address, said Mary Matalin, Mr. Cheney's senior political adviser. Mr. Cheney defended Mr. Bush's choice of phrasing, "axis of evil," to describe Iran, Iraq and North Korea, and their efforts to pursue nuclear, chemical and biological weapons. He touted signs of economic recovery.
Mr. Cheney also got in some political digs, praising the Republican-controlled House for approving trade, economic stimulus and energy bills that the administration favors, while implicitly criticizing the Democratic-controlled Senate for failing to act on the legislation.
The vice president took question after question at his three fund-raisers, where guests paid $1,000 to $12,500 each to hear him. But he held only one news conference during the four-day trip. In the gathering with reporters in Fresno, dominated by agriculture issues, Mr. Cheney had to turn to Agriculture Secretary Ann M. Veneman to answer a question about raisins and almonds.
In San Jose, a few reporters were allowed to accompany the vice president as he toured the Tech Museum of Innovation and marveled at a robotic dog named Cosmo, which chased a plastic ball on command. But the journalists were not allowed to ask Mr. Cheney questions.
"We aren't the newsmakers," said Jennifer Millerwise, Mr. Cheney's press secretary. The idea, she and other aides to Mr. Cheney said, is to reinforce Mr. Bush's message and policies but not get out ahead of them.
Even Mr. Cheney's critics said that getting him out on the hustings was shrewd. 
"In fairness to them, he has other obligations," said Philip M. Schiliro, chief of staff for Representative Henry A. Waxman, a California Democrat who has led the call for release of the energy task force records. "But any time he can change the subject from Enron, he'll do so."
Mr. Cheney denied that he designed his trip to shift attention from the Enron scandal or the impending showdown with Congress. 
"I'd be doing it without any of the stuff with respect to Enron," Mr. Cheney said in the interview. "The idea that the president or vice president can't meet with somebody without telling Henry Waxman that you had the meeting, or who's in the meeting, or what was said in the meeting, I just find an outrageous thought."
In a recent Newsweek poll, 60 percent of Americans said Mr. Cheney should release the information to the accounting office. But when Mr. Leno brought up the subject on Tuesday, Mr. Cheney drew wild applause from the studio audience with this response: "What we've seen over the past 30 years is a continual encroachment by Congress in the executive branch, a weakening of the presidency. The president and I are bound and determined not to allow that to happen on our watch."
Many Democrats remain convinced the issue will dog the vice president throughout the election season. 
"Cheney will be an albatross for the party as Enron unfolds," said Bob Mulholland, a campaign adviser for the California Democratic Party.
For his part, Mr. Cheney said he welcomed a court fight to settle such an important issue. "It ought to be resolved in a court, unless you're willing to compromise on a basic fundamental principle, which we are not," he said.

HEADLINE: Some Taxi Drivers Say a Fare Increase Would Be Bad for Business 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
For New York taxi drivers, the decline in tourism after the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center was bad for business, and many have quit to take other jobs.
 So one would think that a fare increase, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed last week, would be warmly welcomed by the cabbies trying to ride out the economic slump. 
 But it was not.
In interviews across Manhattan yesterday, drivers of yellow taxis said that Mayor Bloomberg's plan was flawed because it failed to take into account the economics of a business that many New Yorkers benefit from, but few understand. 
"From my experience, I'll tell you in one sentence: the money will go to the owners," said Santa Jesus, 51, a Dominican immigrant who has been driving a yellow cab for almost 30 years. Like most cabbies, he drives a car that is owned by one of the 15 major companies that operate in the city. 
Some drivers think that a fare increase would actually make matters worse. Taliby Diakite, 47, a Liberian immigrant who has been a yellow cabby for 13 years, said, "I get scared that we will start to lose passengers if rates go up, and not gain a cent."
Mr. Jesus and other cabbies credit Mr. Bloomberg with not being so naive as to believe that a straight fare increase would be passed on to drivers. But they say they doubt that he will be able to persuade cab companies to refrain from turning around and raising the daily rental fees that drivers pay, as they have done in the past.
Members of several cab owner associations could not be reached for comment yesterday.
The Taxi and Limousine Commission, which is considering a 12 percent to 17 percent fare increase, last approved one in January 1996. The price for the first one-fifth of a mile went to $2 from $1.50, and each additional one-fifth of a mile to 30 cents, up from 25 cents. The night charge of 50 cents and the rate of 20 cents a minute charged while a cab is idling in traffic went unchanged. 
After that increase, most cab companies raised their rental fees within two to three weeks by an average of 20 percent, drivers said. Many drivers pay up to $110 a day for their cars and $25 for gas, and also cover the cost of traffic tickets, insurance and other licenses.
But since then, fares for the city's 12,187 yellow cabs have not gone up, despite higher gasoline prices and strict new regulations pushed through by the Giuliani administration that quadrupled insurance requirements, increased traffic fines for cabbies and made it much easier for them to lose their licenses.
The drop in business after Sept. 11 is just the latest blow in an industry with few cushions for hard times, and when the cabbies suffer, so do the businesses that cater to them. At a popular gathering spot, the Gaseteria on 11th Avenue and West 54th Street, cabbies get their fill: gas for the car and food from Pete's Coffee Trailer, a white truck parked nearby. It is also one of the few places with a public restroom drivers can use. They do not seem to mind that there is no door on the restroom and that they are protected from the cold and from public view only by a metal sign that reads, "New 93 Octane."
The man who sells sandwiches from the truck says he is selling fewer $3.30 tuna-and-cheese wraps and fewer 50-cent cups of coffee. The gas station owner complains that the pumps are not being used as much. 
Across town, in front of the Citigroup Building at Lexington Avenue and 53rd Street, sits Samuel O. Pekoh, a Ghanaian immigrant who drove a company cab for years before buying his own medallion and a $41,000 Ford Explorer. There is not a single dent on the vehicle, now eight months old. He has a video camera, a wireless modem and a credit card machine inside.
But Mr. Pekoh knows that his is a rare success story. Mr. Pekoh, who studied civil engineering in college, said it was not easy for cabbies to start a business for themselves. 
A medallion can run up to $195,000 (down from $250,000 since Sept. 11, when officials estimate that more than 2,000 drivers left the business). Then there are insurance and loan payments, accident costs, annual city license fees, gas prices and ticket fines. 
Without a way to guarantee that the money would end up in the hands of the drivers, Mr. Pekoh said, a fare increase would enrich only the cab companies.
"The companies financed Giuliani, and they were together," Mr. Pekoh said. "I would hope that Bloomberg would talk to real taxicab drivers."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Many cabbies complain that higher fares would help the owners of taxi fleets and not them. "I would hope," said Samuel O. Pekoh, above, that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg "would talk to real taxi cab drivers." (Photographs by Richard Perry/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Notes from Tuscaloosa; 
Alabamians Go by an Outdated Book

BYLINE:  By Diane Roberts; Diane Roberts is an English professor at the University of Alabama.

DATELINE: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. 

 BODY:
It's the second year of the 21st century, and Alabama is still fighting its old battles with prejudice and poverty, still trying to combat the image that it's a state where the only well funded education program is college football. Alabamians are not unnaturally backward in their social attitudes: they want tolerance, good schooling and good jobs.
 What holds Alabama back is its own Constitution, at least according to the growing number of people who want to reform it. Ratified in 1901, the Alabama Constitution has 706 amendments -- so far. It is 315,000 words long, nearly 40 times the length of the United States Constitution. Thicker than the phone books of most Alabama cities, it enshrines an inequitable tax structure, a pauperized education system, racism, and centralization of power in the hands of special interests. 
 There have been periodic attempts to overhaul this document, and all have failed. But this year the issue has taken on new urgency, with even some conservatives supporting constitutional revision. The Alabama Baptist Convention, for example, is pro-reform, though the Christian Coalition is not. Most of the state's newspapers, as well as Gov. Don Siegelman, a moderate Democrat running for re-election, endorse revision. So do two of Governor Siegelman's Republican opponents, Representative Bob Riley and Lt. Gov. Steve Windom.
Tim James, another Republican and the son of former governor Fob James, however, accuses reformers of a "dark agenda" dedicated to raising taxes. The Association for Judeo-Christian Values, a small but vocal group, concurs. The association plans to sue the state to stop revision because any changes will inevitably "bring new taxes in and throw God out."
God and taxes -- and race -- were much on the minds of the 1901 Constitution's authors. Cotton plantation masters and industrialists, known as "Big Mules," saw to it that their tax burden remained light while the Bourbon-class lawmakers made it their mission to reassert white supremacy in Alabama and restore what they saw as divine order. Alabama's 1875 Constitution had made it possible for black men to vote. To the resurgent white gentry, this was intolerable. By instituting an expensive poll tax, as well as allowing local registrars to decide whether an applicant was of "good character," the 1901 Constitution robbed 98 percent of blacks and at least 40,000 poor whites of their right to participate in democracy.
The Voting Rights Act of 1965 eventually trumped Jim Crow. A provision banning interracial marriage, long ago rendered void by the United States Supreme Court, was finally voted out of the Constitution in 2000. But many see the real racism of the 1901 Constitution in a regressive tax regime that disproportionately hits the poor hardest.
For years, politicians have courted New South businesses, but a plantation-friendly tax system still shackles the state to the Old South. Under the Constitution, a family of four earning as little as $4,600 must pay income tax, in addition to paying sales tax on necessities like food.
The Constitution is far kinder to the rich. Alabama allows a full deduction for federal income taxes, which only middle- to upper-income people pay. The Constitution also hands landowners substantial tax breaks: if they claim that something is being grown for sale on the property -- even, say, a few bales' worth of hay on urban land owned by a mall developer -- the landowner pays a risibly low rate for property tax. Timber land is taxed at as little as 95 cents an acre.
If that isn't bad enough, local governments have no power to levy local property taxes to take care of community needs. The 1901 Constitution prevents home rule, so counties have to beg the State Legislature for action on everything from zoning to bingo games. Alabama's schools and universities have been deprived for a century, financed by volatile revenues from sales and state income taxes. The state now ranks 46th in the nation for supporting public education. Even a slight downturn in the economy means teacher layoffs, overcrowded classrooms and no money for repairs or textbooks. 
This is the Alabama the 1901 Constitution has made. More than 60 percent of Alabamians now want reform, recent newspaper polls say. But what sort of reform will depend on the framing of the argument.
The antireformers are using rising taxes as a scare tactic. God has become a useful tool for that camp, too. Roy Moore, chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, for example, has praised the 1901 Constitution for keeping taxes down. He's also personally interested in keeping God in the public arena. Late one night last summer, Justice Moore had a couple of workmen cart a 2 1/2-ton boulder inscribed with the Ten Commandments into the Supreme Court building in Montgomery. Meanwhile, his wife, Kayla Moore, an antireform activist, has said that "man is inherently evil" and that the Constitution restrains evil.
Some legislators have promised to keep God in the Constitution if they can simply rewrite the document amendment by amendment -- an exercise that could take years. Governor Siegelman says he favors a constitutional convention where the people can craft a new governing document for the new Alabama. Most Alabamians are tired of being tied to an unlovely, unjust past, but an election year is a tough time to talk about real change in a state where a word like "tax" has somehow become equated with sin.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Technology's Toxic Trash Is Sent to Poor Nations

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
The global export of electronics waste, including consumer devices, computer monitors and circuit boards, is creating environmental and health problems in the third world, a report to be issued on Monday by five environmental organizations says.
 The report says that 50 to 80 percent of electronics waste collected for recycling in the United States is placed on container ships and sent to China, India, Pakistan or other developing countries, where it is reused or recycled under largely unregulated conditions, often with toxic results. 
 The groups said there were no precise estimates of the amount of such waste currently created by the disposal of obsolete consumer electronic and computing gear. The Environmental Protection Agency estimated last year, however, that in 1997 as many as 3.2 million tons of "e-waste" ended up in United States landfills and that the amount might increase fourfold in several years. 
The groups also cited National Safety Council estimates that as many as 315 million computers have or will become obsolete from 1997 to 2004, generating a wide range of potentially toxic wastes.
For example, each color computer monitor or television display contains an average of four to eight pounds of lead, which can enter the environment when the monitors are illegally disposed of in landfills.
"We've created a problem that has to be dealt with," said Ted Smith, executive director of the Silicon Valley Toxics Coalition, one of the groups that participated in the report. The others are the Basel Action Network, Toxics Link India, Pakistan's Society for the Conservation and Protection of the Environment and Greenpeace China.
An E.P.A. scientist, Robert Tonetti, acknowledged that a significant portion of the nation's obsolete consumer electronics gear was exported. He said, however, that there was no systematic reporting of the shipments, so there was no way to gauge the extent of the problem accurately. "No one has a good grasp of the numbers," said Mr. Tonetti, a senior environmental scientist in the E.P.A.'s office of solid waste.
Mr. Tonetti said that figures in a 1999 National Safety Council report showed that about 723,000 computer monitors had been recycled in the United States and 100,000 had been exported. The report noted that more than a million monitors were unaccounted for and that many of them may have gone to parts brokers who subsequently exported the gear.
There is an international debate over how to deal with the problem, Mr. Tonetti said, adding that the European Union was moving toward requiring manufacturers to take cradle-to-grave responsibility for their products, particularly when they contain potentially hazardous materials. In contrast, the United States industry has resisted this approach, he said.
While there is no consensus on a solution, he said the environmental groups had focused on important issues that should have more attention. Mr. Tonetti added, however, that the cradle-to-grave approach was not endorsed by the United States government. Environmental groups, he said, have overlooked that much electronics manufacturing is now outside of the United States and Europe, complicating the issue of manufacturer responsibility.
He also said that a significant factor in the increased export of obsolete electronics from the United States was the closing of smelters here in recent years, frequently because of environmental regulations.
The report, "Exporting Harm: The Techno-Trashing of Asia," focuses on electronics recycling around the region of Guiyu in Guangdong province in China. The area, which is northeast of Hong Kong, includes a cluster of small villages that since 1995 have become a booming recycling center for electronic gear arriving from all over the globe through the port of Nanhai.
The region has a work force of approximately 100,000 people focused on recycling, the report stated, with the process broken into small, specialized cottage work groups. In one neighborhood, plastics may be salvaged, while in another, circuit boards may be smelted to extract trace amounts of gold and other valuable materials, according to the investigators, who visited the region in December last year. 
One casualty of the recycling boom in the region has been drinking water, the report says. Since 1995, as a result of groundwater pollution, water has been trucked in from 20 miles away.
The investigators said the recycling operations often involved young children, many of whom were unaware of the hazards. The hazardous operations included open burning of plastics and wires, riverbank acid works to extract gold, the melting and burning of soldered circuit boards and the cracking and dumping of cathode ray tubes laden with lead. 
The report described certain areas of Guiyu that were dedicated to dismantling printers. In those areas, toner cartridges were recycled manually, according to Jim Puckett, an author of the report. 
"Workers without any protective respiratory equipment or special clothing of any kind opened cartridges with screwdrivers and then used paint brushes and their hands to wipe the toner into a bucket," the report said. It added that the process created constant clouds of toner, which were routinely inhaled.
Mr. Puckett, coordinator of the Basel Action Network, said, "They call this recycling, but it's really dumping by another name." The network is an international watchdog group that is trying to enforce the Basel Convention, a 1989 United Nations treaty intended to limit the export of hazardous waste. The United States is the only developed nation that has not signed it. 
The convention calls on countries to reduce exports of hazardous wastes to a minimum and deal with their waste problems within their own borders where possible.
The authors of the report argue that stricter environmental regulations in the developed world have caused a trend toward exporting hazardous materials to the poorest countries, where occupational and environmental protections are inadequate.
The environmental groups took water and soil samples along the Lianjiang River and had them tested by a private center in Hong Kong. The results, the groups said, revealed alarming levels of heavy metals that corresponded directly with metals most commonly found in computers. The water sample, taken near a site where circuit boards were processed and burned, showed levels of toxic materials 190 times the levels for drinking water recommended by the World Health Organization.
The report also notes evidence of similar unregulated recycling operations in both Pakistan and India. The researchers said that Karachi, Pakistan, was one of the country's principal markets for second-hand and scrap materials.

HEADLINE: From Notes to Flowcharts 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 

 BODY:
During the 1980's the St. Louis Symphony rose from the heartland to become one of the most acclaimed orchestras in the United States. It toured and recorded widely, delighting both critics and audiences with its fine musicianship and creative musical direction.
 But about two years ago, with a suddenness that took even the orchestra itself by surprise, it plunged into a severe financial crisis caused largely by its ingrained habit of spending beyond its means. It faced the prospect of making devastating budget cuts in order to survive. 
 In recent months the orchestra, which was led for 24 years by Leonard Slatkin, one of the most admired American conductors, has been pulled back from the brink. A new management team has won extraordinary cooperation from musicians and is planning an ambitious fund-raising campaign. 
Many American orchestras are known for tough and sometimes bitter adversarial relations between players and management. If that was once the case in St. Louis, it is no longer. Faced with looming disaster, both sides have joined forces in a way that could prove a model for other orchestras.
Last month the two sides signed a new contract that includes a pay cut of about 8 percent for musicians, far less than was originally proposed. The contract also gives musicians a substantially greater role in planning the orchestra's future. Two musicians now sit on the 49-member board, and they are given access to most of the orchestra's financial records. Major decisions are made only after extensive consultation.
"This is not a well-worn path," said Timothy Myers, a trombone player. "We're figuring things out as we go along. But I'm optimistic because we're addressing the key issue, which is: What is the role of the musician? 
"We've already decided it's not merely to show up and play the notes on the page. But what is it? We're not fund-raisers, we don't plan the musical program, but we can contribute in those areas and in many others. I wasn't trained to do anything more than play the instrument, but that's not enough anymore."
The St. Louis Symphony reached its pinnacle of achievement largely by spending money, both to attract top players and to stage elaborate and expensive productions in its hometown and on tour. Although end-of-season deficits became routine, no one worried much because a handful of donors could always be found to contribute the missing cash.
But as the deficits began to grow, reaching a peak of $10.3 million in 2000, donors became reluctant. At the same time the orchestra was losing money on a variety of projects ranging from a conservatory that it took over in 1994 to summer pops concerts. Voters resoundingly defeated the orchestra's effort to join a group of local cultural institutions that receive annual subsidies from a property tax surcharge. An effort to start a homegrown recording label also failed.
Worst of all, the orchestra made little effort to increase its endowment, which now stands at $18 million. By the standards of orchestras to which some have compared it in quality, like those in Chicago, Cleveland, Philadelphia, New York and Boston, it should have at least $100 million.
Business leaders in St. Louis finally lost patience with the orchestra, concluding that it was not managing itself well enough to deserve further support. Last March a former banker, W. Randolph Adams, was hired as a consultant, and five months later he joined the orchestra as its president and executive director.
"It was clear right away that we had to move from arguing over how to cut up the pie to how to keep the boat from sinking," Mr. Adams said. "We all had to start bailing."
Soon after reviewing the orchestra's books, Mr. Adams proposed a number of radical budget cuts including a 30 percent reduction in musicians' pay. He also raised the possibility of reducing the size of the orchestra from its current complement of 92 musicians. Those steps would almost certainly have led to a palpable decline in the orchestra's quality.
"There was a lot of shock and anger and denial," said Jan Gippo, a piccolo player who is a leader of the musicians' union. "We hadn't seen those kinds of figures before. We came up with demands, and management's response was: 'Here are the books. What do you want us to do?' No one had ever talked to us like that before. So we decided to start learning about flowcharts and business plans.
"We could have just stood our ground and gone on strike, but instead we've worked our way into a new context. There's much more of a partnership, an idea of working together for the institution. It's put us on the leading edge. There's no other major orchestra that has this level of interaction with management at all levels, from the concertmaster down to someone in the back row who has an idea and puts it on the agenda."
Among its cost-cutting steps, the orchestra has turned its conservatory over to Webster University, canceled its summer pops concerts and cut its season from 52 to 42 weeks per year. These and other reductions, together with the willingness of musicians to make concessions, persuaded business leaders and other large donors to begin writing checks again.
The largest came from the Taylor family, which owns Enterprise Rent-a-Car. It donated $40 million, $5 million for operating expenses and the rest to help build the endowment. The donation was contingent on the orchestra raising an equal sum to match it, and so far $16 million has been raised toward that goal. In the last six months an additional $29 million has been raised for a separate fund that will be used mainly to pay off past operating deficits.
Two donors gave $1 million each toward maintaining musicians' salaries, which was one reason why their pay cut in the new contract could be held to 8 percent.
As the financial picture began improving, however, the orchestra faced new uncertainty on the podium. Its music director, Hans Vonk, who replaced Mr. Slatkin in 1996, has Guillain-Barre syndrome, a central-nervous-system disorder. He fell ill this month and was unable to lead the orchestra at concerts in New York and Los Angeles.
Mr. Vonk is expected to return to his post, and orchestra analysts say his illness should not affect the symphony's recovery.
"They're going to make it," said Fred Zenone, president of the Symphony Orchestra Institute in Deerfield, Ill., which monitors orchestras across the country. "The musicians made some major concessions because they recognized that they've got something quite valuable. If they hadn't gotten this situation resolved, many of them would have left, and those are people you can't replace by just holding auditions. 
"It's a permanent roster of people who know each other and have developed together. They have an identity, and it's really nice to know that the music world isn't going to lose that identity."
Everyone at the St. Louis Symphony seems to agree that the key to its long-term stability is a large endowment. A major fund-raising campaign aimed at building one is to be started soon. It will include a concerted effort to raise money from small donors, something the orchestra has not done before.
"This has become a community issue," said David Halen, the concertmaster. "We've gone on radio talk shows, played at fund-raisers and done everything else we could think of. It was a call to action. I think that call is in the process of being answered, but we're just at the beginning. The kind of figures that are needed to resolve the problem are daunting. Matching the $40 million gift is not enough. We need a $150 million endowment."
The orchestra's board chairwoman, Virginia V. Weldon, said that was not as far-fetched a goal as it seemed even a few months ago.
"We had a lot of credibility to win back, especially in the business community, but people who said it couldn't be done are starting to become believers," Ms. Weldon said. "We're telling them that this orchestra is one of the main civic assets of this community. Do we want to lose one of the few things other than sports teams that people across the country and beyond will recognize?
"It's like climbing Mount Everest. We've just reached the base camp. That was a long hike, and there's still quite a distance to the summit. We need oxygen. But we will get there. We're absolutely committed to it."

Saving the Symphony
Articles in this series will examine the ways in which symphony orchestras are coping with financial crises.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
F.C.C. Is Repeatedly Stung By Appeals Court's Rebuke
The rebuke of the Federal Communications Commission by a federal appeals court concerning broadcast regulations last week was far from unusual -- and is unlikely to be the last.
 Over the last year, the commission has lost a vital string of cases before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on issues ranging from telephone rates and wireless spectrum auctions to ownership limits in the cable and broadcasting industries. News Analysis. Page C2. 

In Style's World of Fashion
Introduced to widespread skepticism in 1994, In Style turned out to be a category killer in every respect. The monthly marriage of celebrity and style blurred two distinct coverage areas and became a hugely successful enterprise in a niche it invented. Its founding editor, Martha Nelson, is moving on to edit another AOL Time Warner magazine, People, but she leaves behind a changed landscape in women's magazines. The News Media. C7.

Genomics Database to Be Unveiled
A new genomics database is being unveiled this week that, its developers say, will definitively pinpoint human genes and help clear up the mystery of how many genes there are. The database, known as the Protein Atlas of the Human Genome, starts with human proteins, then works backward to determine the genes that encode them. C2.

San Miguel Chief Retains Control
Eduardo M. Cojuangco Jr., the beer magnate, appears to have once again successfully outmaneuvered government efforts to topple him as chairman of San Miguel, the most prominent company in the Philippines. C8.

Circuits From I.B.M. Are Now Faster
I.B.M. will announce today what it describes as the world's fastest semiconductor circuits, devices that will reach speeds in excess of 110 gigahertz, making possible a new generation of faster communication systems that consume less power. C3.

Intel plans to announce today that it has shipped the first server-computer chips based on its Pentium 4 line of microprocessors. C2.

'The View' to Get a Second Home
ABC's hit daytime talk show, "The View," is about to establish a second home, on the A&E Channel. The move is the latest in a growing trend toward placing very recent reruns on a cable channel that the network or its parent also owns. C7.

A Database of Web Site Owners
People who register a Web address may not realize that the personal information they give the company that handles the registration is made available to the public in a searchable database called Whois. This database enables Internet users to look up any Web address and find out -- in theory, at least -- who owns a particular address. Whois is accessible through the Web sites of most registrars, or at independent sites like betterwhois .com. New Economy. C4.

The Electronic Frontier Foundation and several law schools have created a searchable database for Web site owners who have received copyright infringement letters. C6.

Stepped Up Downloading of Songs
There are few issues that enrage record labels and many performers more than the downloading of songs off the Internet without permission or payment. Their problem may be becoming a lot worse. A visit to a Web site with a fiercely loyal following indicates that a growing number of people are downloading not just songs, but entire albums, cover artwork and liner notes included. The Pop Life. E1.

HEADLINE: Patents; 
To some, globalization, not corporate lobbying, is the real reason copyrights are growing in power.

BYLINE:  By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
THE battle over how long a copyright should last is often portrayed as a fight between Mickey Mouse's bosses and those who want to set him free to live where they believe he rightly belongs: in the public domain.
 As such, the sides in the battle are often starkly drawn. There are the giant music, movie and publishing companies, who support the 1998 Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act because it gives copyright holders an extra 20 years to exploit lucrative songs, stories and brand-name material. Then there are the scholars and supporters of the arts, who oppose the law, saying it is a fetter to inspiration and expression that prevents the public from freely accessing creative works. 
 For several years the sides have waged war in the courts, and last week the Supreme Court announced it would consider the question. In a battle pitting Property against Creativity, the court will focus on the more narrow question of whether the copyright extension law violates the Constitution.
There is an additional element of this dispute, however, often overlooked: namely, that the conflict is an outgrowth of the rapid transformation of United States intellectual property law that has taken place the last decade. Similarly intense, prolonged arguments erupted in the mid-1990's when the government moved to change the life span of patents and for the first time published patent applications 18 months after they were filed.
Both changes were made to bring United States laws in line with those in Europe and Japan. They were greeted with predictions of doom for American innovation, called violations of public rights and decried as the end of the tried-and-true patent system. Yet in spite of the heartfelt concern, once the new laws were in place, inventors adjusted.
So, although major corporations like the Walt Disney Company lobbied for the act, Mickey Mouse is not the only reason that Congress approved the law. 
"It's not just an arbitrary extension, but one designed to harmonize U.S. law with European law, as has been done in many other areas of intellectual property law," explained David Opderbeck, an intellectual property lawyer with McCarter & English, a Newark firm.
"That's a good justification for the extension," he added. "With the Internet, and technology and creativity becoming so global, some argument makes sense that those rules be as uniform as they can across borders."
Much of the creativity that crosses borders now does so in what Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America and an outspoken proponent of the copyright extension, calls the "the copyright industries" -- movies, home video and DVD's, TV programs, music, books and computer software. And he can quickly rattle off their immense value
"They contribute 5 percent of the gross domestic product in this country," Mr. Valenti said. "They create new jobs at three times the rate of the rest of the economy. They bring in more revenue than the automobile, agricultural and aircraft industries. The movie industry alone has a surplus balance of trade with every country in the world. No other industry can make that statement."
He believes some of that revenue and those jobs were threatened before the 1998 copyright extension law. The original copyright law of 1790 granted protection for 14 years. Over the years, that term gradually increased until, just before the Bono Act, a work of art copyrighted after 1978 was protected for "life plus 50," that is, the lifetime of the artist plus 50 years. Works copyrighted before 1978, or by corporations, won copyrights for 75 years. The 1998 law added 20 years to those terms.
"The reason for this extension was the fact that the European Union had different rules and we wanted to match them," Mr. Valenti said. "If we're dealing with the E.U. and our material goes into the public domain 20 years before theirs does, the Europeans can use our product over there and Americans get not one dime back."
"My counterargument is, what difference does 75 or 95 years make?" he added. "What is the consumer benefit of 75 years?"
Many artists and their heirs might also wonder how it serves the public interest to allow free access to a cartoon mouse in red shorts and white gloves. For them, the argument for extended copyrights is simple, and emotional. Why shouldn't the owner of a hit song or a best-selling book be able to bequeath that property to his children, just as he would the family farm, heirloom jewelry or a successful business?
"Maybe Mickey Mouse isn't necessarily the best example," said Mr. Opderbeck. "There's not a lot of cultural significance there, unless you ask my 3-year-old son."
"It's a little overstated to say the public has a right to intellectual property," he continued. But getting a patent or a copyright means entering into a bargain with the government, he said. "The deal is that you have to give it back at some point so it goes into the public domain, and the public can make use of it and improve upon it."
Extending a copyright simply awards a longer monopoly on something already created. And Mr. Opderbeck says that diminishes the power of copyrights to "promote the progress of science and useful arts," as is stated in the Constitution.
"If you've already created it, then there's no more incentive," he said. "You already got your side of the bargain."
It is hard to answer arguments raised by those who say copyrights stifle expression and creativity, and place undue burden on teachers, researchers and academics. But Mr. Valenti is willing to try. 
"Copyrights only stifle if you're going to copy something," he said. "The movie 'Gladiator' is a progeny of 'Spartacus.' 'Gladiator' is about a slave, just as 'Spartacus' is. But it didn't infringe on the 'Spartacus' copyright. There are only so many plots in literature. You just use them in different ways."
"I'm not saying the public domain is bad," Mr. Valenti said. "But how does it benefit the consumer? If a film is in the public domain, who takes care of it? Who refurbishes it if the print goes bad? What incentive does anyone have to keep the movie alive and vibrant?"
In the end, even if much of the argument arises from the emotional issues surrounding yet another major change to intellectual property law, it is now likely to be settled by the Supreme Court's interpretation of the act's constitutionality. And that will turn on whether Congress overstepped the instructions in the Constitution to award copyrights for a "limited period of time." Even Mr. Valenti does not advocate perpetual copyrights, but many advocates agree with him when he declares: "A limited period of time is whatever Congress says it is."

HEADLINE: Impatient Court Pres ses the F.C.C. to Deregulate 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
Last week's rebuke of the F.C.C. by the federal appeals court here was far from unusual -- and is unlikely to be the last.
 Consider another recent case, in which a different panel of the same court pelted a lawyer from the Federal Communications Commission with hostile questions as he tried to defend a significant rule limiting the expansion of media companies within a single metropolitan market. 
 Experts, including top commission officials, now expect that the regulation -- which generally bars a broadcaster from owning more than one station in a market unless there are at least eight other independently owned stations -- is doomed. The only question is whether in the next few weeks the court orders the agency to reconsider the regulation, known as the "eight-voices rule," or simply strikes it down.
That question is part of the broader trend. 
Over the last year, the commission has lost a vital string of cases before the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit on issues ranging from telephone rates and wireless spectrum auctions to ownership limits in the cable and broadcasting industries.
The agency was handed its latest setback last week, when the appeals court struck down one rule that had limited a cable company from owning a broadcaster in the same city, and ordered the commission to reconsider a second rule that prohibits a television network from owning stations that broadcast to more than 35 percent of the nation's homes.
Impatient with the slow pace of deregulation and unfilled promises of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the court has repeatedly shown disdain for the justifications for decades-old rules that had been offered by the appointees of the Clinton administration.
The court's impatience flashed in last week's opinion, when the judges noted that the telecommunications act's mandate "might better be likened to Farragut's order at the battle of Mobile Bay ('Damn the torpedoes! Full speed ahead.') than to the wait-and-see attitude of the commission."
Many regulations like those at issue in last week's decision have been vulnerable because, as a political compromise struck during the drafting of the 1996 act, Congress instructed the commission to justify many of its rules every two years. The biennial review has proved to be problematic for the commission, which has often tried to implement otherwise laudable goals such as promoting diversity of voices on the airwaves, or limiting the economic influence of cable companies by using what appear to be arbitrary numbers and standards.
As a result, the philosophically and politically diverse court has reached out with an unusual degree of unanimity to chip away at the regulations that have long restricted the nation's largest media conglomerates from expanding further.
"The F.C.C. has been getting very little deference," said Richard E. Wiley, a former chairman of the agency whose law firm, Wiley, Rein & Fielding, represents an array of broadcast and cable companies with issues before the courts and regulators. "This is a super-critical court. It is a court that is impatient that the F.C.C. has not properly justified its regulations."
Andrew Jay Schwartzman, president of the Media Access Project, a consumer group that advocates diversity of the airwaves and has tried to defend the commission's regulations, finds himself in a frustrating position.
"The commission is getting hammered in case after case, manifesting a deep skepticism and disdain for the F.C.C.'s decision-making process," he said.
Consumer groups, television affiliates and others on the losing end of the cases are preparing to once again ask Congress and the regulators to try to preserve the old rules. And they have some powerful allies in lawmakers like Senator Ernest F. Hollings, the South Carolina Democrat who heads the Commerce Committee. Repeatedly during the 1980's, Senator Hollings managed virtually single-handedly to preserve ownership rules like the one prohibiting a television station from owning a newspaper in the same city, simply by attaching riders to spending bills and other must-pass legislation.
"Since at least 1995, all we have heard is that the broadcast concentration cap will be repealed within six months," said Alan Frank, the chairman of the Network Affiliated Stations Alliance and the president of Post-Newsweek Stations, the unit of the Washington Post Company that owns six network-affiliated stations around the country. "I think the odds are still good that the cap will hold."
Still, many experts and lawmakers say that they believe that it will be harder than ever to retain many of the current rules in light of the actions by the court, the reticence of most of Congress, and the overall commitments of the Bush administration and top F.C.C. officials to deregulation.
"The stars are aligned for a variety of ownership limits to be relaxed, said Scott C. Cleland, chief executive of the Precursor Group, a research organization that studies regulatory and political trends in telecommunications.
While many of the policy changes being ordered by the court are consistent with the deregulatory views of Michael K. Powell, the commission's chairman, the decisions are a decidedly mixed blessing for his agency.
For years during the Clinton administration, Mr. Powell served as a Republican commissioner who often voted in dissent. He was openly skeptical of many of the same rules that his agency has more recently found itself unsuccessfully defending before the appeals court. In that sense, his admonitions have proven prophetic, and the court's own impatience with deregulation is more or less consistent with his own thinking.
But the court has also steadily undermined the F.C.C. as an institution, and the judges' disregard for the agency's decisions has raised new fears that it will embolden other companies to raise new legal challenges to a host of telecommunications rules. While he appears unsurprised by some of the court decisions, Mr. Powell finds himself troubled by some of their implications.
"It's a tough environment," he said last week. "The judges have raised barriers significantly, and are making it much tougher to justify some of the rules. They are skeptical of theoretical justifications for rules, without more empirical support and greater analytical rigor."
For Mr. Powell, who was appointed chairman last year, the appeals court's pronouncements are particularly poignant. He began his legal career as a clerk to Judge Harry T. Edwards, the former chief judge of the appeals court, who has been particularly critical of some of the commission's regulations and who remains an important mentor.
The appeals court has imposed a heavy legal burden on the commission to justify the regulations, leading some to conclude that it may, in the end, be legally impossible for the agency to adopt any standards. That too, has troubled officials like Mr. Powell, who -- though skeptical of some of the current restrictions -- does not support a completely unregulated market and is sympathetic to some of the goals of the old rules.
"If the presumption that some are hearing from these decisions is no rules, that's just not my philosophy," he said. "The goals of competition and diversity of media are very, very worthy. We need better, more sustainable approaches to those goals. Proponents of the current approach should not be afraid to delve deeper and see if their assumptions are valid and explore more rational and effective policy. What choice is there -- to keep pounding into the judicial wall with 30-year-old rules and rationales?"

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ASIAN ARENA; 
'Yankee Don't Go' Is Message In Philippines Antiterror Rally

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: ZAMBOANGA, the Philippines, Feb. 24 

 BODY:
The White House image makers, with all their expertise, money and sophisticated techniques, could not have choreographed a more emotive demonstration of support for America's war on terrorism than the ordinary citizens in this humble city put on today. 
 Under a hot morning sun, nearly 2,000 residents turned out -- grandmothers, students, government employees, the unemployed. They sang and prayed, waving Philippine and American flags and placards. It was the largest rally here in many years, residents said. 
 On a simple wooden platform a parade of men and women, representing the business community, women, youth, the urban poor and teachers, addressed the assembled in English and Chavacano, which is derived from Spanish. They all had the same message: We want peace, and thank you for coming, America. The sultan of Sulu and North Borneo quoted from the Bible and the Koran. "Christians and Muslims are neighbors, so we have to love one another," he said, to applause.
Philippine political analysts and diplomats in Manila say that the sentiments expressed here in support of the American military activity are overwhelming throughout the country, but have been lost in the vocal opposition of a small minority.
This port city of 600,000, at a southern point of the Philippine archipelago where the Spanish built a fort in 1635, has become the base for the American forces who are here ostensibly to train the Philippine Army in fighting terrorism. Some 160 American Special Forces soldiers are now on the island of Basilan, a quick helicopter ride across the water. The quarry is Abu Sayyaf, the organization whose kidnappings and bombings have terrorized this town for a decade. Under restrictions insisted upon by the Philippine government, the Americans cannot engage in combat and will only be here for six months.
"Americans should stay, forever," said Crispina Bayot Marquez, 72, wearing a straw hat and a white T-shirt showing the American flag. "They are like angels that have come from heaven, to save Filipinos." Her youngest son, Vincent, 34 and unemployed, stood in a gaggle nearby. He looked like a throwback to the anti-American protesters during the Vietnam War, with his scraggly beard and long black hair under a bandana as he waved a banner. Except the bandana was an American flag, and the flag at the end of his long bamboo was the stars and stripes.
The demonstrators gathered in a small square, flanked by a fast-food restaurant, a convenience store and karaoke bar that billed itself "the music brewery." Their message was aimed primarily at Manila, to the politicians and demonstrators there who have been vociferous critics of the American presence. "Shut Up, Manila," read a placard.
"We challenge those who say that we don't need the American soldiers to go to Basilan and fight the Abu Sayyaf themselves," shouted one speaker, Jose Mari "Bong" Bue, 38, the business editor of the Zamboanga Daily Times. "If they cannot or if they have no guts to take our challenge, then just shut up and give us the chance to live a normal life, which we feel we could get as an aftermath of this joint R.P.-U.S. military exercise."
The rally, organized by local civic groups and city hall, also had a message for the United States, beyond the thanks. "They should do more than train our soldiers," said Mr. Bue. "They should fight. We are tired of kidnappings. We are tired of the bombings."
After two hours, the rally was over. It ended with a long line of men and women on the platform, many in baseball caps, including one with the New York Yankees logo, leading the demonstrators in a song. 
With their arms in the air, swaying, the demonstrators sang "America the Beautiful." All the verses.

GRAPHIC: Photo: About 2,000 residents of Zamboanga, the Philippines, rallied yesterday in support of the presence of American forces fighting terrorists. (Carlos H. Conde for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: At U.N., Debating Who Gets the Right to Debate Human Rights 

BYLINE:  By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Feb. 21 

 BODY:
Ten months after the United States lost its seat on the United Nations Human Rights Commission, the panel's regional group of Western countries is wrestling with a formula under which such embarrassing surprises would not be repeated.
 The proposed arrangement would allot each Western state a fixed number of years on the commission over the next 20 years. Everyone agrees that the United States should have the most, and San Marino the least. But why should Italy have more than Canada? Must France have the same number as Britain? What about Portugal? 
 All those involved, save one, agree on one thing -- they are happy not to be saddled with the Solomonic task of creating the formula. The exception is Thorsteinn Ingolfsson, Iceland's ambassador, who has been assigned the job.
Mr. Ingolfsson was cautious in describing his task and the resistance he has encountered. "There is a proposal on the table, but obviously the different weight of member states plays an important role in this respect," he said. "I was asked to provide my good offices to try to arrange this."
Mr. Ingolfsson's task is to rotate 10 seats among 29 nations for 20 years, based on the size, merit and history of the countries.
To understand the problem, it is necessary to understand that almost all committee memberships at the United Nations are divided among geographic groupings. Each group decides who its representatives will be. But if the group fails to agree on a slate, its seats are thrown open to a vote.
That is what happened last May 3 at the Human Rights Commission. The group to which the United States belongs, "Western Europe and Others Group," failed to agree on its candidates, so the Economic and Social Council voted to give the three vacant seats for the group to France, Austria and Sweden. 
The United States, which had been on the commission from the time it was founded under American leadership in 1947 and which regarded its seat as a sinecure for which it did not have to campaign, came in a distant fourth. The vote was widely seen as a reflection of frustration at the time with the Bush administration's dismissive attitude toward international organizations and treaties.
But it was also an acknowledged embarrassment for the United Nations, especially when countries with appalling human rights records like Sierra Leone and Sudan won seats.
So the Western group -- which includes all of Western Europe, the United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Israel -- decided to develop a long-term rotating system. 
Though the elections are not until May, the group is hoping to have its system in place by the time the commission next convenes on March 18. Four of the group's seats are up for grabs this year, and five countries other than the United States have already declared their candidacies.
An agreement is far from certain. Mr. Ingolfsson's first proposal was rejected, and his second has raised strong objections. 
Under the draft, the United States would sit on the commission for 18 of the next 20 years (one of which it is sitting out now), Britain and France for 17, Germany for 15, Italy for 14, and so on down to 2 years for small nations like Andorra, Liechtenstein, Malta, Monaco, San Marino and -- in an apparent tribute to Mr. Ingolfsson's diplomacy -- Iceland.
Predictably, the objections have come from those in between. Canada, for example, would have a seat for 11 years. That hurts, because Canada has been a member for 21 of the last 25 years, and human rights is a priority in its foreign policy. Canada has prepared more resolutions than any other state.
The Portuguese ambassador, Francisco Seixas da Costa, said his country had been a member for 11 of the last 20 years, but would be restricted to 5 years. "We are very effective at winning elections," he said, suggesting that he would be happy to contest a closed ballot.
Most of the critics did not complain about giving the United States 18 years, and the Americans seemed happy with the proposed rotation, because after this year it would miss only 2018.
That means that additional years for some countries would have to be taken from other nations with the most years, including Britain and France. One advantage, diplomats said, was that if a year were taken from one of those nations, that would mean a year would be taken from the other as well, since neither would accept a minute's less time than the other had.
For Mr. Ingolfsson, any further changes would probably mean another lengthy round of hearing what great champions of human rights all these countries were, and fighting to snip a year here or a year there.
"Many member states are seriously interested in accomplishing this," he said, adding, "I really don't know what will come of this."

HEADLINE: Do Vouchers Help Choice or Religion? 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "A Matter of Church and State" (editorial, Feb. 20):
 The current outcomes produced by the voucher system may violate the Establishment Clause. 
However, if quality of education is considered as important as constitutionality, then declaring vouchers unconstitutional is not the solution. 
 Supply and demand dictate that, if the voucher system is found constitutional, the consolidation of vouchers toward religious schools could dissipate. If declared legal, demand for vouchers should increase. It is highly unlikely that the existing religious schools could satisfy this demand. Therefore, competing private schools would spring up, which in turn would reduce the percentage of religious schools receiving the vouchers, increase the educational options available to children, and eliminate arguments that voucher systems are religiously biased.

PAUL POAST
Columbus, Ohio, Feb. 20, 2002

The writer is a lecturer in economics, Ohio State University.

HEADLINE: Trying to Wean America From Oil 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
A Feb. 18 editorial calls oil import requirements an "addiction," implying a distorted motivation. It says the United States, with 4 percent of world population, consumes 25 percent of world oil. 
Yet America represents 25 percent of global G.D.P. 
 We import more than half our requirements. But dependency can be dealt with through supply diversity. For Mideast producers whose only important source of foreign revenue is oil, America is of vital importance. 
 The real issue is not dependency but vulnerability, or sudden unanticipated losses in supply. Yet we have a ready answer, the government's Strategic Petroleum Reserve. 
Your proposed move toward energy independence, a goal of the Carter administration, has been discarded as unachievable and not required. A sensible policy must reflect balance and diversity.

JOHN H. LICHTBLAU
LAWRENCE J. GOLDSTEIN
New York, Feb. 21, 2002

The writers are, respectively, chairman and president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation.
