HEADLINE: Hot Seat, Hard Times; 
City's New Cultural Affairs Commissioner Settles In

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
It is tough enough to take on the job of New York City cultural affairs commissioner just as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has proposed cuts of 15 percent to the agency's expense budget and 20 percent to its capital budget.
 But Kate D. Levin also inherits a department many arts professionals describe as in need of serious reinvigoration. Even as Rudolph W. Giuliani poured an unprecedented amount of city money into cultural building projects and became known for his love of opera, the agency charged with promoting the interests of New York's arts institutions quietly but steadily diminished in size and influence amid years of budgetary ups and downs. 
 Since 1990, the staff of the Department of Cultural Affairs has shrunk to 33 people from 65. (It was at 47 when Mr. Giuliani took office.) The department has been receiving a declining share of money each year from the city budget, according to a recent report by the New York Foundation for the Arts, a nonprofit arts support group. Since 1988 this has cost the agency nearly $250 million in inflation-adjusted spending, the report says. 
"The agency requires significant strengthening to operate more effectively as an agent, catalyst and convener for a large and complex cultural economy," the report, a yearlong study of the city's cultural industry, concluded.
And while the cultural affairs department right now is mostly a conduit for money from the city, arts professionals say that it has the potential to be much more, that the commissioner could lead the charge in making the case for culture as a sound economic investment for both government and the private sector.
The new commissioner "has to figure out how she wants to articulate the role of culture in this city's life," said Mary Schmidt Campbell, who served as cultural affairs commissioner from 1987 to 1991. During the era of Mayor Edward I. Koch, for example, cultural affairs became a symbol that "this city is not going to die," Ms. Campbell said. When crack was rampant, Ms. Campbell continued, Mayor David N. Dinkins missed an opportunity to use cultural affairs as a way to say, "Here is the affirmative side of city life."
Norma P. Munn, chairwoman of the New York City Arts Coalition, a citywide arts advocacy group, and others say the commissioner must argue for culture as a financial engine. This was the theory that held the greatest sway with Mr. Giuliani, as Anthony P. Coles, the deputy mayor who oversaw cultural affairs under Mr. Giuliani, noted. "The mayor tended to look at the arts in large part as economic development -- what's it going to create in jobs and income back to the city?" he said. 
Will Ms. Levin be able to wield the same argument successfully? "Everybody's watching," Ms. Munn said.
In an interview at her office on West 42nd Street in Manhattan, Ms. Levin suggested that she knew the limitations she faced. "The cupboard is bare," she said. "There is only so much you can do. It will be my nonstop effort to see that the cultural community is made whole to the extent that it's possible."
Complicating matters, Ms. Levin comes to the post when arts institutions are still struggling with declines in attendance and a difficult fund-raising climate in the wake of Sept. 11. Many institutions report drops in ticket sales of 10 percent or more, and foundations offering emergency money to arts groups have been deluged with applications.
The commissioner's job will be made tougher by having to walk the line between building strong ties to the mayor and challenging him if necessary on behalf of cultural groups. Mr. Bloomberg, who has served on the boards of Lincoln Center and the Jewish Museum, among other cultural groups, has already said that Lincoln Center's $1.2 billion redevelopment and other major capital projects may have to be put off. Ms. Levin's predecessor, Schuyler G. Chapin, was widely criticized for doing too little too late in defense of the Brooklyn Museum of Art in its clash with Mr. Giuliani over the "Sensation" exhibition, which featured a black Madonna with elephant dung.
But Ms. Levin has been in city government before. She helped Diane M. Coffey, Mayor Koch's chief of staff, run the cultural affairs department on an interim basis when Bess Myerson stepped down as commissioner. And she has worked with Patricia Harris, Mr. Bloomberg's deputy mayor, who oversees cultural affairs as part of her portfolio. Ms. Harris was also assistant to Mayor Koch and executive director of the Art Commission of the City of New York.
Both Ms. Coffey and Ms. Harris were said to be instrumental in putting Ms. Levin forward for the job. Among the candidates Ms. Levin beat out were Laurie Tisch Sussman, chairwoman of the Center for Arts Education, and Stephanie French, formerly vice president for corporate contributions at Philip Morris.
Ms. Levin, 41, who grew up on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, is also a seasoned New Yorker who has moved in cultural and literary circles. Her father, Wilbur A. Levin, is the Kings County clerk. Her mother, Phyllis Lee Levin, is a writer. Her husband is the sculptor Mark di Suvero (they have a 7-year-old daughter), who started the Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens, where Ms. Levin served as a consultant.
With a magna cum laude degree from Harvard and a doctorate from the University of California at Berkeley, Ms. Levin spent the last six years teaching English Renaissance literature and theater history and directing 16th-century plays at the City College of New York. In 1997 she was appointed associate director of the Simon H. Rifkind Center for the Humanities at the college. Ms. Levin earned tenure last year and is currently on leave.
Before earning her Ph.D., Ms. Levin worked as an arts consultant for the Jim Henson Foundation and for the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where she also served as director of corporate relations and director of special projects. So she comes to the job knowing she has more than budget cuts to address, namely the distribution of money to the 34 organizations that make up the city's Cultural Institutions Group and to other nonprofit arts organizations. 
The organizations in the Cultural Institutions Group, which are owned by the city or on city land, are now guaranteed 85 percent of the cultural budget. The rest is distributed among what are known as the program groups, which include about 500 institutions, as large as the Museum of Modern Art and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and as small as the Pan Asian Repertory Theater in Manhattan and the Queens Historical Society. (Mr. Giuliani also established the Cultural Challenge Initiative, which distributes $5 million each year to several hundred arts groups that apply for financial help and have to raise matching private donations.)
Many program groups feel that the distribution of city money is inequitable, while supporters of the Cultural Institutions Group argue that tax money should go primarily to taxpayer-supported institutions. 
In her first public remarks since being named commissioner, Ms. Levin earlier this month described the city as an inconsistent partner for the program groups and said she hoped to steer more money toward them. "It troubles me that there is a kind of second-class-citizenship status," she said.
In addition, arts professionals say, the process by which grants are awarded is ad hoc, the criteria are unclear. Even Ms. Campbell, now dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, conceded that the system needs improvement. "If you try to find some logic or reasoning behind it you will go insane," she said. "In many ways it could be better. But I'm not sure how you would define fair."
Mr. Giuliani's cultural commissioner, Mr. Chapin, 78, helped change city policy so that the program groups could be eligible for money from the capital budget. He is also widely credited with adding a graceful, courteous mien to the agency and advocating on behalf of art in the schools. 
But his agency also lost clout with City Hall and saw its staff depleted in the Giuliani years. Some arts executives say that the mayor simply went around his Cultural Affairs Department to deal with arts groups directly and that his Office of Management and Budget really called the dollars-and-cents shots for the agency. Others say he gave the agency attention.
Mr. Chapin says he made a conscious decision to work quietly from within rather than to challenge the mayor. "I made up my mind that the best way to work with him was to stay off his radar screen," Mr. Chapin said. "I never tried to horn in on anything other than that which was necessary."
City officials say it has been a struggle for the agency to keep up with the workload. 
Ms. Harris suggested that Ms. Levin would have no trouble getting the ear of City Hall. "I can tell you," Ms. Harris said, "Kate will be very involved in this administration."
Those familiar with Ms. Levin's background and personality say she is prepared to seize the opportunity. "She understands the mission, which is to be the chief advocate for the arts in the city," said Ms. Coffey, now managing director at Peter J. Solomon Company, an investment banking firm, who served on Mr. Bloomberg's transition team. As Mayor Koch's chief of staff, Ms. Coffey made Ms. Levin her executive assistant from 1986 to 1989, and she described her recently as "absolutely brilliant." 
Perhaps the most important task for the new commissioner will be fighting to limit erosion of the cultural budget during the current economic hard times. Ms. Munn said that the last time the city's cultural organizations were significantly cut back was in 1992, and it took five to six years to recover.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kate D. Levin, New York's new cultural affairs commissioner, says, "The cupboard is bare." (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush's Plan on Welfare Law Increases Work Requirement 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER and ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
Opening what could be a rough, yearlong debate about welfare, President Bush is proposing to increase the work requirements for welfare recipients and push the states harder to meet them.
 The administration, which already unveiled part of its plan to overhaul the landmark 1996 welfare law, plans to announce its proposals on Tuesday. Mr. Bush told the nation's governors meeting here today that he would ask Congress to approve new work requirements but would also seek to give states the flexibility to meet the needs of people who need training or drug abuse treatment. 
 Still, Mr. Bush said, "work ought to be the core of welfare reform." 
In an excerpt from an advance text of his speech, Mr. Bush declares: "We are encouraged by the initial results of welfare reform, but we are not content. We ended welfare as we've known it, yet this is not a post-poverty America. Child poverty is still too high, too many families are strained and fragile and broken -- too many Americans still have not found work and the purpose it brings. Because these needs continue, our work is not done."
At least 50 percent of a state's welfare families must now participate in work and other activities aimed at self-sufficiency; Mr. Bush proposes to raise that requirement so that 70 percent must be working by 2007. Administration officials also said they hoped to close loopholes that render the work requirement, in some cases, largely meaningless.
The administration plans to require welfare recipients to work 40 hours a week "at a job or in programs designed to help them achieve independence." Adults are now generally required to work 30 hours a week, of which no more 10 could be in job training or education programs.
A fact sheet released by the administration tonight said that the plan would "make special accommodations for parents with infants and individuals who need substance abuse treatment, rehabilitation or special work-related training."
Gov. John Engler, the Michigan Republican who is chairman of the National Governors' Association, and Gov. Paul E. Patton, the Kentucky Democrat who is the group's vice chairman, said governors were generally pleased with what they learned about the plan, though details were tightly held until tonight.
But advocates for low-income people were already starting to mobilize against the plan.
"It's almost welfare reform in Wonderland," said Deepak Bhargava, director of the National Campaign for Jobs and Income Support, a group seeking to liberalize the welfare law. "We're in the middle of a recession. Now is a strange time to be arguing we ought to toughen work requirements on poor families."
Administration officials said the Bush plan would allow for creative combinations of job training, education and work. Increasing poor people's opportunities for training -- and thus moving up the economic ladder -- is a primary goal for Democrats and some Republicans on Capitol Hill this year.
Douglas J. Besharov, a welfare expert at the American Enterprise Institute, said combining tougher work requirements with more training possibilities permitted the administration "to go left and right at the same time."
Mr. Bush's proposals come as Congress begins to review the 1996 law, much of which expires this year. That law abolished entitlements for cash assistance for poor families, replacing them with block grants to states and new work requirements.
Mr. Bush plans to argue, aides said, that the 1996 law was an unalloyed success. He will also, aides said, try to refute the idea -- held by some welfare experts -- that the booming economy was the most important factor in the substantial drop in welfare cases in recent years.
The aides also said Mr. Bush considered welfare legislation a primary goal this year, and many analysts have suggested it may be one of the few major measures that could pass in this intensely political year.
In their fact sheet, Bush officials said they would seek to extend the existing five-year ban on federal welfare benefits for immigrants who entered the United States after 1996 and have not become citizens. 
The fact sheet also said the administration would direct "up to $300 million" for programs aimed at "encouraging healthy, stable marriages." That included a $100 million fund for experimental programs on marriage training at the state level that had been previously announced.
The administration indicated it would give states the "flexibility to streamline and coordinate" support programs like food stamps and child care that help poor families with the transition from welfare to work.
Though the law stipulates that half the adults on a state's welfare rolls be working, the requirement's significance has been eroded by another provision of the law. A state that has cut its welfare caseload since 1995 is given credit toward meeting the work requirement. In many states, the caseload has shrunk so much that they are no longer subject to a significant work requirement for those people remaining on welfare. Bush aides said they wanted Congress to impose more meaningful work requirements. 
This year, as in 1996, Republicans and moderate Democrats may find areas of agreement. Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, chairman of the centrist Democratic Leadership Council, said: "Philosophically, the president is heading in the right direction. We need to make sure that the tools are there for people to meet the work requirements, and that states have some flexibility."
Mr. Bayh said he and Senator Thomas R. Carper, Democrat of Delaware, were writing a bill that would gradually raise work requirements. 
Representative Sander M. Levin of Michigan, a leading Democratic expert on welfare, said he could not evaluate Mr. Bush's proposal without more information, which the White House has yet to provide.
"The acceptability of the increase in work requirements will depend on whether states have adequate flexibility to combine work with the training necessary for people to move up the ladder and achieve financial security and independence," Mr. Levin said.

HEADLINE: Deputy Is Appointed to Direct Food and Drug Agency as Impasse Continues 

BYLINE:  By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
After months of disagreement with Senate Democrats over a nominee to be commissioner of food and drugs, the Bush administration named a food safety expert today to run the Food and Drug Administration as deputy commissioner until a permanent chief was found.
 The appointment of Dr. Lester Crawford, director of a research institute affiliated with Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, effectively lets the administration install its own person at the agency without having to worry about Senate confirmation. 
 In the fall, Tommy G. Thompson, secretary for health and human services, discreetly circulated the name of Dr. Crawford, a veterinarian with a degree in pharmacology, at the Capitol, telling selected lawmakers that Dr. Crawford was his choice for commissioner. Mr. Thompson has been especially concerned about food safety, which is what drew him to Dr. Crawford, who has been administrator of the Agriculture Food Safety and Inspection Service in the Agriculture Department. 
The commissioner of food and drugs has traditionally been a medical doctor, and people familiar with the selection process said the White House might have preferred a physician for the agency's top job.
"Lester Crawford has devoted his career to promoting safer products for the public," Mr. Thompson said in announcing the appointment, "and he brings to the F.D.A. valuable experience and leadership skills. With his help, the F.D.A. will continue to build on its successes in ensuring the safety of foods, drugs and medical products for all Americans."
As Dr. Crawford begins work immediately, a spokesman for the health department, Bill Pierce, said the White House was "actively looking for an F.D.A. commissioner." 
The agency is a vast organization that regulates products that account for one-fourth of the American economy. Because it monitors food safety and approves new drugs and vaccines, it has taken a growing role in domestic security as the administration tries to improve defenses against bioterrorism.
Lawmakers and health experts have been saying it is critical for the White House to name someone as commissioner soon. Among them is Dr. Gail R. Wilensky, who ran the Health Care Financing Administration under President George Bush.
In an interview, Dr. Wilensky said today that Dr. Crawford's appointment "takes maybe a teeny bit of the pressure off." But, she added, "it does not take the place of having a duly confirmed political appointee."
The agency has lacked a commissioner since Mr. Bush took office. It has been run by a career employee, Dr. Bernard A. Schwetz. 
In seeking to fill the position, Mr. Bush has faced a quandary. If he names someone with close ties to the pharmaceutical industry, he angers Senate Democrats. If he names someone who lacks those ties, he angers industry executives.
Already, that tension has scuttled two candidates. Last week, the White House informed Dr. Alastair J. J. Wood, an expert on drug safety who had been widely considered the leading contender, that he did not have the position. Drug executives had objected to Dr. Wood, describing him as too aggressive a regulator.
Another candidate, Michael J. Astrue, a biotechnology lawyer, drew opposition from Senate Democrats, particularly Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, because of his industry ties.
Because he comes from academia, Dr. Crawford would appear to escape that criticism, although consumer advocates have argued that his institute, the Center for Food and Nutrition Policy, receives too much support from industry.
"His distance from industry is more semantic than real," Michael F. Jacobson, executive director of Center for Science in the Public Interest, an advocacy group, wrote to the White House when Dr. Crawford's name surfaced in the fall.

HEADLINE: A Sluggish Swiss Insurer Shifts Management a Bit 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
Rolf Huppi will resign as chief executive at Zurich Financial Services, which has had a 60 percent drop in its share price over a year, the company said today.
 But Mr. Huppi will remain chairman, the company said. No successor as chief executive has been named, meaning Mr. Huppi, 58, will continue to run the company at least through midyear. 
 The stock rose on the news, even though the announcement did not bring the sweeping changes many analysts say were necessary to resuscitate the fortunes of the 130-year-old insurance group.
"It's a glass-half-empty announcement," said Alain Kupferschmid, insurance analyst for the Darier Hentsch Bank. "The company really needs a big change in its operational side."
Mr. Huppi, who has worked at the company since he was a teenager and has been chief executive for 11 years and chairman for 7, had been under pressure to give up one of the posts. He survived a no-confidence vote at last year's shareholders' meeting, and he told a Swiss weekly last month that he had no plans to step down. But Zurich Financial issued four earnings warnings last year, and the sagging share price finally obliged him to give up day-to-day control of the company.
Further complicating Zurich Financial's situation was a request today from Swiss insurance authorities that the company explain its profit forecasts and give details of its financial condition. The regulators made the same request of Swiss Life, the country's largest insurer, which has also been hurt by difficult markets. Each company will now have to meet with the regulators before reporting results for 2001; Zurich Financial now plans to release its results on March 21.
The latest forecast, in December, was for a loss of $200 million to $400 million, mainly because of some $760 million in losses directly related to the Sept. 11 terror attacks and a $900 million write-down on its investment portfolio, hit hard by the global economic downturn. 
Earlier this month, Standard & Poor's lowered Zurich Financial's credit rating to AA-, because of concerns about flagging earnings, eroding capital and inconsistent management. For example, Mr. Huppi tried to increase profits by buying Scudder Investments, an American mutual fund company, and a financial services unit of British-American Tobacco, only to sell them again last year as earnings fell. The company also sold its reinsurance unit, renamed Converium Holding, raising some $2 billion.
Among major Swiss financial services firms here, only the Credit Suisse Group now combines both top posts in a single executive, Lukas Muhlemann. 
There is no clear successor to Mr. Huppi. Constantine Iordanou had been heir apparent, but he quit after five months as chief operating officer. For now, Peter Eckert has been named to oversee group operations and business development, beginning on March 1, the company said.
Another contender, James Schiro, will join the company that day as chief operating officer for group finance. He comes to Zurich Financial from PricewaterhouseCoopers. But analysts say Mr. Eckert's insurance experience gives him an inside track.

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: CORPORATE CULTURE; 
At Enron, Lavish Excess Often Came Before Success

BYLINE:  This story was reported by Neela Banerjee, David Barboza and Audrey Warren and was written by Ms. Banerjee. 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Feb. 25 

 BODY:
For years, the Enron Corporation thrived on spending big, and even as late as October -- with warnings ringing loudly about its rickety finances -- no one at Enron saw any reason to change.
 The company had set aside $1.5 million for a Christmas party at Enron Field, Houston's sparkling new sports stadium, hoping to match the sumptuous gatherings of earlier years. Only in mid-November, when a ruined Enron was heading for bankruptcy and trying to sell itself to Dynegy, its crosstown rival, was the celebration finally called off. 
 Everything Enron did had to be better and flashier -- from the new business ventures it unveiled nearly every year to the way it celebrated Secretaries' Day with gifts of Waterford crystal -- and no gesture seemed too lavish, workers and competitors agree.
Extravagance, by itself, did not bring the company down. But the company's spending reflected a go-go corporate culture, former employees said, in which top executives cast traditional business controls by the wayside. And that -- from top officers who insisted they were unaware of financial details to a relaxed attitude about conflicts that let executives sit on both sides of multimillion-dollar deals -- figured heavily in Enron's collapse. 
"The lack of risk controls was mind boggling," said Gary Cardone, president of Dynegy Europe, whose parent company has hired a number of energy traders and other employees from Enron. "The Enron culture went way too far."
Vance Meyer, a spokesman for Enron, said such criticisms were unfairly vague. "When allegations are made about controls and culture at Enron, my hope is that people don't paint all employees with the same broad brush, despite what a handful of people might or might not have done," he said. "There are 20,000 great people here who deserve a shot at putting this company back on its feet."
Enron distanced itself from those it considered the old fogies of the energy industry, laying claim instead to being among the mold-breaking dot-coms, a company reliant on information and new ideas rather than hard assets. And like many an Internet start-up in its heyday, Enron spent freely on image and luxury.
At employee meetings for one division, Enron International, a live elephant made a cameo appearance -- twice. Enron Energy Services, another money-losing unit, spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to build a Potemkin-village trading floor to impress equity analysts invited to a conference, though the unit had no trading function. For one family picnic, Enron rented the 85-acre Astroworld amusement park.
At work, the attention to quotidian comfort was boundless: free laptops and hand-held devices, the best ergonomic chairs money could buy, office lunches at Houston's best restaurants. Workers fondly recalled the day in May 1998 when Enron's shares surpassed the $50 mark and the company left $100 bills on each employee's desk.
"Appearances were very important," said Jeff Gray, a former economist at Enron Energy Services. "It was important for employees to believe the hype just as it was important for analysts and investors to believe it."
Although many large corporations routinely treat employees to trips and amenities, at Enron, the scale of spending was vast, particularly by Houston's standards. 
"Enron was doing so many things on the edge," said Carol Freedenthal, a principal at Jofree Energy Consulting here. "The Enron people were really living high on the hog compared to most energy people. Nobody went like Enron."
And many employees concluded that they deserved the perks, since joining Enron often meant 12-hour workdays and ceaseless travel. 
"I would go away for a three-day trip that would turn into a three-month trip," one former Enron International executive said.
Devotion was well rewarded. Enron paid much better than its counterparts in Houston and often competed with top Wall Street firms for talent. Enron employees flew first-class or business-class and stayed exclusively at luxury hotels. The company's parking garage was filled with Porsches, Ferraris and BMW's, emblems of the sizable bonuses many employees earned. 
Gambling was popular, as at many high-risk, high-reward companies. The annual N.C.A.A. basketball tournament pools, in which college teams were "auctioned" to fans, sometimes reached nearly $90,000, another former Enron International executive said. 
In the early 1990's, Enron took clients to the Hyatt Regency in Beaver Creek, a luxurious Colorado resort, for ski trips, but over time such visits mostly turned into an internal Enron perk, this executive said. For one meeting in 1999, Enron flew in more than 300 of its vice presidents from around the globe to the Hyatt, where rooms now start at $320 a night. "It was three days of fun in the snow," one manager said. "It must have cost them a fortune."
Employees in the broadband unit, Enron's failed attempt to enter the high-speed Internet delivery business, frequently used sport utility limousines, even to go to lunch, and stayed in five-star hotels. "Nobody I ever worked with stayed in a Holiday Inn," said Katherine Harper, an administrative assistant who handled expense reports for the unit.
The bill for all this was footed by Enron Capital and Trade, the natural gas and electricity trading business (later called Enron North America) upon which the company built its reputation in the years before its collapse. The message within Enron, employees said, was that the trading business would subsidize huge investments in new ventures like broadband, international power projects and retail energy services until these, too, became money makers. But they never did. 
"We'd run up these huge bills, but we weren't making any money," one Enron International manager said. "Enron Capital and Trade made all the money, and we spent it."
Spend they did. In the fall of 1997, the 1,000 or so employees of Enron International gathered at the Del Lago Resort outside Houston for the unit's annual meeting. To open one morning session, the two top executives, Rebecca Mark and Joseph Sutton, rode into the room and onto the stage on Harley-Davidson motorcycles, engines revving as the Survivor song "Eye of the Tiger" blared. Dressed in leather jackets and chaps, they told the pep rally that the international unit was unstoppable. 
Each division then put on a skit it had polished for weeks, often with the help of professional choreographers. The capper was when one executive in charge of Enron's big power project in India rode in on a horse and another entered on an elephant. It was the second year that an elephant made it to the gathering, former employees said.
The same culture of competitiveness spurred Enron units to try to outdo one another in the extravagance of their Christmas parties. In 2000, employees of Enron Energy Services attended a black-tie party at the Museum of Natural Science in Houston, its rooms decorated with ice sculptures. That same year, Enron Capital and Trade feted its employees and their companions, about 5,000 people, at Enron Field; one guest remarked on the overabundance of everything that night -- the food, the liquor, the number of waiters. (Last year's planned party at the stadium was to be an all-company affair, in recognition of Enron's straitened circumstances.)
Enron also spared few expenses to impress outsiders. In early 1998, the company hoped to persuade Wall Street analysts it invited to Houston that a new venture, Enron Energy Services, would soon deliver big profits. Assuming that the analysts would be most impressed by the hurly-burly of trading, Enron in three weeks built a highly advanced trading floor at its headquarters.
As first reported by The Wall Street Journal, former employees said they rehearsed what to do in front of the analysts, and on the big day, computer technicians and secretaries were brought in to pretend that they were Energy Services "traders." Enron declined to comment on the episode.
Enron executives had a flair for generating new businesses and renaming old ones. Units were sometimes reorganized three or four times a year, which always meant moving people around, at a cost of roughly $500 a person just to set up a new desk, according to Cheryl Brashier, who worked at the company for nearly 11 years as an administrative assistant. On any given weekend, several hundred people would be moved from one floor to another at Enron headquarters, she said. 
Accounting had a hard time keeping up with the continual reshuffling, former employees said, and that gave departments the chance to hide lavish spending. Once a business was reorganized, it received its own accounting "cost code," or identification number, but the old codes were not immediately expunged.
"We were supposed to keep to budgets and orders were supposed to go through us," Ms. Brashier said, describing the work of administrative assistants. But employees circumvented procedures by ordering items on their own and by charging purchases to the newly abandoned cost centers. 
Like other former employees, Ms. Brashier and her friend Angela Buis, who worked in the Broadband unit, remember Enron's excesses with a mix of amazement and wistfulness.
Ms. Brashier's boss at Enron Capital and Trade, for example, sent 22 secretaries on a New Orleans trip to thank them for their hard work.
"We knew we weren't making money," Ms. Buis said. "But the extravagance, you know, is what made it great to work there."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Optimistic Reports by G.M. and Lowe's Push Shares Up

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks rallied yesterday after General Motors and Lowe's said business was picking up and a report showed that existing homes sold at a record pace in January.
 Together, the news suggested that consumer spending was driving a rebound in corporate profit. 
 "The worst is over," said Eric T. McKissack, manager of the Ariel Appreciation Fund. "The market is getting more confident." 
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 177.56 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,145.71, its highest close in seven weeks. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 45.34 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,769.88, its biggest one-day gain since Jan 3.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index advanced 19.59 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,109.43, led by General Electric and Intel.
Speculation -- prompted by the Enron scandal -- that companies have used accounting to overstate profits is overdone, said Edward Kerschner, chief global strategist at UBS Warburg.
"Earnings quality is remarkably good," he said in a research note.
Expectations for an economic recovery were bolstered by a report from the National Association of Realtors that showed home sales increased more than expected last month.
General Motors climbed $2.37, to $55.48. G.M., the biggest automaker, raised its estimate for first-quarter and full-year earnings, citing better-than-expected sales in the United States.
Ford Motor, the No. 2 automaker, advanced 65 cents, to $15.23. DaimlerChrysler rose $1.85, to $39.73.
General Electric, the biggest company by market value, gained $1.11, to $39.20.
Lowe's rose $1.44, to $47.49. The company, the second-largest home- improvement retailer after Home Depot, said first-quarter profit would top analysts' estimates and that fiscal fourth-quarter earnings had jumped more than expected.
Intel, the largest chip maker, rose $1.49, to $31.02, and Microsoft gained $1.09, to $59.08.
Sun Microsystems rose 80 cents, to $8.87, trimming its decline this year to 28 percent.
A Banc of America Securities analyst, Joel Wagonfeld, said Sun Microsystems, a maker of server computers that run Web sites and corporate networks, was inexpensive and would benefit in the second half as demand picked up. 
Williams Communications fell 29 cents, closing at 22 cents and extending its decline this year to 91 percent.
Williams Communications, a phone-and-data network operator, said it might seek bankruptcy protection from creditors, threatening to leave its former parent, the Williams Companies, responsible for $2.6 billion of costs.
The Williams Companies, meanwhile, tumbled $1.46, to close at $14.84. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
By Reuters
Treasury bond prices slid yesterday as stocks soared.
A record 16.2 percent increase in existing-home sales, to a 6.04 million annualized unit rate in January, also took the wind out of Treasuries as the data underscored a vibrant and healthy housing market and raised hopes for a swift recovery.
The 10-year note fell 6/32 , to a price of 100 7/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from price, rose to 4.85 percent from 4.82 percent on Friday.
The price of a 30-year bond fell 11/32 , to 100 6/32 . Its yield rose to 5.36 percent from 5.34 percent.

HEADLINE: EATING WELL; 
Unraveling a Caviar Mystery

BYLINE:  By Marian Burros 

 BODY:
WHEN Russian sevruga caviar was selling for $20 to $30 an ounce a couple of years ago, a thought crossed my mind: How does Trader Joe's sell it for $11? I asked the same question for years when caviar wars in New York at Christmas produced unbelievably low prices. Now I think I have the answer.
 Some people who sell caviar are crooks. The business of buying and selling one of the rarest, most highly prized foods in the world has always had more than its share of bootleggers, smugglers, counterfeiters and run-of-the-mill greedy entrepreneurs willing to destroy a species to make a buck. 
 These days it is both easier and harder than ever to skirt the law, because the best caviar in the world comes from the dwindling population of sturgeon in the Caspian Sea, which is bordered by nations of the former Soviet Union, where smugglers and poachers operate freely. At the same time the United States has tightened restrictions on caviar imports to protect the fish. 
Dr. Ellen Pikitch, director of marine programs for the Wildlife Conservation Society, said there has been more than a 40 percent decline in the population of mature beluga sturgeon in the northern part of the Caspian Sea in the last seven years, and that there is no longer evidence of mature beluga sturgeon in the middle and southern Caspian.
Since 1998, three major cases of caviar smuggling have led to convictions, jail terms and fines, in one case of $10 million. The most recent was announced by the Justice Department last month. Many individual couriers have also been caught trying to smuggle suitcases of caviar into the United States. 
Four years ago, when controls on imported and domestic caviar went into effect under the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, the Fish and Wildlife Service of the Interior Department stepped up surveillance. Now importing and exporting caviar require documentation and permits. 
"We are looking into something that was probably rife with black market dealings for decades," said Sal Amato, who is in charge of law enforcement at the Maryland and Delaware offices of the Fish and Wildlife Service. "There's too much money to be made, too much incentive to circumvent the guidelines that have been set up to preserve the sturgeon."
In the latest case, Alfred Yazbak, president and owner of Connoisseur Brands Ltd. of New York, is scheduled to go to prison for two years and will pay fines and duties of $185,000 for "conspiring to smuggle protected sturgeon caviar," "selling counterfeit caviar to retail food companies with false labels" and "making false statements" over four or five years, according to court papers.
Retailers who purchased caviar from Connoisseur, like Dean & DeLuca, Balducci's and Zabar's, say they were duped. The criminal activity affects domestic caviar as well. Because of the reduced supply of Caspian Sea caviar -- it is more difficult to import and there is less of it than before -- some unscrupulous dealers are buying the roe of the American paddlefish and selling it as Russian sevruga.
The Fish and Wildlife agents called their undercover efforts Operation Malossol, for the method of preserving caviar by lightly salting it, and Operation Wedgehead, for the nickname of the American paddlefish. 
In a recent sting, an agent posed as a buyer from the specialty food chain Sutton Place Gourmet, which owns Balducci's. Mr. Yazbak sold him what he claimed was Russian sevruga caviar, but DNA testing proved it was not; the vast majority of the eggs came from American paddlefish, a protected species indigenous to the United States. Paddlefish caviar is not as expensive, but, the Justice Department said, "it can be passed off to the uninformed consumer as sevruga caviar from the Caspian Sea." 
Rod Mitchell, owner of Browne Trading, which sells fish and caviar to many of the finest restaurants in the country, said an expert caviar buyer could definitely tell the difference between paddlefish caviar and sevruga. "Paddlefish caviar has a very distinct taste and a slightly muddy flavor," Mr. Mitchell said. "It's very different. If you see cheap caviar you know it's illegal, meaning bootlegged, previously frozen or there's something wrong with it, and people who buy it are interested in only one thing: price."
While the first sting against Mr. Yazbak was under way, another Fish and Wildlife agent, posing as a fisherman, warned Mr. Yazbak that the paddlefish roe he was selling was illegal. Mr. Yazbak bought it anyway. (Lest anyone think government agents killed protected fish for the operation, they used roe that had been seized in another unlawful harvesting operation.) 
In one taped conversation, Mr. Yazbak told the phony fisherman that he wanted everything he could bring him, whether it was of good quality or not.
Mr. Yazbak was also convicted of purchasing black-market caviar smuggled out of the former Soviet Union in the luggage of couriers. Because the caviar was not in the best condition, it underwent a process known as caviar washing. The frozen caviar is defrosted, drained of its oil, washed with salted water, mixed with walnut or hazelnut oil to disguise bad smells or tastes and then partially pasteurized. It is sold as unpasteurized caviar, the most expensive kind.
"Caviar smuggling is not that much different from narcotics smuggling," said Richard A. Udell, a senior trial lawyer at the Justice Department who prosecuted two of the major cases. "Law enforcement must assume it is only catching a small part of the criminal conduct. These people have helped to hasten the demise of a prehistoric animal."
Talking about a friend who had already gone to jail for smuggling and mislabeling caviar, Mr. Yazbak told an undercover officer: "They'll put him in jail for it. I don't want to go to jail. You know. Not for caviar."

HEADLINE: They Steal Napkins, Don't They? (And That's Just a Start) 

BYLINE:  By DONNA PAUL; Additional reporting by Amanda Hesser.

 BODY:
ON a recent Friday night at Ten Penh, a sleek fusion restaurant in Washington, three friends gathered around a table of small luxuries: a tin of caviar the size of a hockey puck, many pink cosmopolitans and three mother-of-pearl caviar spoons.
 It was an evening to savor. And one of the women -- a 32-year-old design professional who will remain nameless -- wanted a little something to help remember it. She wanted one of those little spoons. 
 "I rationalized that the restaurant probably had 200 of them," she said. And with that thought, she slipped the spoon into her bag. After wiping it clean with a napkin, of course. 
As chefs have achieved celebrity status, dining out has become a theatrical event, with the setting and the props as thrilled over as the tuna tartare. Restaurants have become temples of design, filled with beautiful objects. And diners are helping themselves to more than just the bread. A lot more.
From $3 water glasses to $1,200 silver ice buckets, from vintage photographs hanging on the walls to scented candles burning in the bathrooms -- if it isn't nailed down, diners have walked off with it. Over the course of a year, restaurants around the country lose as much as 3 percent of their earnings to theft by customers who seem to be getting more brazen by the minute. Demitasse spoons, Peugeot pepper mills, imported wineglasses, Frette linens, framed artwork, serving platters, Champagne buckets. The list of stolen goods boggles the imagination. And the ways restaurateurs are coping with the phenomenon is changing the dining experience for everyone.
"I'm considering installing metal detectors at the door," said Geoffrey Zakarian, the chef and owner of Town in Manhattan. He was only half joking. Within three months of the restaurant's opening last March, at least 125 of its dot-patterned custom-designed glasses were missing. Not to mention the 60 place settings of Richard Meier flatware that disappeared, or the 200 logo ashtrays. 
Sitting at the bar on a recent afternoon, Mr. Zakarian gestured to the silver cocktail shakers and almost casually mentioned how they have been taken, "with ice still in them." Once, he watched a customer open her purse and pop two glasses inside it. As she left, he introduced himself and said, "I am flattered that you have chosen my glasses to steal, enjoy them." 
Perhaps Danny Meyer should have been even more flattered. At his restaurant in the Flatiron district, Gramercy Tavern, a designer sconce was ripped from the wall in the men's room during the dinner service. Mr. Meyer didn't bother replacing it. Still, he wondered, "How do you possibly add value, for the customer, to the experience of going into the bathroom?" So, he burns ginger and grapefruit candles by Jo Malone that cost him $25 each. And those are out the door on a daily basis. 
At D'Artagnan in Midtown, Ariane Daguin, an owner, trained employees to count every item on the table and be sure it all comes back, particularly the $32 Laguiole steak knives. "Those were easy to take because you could fold them," she said. 
One night a waiter spotted a man putting one in his napkin. "So what I did was, I put it on the bill," Ms. Daguin said. "And when they saw the bill, they decided to return the knife. That's how we dealt with it."
Then there is the matter of stolen artwork. Incredibly, large paintings and photographs disappear from restaurant walls. At Colvin Run Tavern, Bob Kinkead's new spot in suburban Virginia, "we caught someone taking a photograph of me and Bill Clinton," Mr. Kinkead said. "You know, under a raincoat, one of those deals. I said 'Give it back,' and he gave it back."
Eleven Madison Park in New York had a $1,500 vintage photograph taken. 
And Lydia Shire, the chef and owner of Biba in Boston, was crushed when one of her treasured possessions vanished: "The day my mother's painting was stolen, that was it for me," she said.
Since then, Ms. Shire has taken over Locke-Ober, one of Boston's oldest dining establishments, and she has had other losses to endure: a $1,200 silver Champagne bucket from Paris, silver coasters and a Murano glass decanter. All are gone.
The impulse to take things is powerful, and complicated. Suzanne Goin, the chef at Lucques in Los Angeles, says customers think that because they're spending money it is acceptable for them to take what they want. They may want a souvenir of the evening, like the woman at Ten Penh, or a thrill, or even a measure of revenge, if they were unhappy with the experience. 
Some simply can't resist the allure of a great-looking object. One diner at Town, a 50-year-old man who calls himself an obsessive collector, entered the men's room and was struck by the display of plastic Statue of Liberty replicas arranged grid-like on the wall. "I thought it was incredible, innovative, really cool," he said. And as his eyes scanned the wall, he noticed five had been removed. He wiggled one of the statues. It popped off -- and went right into his pocket. 
After 200 statues were taken, the restaurant sealed them all behind plexiglass.
Restaurants figure on losing 2 to 3 percent of their "service ware" over the course of a year, said Arlene Spiegel, the president of Arlene Spiegel & Associates, a food and beverage consulting firm in Manhattan.
Most chefs agree that theft contributes to the rising cost of menu prices -- though not enormously. They chalk it up to the cost of doing business, something that's more of a constant nuisance than a serious dollar issue. The items stolen aren't usually worth enough to submit an insurance claim, let alone a crime report. And even when they are, restaurateurs tend not to. Not one of the dozens interviewed for this article has ever prosecuted a customer for theft.
"It's really expensive to prosecute," Mr. Kinkead said. "For the amount you're going to spend, and the time spent in court, it's not worth it."
Prof. Robert McCrie, who teaches security management at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said that everyone in the hospitality industry struggles with this issue. "The conflict is, what is the patron permitted to take with impunity and encouragement?" he said. "Business cards, matchbooks, leftover food -- that's it. Beyond that, these people are committing a criminal act, and should be treated as such." If a small item is taken, it's petty larceny, he said; if the value is $1,000 or more, according to the New York State penal law, it is grand larceny.
Gary Levy, a partner at J. H. Cohn, an accounting and consulting firm that specializes in restaurants, said that his clients budget 2 to 3 percent of their gross sales to replacing "lost" items. That includes breakage, wear and tear, and theft.
"Anything with writing on it says 'take me,' " said George Germon, an owner of Al Forno in Providence, R.I. Tracy Nieporent, the marketing director for the Myriad restaurant group, which owns several New York restaurants, concurs. "An item is very game for taking when the restaurant's name is on it," he said.
The restrooms, however, seem to have their own subculture, where emboldened thieves will stop at nothing. Faucets are the big item here. Yes, faucets. Mr. Germon woefully tells his tale of the disappearance of an antique bronze fixture from France. He had had a pair of them installed in the men's room. One evening, as the chefs were tending to the wood fire, preparing the restaurant's famous grilled pizza, someone else was busy in the men's room, removing the precious antique. The thief even took the time to install a replacement faucet that was a cheap American reproduction. "I couldn't believe it -- whoever did this knew exactly how," Mr. Germon said. "They were so good, they even used Teflon tape."
A similar thing happened at Oran Mor, a restaurant on Nantucket. On a busy Saturday night, as Peter Wallace, the chef and an owner, was sweating over the stove, he was told that the faucet handles in the ladies' room had been removed. This time, the thief left no replacement. "It was so infuriating," Mr. Wallace said. "We had to use vise grips to get through the night."
At Lucques, Ms. Goin laments the loss of flowers from the restrooms. "The customers walk right out the door with them," she said.
Preventing theft, said Stephen Zagor, the director of management programs at the Institute for Culinary Education in New York, is a matter of vigilance. "Keeping a watchful eye," he said. Without the customer noticing, of course. "We teach our managers-to-be or our owners-to-be to impart a feeling of ownership to the waiters." 
For example, what seems to be a gracious act of service -- the tuxedo-clad waiter wielding a pepper mill the size of a baseball bat -- is more likely a restaurateur's attempt to prevent theft of pepper mills that once sat on the table, Mr. Meyer said.
Bradley Ogden, the Northern California restaurateur, makes the waiters responsible for retrieving the small saucepans he uses to serve some dishes at his new restaurant, Parcel 104, in Santa Clara. He figures that the pans are likely targets, and says making the waiters feel responsible gives them "ownership mentality."
It isn't just the waiters who are watching, either. The bathroom attendant is there to do more than hand out towels, and those video cameras restaurants have begun installing to monitor service also help keep an eye on customers. 
"It is obviously a theft issue, but it's also a security issue," Ms. Spiegel said of the cameras and attendants. "No one will come forward and tell you it's a theft issue."
Restaurant designers are becoming more aware of creating "control points," she said, meaning that expensive objects are placed where someone is always nearby. Steve Hanson, the owner of Blue Water Grill, Blue Fin and other Manhattan restaurants, uses antitheft hinges to bolt all artwork to the walls and glues down other pieces of art.
Tom Douglas, the chef and owner of the Dahlia Lounge in Seattle, learned the hard way. He was busy cleaning the kitchen one night when one of his prize $1,000 fish-shaped lamps disappeared from the dining room. The last table was lingering late, he recalls, and the waiters weren't paying attention. It was only after the room cleared that they noticed the papier-mache and bamboo lamp on that table was gone.
"It was not an easy thing to take, the shade was the shape and size of a 15-pound rockfish," Mr. Douglas said. After that, he screwed the lamps to the tabletops. 
No wonder some restaurants are becoming less extravagant with their decor. It's a double-edged sword, said Mr. Meyer, who believes that one of the ways restaurants distinguish themselves is by making the tabletop look special. But the more attractive it is, the more guests want what's on it. 
When Mr. Germon opened Al Forno with Johanne Killeen, the couple hand-carried 2,000 pieces of overscaled silverware from Italy. In six years they were all gone. Then, Ms. Killeen said, the couple went to France and brought back more silver. That, too, is gone. Today, their flatware is an Asian knockoff of the original Italian pattern. 
Ms. Spiegel knows of a restaurant that went to a cheaper napkin once they began noticing that they always came back with fewer Frette napkins than they put out. 
"It's a collection of things that devalue the overall dining experience," Ms. Spiegel said, "and I think at this time, in this economic climate, restaurants are really looking at these ways to save money."
Finally, many restaurateurs have decided the best strategy is to simply go into the housewares business themselves.
Mr. Zakarian has since made the more "popular" items at Town for sale. Not a bad idea, considering he sells the pepper mills that cost him $75 for $200. D'Artagnan also sells the Laguiole knives (though Ms. Daguin worries that when diners see the price, they may be more inclined to steal them, not less) and the silverware. If customers ask, Mr. Meyer, who is also an owner of Eleven Madison Park, Tabla and other Manhattan restaurants, offers much of what they use, wholesale.
One 60-year-old woman, who has been taking silverware and plates from restaurants for nearly 40 years, spoke about it with passion. And entitlement. "It was all about the shape and having the name on it," she said, of the many spoons she has slipped into purses and pockets from such legendary places as La Grenouille, the Carlyle Hotel, the Tour d'Argent in Paris and the Hotel de Paris in Monte Carlo. Even a spoon from the Mount Sinai cafeteria. Yes, the hospital.
Now all are glued neatly into a gold frame and on display in her dining room. Recently the spoon collector has slacked off. And not because restaurants are making it more difficult. Most, she complains, no longer emblazon their logos on their spoons.
"If there's a place that still has some silver with a name on it," she said, "let me know."

HEADLINE: Consumer Confidence Declines On Concern About Employment 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence fell this month as concerns about unemployment and the reliability of company earnings reports dimmed enthusiasm that had been building since September, a private research group said today.
 The Conference Board reported that its gauge of sentiment dropped to 94.1 after rising to 97.8 in January. The decline was the first in three months and was larger than expected. More than 80 percent of those surveyed indicated they were concerned about jobs. 
 The decline may be a one-time occurrence that also reflects doubts over stock values in the wake of revelations about deceptive accounting at the Enron Corporation, analysts said. Consumers remained optimistic about economic conditions in coming months.
"While consumers see the future as reasonably bright, they live in the present," said Oscar Gonzalez, an economist at John Hancock Financial Services Inc. "They're worried about their jobs, but at the same time, I think they sense that this mild recession appears to be ending, and that will raise their hopes."
The confidence index sank to its lowest level in seven and a half years in November as Americans were still reeling from the September terrorist attacks. Since then, confidence has increased as the country made progress in the war against terrorism and evidence built that the economy was rebounding from its economic slump.
While February's gauge of consumer expectations for the next six months fell to 93.6, it is still the second highest since August. 
"Expectations are the key" to increased consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the economy, said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. The expectations index "is unlikely to fall too much further and remains consistent with consumer spending growth of about 3 percent."
The index measuring current conditions dropped to 94.8 this month, the lowest since October 1994, from 98.1 in January. That may be the result of an unemployment rate that reached its highest in six and a half years in December and a decrease in stock values.
The Conference Board report showed less optimism about labor markets. The share of consumers who said jobs were plentiful fell to 17.8 percent in February from 18.4 percent in January. The share that said jobs were not so plentiful rose to 59.4 percent from 59.1 percent.

HEADLINE: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe Runs Against an Old Rival: Colonialism 

BYLINE:  By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

DATELINE: HARARE, Zimbabwe, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
The political banners proclaimed: "Zimbabwe will never be a colony again." The crowd roared its willingness to fight the old enemy. When President Robert Mugabe finally stepped behind the microphone today at a campaign rally in a ramshackle township here, he was ready for battle.
 Mr. Mugabe described the presidential elections, on March 9 and 10, as the last round of the liberation struggle, the last chance to rid the country of the vestiges of colonialism. He assailed the opposition candidate, Morgan Tsvangirai, as a front man for whites who hoped to control the country. 
 "We must decide whether we shall be the decision makers of Zimbabwe, or whether the British and their settlers here, using stooges, will remain in power over us," cried Mr. Mugabe, who is 78. "Imperialism must fail! We must crush it here."
Westerners scoff at the notion that Zimbabwe might be threatened by its white minority or by Britain, the former colonial ruler. After all, Mr. Mugabe won his liberation struggle 22 years ago when he became this country's leader and ended white rule. But his message still resonates with some Zimbabweans.
In many ways, the coming election reflects this divided nation's struggle to come to terms with the past, and the role that history should play in the future. Almost every day now, the relevance of the liberation struggle in modern Zimbabwe is debated.
The government says that whites here and abroad have undertaken a campaign to demonize Mr. Mugabe in an effort to derail his plan to force the white minority here to return land that was seized from blacks during colonial rule. 
Opposition party supporters say the struggle with whites is largely irrelevant in a country where blacks control the government, and most ordinary people struggle just to survive. The opposition says Mr. Mugabe is using whites as scapegoats to avoid taking responsibility for a collapsing economy.
But even opposition officials acknowledge that the anxiety about whites still simmers in some places. Whites here still control more than half of the fertile land as well as the banks, manufacturing and mines. Whites are also financing the opposition party of Mr. Tsvangirai.
This week, he was charged with treason along with two colleagues in what the government described as a plot to assassinate Mr. Mugabe supported by Britain and the United States. The opposition dismissed the charges as a ploy to sully the reputation of its leader before the election. 
Whether voters accept Mr. Mugabe's message will certainly influence the outcome of next week's election. In the impoverished Harare township of Epworth, which voted overwhelmingly for the opposition in the parliamentary elections in 2000, the debate bubbled up in shouts and murmurs today as thousands of people awaited Mr. Mugabe's arrival.
"He fought for liberation and he wants to leave what he fought for to the young generation," said Edward Raposa, 39, who was waving a banner with a picture of Mr. Mugabe. "The economy is still in the hands of the whites. That has to change."
Norman Viyora, a 29-year-old opposition supporter, disagreed.
"Me, I don't think it's going to be a colony if this opposition party wins," Mr. Viyora said. "That's the message that's being spread, but that's not the reality."
Mr. Viyora said that he and others were forced to attend the rally by government supporters who went door to door before Mr. Mugabe arrived and threatened anyone who expressed reluctance.
Mr. Mugabe blamed whites for sabotaging the economy and vowed today that the economy would improve if he was reelected.
"I won't let you down," Mr. Mugabe said. "I won't retreat. I don't know the word surrender. I didn't know it in the past and I don't know it now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Mugabe at a campaign rally yesterday in Harare, Zimbabwe. (Joao Silva for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Rethinking Dire Warnings By Insurers After Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Last fall, soon after the attack on the World Trade Center, the nation's insurance companies, supported by bankers, builders and real estate companies, warned that if Congress did not shield the insurers from losses in future attacks, terrorism coverage would vanish and the economy would grind to a halt.
 But Congress did not act. Now, two months into the new year, the consequences appear to be far milder than the insurers suggested. 
 Commercial insurance costs in general have risen steeply, and terrorism coverage, still extremely limited, is particularly expensive. But there is growing evidence that American businesses and their insurers are solving their problems without Washington's help. 
Terrorism coverage, which was unobtainable immediately after the September attacks, is becoming more widely available and in larger amounts. Premiums are falling as more insurers enter the market.
So what of the dire predictions? The proponents of government intervention, which include Bush administration officials, maintain that hard times are coming -- that calamity has simply been slow to develop. They say that the lack of full terrorism coverage at reasonable prices is creating a drag on the economy, the effect of which may not be felt for months.
"This is a slow-moving glacier that will destroy everything in its path," said Stephen Bartlett, the president of the Financial Services Roundtable, an association of some of the largest insurers and banks.
The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, echoed those concerns in a report released yesterday afternoon. The report, requested by Representative Michael G. Oxley, the author of legislation providing for government assistance that has so far succeeded only in the House, cited nine examples across the nation of unidentified commercial property owners being unable to get full or partial terrorism coverage or being unwilling to pay what insurers were asking. A Congressional hearing on terrorism coverage is scheduled for this afternoon.
But Congress's interest in the issue has generally cooled as it has become preoccupied with the Enron debacle, and major business disruptions have yet to occur. Many insurers doubt that, barring another major attack, any help will be coming from Washington.
Some in Congress still say that they favor government intervention, but no action is scheduled. "The air has been taken out of the balloon," a Democratic staff member in the Senate said. "The urgency doesn't seem to be there. We're now into February, and we don't seem to have a major problem."
Proponents of Washington intervention contended last fall that without terrorism coverage, banks would stop lending, real estate transactions would halt and new construction would cease.
Insurers, who had previously included terrorism coverage in standard commercial policies, began excluding it, saying that the risks were unpredictable and potentially bankrupting. The only hope, they said, was government intervention.
So far, that seems to be an overstatement. More than a dozen entrepreneurial insurance companies are now collectively offering up to $500 million in coverage per building. This is less than the cost of replacing the tallest buildings, those most likely to be attacked, but more than enough for most commercial properties. The policies cover physical damage to property from terrorism and, in some cases, loss of business income.
Dazzled by the enormous premiums that terrorism coverage is generating -- sometimes 10 or 20 times basic commercial property insurance -- several other insurers, including Allianz of Germany, Swiss Reinsurance and Zurich Financial Services, are considering offering it.
"They're looking at this as a new product line to grow their revenue," said Gary Mathieson, a senior executive at Willis Group Holdings, a big insurance broker.
For their part, businesses are either paying for terrorism coverage or betting that they are unlikely targets and can put off buying policies until premiums drop.
Scores of corporations are talking with consultants about setting up their own insurance companies. The Air Transport Association of America, the trade group for the nation's big airlines, said it hoped to decide soon whether to start an insurance cooperative.
In New York, some big real estate transactions have stalled over negotiations for terrorism coverage, but others are proceeding. The market for bonds based on commercial mortgages, which are secured by buildings, is going strong.
Darrell Wheeler, a financial analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said the terrorist attacks have had virtually no effect on 80 percent of the $70 billion market in commercial mortgage bonds. Most older bonds are trading at about the same prices, he said, and new ones are being issued. But for the remainder of the market, there is some reluctance to finance projects of $100 million or more, he said, and some investors are reluctant to buy bonds tied to individual office towers, apartment buildings and shopping malls.
Instead of foreclosing on existing loans because buildings now lack full insurance coverage, lenders are increasing their interest charges, requesting borrowers to put up more cash, or, as a real estate executive said, "holding their breath."
Some financial institutions have also begun softening their insurance coverage requirements. Instead of insisting on full coverage, some lenders now just say that borrowers should make "reasonable efforts" to obtain terrorism coverage.
Mr. Mathieson said that $100 million in terrorism coverage could easily cost $5 million to $10 million a year, down from $20 million at the end of last year, but this is an approximation. Late last year, a nationwide retailer, which did not want to be identified, said it received quotes of $3 million and $7.5 million for $150 million of terrorism coverage. Now, Mr. Mathieson said, the retailer is buying the coverage for $450,000.
Kenneth A. Froot, a financial economist at Harvard Business School, confirmed this trend. "It looks like the market is beginning to work this out," he said. "We haven't moved to the point where we have as much coverage as we need. But we should see continuing improvement over the next 12 to 18 months."
Proponents of government intervention say that the situation is worse than it appears, but that documenting the harm is difficult. "Nobody wants to be seen as having a 'serious' problem," said Deborah B. Beck, executive vice president of the Real Estate Board of New York, an association of brokers, builders and financial institutions. 
Sheila C. Bair, assistant secretary of the Treasury for financial institutions, said the Bush administration remained committed to legislation that would pay 90 percent of all terrorism losses in excess of $10 billion.
Professor Froot and some other economists say that the government should keep its distance from terrorism coverage. "There are big benefits from delaying any government plan," he said. "First, the true price will emerge, as opposed to an artificial one. Second, prices will force people to make decisions about construction and security. With government intervention, that is not going to happen."
For some, though, the prospect of letting the economy find the way is daunting. "If this were a superhot economy, there might be more room for the economy to perfect itself," said Darcy Stacom, an executive vice president at Cushman & Wakefield, one of the largest commercial real estate brokers."
Commercial insurers said that even though they had more than $100 billion in capital, twice their losses from the September attacks, they could be wiped out by a cataclysmic terrorist attack, leaving claims unpaid.
"Not having a government backup for major terrorist attacks now is like saying you don't need an army until war has been declared," said Maurice R. Greenberg, chief executive of the American International Group, one of the world's largest insurers. "The industry has limited capacity. So while there is some coverage being offered, the reality is that it's not very much in relation to the potential need."
Both critics and supporters of intervention expect government assistance in the event of another big attack.
Business executives do not want to wait. Nelson Rising, chairman of the Real Estate Roundtable, is among those who argue that it would cost the government nothing to create a mechanism to protect insurers against monumental losses. The protection might never be used, he said, but it would give insurers confidence to offer abundant coverage at affordable prices. "By not taking action in advance," Mr. Rising said, "you run the risk of destabilizing the economy."

HEADLINE: Homeless Man Is Convicted Of Murder in 1989 Stabbing 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT F. WORTH 

 BODY:
More than 12 years after a young computer engineer was stabbed to death in the vestibule of his Upper West Side apartment building, a Manhattan jury convicted a homeless man yesterday of a second charge related to the slaying, concluding a case that had languished for years and that had ultimately been decided by the testimony of a fellow panhandler.
 The defendant, Frank Barnes, was convicted of felony murder charges yesterday, a day after being convicted of second-degree murder following a three-day trial. The felony murder charge applied because Mr. Barnes committed the crime in the course of another felony, in this case robbery, prosecutors say. 
 Mr. Barnes shook his head after the first verdict was read on Monday and denied his guilt until Justice Leslie Crocker Snyder of State Supreme Court in Manhattan told him to behave himself. He had no reaction to the second verdict yesterday.
Family and friends of the victim, David Burns, attended the trial, and expressed their relief afterward about a case that had seemed a lost cause. "We've been waiting for this a long time," said Bob Burns, 48, the victim's older brother. "It's mind-boggling how one episode can change so many people's lives."
That episode began when David Burns, 32, was stabbed to death as he returned from his girlfriend's house to his apartment on West 114th Street on July 29, 1989. The murder shocked the neighborhood, and at the time some residents said aggressive panhandlers in the area might have been to blame.
But investigators found few leads, and Bob Burns hired a private investigator in the early 1990's, to no avail. In 1996, officers in the Police Department's cold-case squad took over the case, and arrested Mr. Barnes, just over a year ago.
The trial turned on the testimony of James Salter, 40, an unemployed security guard who said he had seen Mr. Barnes running near the scene of the killing with a knife in his hand and blood on his shirt, and saying, "I shouldn't have done it, he didn't have any money anyway."
Mr. Salter, who was homeless and addicted to drugs at the time, said that Mr. Barnes tried to force him to jump in front of an oncoming subway train a few weeks later but that he escaped by running to the next station on the tracks before the train arrived.
Mr. Barnes's lawyer, Sol Schwartzberg, tried to cast doubt on Mr. Salter's trustworthiness by highlighting his lengthy history with drugs and petty crime. But Mr. Salter, who is no longer homeless and said he had been free of drugs and alcohol for almost five years, never wavered in his testimony.
Mr. Barnes faces up to 25 years to life in prison at his sentencing, scheduled for March 26.

HEADLINE: Alabama Governor Set for Tough Race 

BYLINE:  By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 21 

 BODY:
When Donald Siegelman became governor three years ago, there was much talk that a new day had dawned in Alabama politics. 
 Mr. Siegelman spoke of improving schools, of consensus, of revamping the state's Constitution, a document of the Old South. He offered experience, having been elected lieutenant governor, secretary of state and state attorney general. 
 And he mostly avoided superheated language, the hallmark of so many Alabama politicians of the last half-century, including Fob James, whom Mr. Siegelman, a Democrat, handily turned out of office in the fall of 1998, though not before Mr. James had suggested that a Republican primary opponent was a "fat monkey" and insisted that the Bill of Rights did not apply in Alabama.
So three years later, is there really a new political day in Alabama?
Not yet, say many of the people who had high hopes for Mr. Siegelman. 
Battered by aggressive special-interest lobbies, weakness in the economy, a shortfall in tax receipts and a whiff of scandal, Mr. Siegelman has slipped steadily in the polls almost from the day he took office. By his own account, the governor, who turns 56 on Sunday, faces "a tough, hard-fought campaign" for re-election in the fall.
In trying to make good on his campaign promise to create a state-run lottery to finance education improvements, Mr. Siegelman ran afoul of several powerful lobbies, especially church and education groups. After church groups killed the lottery proposal, the education groups insisted that he find the money elsewhere, an all but impossible task with the economy faltering and every special interest grabbing for the remaining revenue.
Frustrated at being caught between the political power of the church groups and the intense anger of the education lobby, the governor threw up his hands at one point and lamented, "I have no Plan B."
Besides the policy challenges, the Siegelman administration faces accusations of cronyism and other misdeeds in the awarding of state contracts. State and federal prosecutors have won several guilty pleas after uncovering evidence that some state agencies awarded lucrative business contracts to the governor's friends and supporters without seeking competitive bids. Just last week The Birmingham News disclosed that some of his personal financial records had been subpoenaed. 
The paper also reported that in filing financial disclosure statements with the Alabama Ethics Commission, as is required of top state officials, Mr. Siegelman had failed over the last few years to list at least $100,000 in earnings from various investments and transactions, and been forced to file amended statements. 
Mr. Siegelman says the earnings were understated because the disclosure forms are confusing. As for his subpoenaed financial records, he denies any personal wrongdoing and accuses Republicans of conspiring to use leaks to the press to smear him as the election campaign gets under way.
State Attorney General Bill Pryor, a Republican, and the United States attorney in Montgomery, Leura Garrett Canary, an appointee of President Bush, declined to comment.
The latest polls, taken two weeks ago for The Birmingham News and The Mobile Register, suggest that the governor's prediction of a tough campaign may prove squarely on the mark. 
While showing Mr. Siegelman easily ahead in the race for the Democratic primary on June 4, the polls found him neck and neck with two Republican candidates: Lt. Gov. Steve Windom, whom Mr. Siegelman trailed by a couple of percentage points, and Representative Bob Riley of the Third Congressional District, in the east-central part of the state, whom the governor led by a couple of points. In the Republican primary matchup, Mr. Windom was ahead of Mr. Riley by about 10 points.
"It's unusual for a lieutenant governor, or a congressman little known beyond his own district, to be doing this well this soon against an incumbent governor," said Larry Powell, a political scientist at the University of Alabama-Birmingham who conducted the Birmingham News poll. "And his situation may be even worse than it looks at first, because the two latest polls were completed before word got out that his own financial records had been subpoenaed."
Mr. Windom, who calls Mr. Siegelman "ethically challenged" and whose campaign advertisements promise that "I'll stop the no-bid contracts," ridiculed the governor's assertion that Republicans were conspiring to smear him.
"If there's a conspiracy," Mr. Windom said, "it's a conspiracy by the governor and his administration to enrich the cronies and friends of the administration at the expense of the taxpayer."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Donald Siegelman has encountered tough sailing ever since he was elected Alabama governor in 1998. His re-election is now in doubt. (Associated Press)
