HEADLINE: Smart, Generous, Low-Key And Indicted in Bribery Plot 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
He was the man who understood the arcana of an arcane process, a former tax assessor whom building owners could hire for a not inconsiderable fee and feel confident that they had retained the man who knew just what it took to convince an assessor to keep their tax bills down.
 There was nothing flashy about Albert Schussler, people in the real estate industry said yesterday about the 85-year-old tax consultant at the center of the city's alleged $10 million tax-assessment bribery scheme. Quite the contrary, they said; he always struck them as quiet, knowledgeable, down to earth. 
 And generous, too.
Mr. Schussler, who was indicted on Monday, was a major supporter of many Jewish charities -- a past president of the American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra, a director of the UJA-Federation of New York, a longtime supporter of the New Israel Fund and American Friends of the Open University of Israel. 
"He was a low-key guy, intelligent, a professional" said Jeffrey Gural, a building owner and manager who said Mr. Schussler had worked with Mr. Gural's father, Aaron. "It's like when you hire a lobbyist. You hope that he's going to convince whoever you hired him to lobby that your position is correct."
"And you also hope that he's doing it aboveboard," he said.
Mr. Schussler, a tax consultant and building owner who had previously worked in the assessor's office for 30 years, is said by the United States attorney's office in Manhattan to have offered assessors bribes ranging from expensive dinners to thousands of dollars in exchange for desirable assessments on buildings owned by him and by others who hired him to represent them.
A lawyer for Mr. Schussler, Steven Cohen, declined on Monday to comment on the charges.
Consultants like Mr. Schussler serve as intermediaries between some landlords and assessors, ostensibly supplying late-breaking information that might enable an assessor to better understand the economics of a building. "You want people who understand the process better than you," said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, a trade association.
Mr. Schussler is also an owner of the landmark Ansonia Hotel and other buildings on the Upper West Side. He has served on the real estate tax assessment committee of the Real Estate Board. He lives in the Sovereign, a 48-story glass tower on East 58th Street near Sutton Place.
Yesterday, Mr. Spinola, Mr. Gural and others described Mr. Schussler as quiet and extremely knowledgeable about tax assessments and real estate values. "If you had a conversation with him, you would be impressed with what he knew and the technical expertise he had in the area," Mr. Spinola said. "Which I think impressed an awful lot of people."
Mr. Gural said, "Being an ex-assessor, he understood more than anyone what the assessors look for, and what it would take to convince an assessor that a building shouldn't have its assessment raised." Mr. Gural, chairman of Newmark & Company, a leasing and management company, said his father hired Mr. Schussler as a consultant on some buildings in which the younger Mr. Gural was a partner.
Max Kampelman, a retired lawyer in Washington who said he had been an investor with Mr. Schussler in the Ansonia years ago, called him "a warm, plain, down-to-earth person." He recalled getting a letter from Mr. Schussler encouraging him to contribute to the American Friends of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra.
In addition to supporting the orchestra, Mr. Schussler and his wife, Claire, are longtime donors to the New Israel Fund, which raises money to support civil rights, human rights and religious pluralism in Israel; and to the American Friends of the Open University of Israel, a distance-learning and online university.
A spokesman for the UJA-Federation said: "He's been very active over the years. He has served on our board of directors. He's been an active major contributor to the campaign for years and years and years."
Eric Heffler, executive vice president of the American Friends of the Open University of Israel, who said he had sought Mr. Schussler's advice in the past on strategic planning matters, said: "He's just a very sweet, wonderful gentleman and I am very, very hurt and sorry over what I'm reading. He is one of the nicest people I've ever met."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Albert Schussler, 85, a tax consultant, leaving the federal courthouse in Manhattan on Monday, when he was indicted on bribery charges. (Kristen Artz)

HEADLINE: Technology; 
Congressional Broadband Fight Intensifies

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Two weeks after the House of Representatives approved legislation to limit the influence of money in politics, the House is expected to approve a telecommunications bill that is largely shaped by the huge campaign contributions it has generated.
 The measure, a bill to deregulate the high-speed Internet market, has become known informally on Capitol Hill as the big bucks bill of the year, although it has little chance of becoming law any time soon. As a result, experts predict it will continue to be lucrative for lawmakers for years to come, encouraging the telecommunications industry to find ways to make tens of millions of dollars in contributions long after Congress completes its work on the campaign finance legislation. Senate leaders say the bill, to be taken up by the House on Wednesday, has virtually no hope of approval by the Senate this year. 
 The fight over the broadband bill is reminiscent of the great Congressional battles in the 1990's to revise the Depression-era banking laws, a decade-long struggle that yielded no new laws for years but generated millions of dollars for lobbyists and the campaigns of lawmakers as banks, insurers and securities firms fought one another to a draw.
The Internet measure, called the Tauzin-Dingell bill after its chief sponsors, has already provoked a multiyear pitched political battle over the broadband market among many of the wealthiest telecommunications companies. In the opening months of this election cycle, telecommunications companies have spent more than $5 million on contributions, and experts predict it will be the most lucrative legislative fight of the year, surpassing the fight over a patients' bill of rights that also generated huge contributions. 
On one side are the regional Bell companies -- BellSouth, Qwest, SBC Communications and Verizon -- that want to eliminate the restrictions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996. They say that law has prevented them from expanding more aggressively in the broadband market and that they face onerous requirements to lease their equipment and wires to start-ups in an ill-considered effort to promote competition. 
On the other side are the long-distance carriers, like AT&T, WorldCom and Sprint, and some cable companies and the competitive start-ups, which favor the current rules and worry that changes will cost them revenue and permit the Bell companies to grow even stronger in the regions where they already dominate local phone service.
Both supporters and detractors of the legislation describe a kind of political arms race -- a need to continue spending millions on contributions, lobbying and marketing simply to try to keep up with the other side.
"The costs are rapidly getting out of control," said William M. Daley, the former commerce secretary in the Clinton administration who is president of SBC. "There is a general sense that sure, we'd like to be spending our efforts on other things. But if the other side is spending $20 million on advertisements, or whatever it is that they are spending, then we have to respond."
On the other side of the issue, Royce J. Holland, the chief executive of Allegiance Telecom Inc., a smaller competitor to the largest phone carriers, said that "the regional Bell money has been responsible for every piece of this legislation."
Blair Levin, a former senior official at the Federal Communications Commission who is a regulatory analyst at Legg Mason, said that the political climate bears an interesting resemblance to the marketplace. "As markets know and consumers know and politicians know, competition is a good thing," he said. "It's much more fun for a politician to go to a fund-raiser when both sides are present."
Precise figures on the lobbying effort have not been filed, although during the 1999-2000 election cycle, telephone companies and others with interest in the legislation gave more than $22 million in political action committee, soft money and direct campaign donations, almost exclusively to advance the broadband legislation. The two sides have also spent many millions of dollars on teams of lobbyists, staffs of surrogate "grass-roots organizations" and floods of broadcast and newspaper advertisements.
"It's a definite irony," said Holly Bailey at the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan research organization that monitors political money. "At the same time they say they are trying to curb special interests on Congress, this is a bill that is drawing a big amount of special interests out of the woodwork. A lot of checks are being mailed to members of Congress specifically following the bill."
Analysts and consumer groups that have opposed the legislation agreed.
"This is an example of squeezing the maximum money out of special interests at the same time that Congress purports to be shutting the door on special interests," said Gene Kimmelman, a senior director at Consumers Union.
The fund-raising efforts have relied on both traditional and innovative techniques. A study this week by Public Citizen found that the regional Bell companies have poured more than $277,000 into special campaign financing vehicles established by the Republican leadership in the House that supports the legislation. The vehicles, formed under a loophole in the law and known as 527 groups for a section of a tax statute, enable virtually unlimited contributions with limited disclosure and few restraints on spending.
The legislation is expected to pass by a wide margin in the House this week but faces overwhelming political obstacles in the Senate, including heavy opposition from the Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi; Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, the chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee; and Senator Ted Stevens of Alaska, the ranking Republican on the Senate Appropriations Committee. The administration has remained neutral in the fight, although the Federal Communications Commission, an independent agency dominated by Bush appointees, has moved to begin providing the relief the regional operating companies have sought.
For all the millions of dollars being spent in Washington over the political fight and on Madison Avenue over the advertising campaign, it is pocket change compared with the larger economic stakes at issue. The broadband market for which local and long-distance carriers are competing for high-speed data transmission is among the fastest-growing segments of a telecommunications market valued now at about $150 billion a year.
The measure would revise major sections of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, which enabled the regional Bell companies to enter the long- distance market only after they demonstrated that their own local markets had been opened to sufficient competition. The companies are just beginning to obtain permission in a number of states but still face regulatory fights in others. 
Supporters say it is essential to attract new capital for further development of high-speed Internet and it would put the telephone companies on a more equal footing with the less regulated cable industry, which also offers broadband services. 
But critics counter that the measure would enable the regional Bell companies, which already dominate and in many instances monopolize their markets, to extend their reach into high-speed Internet service, driving out smaller competitors and solidifying their grip.

HEADLINE: Unions Hope to Regain Attention of Lawmakers 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
As labor leaders gather here, they are grumbling that many of the issues that American workers care deeply about -- issues like soaring health care costs and safeguarding Social Security -- are largely absent from the nation's political dialogue, eclipsed by the war on terrorism and the Republican push for tax cuts.
 So at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s executive council meeting, they agreed today to try to shift the nation's focus to worker-related issues. 
 They hope this strategy will highlight President Bush's political weaknesses and help elect candidates friendly to worker causes. They agreed to an assessment on the federation's 66 unions that will raise $17 million more for political efforts over the next three years. 
"There is a lack of talk this year about the issues that workers care about," said Gerald McEntee, chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political committee and president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. "This can be traced to Bush's popularity and to the war against terrorism. But the problems that existed for working people before Sept. 11 still exist. We feel it's the role of the American labor movement to put these issues on the nation's agenda."
In a resolution, the labor leaders listed issue after issue that they say political leaders should focus on: the lack of strategies to create jobs, the expiration of unemployment insurance after 26 weeks, the loss of manufacturing jobs, rising prescription costs, tax cuts that cause the government to dig into Social Security money, and fears that workers' retirement savings can be wiped out. 
These leaders point to focus groups and polls showing that while workers are concerned about the war on terrorism, how they vote will be most influenced by bread-and-butter issues and the economy.
"These working-family issues are not on the front burner," said John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president. "I think the election this November is going to be on these very issues."
It is a difficult time for labor. Unions have been unable to reverse membership declines. They worked to elect Al Gore, but now they have a president who often takes actions hostile to labor. The recession has knocked the wind out of many unionized industries and unions.
Then there are tensions between unions. For example, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted against the new assessment, which will require unions to pay 4 cents more per member per month.
Michael Mathis, the Teamsters' political director, said his union opposed the assessment because the federation planned to spend some of that money on the Democratic candidate it backed for governor of Michigan, David E. Bonior, when the Teamsters favored another Democrat, Jennifer Granholm.
In addition, the Teamsters say the A.F.L.-C.I.O. leans strongly toward Democrats when the Teamsters have been strengthening ties with Republicans, working closely with them on Mr. Bush's proposal to drill for oil in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge. Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao spoke to the labor leaders today, and she urged other unions to join the Teamsters in backing Mr. Bush's energy plan.
"We need a significant number of Republicans to support us on a wide range of issues, including aggressive labor-law reform," Mr. Mathis said. "We have to build a base of support in the Republican Party. Any way you put it, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. dues increase is going to be seen as a pool of money to be used to beat Republicans."
The federation's leaders said they would focus their energies this fall on two dozen House races, a dozen Senate races and 22 governor's races, especially those in New York, California and Illinois.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, spoke to the labor leaders this morning, asking them to help restore Democratic control of the House. But Steve Rosenthal, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political director, hedged, saying: "We're not saying that our goal is to have a Democratic majority in the House. We want to have a pro-working-family majority in the House. But sure, we'd rather have Dick Gephardt as speaker."
Carl Forti, a spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, said, "I think it's great that they're supporting more Republicans, but I think there are a lot of Democrats up there who aren't worthy of their support."
For labor leaders, the Enron scandal provides ammunition against the Bush administration.
Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster, said: "Before Sept. 11, union members had a clear perception that the Bush administration had abandoned any semblance of an even playing field between workers and corporations. And now with the emergency of Enron, that perception has come back stronger than ever."

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Heroic Teachers and Schools

BYLINE:  By Anemona Hartocollis 

 BODY:
 The Carnegie Corporation has given $1.85 million to downtown schools "in honor of the teachers who played such a pivotal role for students in the wake of the attack on the World Trade Center." Of the grant, $800,000 is to build libraries in two schools within District 1, on the Lower East Side, and District 2, which runs from the Battery to Midtown. 
Another $300,000 goes to each of the two district superintendents for projects in consultation with teachers. 
 The three downtown high schools that were evacuated -- Stuyvesant, Leadership and Public Service and Economics and Finance -- will receive $100,000 each. Finally, the high schools that temporarily took in the evacuated students will receive $50,000 each. These are Brooklyn Tech, Fashion Industries and Norman Thomas.
 Anemona Hartocollis

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Site Group Criticized 

BYLINE:  By Edward Wyatt (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 City Council members have scolded representatives of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, the agency overseeing rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, for not having a more racially and ethnically diverse board and staff. 
Council members also said on Monday that they wanted a greater voice in planning the redevelopment. James Sanders Jr., chairman of the Council's Committee on Economic Development, said the agency's 11-member board did not resemble "the city that it hopes to rebuild." Louis Tomson, executive director of the agency, said he would work harder to recruit more women and minorities. Edward Wyatt (NYT)

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE TRANSACTIONS; 
Enron Hid Big Loans, Data Indicate

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Even as executives with the Enron Corporation were being privately warned last September that huge corporate debts were being hidden from investors, the company entered into a series of deals that appear to have disguised more than $350 million in new bank loans, according to internal company documents, court records and accountants.
 The transactions took place on Sept. 28, Enron's last business day before it began calculating its quarterly results, with J. P. Morgan Chase and an offshore entity, and were supposed to carry little risk. But now, with Enron in bankruptcy since early December, whether the bank will recover the full value of the money it advanced to Enron is a matter that will have to be decided in court. 
 For all outward appearances, the transactions were a series of trades intended as protection against possible future rises in the price of natural gas. But they actually served, the records show, simply to transfer hundreds of millions of dollars temporarily from J. P. Morgan to Enron, which was supposed to return the money plus a few million more in a matter of months. In essence, the transaction was a loan with an interest rate of more than 3 percent. 
The trades, while apparently following legal requirements, underscore how some of the most aggressive financing techniques used by Enron continued up to its demise. Indeed, they indicate that even after Enron disclosed to Wall Street a number of transactions that served to hide debt and increase earnings, there were still significant secrets hidden in its financial statements, yet to be revealed.
Unlike the partnership dealings, these transactions are believed by lawyers and accountants to have been reflected in Enron's financial statements. However, they allowed something that had all the earmarks of a bank loan to instead be written up as cash assets and liabilities from the company's trading business.
Vance Meyer, a spokesman for Enron, declined to comment, citing litigation involving the transactions.
Kristin Lemkau, a spokeswoman for J. P. Morgan Chase, said that the trades were a common type of transaction, known as structured finance, that would have been reflected in the financial reports of both companies, although not as loans.
The transactions "were on J. P. Morgan Chase's balance sheet and were designed to be reflected on Enron's balance sheet," she said, adding that "structured finance is used by virtually every company in America; it allows companies to lower their costs of financing and diversify their investor base."
The trades involved an offshore entity based in Jersey, in the Channel Islands, and known as Mahonia Ltd. Many earlier transactions among Enron, Morgan and Mahonia also appeared to be contracts for future purchases of natural gas, and a series of insurance companies issued guarantees that payment would be made if the commodity was not delivered. In those deals, the insurers have sued, contending that the transactions were fraudulent, and that no delivery of gas was ever intended.
The trades last fall, however, were not covered by guarantees issued by the insurers. Instead, Enron turned to Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale, known as WestLB. Enron received a letter of credit that would be paid to Mahonia and, because of the transactions, ultimately to J. P. Morgan to guarantee that Enron would meet its obligations under the trade.
All told, J. P. Morgan has exposure of $1.1 billion from the series of transactions involving Mahonia. Of that amount, $165 million is from the WestLB letter of credit that has not been paid; the remaining part of the $350 million loan was sold off to other banks.
Earlier this month, Mahonia sued WestLB in a British court, demanding payment on the letter of credit. WestLB has refused, contending that the series of three transactions among Enron, J. P. Morgan and Mahonia were simply a mechanism to hide bank loans.
"Under the right circumstances, any one of these swap transactions by itself could have been legitimate," said Fred Mauhs, a managing director with WestLB in New York. But when the parties entered into all three transactions simultaneously, he added, "the only possible purpose we can discern was to disguise a loan from Chase to Enron."
For their part, J. P. Morgan officials criticized WestLB's efforts to void the letter of credit, saying that none of the details that have emerged changed the nature of the obligation.
"WestLB's conduct is an outrageous attempt to get out of a straightforward letter of credit obligation," Ms. Lemkau, the spokeswoman, said. "It will only cause damage and uncertainty to the commercial market."
In court papers, WestLB has advanced evidence that Mahonia served no true role in the transaction. For example, the papers contain details of an interview conducted by lawyers for WestLB this year, on Feb. 5, with Joseph Deffner, an Enron executive involved in the trades. In the interview, Mr. Deffner said that to the best of his recollection, all of the negotiations about the trades with Mahonia and J. P. Morgan were conducted between Enron and the bank directly. Mahonia played no role in those talks, according to court records describing the interview.
The transactions last September involved a series of trades of a fixed value of cash for another value that floated depending on the future price of natural gas contracts. This theoretically would allow one side of the transaction to lock in a price for a quantity of natural gas, regardless of where the price for the commodity went.
The trades began between Morgan and Mahonia. Records of the trade show that the bank agreed to pay $350 million, deliverable immediately on Sept. 28, in exchange for a payment based on the variable value of gas futures contracts as of March 25 of this year, with payment due the following day.
At the same time, Mahonia entered into a transaction with Enron, with the exact same terms. As a result, the $350 million flowed on Sept. 28 from the bank to Mahonia, then from Mahonia to Enron.
The third leg of the transaction -- between J. P. Morgan and Enron -- was also created that day, documents show. Under that transaction, Enron agreed to pay Morgan a fixed obligation of about $356 million, according to court records. Meanwhile, Morgan agreed to pay Enron the variable value of the exact same number of gas contracts in the other two trades. Both cash deliveries were due on the same day, March 26.
A result of these series of trades was a circular transaction, the records indicate, in which many of the obligations created by the trade were simply canceled. Under the deal, Enron owes Mahonia a variable payment on March 26, which equals the variable payment owed by Mahonia to Morgan, which equals the variable payment owed by Morgan to Enron, all due on the same day.
Ultimately, Enron was required by the three legs to do nothing more than give the variable payment to itself. But the fixed payment is real. Morgan gave the $350 million to Mahonia, which in turn gave it to Enron on Sept. 28. Then, on March 26, Enron was supposed to pay $356 million to Morgan and owe nothing else to anyone. The payment was equivalent to the principal plus an interest payment at a rate of about 3.4 percent. At the time, that was the going rate for similar six-month loans.
The only way the variable payment would come into play would be if Enron defaulted on its obligation. Given its bankruptcy, that is now certain to happen. With Enron unable to even start the variable payment on its circular route, Mahonia hoped to be paid by the letter of credit from WestLB. That money, then, would go to J. P. Morgan to meet the variable payment obligation of Mahonia. With Enron unable to complete its trade with J. P. Morgan, the variable payment would stop there, potentially reimbursing the bank the full amount it had advanced. But with WestLB refusing to pay, that will not occur unless a court orders it.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "The Money Merry-Go-Round"Late last year, Enron and J.P. Morgan Chase engaged in a deal with a third entity that ostensbly was a hedge to protect against rising prices of natural gas. As a result of the deal, Enron counted $350 million in additional cash flow in its third-quarter financial statements. The structure of the deal, however, makes it appear to be a loan, not a hedge. Here is how the deal worked, on paper. 1. On Sept. 28, 2001, Chase paid Mahonia, an entity based in Jersey in the Channel Islands, $350 million. Mahonia agreed to pay Chase on March 26, 2002, a variable amount dependent on the price of natural gas futures contracts as of March 25. 2. The same day Mahonia struck its deal with Chase, it did the same deal with Enron, paying Enron $350 million for the same promise of a payment based on futures contracts on March 25, 2002. The net effect was that the money from Chase passed to Enron. 3. Also on the same day, Enron agreed to pay Chase $356 million on March 26, 2002, in return for a payment equal to the value of the variable payment that Chase was due from Mahonia on that day. NET EFFECT: The obligation for the variable payment passed from Enron to Mahonia to Chase and back to Enron -- a net zero. Enron ended up obligated to pay Chase $6 million more than it received on Sept. 28, 2001, the equivalent of an interest payment of about 3.4 percent on a loan. (pg. C8)

HEADLINE: ENRON'S MANY STRANDS: THE OVERVIEW; 
AN ENRON EX-CHIEF USES DEFIANT TONE AT SENATE HEARING

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former Enron chief executive, testified during a contentious hearing before a Senate panel today that he did not lie to Congress earlier this month about his role in Enron's collapse, and he criticized members of Congress for conducting their inquiry "with a complete disregard for the facts and evidence."
 Under skeptical and at times sarcastic questioning from members of both parties, Mr. Skilling defended himself against suggestions that he had tolerated or encouraged improper financial transactions at Enron. He told the panel he knew little about flawed partnership deals central to the company's collapse and insisted that the company's auditors and his subordinates had approved them. 
 At several points, Mr. Skilling, who appeared before the Senate Commerce Committee, said that Congress was engaged in a rush to political judgment that paralleled what he called similarly hasty decisions by lenders to withdraw credit from Enron when it began to falter last fall. News analysis, Page C1. 
After being battered during testimony three weeks ago before a House subcommittee, Mr. Skilling, who has been described by other Enron executives as arrogant and intimidating, repeatedly interrupted Senators to accuse them of mangling the facts or mischaracterizing testimony.
In his opening statement, he complained that Enron managers had been called "everything from hucksters to criminals" and asserted, "I have not lied to Congress or anyone else" in previous testimony. He also lectured panel members about financial matters. 
Mr. Skilling testified today alongside one of his harshest critics, Sherron S. Watkins, the Enron vice president who accused him of "duping" Enron's former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay. Jeffrey McMahon, a senior Enron executive who testified that he warned Mr. Skilling of potential problems two years ago, also appeared on the witness panel.
"I never duped Ken Lay," said Mr. Skilling, who at times appeared to glare at Ms. Watkins. "I heard Ms. Watkins testify to her opinion; I have no idea what the basis is for that opinion."
"Unlike so many others so much less fortunate than me, I am not a victim," Mr. Skilling added. "But also, unlike others, I am not one of the perpetrators, either."
Mr. Skilling, in a possible preview of his defense against lawsuits that he predicted today might strip him of $66 million generated by selling stock in the years before Enron's collapse, repeatedly said that he had relied on accountants from Arthur Andersen and hundreds of employees in Enron's internal accounting and risk-control offices for assurances that the company's financial dealings were proper. The board, he added, was well briefed in detail about the structure of partnerships that investigators say led to the company's collapse.
Mr. Skilling's most frequent refrain during the day's testimony was, "I'm not an accountant." But after one exchange in which Mr. Skilling lectured the panel at length about the ways Enron could have hedged certain assets, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a North Dakota Democrat, said wryly, "You seem to know more about accounting and finance than you let on."
Senator Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, added: "You may well say that you didn't understand, you didn't know, you didn't realize or whatever. But it's such a massive scale. And I think that's the difficulty of understanding, comprehending your lack of awareness."
Much of the hearing focused on Mr. Skilling's knowledge of partnerships that had been run by Enron's former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow. The partnerships were supposedly to be used to hedge Enron assets but, according to a report by a special committee of Enron directors, ended up concealing close to $1 billion in losses and enriching a handful of senior executives. The report was highly critical of Mr. Skilling, saying he failed to oversee controls intended to assure that the partnership dealings were proper and noting that other Enron employees believe that Mr. Skilling had greater knowledge of certain deals than he acknowledges.
Mr. Skilling says he had no inkling that the partnerships were ever used to hide debt or conceal losses, or for any other improper purpose. Unlike some other senior executives, Mr. Skilling was never an investor in the Enron partnership deals.
Ms. Watkins, who in testimony on Feb. 14 before the House subcommittee compared Mr. Skilling to a "swindler," restated her belief today that he must have known about the company's troubled finances. 
"I believe," she said, "that Mr. Andy Fastow would not have put his hands in the Enron candy jar without an explicit or implicit approval to do so by Mr. Skilling." She offered no specific evidence of her own, however, that Mr. Skilling had actually known more about the partnerships than what he had said during testimony.
While lawmakers have praised Ms. Watkins for warning Mr. Lay in August that Enron would implode in an accounting scandal, they have expressed skepticism about the account she gave the House subcommittee earlier this month that Mr. Lay was largely unaware of the company's problems.
Today, however, Ms. Watkins painted a less favorable view of Mr. Lay, pointedly stating at the outset of her testimony that she was "incredibly frustrated" that he did not fully follow through on her warnings.
"I believe that Enron had a brief window to salvage itself this past fall," she said, "and we missed that opportunity because of Mr. Lay's failure to recognize or accept that the company had manipulated its financial statements."
Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois, asked Ms. Watkins whether she believed that Mr. Lay was "bright."
She replied, "Not after this fall."
After the hearing, Ms. Watkins's lawyer, Philip Hilder, said she had been upset about what he said were mischaracterizations of her earlier testimony that she had given "cover" to Mr. Lay by saying he was misled by subordinates and was not aware of the company's precarious finances. Today, he said, Ms. Watkins sought to emphasize that she was also very disappointed with the way Mr. Lay had handled her complaints and that "she wasn't giving cover to him or making excuses for him."
Despite the critical comments from lawmakers, Mr. Skilling's performance today contrasted with his appearance on Feb. 7 before a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, at which he stumbled on some answers and was reduced to telling the committee, on one occasion, that he could not recall a crucial detail of a board meeting in part because the electricity had failed.
Today, Mr. Skilling appeared well coached and well prepared, and he repeatedly challenged statements by panel members about how much stock he sold in the years before Enron's collapse; the number of partnerships operated by General Electric and other companies; what Enron board minutes say about his role in overseeing the company's partnership deals; and whether Enron's financial statements properly disclosed debts carried by the company's partnerships.
In response to one question from Mr. Fitzgerald, he said, "Senator, you may be a great senator, but when it comes to understanding what happens in bankruptcy," and then he explained why he believed that the premise of the question was false. 
In a notable departure from Enron's antiregulation philosophy, Mr. Skilling urged lawmakers to do something about the speed with which creditors, investment partners and other entities dealing with Enron cut the company off financially when its problems became apparent last fall. He cited widespread use of "material adverse change" clauses in derivatives deals and other financial arrangements that allow investors to pull their money out immediately. He suggested that such clauses helped lead to a "run on the bank" that brought Enron down as it lost access to financing just when it needed it most. 
Perhaps mindful of Enron's aggressive efforts in the past in lobbying to eliminate or avoid regulation of derivatives, energy contracts and other transactions critical to Enron's business, the Senate panel was clearly skeptical of Mr. Skilling's policy recommendations. "I'll get advice on what we ought to do in the future from others," Mr. Dorgan said.
One of his most persistent questioners, Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, played a videotape of what she said was a 1999 employee meeting at which Mr. Skilling smiles and nods his head after another Enron executive asks whether employees should put all their 401(k) retirement money into Enron stock. Many Enron employees lost the bulk of their savings when Enron's stock collapsed, where they had, on average, invested about 60 percent of their 401(k) money. Those losses are the focus of several of the Congressional inquiries. Senior Enron officials sold more than $1 billion in stock in the years before Enron's collapse.
"Why is it that you had begun unloading your stock pretty heavily before that date and yet led the employees to think they should keep buying stock?" Ms. Boxer asked Mr. Skilling.
In response, Mr. Skilling, referring to her as "Ms. Senator," later said that he followed a program of selling modest amounts of Enron stock over many months. 
Later, Mr. Dorgan asked Mr. Skilling about a North Dakota Enron employee whose $330,000 retirement plan dwindled to $1,700. "You still have most of your $66 million. That family has lost their life savings. How do we reconcile that?" Mr. Dorgan asked. "How is it that the people at the top got wealthy and the people at the bottom got broke?"
Mr. Skilling replied: "I think, if I thought that there was a concern, I would imagine any economic adviser would say, 'You probably should have sold more, diversified more.' And I think it's very tough. I mean, I don't know what to say to the employees."
In his comments today, Mr. McMahon, who is now the company's president and chief operating officer, repeated earlier testimony that in March 2000 he met with Mr. Skilling to tell him that Enron finance employees were subjected daily to conflicts of interest because they negotiated against partnerships headed by their boss, Mr. Fastow. Several weeks later, Mr. McMahon said he transferred to a different job within the company after Mr. Fastow confronted him over the meeting with Mr. Skilling. 
Mr. Skilling, who asserted his testimony was not "materially different" from Mr. McMahon's, said he recalled Mr. McMahon's complaining not about how the partnerships could affect shareholders, but about whether it would affect his compensation.
Mr. Skilling also said he had "talked to Mr. Fastow and put him on notice that there had been a complaint, and then I expected him to deal with it."
In response to a question about the shredding of documents at Enron that is being investigated by the F.B.I., Mr. McMahon said, "I don't believe we do know what records were destroyed."

HEADLINE: Bush Urges Work and Marriage Programs in Welfare Plan 

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER and ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 

 BODY:
Declaring that the 1996 welfare overhaul was a resounding success in ending generations of welfare dependency, President Bush called today for even stronger work requirements and $300 million annually to promote marriage and strengthen families among poor people.
 Mr. Bush formally unveiled his welfare plan today beneath a huge sign that declared, "Working Toward Independence," before an audience of community activists in St. Luke's Catholic Church in Southeast Washington. His remarks were vintage compassionate conservatism, a blend of tough talk about the virtues of work and gentle vows that, "We will not leave people in need to their own struggle, and we will not leave them to their own fate." Even as he denounced much of the war on poverty, he hailed Hubert H. Humphrey, one of its staunchest advocates. 
 Critics said that states would have great difficulty meeting Mr. Bush's new work standards, which would mandate that 70 percent of all welfare recipients in a state be working by 2007. Right now, administration officials said, the typical state has 30 percent of its welfare cases working. Critics also asserted the Bush plan would not give states the flexibility they need to design programs that reflect their local economic conditions and their caseloads.
As expected, Mr. Bush combined his tougher work requirements with a nod to those who assert that poor people need more education and training to move beyond the lowest paying jobs. He said welfare recipients, under his proposal, would be required to spend 40 hours a week in work, but added that up to two of those work days could be spent on education and training. Under current law, adults are typically required to work 30 hours a week, a third of which could be in education or training, but critics assert there is much more flexibility.
The Bush proposal would also allow three months of full-time drug rehabilitation or job training "for people who need intensive short-term help," the president said. And it would preserve the current law's five-year ban on welfare benefits for immigrants who entered the country after 1996 and have not become citizens.
Mr. Bush, forshadowing the political debate to come, argued that it was the focus on work that explained why the 1996 law "dramatically improved" the lives of poor people, after 30 years of a welfare system that became "an enemy of individual effort and responsibility, with dependence passed from one generation to the next."
Mr. Bush presented his proposals to strengthen marriages and families, which critics assert is an inappropriate realm for the government, as a way to help children. "Across America, no doubt about it, single mothers do heroic work," he said. "They have the toughest job in our country." But he added, "In many cases, their lives and their children's lives would be better if their fathers had lived up to their responsibilities."
The administration, confronting an out-of-wedlock birth rate that has stabilized but remains a stubborn 33 percent of all births, is hoping to turn the tide by financing experimental programs in the states, like public education campaigns on the benefits of marriage and premarital counseling. 
Mr. Bush also made the case today for his proposed $135 million for abstinence education, also part of his welfare plan. "Abstinence is the surest way and the only completely effective way to prevent unwanted pregnancies and sexually transmitted diseases," he said. "When our children face a choice between self-restraint and self-destruction, government should not be neutral."
The Bush proposals were hailed by Republican Congressional leaders. But the Bush plan is only the opening bid in a lengthy legislative process that will culminate in the reauthorization and rewriting of the 1996 law, much of which expires this year.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, discussed the administration's proposal today at an exceptionally cordial meeting on Capitol Hill with governors and members of Congress from both parties.
Democratic reaction was mixed. Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, said he could accept stricter work requirements, provided the standards could be relaxed or adjusted in bad economic times. "You have to be very careful," Mr. Kerry said. 
Other Democrats also expressed concern. Two of the party's experts on welfare policy, Representatives Benjamin L. Cardin of Maryland and Sander M. Levin of Michigan, said the work requirements in the president's plan were so strict that they would encourage states to put welfare recipients in publicly subsidized jobs with little hope of career advancement.
"In effect," Mr. Cardin said, "the administration would force states to put people in unpaid workfare positions in order to satisfy the work requirement, rather than providing the skills necessary for a person to be successful in a wage-earning job."
Others worried about the availability of child care for single mothers trying to meet those work requirements. Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, a liberal group that strenuously opposed enactment of the 1996 law, also criticized Mr. Bush's proposals today. "The president requires more hours of work, but not one dime more for child care," Mrs. Edelman said. "Right now only one in seven children eligible for federal child care assistance gets it."

HEADLINE: Bloomberg and Pataki Say Rebuilding of Downtown Should Wait for Overall Plan 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Gov. George E. Pataki suggested yesterday that a Manhattan developer should not go ahead with construction at 7 World Trade Center until completion of an overall development plan for Lower Manhattan.
 The remarks contrast with recent signals from state and city officials on the pace of rebuilding Lower Manhattan. They also cast further doubt on the hopes of the developer, Larry A. Silverstein, the real estate executive who owns the development rights to the World Trade Center complex, to begin construction soon on a replacement for 7 World Trade Center. 
 Mr. Silverstein has said that he hopes to begin building at the 7 World Trade Center site by June. The site lies just north of the former main complex of trade center buildings, across Vesey Street. The chairman of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, John C. Whitehead, said last week that he felt it was desirable for a new building at 7 World Trade Center "to proceed promptly." 
But Mr. Bloomberg said to reporters yesterday morning that any such effort should proceed slowly, and that people affected by the attack on Sept. 11 and by the redevelopment of the area south of Chambers Street should first have adequate opportunities to express their views about a memorial, transportation, buildings and other changes downtown.
Asked about the mayor's remarks and their conflict with those of Mr. Whitehead, who was appointed by Mr. Pataki, Mollie Fullington, a spokeswoman for the governor, said Mr. Pataki "believes we should move forward in an appropriate time frame consistent with an overall vision for the redevelopment of downtown."
The confusion over multiple lines of authority at the World Trade Center site has left many interested parties unsure where to turn. "Obviously there is a tremendous amount of public concern about 7 World Trade," said Robert D. Yaro, president of the Regional Plan Association. 
Because Mr. Silverstein holds the lease on the property, which is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, it is not clear whether Mr. Bloomberg has any true power over what happens there. Although the mayor controls 4 of the 11 seats on the board of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, those board members were appointed by his predecessor, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Bloomberg's aides have said, however, that the four directors serve at his pleasure.
Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Silverstein, said yesterday that Mr. Silverstein "is seeking to work cooperatively with the mayor, the governor, the Port Authority and the community on issues involving new construction." He declined to comment directly on Mr. Bloomberg's remarks, but added that Mr. Silverstein "is seeking to build as expeditiously as possible."
Support for Mr. Silverstein's quick rebuilding of 7 World Trade Center had appeared to extend to state officials, if not to the governor himself. Charles A. Gargano, a Pataki appointee who is the state's chief economic development executive, said earlier this month that he supported Mr. Silverstein's plans to begin rebuilding in June. Mr. Gargano is chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the parent organization of the Lower Manhattan group, and vice chairman of the Port Authority.
Mr. Bloomberg had previously said little regarding the speed of development at the site, although he had expressed support for a mixed-use plan, including a memorial, office buildings and perhaps stores and a cultural center.
Speaking yesterday during an event at the William O'Shea Middle School on West 77th Street, Mr. Bloomberg said, "I don't know that you can go any faster than what you're doing right now, nor do I think it is appropriate. So I certainly would recommend stalling a little while longer. I think over the summer, you'll start to see people be able to sit down and look at a more comprehensive plan."
Asked if that meant that a plan should precede any construction, Mr. Bloomberg added: "I think the first thing is the recovery effort. The second thing is giving everybody a chance to talk, and then, yes, you should not go build any one building without a plan."
Residents of Lower Manhattan have pushed for a delay in the construction of any buildings, saying they want a comprehensive plan that will lay out what happens at the 16 acres formerly occupied by the World Trade Center as well as in the surrounding neighborhoods. 
Members of the families of victims also advocate going slowly, in part because some of them want the entire 16-acre site to be a memorial to the victims. 
Con Edison, meanwhile, wants to start rebuilding the electrical substations that were in 7 World Trade Center, which were destroyed when that building collapsed on Sept. 11. 
Mr. Silverstein's desire to build is tied to the fact that he is continuing to make lease payments on the World Trade Center site while not getting any money from it. Because Mr. Silverstein is currently using insurance money to make lease payments to the Port Authority, some politicians would also like him to proceed, in part so he cannot make a legal claim that the city or the state is hindering him from operating his business.
Some of Mr. Silverstein's supporters have said that starting a new project would send a strong signal to the world that the city -- and the nation -- were recovering from the attacks. But Daniel Doctoroff, the deputy mayor for economic development, said yesterday, "I don't think we need to send signals that downtown is coming back."
Speaking at a breakfast forum sponsored by Crain's New York Business, Mr. Doctoroff said that development of Lower Manhattan should include a redesigned transportation hub that could include the re-establishment of streets that were removed for the construction of the World Trade Center.
